column2: On Election Night, the Republican party nearly succeeded in its goal to capture control of Congress only two years after a Democratic sweep.
MEDOFF--Rita September 23, 2009 Love Unbridled; Absence Unconquered. Alan, De, Jeff, Bruce and Children
SPIEGEL--Judy. A woman of valor, rest in peace my special friend. Love, Karen B.

SCHNEIRLA--William Sutfin, V. Rev. Paul, 98, on September 20, 2014, Stanton, NJ. Husband of 70 years to Shirley Dillon Warriner Page, father of Dorothy Downie Orrill, Peter C. Schneirla and the late William Sutfin Schneirla Jr. Pastor for 50 years, St. Mary's Antiochian Orthodox Church, Brooklyn, NY; Old Testament Professor, St. Vladimir's Seminary; Vicar General, Western Right Orthodoxy; founding member, Standing Conference of Canonical Orthodox Bishops. Burial is private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Fr. Paul Schneirla Scholarship Fund, St. Mary's, 8005 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn, NY 11209.

POTLER--Cathy. We mourn the passing and honor the memory of our Executive Director Cathy Potler, who served the people of New York tirelessly with courage, honesty, and tenacity for more than twenty years. She inspired us her colleagues and staff to carry out the Board's mission of overseeing the city's jails and reminded us that, as Dostoevsky said, a society's civilization can be judged by entering its prisons. Those who have worked or resided at the city's jails owe Cathy Potler more than they can imagine. We shall miss her leadership, company and counsel, and we offer our heartfelt condolences to her family Martin and Natan.

LUBART--Hilda. Beloved wife of the late Alfred, of blessed memory. Devoted mother of Marion Sue, of blessed memory, Mitchell, Matthew and Daniel. Cherished grandmother of Jennie, Adam, Hannah, Morgan, Victoria, Sydney, Zachary and Samantha, and great-grandmother of Craig and Eli. Passed on peacefully on September 22. She will be greatly missed.
LIPOW--Maurice G.,on September 21, 2014. Beloved husband of Annette. Loving husband of the late Anne. Devoted father of Andrew, Emily, and Larry. Cherished grandfather of Alexis, Andrea, and Zachary.

LEVENTHAL--Alan D.,of Manhattan died on September 20, age 77. Survived by daughter Claire Richard of Manhattan and a brother, Ronald Burial will be private, an announcement for a memorial service will be made at a later date. 1-866-473-3700 for memorial contribution information.

KOLLEENY--Steven J. The Board and staff of Human Rights First mourn the loss of Steven J. Kolleeny, a member of our Board of Advocates and pro bono colleague. Through his pro bono legal work and mentoring of other volunteer attorneys, Steve helped hundreds of people who faced persecution secure safety in the United States. These former refugees and their children are now rebuilding their lives, free from violence and harm, in this country. It was an honor to work with him and we will miss him greatly.

KOLLEENY--Steve. The Bellevue/NYU Program for Survivors of Torture mourns the loss of our beloved advisory board member. In Steve's memory, we re-dedicate ourselves to helping rebuild the lives of the asylum seekers we care for.

GWATHMEY--William G. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul. Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the passing on Friday, September 19th of William "Willie" Gwathmey, beloved son of our friend and partner Gaines Gwathmey. We express our deepest sympathies to Gaines, Rose, Katie and all other members of the Gwathmey family.
GWATHMEY--William. Rose, Gaines and Katie - our hearts and thoughts go out to you and your family and friends right now. With our deepest sympathy, All of us at OSI

GWATHMEY--William "Willie". William "Willie" Gaines Gwathmey. Beloved son of Gaines Gwathmey and Rose Harvey; devoted brother of Katie Gwathmey; passed away on September 19th, in Washington, D.C. He was 20. The 6'2," freckle-faced New York native, with a big smile and an even bigger heart, lived life to the fullest. He was known for his easy charm, boundless energy and infectious enthusiasm. A 2012 graduate of Collegiate High School, in New York, Willie excelled both in the classroom and on the court. During his junior and senior year, he helped lead the school's varsity basketball team, the "Mighty Dutchmen," to back-to-back state championships. He was also an avid tennis player. Willie was a junior at George Washington University (GW), pursuing a degree in Finance and Economics at its School of Business, at the time of his passing. In addition to his parents and older sister, Willie is survived by an extended family of relations and friends from every walk of life. A service to commemorate Willie's life will be held at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, located at 1157 Lexington Ave, New York, at 11am on Wednesday, September 24th. Anyone wishing to make a contribution in Willie's memory might consider a donation to the Collegiate School's Athletic Fund.
GANS--Helene August 3, 1930, died September 21, 2014. Wife of Laurence, mother to Leslie and Michael. Burial Service: 11am, September 28, Mount Carmel Cemetery NY.
EISNER--Eugene. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Eugene Eisner, associated with The New York Times from November 1, 1955 until retiring on July 1, 1988.

DRISCOLL--Doris Tracy, of Rockville Centre, Brooklyn, and East Hampton died on September 20, 2014 at age 87. Daughter of the late James and Marguerite Heaney and the adopted daughter of the late Mrs. Thomas F. Tracy, wife of the late James Patrick Driscoll. Predeceased by five brothers, Thomas, James and Robert Heaney, Walter and William Tracy and three sisters, Helen Tracy Driscoll, Marie Tracy Murphy and Kathleen Tracy. She is survived by her children James, Doris, and David. Six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Doris attended St. Saviour Elementary and High School and was a graduate of the College of New Rochelle. Later, she became a faculty member at St. Saviour's High School. Doris will always be remembered for her humor, quick wit and unforgettable parties. Reposing Monday, 7-9pm and Tuesday, 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Joseph G. Duffy Funeral Home, 255 9th Street, Brooklyn, NY 11215. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Wednesday at the Church of St. Saviour, 11am. Interment to follow at Holy Cross Cemetery.

BRENNER--Simon. The Officers, Board of Governors, The Women's Group, Members and Staff of The Muttontown Club mourn the passing of our beloved member, Simon Brenner, and extend our sincerest condolences to his children Fawn Rich, Phylis Buchwald, Dean Brenner and grandchildren Evan and Eric Rich, Allison Strauss, Tori, Ross and Jared Brenner. Robert Sherman, President

CONFORD--Matilda, born February 4, 1918, passed away in Manhattan on September 21, 2014, at the age of 96 and one-half years young. The daughter of Mary and Isaac Rubin, "Mattie" survived her siblings, Evelyn, Eli and Sylvia. She was married for 46 years to Harold Conford, who died in 1987. Mattie had a long and distinguished career as an executive secretary to numerous corporate CEO's. Long a resident of New Jersey, she spent her last years living in happiness and contentment on the Upper West Side. Always sociable and caring, she remained fiercely independent (and impeccably dressed) until the end. She was a beloved aunt, great aunt and friend to many. She is survived by Karla Conford, Alan Levitt, Pamela Conford and Bruce Ortwine. A Memorial Service for Mattie will be held at 2pm on Tuesday, September 23, at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. (91st St.) in Manhattan. Shiva will be held at the home of Pam and Bruce at 77 East 12th Street, Manhattan following the memorial service on Tuesday and from noon to 4pm on Wednesday.

BERNSTEIN--Joan M.,83, of Tenafly, New Jersey passed in comfort on Monday morning. Beloved wife to James she is survived by: her brother Stephen and his wife Barbara; her daughter Jan; her son John and his wife Diana; and her granddaughter Samantha. Daughter of Rose and Lawrence Wertheimer Joan was raised in Rockville Center. Living in Manhattan then New Jersey, Joan was always a New Yorker at heart enjoying the best of theatre, restaurants, and the arts. A graduate of Syracuse University, she also enjoyed substitute teaching. Always fashionably dressed, and possessed of a genuine joie de vivre Joan particularly enjoyed travelling and became a serious collector of American Indian art and jewelry. She shared her passions generously with her family and with a large extended family of close friends and many "surrogate" daughters whom she loved. Joan passed comfortably after a heroic battle with Leukemia at NYP with a view of the City she loved. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Patient Services at New York Presbyterian c/o Susan Mascitelli, 525 East 68th Street, NY, NY 10065 www.nyp.org. Services for friends of the family will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison (81st) on Wednesday at 11:30am
AMINOFF--Nadja Woloshyn. September 4, 2014. Long-time resident of Greenwich, CT. Survived by son Alexander Aminoff and sisters Lydia Woloshyn and Valya Kohut. You will be missed.

WILFORD--Janice Roberts, age 86, died Wednesday, September 17, 2014 at Stamford Hospital. Born in Bridgeport, CT on January 17, 1928, she was the daughter of the late Edward and Frances Meriman Roberts. Janice is survived by her son, Chris, his wife, Meredith, and their daughter, Addison Anne of New York City. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, September 26 at 11am at St Mark's Church, 111 Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan, CT 06840.

TRIANT--Theodore Demetri, 87, of NYC. Beloved husband of Christine A. (nee) Artopiades. Loving father of Cathy (George N.) Buxton. Funeral service Friday, 11am at the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 E 74th St, NYC. Entombment will be private. Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel.

TARLOV--Jill Anne, age 58, of Fairfield, Conn. and New York City, passed away on Sunday, September 21, 2014 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. She succumbed to injuries suffered three days earlier when she was tragically struck by a cyclist in New York's Central Park. Jill was born on November 25, 1955 in Norwalk, Conn. to Harriett and Malcolm Tarlov. She grew up in Norwalk along with her brother Mark and attended Norwalk High School before continuing her studies at Boston University, where she earned her Bachelor of Science degree in communications. In 1982, she was hired by Westinghouse Broadcasting Company (now CBS) to oversee marketing, public relations and advertising for 1010 WINS, the nation's oldest all-news radio station, in New York City. While working at WINS, Jill met Michael Wittman, the station's financial controller. They married in Ridgefield, Conn. on April 20, 1986. Scott Herman, who worked with Jill at WINS and is now Executive Vice President, Operations, CBS Radio, said, "Jill loved her time at 1010 WINS, especially because she met Mike there. She was fun loving and cared about others. When you were her friend, you were a friend for life." Jill had a tremendous passion for children in both her personal and professional life. As parents, she and Mike were blessed with a son, Matthew (age 24), and a daughter, Anna (age 23). Jill regularly embraced her passion for life by serving as a volunteer, with an emphasis on working with children. She dedicated considerable time to working with inner-city youth, in addition to working in a garden for kids. Jill believed in the difference her time would make in children's futures and her passion for helping them was contagious to those around her. In 1986, Jill transitioned from 1010 WINS to Group W Television Sales (now CBS Television Sales) and was responsible for marketing the public service initiative "For Kids' Sake." While devoting much of her time to raising Matthew and Anna during their formative years, Jill also pursued her continuing education by earning a graduate certificate in teaching and learning with technology from Teachers College at Columbia University, the oldest and largest graduate school of education in the country. She later received her Master of Arts in educational technology from Fairfield University. In 2005, Jill began a deeply meaningful six years with the Anti-Defamation League in New York City. Originally hired to support ADL's multimedia Holocaust education project, she went on to serve in a number of roles in support of the human rights organization's mission to combat hate and anti-Semitism. Abraham H. Foxman, National Director of the Anti-Defamation League, said, "Everyone here is devastated by the news about our good friend and colleague, Jill Tarlov. Jill was a warm, engaging, and deeply caring person, a terrific colleague and a good friend to many people on our staff." In 2011, Jill became the first marketing director at Partnership with Children, an organization that provides counseling to at-risk students at New York City's public schools. Jill is survived by her loving husband of 28 years, Mike, who is employed as Senior Vice President of Finance for the CBS Television Stations group; their two children, Matthew and Anna; and her brother, Mark Tarlov. With the sudden loss of our beloved Jill, her family plans to establish a permanent legacy in the form of a charitable fund in her name to carry on her dedication and love for helping others. Persons who wish to honor Jill's memory may send donations to the Jill Tarlov Fund, c/o Charles Lenore, Esq, Day Pitney LLP, 242 Trumbull St., Hartford, CT 06103.

GIORDANO--John C.,Jr., John C. "Jack" Giordano Jr., founder of the prominent law firm Giordano Halleran & Ciesla of Middletown, NJ, died at his beloved Southampton, NY home on September 11, 2014. He was born in Long Branch, NJ on March 17, 1930. Jack attended The Lawrenceville School (1948), Princeton University (B.A. 1952); Rutgers University School of Law (1955), Phi Delta Phi. He was Editor of the Rutgers Law Review from 1953-1955 and Law Secretary to New Jersey Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan, Jr. Upon completing his clerkship with Justice Brennan in 1955, Jack formed the Giordano & Giordano law firm with his father, the Honorable John C. Giordano, Sr. who served as a Superior Court Judge in Monmouth and Ocean Counties, New Jersey. The multi-service firm Giordano Halleran & Ciesla was established in 1964 and today employs more than 100 lawyers and support staff. During his career of 55+ years in law and in business, Jack was also a co-founder of the Navesink Country Club of Middletown, NJ which celebrated its 50th anniversary in 2013. Jack's legal and business skills, his leadership and vision and his ability to build and maintain professional and personal relationships brought longevity and success to everything that he was part of. He mentored colleagues, clients, politicians and friends and most importantly, his family. Jack leaves behind his wife Andrea J. (Cerullo) Giordano, his three sons: John C. (JC) Giordano, III (Errol Train Giordano), Mark V. Giordano (Sallie Dinkel Giordano), Paul G. Giordano, and his step-son V. Andrew Cerullo. Jack has five grandchildren: John C. (Jake) Giordano, IV, Schuyler H. Giordano, Nicholas B. Giordano, Leta K. Giordano and Allegra L. Giordano. He is also survived by his sisters, Gloria Henneberry and Joy Conhagen and their families. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him.
GANS--Helene August 3, 1930, died September 21, 2014. Wife of Laurence, mother to Leslie and Michael. Burial Service: 11am, September 28, Mount Carmel Cemetery NY.

FOX--Marjorie Claire, 67, succumbed to cancer Sunday morning in La Jolla, California, surrounded by her adoring husband, Dean, and loving children, Lila (Eric Lerner) and Cory (Molly). Beautiful, charming and determined, Marjorie was equally committed to her family and to improving education. A proud graduate of NYU and NYU Graduate School with a Masters in Education, Marjorie passionately pursued her career as an educator, educational sales executive and consultant. She was the motivation and inspiration to her family, and adored her grandchildren, Zoe and Theo. Marjorie was unique, a dynamic combination of warmth, sunshine and lightning. Her passions included her friends, fashion and travel, especially to Paris. Donations in her name to the American Cancer Society are appreciated.

A beautiful personality. Leaves a void; leaves an indelible mark. Services: Wednesday, at 11:30am at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, Queens. 718-445-0300.

DAMON--Allan Lincoln, of Somers, NY, died at his home on September 22, 2014. Born in Ware, MA in 1934, he obtained degrees from Amherst College (BA, 1956) and Colombia (MA, 1958 and Ph.D. in American History, 1994). He taught American History for 33 years at Horace Greeley High School in Chappaqua, NY, served as a trustee and treasurer of the National Council for History Education and was a contributing editor for American Heritage. He is survived by Claire, his wife, their sons and their families. He will be greatly missed.

CUOCO--Daniel. A. The managing principals, partners and staff of Thornton Tomasetti mourn the loss of Dan Cuoco, our former president and CEO, a brilliant engineer and leader who made tremendous contributions to our firm's growth as well as to the built environment around the world. In his four decades with Thornton Tomasetti, Dan established new offices, launched innovative ventures, and helped us build preeminent structural engineering and investigation practices. He worked on remarkable projects, including the firm's first high-rise building, and numerous landmarks, such as the Roosevelt Island Aerial Tramway and World Bank headquarters in Washington, D.C. Dan was a leader in times of prosperity and challenge, and was among the first to respond to calls for engineering support on 9/11. His contributions to our firm and the engineering profession are too many to list, but will be celebrated and remembered forever. Our hearts go out to his wife, Dianne, his children and grandchildren, who were his greatest joy. His memory will inspire us to achieve great things.

CONFORD--Matilda, born February 4, 1918, passed away in Manhattan on September 21, 2014, at the age of 96 and one-half years young. The daughter of Mary and Isaac Rubin, "Mattie" survived her siblings, Evelyn, Eli and Sylvia. She was married for 46 years to Harold Conford, who died in 1987. Mattie had a long and distinguished career as an executive secretary to numerous corporate CEO's. Long a resident of New Jersey, she spent her last years living in happiness and contentment on the Upper West Side. Always sociable and caring, she remained fiercely independent (and impeccably dressed) until the end. She was a beloved aunt, great aunt and friend to many. She is survived by Karla Conford, Alan Levitt, Pamela Conford and Bruce Ortwine. A Memorial Service for Mattie will be held at 2pm on Tuesday, September 23, at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. (91st St.) in Manhattan. Shiva will be held at the home of Pam and Bruce at 77 East 12th Street, Manhattan following the memorial service on Tuesday and from noon to 4pm on Wednesday.

CHESBROUGH--Herb. Newport Festivals Foundation is saddened at the passing of its Executive Director, Herb Chesbrough. George Wein, Chairman, Board of Directors and Staff

CASTELLS VALLE--Raul, 17, on September 20. Beloved son of Doris and Raul Castells. Loving brother of Noelle Pallais. Mass of the Resurrection St. Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Avenue (66th Street), Friday 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, a donation to the Bone Marrow Foundation would be appreciated.

BERNSTEIN--Joan M.,83, of Tenafly, New Jersey passed in comfort on Monday morning. Beloved wife to James she is survived by: her brother Stephen and his wife Barbara; her daughter Jan; her son John and his wife Diana; and her granddaughter Samantha. Daughter of Rose and Lawrence Wertheimer Joan was raised in Rockville Center. Living in Manhattan then New Jersey, Joan was always a New Yorker at heart enjoying the best of theatre, restaurants, and the arts. A graduate of Syracuse University, she also enjoyed substitute teaching. Always fashionably dressed, and possessed of a genuine joie de vivre Joan particularly enjoyed travelling and became a serious collector of American Indian art and jewelry. She shared her passions generously with her family and with a large extended family of close friends and many "surrogate" daughters whom she loved. Joan passed comfortably after a heroic battle with Leukemia at NYP with a view of the City she loved. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Patient Services at New York Presbyterian c/o Susan Mascitelli, 525 East 68th Street, NY, NY 10065 www.nyp.org. Services for friends of the family will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison (81st) on Wednesday at 11:30am

BANDY--Mary Lea. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of Mary Lea Bandy. Mary Lea began her career at the Museum in 1973 as an associate editor in Publications, after having been an editor of art history publications at Harry N. Abrams, Inc. She was appointed Director of MoMA's Film Department in 1980, and Chief Curator of the Department of Film and Video (later the Department of Film and Media) in 1994, a title she held until her retirement in 2005. In addition to her Film Department responsibilities she served as MoMA's Deputy Director for Curatorial Affairs from 1999 to 2005 and played an instrumental role in the Museum's 2004 expansion project. Mary Lea championed the restoration and preservation of film as an art form, as evidenced by her tireless work during the creation of The Celeste Bartos Film Preservation Center, which opened in 1996. She facilitated the acquisition of hundreds of films for the Museum, including those of Woody Allen, Clint Eastwood, Rainer Werner Fassbinder, Federico Fellini, Martin Scorsese, and Andy Warhol. She also coproduced two films, helped to create the Women's Film Preservation Fund of New York Women in Films and Television, a unique program devoted exclusively to saving films by women filmmakers, and organized many exhibitions for MoMA and several international archives. The French government named her Chevalier des Arts et Lettres in 1984 and Officier des Arts et Lettres in 1992. In 1999 she received the MUSE Award from New York Women in Film and Television. In 2012 she published her comprehensive story of the American Western, "Ride, Boldly Ride," with Kevin Stoehr. Mary Lea's passion for film firmly established the moving image as a pillar of MoMA's curatorial activities, and she will be sorely missed. Like the heroes of the American Westerns that she loved so dearly, Mary Lea was a true and loyal friend and colleague. We will miss her dearly. We send our deepest sympathies to her husband, Gary, and all of her family. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

WILFORD--Janice Roberts, age 86, died Wednesday, September 17, 2014 at Stamford Hospital. Born in Bridgeport, CT on January 17, 1928, she was the daughter of the late Edward and Frances Meriman Roberts. Janice is survived by her son, Chris, his wife, Meredith, and their daughter, Addison Anne of New York City. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, September 26 at 11am at St Mark's Church, 111 Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan, CT 06840.

WENTZ--Howard B. Jr.,of Hobe Sound, FL. Born 1930 to Emmy Lou Cawthon and Howard B. Wentz of Pittsburgh, PA. Predeceased by brother Sidney Frederick Wentz. Married 1958 to Judith Ann Blough. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, children H. Beck Wentz lll, Roger Blough Wentz, Elizabeth Ann Wentz-Stewart and four grandchildren. His education included Principia '44-'48; Princeton '48-'52 (BS Engineering) and Harvard Business School '55-'57 (MBA). In the United States Navy, between '52-'55 during the Korean War, Howard flew as a Lieutenant JG Airman from the carrier USS Princeton. Initially employed in the Jet Propulsion Laboratory of NASA, Howard worked in engineering consulting and manufacturing operations, eventually entering into a career with Amstar Corporation. Here he held positions as VP Operations '72 '79; COO '79 '81; Chairman '83 '89; President '81-'89 and CEO '82 '89. In the 1990s Amstar was owned/controlled principally by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners (MLCP). When Amstar divested its' major businesses-related to the production and distribution of sugar, the remaining companies, the largest of which was Milwaukee Electric Tool Inc., were merged with another MLCP controlled company in a similar industry known as ESSEX Industries. Howard became the Chairman of this new combined entity called ESSTAR Inc. 1989-1996. During this same period Howard was Chairman of Tambrands, 1993-1996. He was a tireless and influential director serving Crompton & Knowles '87 '95; Tambrands '85 '96; Interpace; Amstar Corp. '76 '89; Amstar Holdings '84; Uniroyal; American Skandia; and Colgate-Palmolive '82 '04 and '05 '07. Howard founded and funded a Junior Faculty Award at Princeton's School of Engineering and Applied Sciences with the purpose of recognizing and assisting the research of promising junior faculty members in engineering. Howard was an adamant believer in the need to advance America's sciences education and especially engineering toward bolstering economic competitiveness. With his wife, he has co-funded the Judith B. and Howard B. Wentz Jr. College Scholarship Prize in Pre-Engineering at Kent School. He expanded and intensified his support of the cause, establishing both a teaching chair and fellowship while also funding the school's now flourishing Pre-Engineering Program. Howard was an avid golfer, also devoting much time to wing shooting, clays shooting, fly fishing and racquet sports. Balancing well his work and play, Howard invested time and service in the social and sporting pleasures of a variety of club memberships including: Hemisphere Club, NYC; University Club, NYC; The Blind Brook Club, NY; Woodway Country Club., Connecticut; Pine Valley Golf Club, New Jersey; The City Club of Palm Beach, Florida; Jupiter Hills Club, Florida; and held current memberships at Medalist Golf Club, Florida; Loblolly, Florida; and Blooming Grove Health & Fitness Club, Pennsylvania. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Wentz Pre-Engineering Program at Kent School, Kent, CT. 06757. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 27th at 10am at The First Presbyterian Church of Hawley, 815 Church St., Hawley, PA 18428.

TRIANT--Theodore Demetri, 87, of NYC. Beloved husband of Christine A. (nee) Artopiades. Loving father of Cathy (George N.) Buxton. Funeral service Friday, 11am at the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 E 74th St, NYC. Entombment will be private. Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel.

TARLOV--Jill Anne, age 58, of Fairfield, Conn. and New York City, passed away on Sunday, September 21, 2014 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. She succumbed to injuries suffered three days earlier when she was tragically struck by a cyclist in New York's Central Park. Jill was born on November 25, 1955 in Norwalk, Conn. to Harriett and Malcolm Tarlov. She grew up in Norwalk along with her brother Mark and attended Norwalk High School before continuing her studies at Boston University, where she earned her Bachelor of Science degree in communications. In 1982, she was hired by Westinghouse Broadcasting Company (now CBS) to oversee marketing, public relations and advertising for 1010 WINS, the nation's oldest all-news radio station, in New York City. While working at WINS, Jill met Michael Wittman, the station's financial controller. They married in Ridgefield, Conn. on April 20, 1986. Scott Herman, who worked with Jill at WINS and is now Executive Vice President, Operations, CBS Radio, said, "Jill loved her time at 1010 WINS, especially because she met Mike there. She was fun loving and cared about others. When you were her friend, you were a friend for life." Jill had a tremendous passion for children in both her personal and professional life. As parents, she and Mike were blessed with a son, Matthew (age 24), and a daughter, Anna (age 23). Jill regularly embraced her passion for life by serving as a volunteer, with an emphasis on working with children. She dedicated considerable time to working with inner-city youth, in addition to working in a garden for kids. Jill believed in the difference her time would make in children's futures and her passion for helping them was contagious to those around her. In 1986, Jill transitioned from 1010 WINS to Group W Television Sales (now CBS Television Sales) and was responsible for marketing the public service initiative "For Kids' Sake." While devoting much of her time to raising Matthew and Anna during their formative years, Jill also pursued her continuing education by earning a graduate certificate in teaching and learning with technology from Teachers College at Columbia University, the oldest and largest graduate school of education in the country. She later received her Master of Arts in educational technology from Fairfield University. In 2005, Jill began a deeply meaningful six years with the Anti-Defamation League in New York City. Originally hired to support ADL's multimedia Holocaust education project, she went on to serve in a number of roles in support of the human rights organization's mission to combat hate and anti-Semitism. Abraham H. Foxman, National Director of the Anti-Defamation League, said, "Everyone here is devastated by the news about our good friend and colleague, Jill Tarlov. Jill was a warm, engaging, and deeply caring person, a terrific colleague and a good friend to many people on our staff." In 2011, Jill became the first marketing director at Partnership with Children, an organization that provides counseling to at-risk students at New York City's public schools. Jill is survived by her loving husband of 28 years, Mike, who is employed as Senior Vice President of Finance for the CBS Television Stations group; their two children, Matthew and Anna; and her brother, Mark Tarlov. With the sudden loss of our beloved Jill, her family plans to establish a permanent legacy in the form of a charitable fund in her name to carry on her dedication and love for helping others. Persons who wish to honor Jill's memory may send donations to the Jill Tarlov Fund, c/o Charles Lenore, Esq, Day Pitney LLP, 242 Trumbull St., Hartford, CT 06103.

MAUSNER--Jack, B.Sc, Ph.D, passed away peacefully at his home after a long illness. Born in Lwow Poland in 1930, moved to England in 1946, and died in New York City on September 21, 2014. He received his B.Sc. and Ph.D from London University. He came to the US in 1970, where he was head of Research and Development World Wide for Helena Rubenstein, the cosmetics company. He later joined Chanel Inc. as head of Research and Development. He is mourned by his wife, Irena, his children Ian and Nicole, and his grandchildren, Oliver, Samantha, Sofia and Charlotte. Funeral will take place at Frank E. Campbell funeral home on Sunday, September 28, at 10:30am.

CUOCO--Daniel. A. The managing principals, partners and staff of Thornton Tomasetti mourn the loss of Dan Cuoco, our former president and CEO, a brilliant engineer and leader who made tremendous contributions to our firm's growth as well as to the built environment around the world. In his four decades with Thornton Tomasetti, Dan established new offices, launched innovative ventures, and helped us build preeminent structural engineering and investigation practices. He worked on remarkable projects, including the firm's first high-rise building, and numerous landmarks, such as the Roosevelt Island Aerial Tramway and World Bank headquarters in Washington, D.C. Dan was a leader in times of prosperity and challenge, and was among the first to respond to calls for engineering support on 9/11. His contributions to our firm and the engineering profession are too many to list, but will be celebrated and remembered forever. Our hearts go out to his wife, Dianne, his children and grandchildren, who were his greatest joy. His memory will inspire us to achieve great things.

WENTZ--Howard B. Jr.,of Hobe Sound, FL. Born 1930 to Emmy Lou Cawthon and Howard B. Wentz of Pittsburgh, PA. Predeceased by brother Sidney Frederick Wentz. Married 1958 to Judith Ann Blough. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, children H. Beck Wentz lll, Roger Blough Wentz, Elizabeth Ann Wentz-Stewart and four grandchildren. His education included Principia '44-'48; Princeton '48-'52 (BS Engineering) and Harvard Business School '55-'57 (MBA). In the United States Navy, between '52-'55 during the Korean War, Howard flew as a Lieutenant JG Airman from the carrier USS Princeton. Initially employed in the Jet Propulsion Laboratory of NASA, Howard worked in engineering consulting and manufacturing operations, eventually entering into a career with Amstar Corporation. Here he held positions as VP Operations '72 '79; COO '79 '81; Chairman '83 '89; President '81-'89 and CEO '82 '89. In the 1990s Amstar was owned/controlled principally by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners (MLCP). When Amstar divested its' major businesses-related to the production and distribution of sugar, the remaining companies, the largest of which was Milwaukee Electric Tool Inc., were merged with another MLCP controlled company in a similar industry known as ESSEX Industries. Howard became the Chairman of this new combined entity called ESSTAR Inc. 1989-1996. During this same period Howard was Chairman of Tambrands, 1993-1996. He was a tireless and influential director serving Crompton & Knowles '87 '95; Tambrands '85 '96; Interpace; Amstar Corp. '76 '89; Amstar Holdings '84; Uniroyal; American Skandia; and Colgate-Palmolive '82 '04 and '05 '07. Howard founded and funded a Junior Faculty Award at Princeton's School of Engineering and Applied Sciences with the purpose of recognizing and assisting the research of promising junior faculty members in engineering. Howard was an adamant believer in the need to advance America's sciences education and especially engineering toward bolstering economic competitiveness. With his wife, he has co-funded the Judith B. and Howard B. Wentz Jr. College Scholarship Prize in Pre-Engineering at Kent School. He expanded and intensified his support of the cause, establishing both a teaching chair and fellowship while also funding the school's now flourishing Pre-Engineering Program. Howard was an avid golfer, also devoting much time to wing shooting, clays shooting, fly fishing and racquet sports. Balancing well his work and play, Howard invested time and service in the social and sporting pleasures of a variety of club memberships including: Hemisphere Club, NYC; University Club, NYC; The Blind Brook Club, NY; Woodway Country Club., Connecticut; Pine Valley Golf Club, New Jersey; The City Club of Palm Beach, Florida; Jupiter Hills Club, Florida; and held current memberships at Medalist Golf Club, Florida; Loblolly, Florida; and Blooming Grove Health & Fitness Club, Pennsylvania. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Wentz Pre-Engineering Program at Kent School, Kent, CT. 06757. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 27th at 10am at The First Presbyterian Church of Hawley, 815 Church St., Hawley, PA 18428.

TRUSH--Edward H.,November 5, 1928 - September 22, 2014. Born in Manhattan, a graduate of City College of New York and Columbia Law School. He married Palma (Pam) on January 18, 1958 in New York. Ed had a long career as a government contracts attorney. The couple resided in Cranford, NJ. An avid tennis player and swimmer, and member of the Cranford Charter Review Commission. With a quick wit, expansive vocabulary, and great sense of humor, he will be missed by all. He is survived by Palma, his wife of 56 years, his sons Stephen, James, and Daniel, four grandchildren, cousins John and Kenneth Trush, sister-in-law Joanne Koenig, and niece Tara. Memorial will be Tuesday, September 30, 2014 at 11am at the Unitarian Church, 4 Waldron Avenue, Summit, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: www.danielsmusic.org.

STERLING--Robert Lee, Jr. Investment Company Executive. June 12, 1933 September 22, 2014. Mr. Sterling attended the Hawkin and University Schools in Cleveland and was a graduate of the Gunnery School Washington, Connecticut, Brown University and Columbia University Graduate School of Business. He served as an officer in the United States Naval Air Force. Mr. Sterling was an investment manager and former Senior Vice President of Shearson Lehman Brothers, and a Vice President of White, Weld & Co, JP Morgan Chase, Woods Struthers, Winthrop, Merrill Lynch and an Executive Vice President of Melhado Flynn and Associates. Mr. Sterling served on numerous boards including being a former trustee of Lennox Hill Hospital for 15 years in New York, The Norton Museum of Art, The Preservation Society, the Society of the Four Arts in Palm Beach, and the Community Chest United Way of Palm Beach and was on the International Advisory Board of the Museum of Modern Art (Modern Art Oxford) in Oxford England. He was a former trustee of the Game Conservancy of the USA, and of the Institute of Sports Medicine of New York. He was a 50 year member of University Club of New York and The Everglades Club, Bath and Tennis Club of Palm Beach, The Meadow Club and Bathing Corp of Southampton, and Annabel's Club in London. He was also a member of the Society of the Cincinnati where he was past President of the New York States Society, a former President of The New England Society of New York, and recipient of their JP Morgan Medal, and a member of the Pilgrims and St. Nicholas Society. He is survived by his wife Joyce Lanier Milner Sterling and three sons from a previous marriage, Robert Livingston Sterling, William Lee Sterling and Cameron Platt Sterling, two grandsons; Blake and Aren and four granddaughters: Clare, Sophie, Alexis and Piper of Greenwich, Connecticut and his sister Cynthia Cleminshaw of Cleveland. He was the son of Robert Lee Sterling of Cleveland and Kathryn Durell Brand of Cleveland and Chicago, and grandson of George B. Durell and Robert W. Sterling of Cleveland. Funeral services will be held Friday, September 26 at 11 o'clock at The Cathedral of St. Philip, 2744 Peachtree Road NW Atlanta, Georgia 30305. A reception will follow at Joyce Sterling's home. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Emory Cancer Center. Online condolences may be made at: hmpattersonspringhill.com.

NEWMAN--Robert L.,born in New York City on July 18, 1938 passed away on September 21, 2014. He is survived by his beloved wife, Ruth, and his daughter Kaja. He was self-employed and spent much of his life as President of the School Board and Board Member for the William George Agency for Children Services. A courageous, caring and loving man, he will be missed by all. In lieu of flowers or gifts, donations may be made in the name of Robert L. Newman to the William George Agency for Children Services, 380 Freeville Road, Freeville, NY 13068.

MAUSNER--Jack, B.Sc, Ph.D, passed away peacefully at his home after a long illness. Born in Lwow Poland in 1930, moved to England in 1946, and died in New York City on September 21, 2014. He received his B.Sc. and Ph.D from London University. He came to the US in 1970, where he was head of Research and Development World Wide for Helena Rubenstein, the cosmetics company. He later joined Chanel Inc. as head of Research and Development. He is mourned by his wife, Irena, his children Ian and Nicole, and his grandchildren, Oliver, Samantha, Sofia and Charlotte. Funeral will take place at Frank E. Campbell funeral home on Sunday, September 28, at 10:30am.

JHABVALA--Cyrus. Loving husband, father, grandfather, architect with vision, artist of talent, man of wit and charm and dear friend. We mourn Jhab's death and send condolences to his devoted daughters, Renana, Ava, Firoza and their families. Dan and Joanna Rose

FELDER--Sara, 92, passed away on Tuesday, September 24th. Born in Ohio, Sara was a graduate of the Cleveland Institute of Music, where she was also on the String faculty, the beginning of her lifelong career as violin teacher to scores of students. A longtime resident of New Jersey, Sara's participation in community events included many performances with her string quartet and piano accompanist. A gifted decorator and homemaker, she cherished beautiful things and always maintained an impeccable household open to her many friends, including her book club group of forty years. Sara immersed herself in Torah study and other activities at Temple Sinai of Bergen County, where she was honored to be asked to sing the Haftarah every year during Rosh Hashanah services. Pre-deceased by Marvin, her devoted husband of 66 years, and sister Bessie, she is survived by children Joan and Mitchell (Susan), grandsons Justin and Sam, and sister Rose. Services will be held at 11:30am on Sunday, September 28th at Temple Sinai of Bergen County, 1 Engle Street, Tenafly, New Jersey.

FEINBERG--Mortimer, 93, of Tamarac, FL passed of natural causes in his sleep late Tuesday evening. Beloved father, father-in-law, grandfather, great-grandfather, brother-in-law and uncle, he will be dearly missed by grandchildren Alissa and Zach Miller and Erin and Brent Rogol, and son-in-law John Miller. Morty -- known to many as "Poppy" -- was a loving father and active and involved grandfather -- always with a camera in hand. He was a wonderful husband to Shirley, to whom he was married for 67 years. She was his greatest passion and together they enjoyed later years of travel, golf, and social life with friends in Long Island and Florida. He was a successful entrepreneur, growing and running his father's company Milton Feinberg Trucking along with his brother Jerry. He was an avid sports fan; and held season tickets to the New York Giants for decades. He loved food and people and lighthearted mischief. He lived a rich, long life surrounded by a big family that he loved and loved him dearly. He is finally reunited with the love of his life Shirley and their darling daughter Joan.

DONOVAN--Patricia (nee Cosgrove). Beloved wife of the late Patrick. Loving mother of Barbara. Devoted daughter of the late Martin and Margaret Cosgrove. Loving sister of the late Francis and Agnes. Beloved aunt of numerous nieces and nephews. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call Thursday and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9pm at Frank E Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, September 27th, 10am at St. Jean Baptiste Church, NYC.

SHEPARD-GEISER--Jeanne, 92, of New York City and Mamaroneck NY, passed away peacefully at home on Thursday, September 25th. Beloved wife of Hank Geiser and former wife of the late Irv Shepard. A loving mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, she will be deeply missed by her daughters Lori Shepard (Victor Germack), Karla Shepard Rubinger (Michael), Robin Shepard (Walter Donway), and Sameth Shepard; grandchildren Aron, Shep, Matt, and Elizabeth; and great-grandchildren Sylvia and Lena. A selfless person during her entire life, Jeanne always put her immediate and extended family ahead of herself and all other concerns. She will always live in our thoughts. Services will be held at 12:30pm on Sunday, September 28 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Martha Stewart Center at Mt. Sinai Hospital.

SCHWARTZ--Anita, nee Mendelsohn, born July 21, 1920 in New York City, died September 25, 2014. B.A. Brooklyn College; M.A. Columbia University. Economist at Commodities Futures Trading Commission for 26 years. Predeceased by husband, David Schwartz and brothers Marcel and Howard Mendelsohn. Beloved mother of Rebecca Schwartz Greene, Adina Schwartz and Joseph Schwartz. Devoted grandmother of Abraham Greene, Ethan Frederick Greene, Jacob D'Eustachio, Michael Migiel-Schwartz and Leah Rossi-Schwartz. Great-grandmother of Mateo Lagarda Greene. Funeral Sunday, September 28, 2014, 1pm at Menorah Chapels, Union, NJ.

ROOB--Rona, 75, died peacefully in Manhattan on September 26 after a courageous battle with cancer. Rona's life revolved around her family, the world of modern art, and a close circle of friends. She was devoted to and complemented her gentle husband of 52 years, Richard, who passed away on June 2. She enjoyed nothing more than spending time with her two daughters and their husbands--Nancy Roob and Lukas Weinstein, and Helen and Marc Jerome--and her five grandchildren: Hanna, Ella, Sophie, Lucy and Sam. Born in New York City, Rona graduated from Barnard College, majoring in Art History, and later earned a Master's in Library Science at Columbia University. She had a life-long love of modern art, and the Museum of Modern Art was her second family. She first worked at MoMA in the 1960s, as secretary to Alfred H. Barr, then Director of the Museum Collections. Barr and his wife, Marga, profoundly influenced her life. She was named Chief Archivist in 1996, and upon her retirement in 1998, the position of Rona Roob Senior Museum Archivist was established. Rona embodied the archives: She was passionate about preserving MoMA's institutional history, loved facts and details, and had an extraordinary capacity to organize and retain large amounts of information. She made many presentations and wrote numerous articles, including "A Noble Legacy," considered the definitive article on MoMA co-founder Lillie Bliss, "1936: The Museum Selects an Architect," and "The Rockefeller Vision and the Making of the Museum of Modern Art." Rona was a trustee emerita of the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution, and a member of MoMA's Trustee Committee on Archives, Library and Research, the advisory committee of the Frick Museum, and the board of trustees of Guild Hall. Her family and friends greatly mourn her loss. Funeral services will be private. Notes of sympathy may be sent to the Family of Rona Roob at her home address. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Rona Roob Archives Fund at MoMA.

MAUSNER--Jack, B.Sc, Ph.D, passed away peacefully at his home after a long illness. Born in Lwow Poland in 1930, moved to England in 1946, and died in New York City on September 21, 2014. He received his B.Sc. and Ph.D from London University. He came to the US in 1970, where he was head of Research and Development World Wide for Helena Rubenstein, the cosmetics company. He later joined Chanel Inc. as head of Research and Development. He is mourned by his wife, Irena, his children Ian and Nicole, and his grandchildren, Oliver, Samantha, Sofia and Charlotte. Funeral will take place at Frank E. Campbell funeral home on Sunday, September 28, at 10:30am.

FELDER--Sara, 92, passed away on Tuesday, September 24th. Born in Ohio, Sara was a graduate of the Cleveland Institute of Music, where she was also on the String faculty, the beginning of her lifelong career as violin teacher to scores of students. A longtime resident of New Jersey, Sara's participation in community events included many performances with her string quartet and piano accompanist. A gifted decorator and homemaker, she cherished beautiful things and always maintained an impeccable household open to her many friends, including her book club group of forty years. Sara immersed herself in Torah study and other activities at Temple Sinai of Bergen County, where she was honored to be asked to sing the Haftarah every year during Rosh Hashanah services. Pre-deceased by Marvin, her devoted husband of 66 years, and sister Bessie, she is survived by children Joan and Mitchell (Susan), grandsons Justin and Sam, and sister Rose. Services will be held at 11:30am on Sunday, September 28th at Temple Sinai of Bergen County, 1 Engle Street, Tenafly, New Jersey.

BLANK--Robert Gray, 94. February 24, 1920 - September 25, 2014, of Long Island, NY. Beloved husband of 72 years to Joan, the love of his life. He will be dearly missed by his children, Lois and Rob, grandchildren Chris, Budd and Robbie, great-grandchildren, family, and many friends whose lives he enriched.

APPLEBAUM--Lila Roth, 83, graduated Smith College, founded Applebaum Associates Inc. Survived by daughters Lynn, Amy, Jo, their spouses, and grandchildren Graham, Rachel, Maggie, Gabriel. Donations to Children's Health Fund. Memorial to be held in late October.

WINCOR--Daisy Maria, passed away peacefully at home on July 6, 2014 at the age of 86. Born in Czechoslovakia, Daisy left with her family to find safe haven in England at the start of WWII. Daisy attended Teacher's College, eventually moving to the Highgate area of London. As a young widow, Daisy met Richard Wincor, an American lawyer; they married in 1972 and moved to New York City shortly thereafter. Daisy was an active member of the Daughters of the British Empire for 30 years, and always an avid theater-goer. She was a lover of good restaurants, museums, films, mystery novels, crossword puzzles, and all things British, while officially becoming an American citizen in 2002. We shall all miss her great wisdom, humor, advice and fierce loyalty to her friends and family. She was predeceased by her husband in 2003 and her brother John in 2009. Contributions in Daisy's memory may be made to the Victoria Home in Ossining, NY. www.victoriahome.org

SWEENEY--Joseph Lee, 76, of Park Slope, Brooklyn, NY and Hilton Head Island, SC, died on September 22, 2014, after a brief illness. Born in Manhattan on October 24, 1937, to Joseph and Fanny Sweeney. Joe was a member of the 1955 graduating class of Friends Seminary and the first graduate to become Clerk of the School Committee. He volunteered at the Friends Homeless Shelter for 25 years. He received a Bachelor of Science in Architecture from the University of Minnesota. He taught at Pratt Institute and CUNY, and was a math tutor for several organizations. During his professional career Joe was involved in various aspects of the housing industry throughout the U.S., Caribbean, South America, Philippines, and the Middle East. He was predeceased by his parents and his, sister Helen Marie Tynan. Surviving to cherish his memory are: Dr. Monica Sweeney, his wife of 48 years, his son Marvin Sweeney, three daughters; Marilyn B Sweeney, Simone Mouflih (Zouhair), Monica Musich (Mikel); grandchildren: Kieran Sweeney, Sojourner Lee Coles, Leila Mouflih, Mikel and Mya Musich, and great niece Monica Brunch, fondly called the "6th grandchild": two sisters-in-law Hazel Samuels, Jane Moreland, brother-in-law Richard Bagwell and many nieces and nephews. There are many dear friends whom we thank for their support. A memorial service will be held at Friends Meeting House, 15 Rutherford Pl., NYC 10003 on October 24, 2014 at 5:30pm. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to Friends Seminary, Friends Homeless Shelter, Institute of Jazz Studies, 185 University Ave., Newark, NJ 07102 or Caringbridge.org.

ROOB--Rona. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of Rona Roob. Rona first worked at the Museum in the 1960s, assisting Alfred H. Barr, Jr. in the Department of Museum Collections. She left in 1965, then returned in the 1980s, first as a researcher and then to work on the institution's archives. The Museum Archives was formally established as a separate department in 1989, with Rona as the founding archivist. She was named Chief Archivist in 1996 and held that position until she retired from the Museum in 1998. Rona also supported MoMA as a member of the Museum's Trustee Committee on Archives, Library, and Research, and through her participation in The Print Associates and The Contemporary Arts Council. Rona's impact on the Museum was immeasurable. From maintaining an institutional connection for more than five decades to establishing an archives program that has become a model in its field, Rona possessed a sense of tenacity and distinct vision which was admired by all. She was tireless in her efforts to preserve and make known MoMA's complex and fascinating history, and she conceived, designed, and established The Museum of Modern Art Archives and Records Management Program. She was generous in sharing her knowledge and helped guide countless curators and scholars through the wealth of documentation housed in the MoMA Archives. The depth of her knowledge, and her dedication to MoMA, was astounding. She was known for her uncanny ability to automatically recall myriad facts and stories, solely from memory. We extend our deepest sympathies to her daughters Nancy Roob and Helen Jerome and their families. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

ROOB--Rona, 75, died peacefully in Manhattan on September 26 after a courageous battle with cancer. Rona's life revolved around her family, the world of modern art, and a close circle of friends. She was devoted to and complemented her gentle husband of 52 years, Richard, who passed away on June 2. She enjoyed nothing more than spending time with her two daughters and their husbands--Nancy Roob and Lukas Weinstein, and Helen and Marc Jerome--and her five grandchildren: Hanna, Ella, Sophie, Lucy and Sam. Born in New York City, Rona graduated from Barnard College, majoring in Art History, and later earned a Master's in Library Science at Columbia University. She had a life-long love of modern art, and The Museum of Modern Art was her second family. She first worked at MoMA in the 1960s, as secretary to Alfred H. Barr, then Director of the Museum Collections. Barr and his wife, Marga, profoundly influenced her life. In the 1980's Rona helped to build The Museum of Modern Art Archives Records Management Program, which was formerly established as a separate department in 1989 with Rona as the founding Archivist. She was named Chief Archivist in 1996, and upon her retirement in 1998, the position of Rona Roob Museum Archivist was established. Rona embodied the archives: She was passionate about preserving MoMA's institutional history, loved facts and details, and had an extraordinary capacity to organize and retain large amounts of information. She made many presentations and wrote numerous articles, including "A Noble Legacy," considered the definitive article on MoMA co-founder Lillie Bliss, "1936: The Museum Selects an Architect," and "The Rockefeller Vision and the Making of The Museum of Modern Art." Rona was a trustee emerita of the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution, and a member of MoMA's Trustee Committee on Archives, Library and Research, the Advisory Committee of the Frick Center for the History of Collecting, and the board of trustees of Guild Hall. She was also a member of the Century Association and Cosmopolitan Club. Her family and friends greatly mourn her loss. Funeral services will be private. Notes of sympathy may be sent to the Family of Rona Roob at her home address. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Rona Roob Archives Fund at MoMA.

O'CONNELL--Richard Strong, of Branchburg, New Jersey, died Wednesday, September 24. He was 84. Dick was born to a Columbia Presbyterian nurse and AT & T engineer and lived on a farm in Green Village, NJ during his early youth during the Depression. Later the family moved to Bergenfield, NJ where Dick was a standout athlete in high school. At Rutgers University, from which he graduated and received his Masters in Education, Dick lettered in varsity soccer and also played baseball. Known as "Oke," he was revered at Rutgers Preparatory School where he started as Athletic Director in 1952, the same year he married. He then embarked on a 45 year career at RPS that would see him serve that entire time as Athletic Director and coach baseball (four State titles), soccer, cross country, swimming, and lacrosse. Oke built the RPS athletic program from three teams to the over 40 it boasts today, with a commitment to improving athletic offerings for girls. His greatest coaching achievements, however, came on the basketball court where he was head coach of Boys' Basketball for 45 years, coaching over 1,000 games with 700 wins, and winning nine New Jersey Prep Conference titles, eight State Prep tournaments and four Somerset County crowns. At the time of his retirement in 1997, he held the New Jersey record for most career wins in high school boys' basketball and remains in the top ten today. Oke was inducted into many associations' Halls of Fame, including the New Jersey Scholastic Coaches Association, the New Jersey Sportswriters Association and that of Rutgers Prep. After his retirement, Oke and Pegeen, his wife of 57 years, assumed the roles of Rutgers Prep ambassadors, re-uniting with his former students and players and sharing the milestones of RPS graduates at their homes all over the country. Pegeen pre-deceased him in 2009. The Rutgers Prep gymnasium was re-named the Richard S. O'Connell Athletic Center. The RPS dining facility was recently constructed and named the Pegeen O'Connell Dining Commons. Oke leaves behind son Kevin O'Connell, his wife Twila, and granddaughter Shannon; son Rory O'Connell, his wife Moira, and grandsons Adrian and Benjamin; son John O'Connell, his wife Stacey and grandson Tristan; and daughter Tara Klipstein, her husband David and grandsons Ryan, Reaves, and Christian. A memorial service at Rutgers Prep is planned for October 19 at 11:30am. For more information, please visit www.rutgersprep.org. In lieu of flowers or gifts, Oke asked that donations be made to Rutgers Preparatory School.

MIRMAN--Paul Steven, Esq.,of Brooklyn, NY, died September 27, 2014, after a fierce battle against the multiple sclerosis and its effects that plagued him for the last 23 years. Mr. Mirman grew up in East New York, attended Thomas Jefferson High School, Brooklyn College, and Brooklyn Law School. He was proud to have been a plaintiff's personal injury attorney and to have represented significant numbers of injured New Yorkers since his admission to the New York State Bar in March, 1969. His original office was in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn, where his name was emblazoned across the top of the corner building at Rockaway Parkway and Flatlands Avenue. Mr. Mirman's down-to-earth, magnetic personality drew thousands of New Yorkers to him for representation. He was one of the first lawyers in New York City to take advantage of attorney advertising, which he did on the subways, buses, in print, and on radio and television. Numerous young lawyers came through his office, learning from him to litigate, try cases, and most importantly to stand up and fight for their clients. In addition to his wife, the former Michele Turchin, Mr. Mirman is survived by their children, Phoebe and Matthew; by John and Lawrence, sons of his first marriage; his brothers Ronald, Alvin, and Leonard Mirman; and four grandchildren. The funeral service will be held Monday, September 29, 2014, at 12:45pm at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY. (718) 445-0300. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society http:// www.nationalmssociety.org/ The family will be accepting visitors at the home of Michele Mirman on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, September 29 through October 1, 2014, from 4pm-8 pm.

LI--Chu-tsing. 1920-2014, passed away peacefully Tuesday, September 16th at the age of 94 in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. He graduated from Puiching High School in Macao, received a: BA in English from Nanjiing University. in Chengdu, MA in English and PhD in Art History from the University of Iowa (1954) where he taught for 10 years. At the University of Kansas for 19 years, he developed the program in Asian Art History where he was the Judith Harris Murphy Distinguished Professor of Art History and Research Curator, Nelson-Atkins Museum, Kansas City. Also taught at Oberlin and Chinese University of Hong Kong. Received a Ford Foundation Grant to retrain in Chinese Art at Harvard and Princeton (1960) and an American Council of Learned Studies Grant to spend a one-year sabbatical in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Japan (1964). He visited China frequently after 1972 and became the first Fulbright Visiting Exchange Scholar to China in 1979. He had an illustrious career in Chinese art history. A tireless teacher, he mentored 28 PhD and 50 MA students who taught or curated at Harvard, Princeton, Washington University-St. Louis, and National Palace Museum, Taiwan. A relentless scholar of Yuan painting, he published 19 books and catalogs including the seminal "Autumn Colors on the Ch'iao and Hua Mountains by Chao Meng-fu (1964)", later writing on Ming, Qing and contemporary works. With a keen eye, he first recognized the merit of contemporary (abstract) Chinese ink paintings in early 1960s, organized exhibitions and opened up the field. Many of his collected works in "A Tradition Redefined: Chinese Ink Paintings in the C.T. Li Collection" will be donated to Harvard and Phoenix Art Museums. He touched many graduate students, art historians, collectors, curators and Chinese artists throughout the world with his rigorous, yet humble approach. Husband of the late Yao-wen Kwang Li (56 years). Son of deceased Wu Zi Li and Jing Tran Hsieh (Taiwan). Father of B U.K. Li (Milwaukee) and Amy Lee (Portland). Grandfather to Rachel Li Cullivan (spouse John NJ) and Benjamin Li (MI), and Daniel Lee, Brandon Lee, Christopher Lee (OR). Great grandfather to Jack and Naomi Cullivan. Preceded in death by elder and young brothers Chu-ling Li and Chu-shan Li. Further survived by relatives in California, Taiwan and Guangzhou, China, his birthplace. There will be a formal memorial service in May of 2015 in Lawrence, Kansas TBA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: Chu-tsing Li Award for Graduate Students in Chinese Art, University of Kansas Endowment Association, P.O. Box 928, Lawrence, KS 66044.

KRISHNA--Kumar. Entomologist and world authority on termites - a group of some 3,100 species of singular ecological significance - died on September 19 in his home in Manhattan after triumphing over multiple cancers for 15 years. He was 86. Dr. Krishna spent 34 years as Professor at the City College of New York and 52 years as a Research Associate at the American Museum of Natural History, where he was steward to the Museum's monumental termite collection of over one million specimens. He served as Chairman of the Graduate Program in Biology at City College, among other administrative positions. During that tenure, he also helped develop a formal program in graduate research training between City College and the Museum, which produced many notable biologists and continues to thrive. His greatest pleasure, however, was being on the 5th floor of the Museum working on papers that would eventually re-define the diversity and evolutionary history of the most social of all insects. Dr. Krishna graduated from the University of Chicago under the eminent biologist Alfred E. Emerson, who had a transformative effect on the nascent entomologist. Over the years, Dr. Krishna greatly expanded Emerson's collection, spending many months in the forests of Sri Lanka, South India, Malaysia, and Indonesia, searching out and observing termites, making the collection on Central Park West into the largest and most comprehensive in the world. Dr. Krishna retired from City College in 1996 and focused on research for the next 18 years. A special interest was termites fossilized in amber, revealing, for example, that termites formed nature's original societies probably more than 130 million years ago, well before ants. Dr. Krishna's main post-retirement research was his magnum opus on the world's termites. On April 25, 2013, the 7-volume, 2704-page "Treatise on the Isoptera of the World" was published, one of the largest projects ever done in the 144-year history of the AMNH, and the most comprehensive single study done on any group of social insects. Into his 80's, he and his wife Valerie often spent late evenings at the museum working on the "Treatise", like graduate students again. Dr. Krishna broke the mold of the academic persona, always handsomely attired, delighting in classical music and fine food and wine. He was jovial, enthusiastic, generous, and highly encouraging to students and young faculty. Dr. Krishna was a member of the Linnean Society of London and the Oriental Club, London; there are 14 species and genera of insects named after him. In 2011, a 324-page Festschrift volume was published in his honor. Kumar Krishna was born 21 June 1928 in Rangoon, then part of British India; he grew up in Dehra Dun, in the foothills of the Indian Himalayas. His father was a physician and one of the first Indians to serve in the British Army as a major in WWI. Young Kumar received his B.Sc. from Agra University in 1950 and his M.Sc. from Lucknow University in 1952. He met his wife, Valerie Smith, while studying for his Ph.D. at the University of Chicago from 1955 to 1961. When they moved to New York Valerie took a position as Professor of English at City College, simultaneously studying for her Ph.D. at New York University. She is a noted scholar on Arthurian literature and Chaucer's "Canterbury Tales". Besides his devoted and loving wife Valerie, Dr. Krishna is survived by two sisters, Veena Puri of Adelaide, Australia, and Dr. Prabha Prakash of White Plains, by ten nieces and nephews, and many friends and admiring colleagues.

JAFFE--Israeli Aaron, born Brooklyn, December 21, 1927, passed away September 24, 2014, at New York Presbyterian Hospital, where he was an Attending Physician in Rheumatology for several decades. Dr. Jaffe graduated from New York University in 1947, and from the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, in 1950. He was a Master of the American College of Rheumatology, and received Lifetime Achievement Awards from the New York Chapter of the Arthritis Foundation (2006) and the New York State Rheumatology Society (2014). Ray, as many called him, had many passions, including a love for classical music and fine stereo equipment. He was also a connoisseur of fine wines and a skilled photographer. He leaves his beloved wife Judith; daughters Naomi, Audrey, and Carrie and their husbands David, Peter, and Emmett, and two adored grandchildren, Eli and Seth.
