GURIN--Bertram, passed away peacefully on September 10, 2014 at the age of 85, surrounded by his wife and daughters. Bertram was happily married to Doris Gurin, nee Singer, for 61 years. Following his retirement in computer systems analysis he became an actor, enjoying theatre and the numerous characterizations he portrayed. Bertram is lovingly remembered by his wife Doris Gurin, his daughters and their husbands Judith and Luca Missoni, Barbara and Marc Wachspress, Janice and Harry Prawer, and his grandchildren Jennifer, Michel- angelo, Madeleine, Eliezer, Benyamin, Zahava, Gabriella, Schmuel, Eliezra, Dovid, Menachim, and other relatives. Memorial donations may be made to the Camphill Special School, 1784 Fairview Road, Glenmoore, PA 19343.
GOLDSTEIN--Allen. "AJ" you will be sorely missed. Vivian and Ira Merritt

GOLDSTEIN--Allen "AJ," passed away peacefully on September 23. Devoted and loving husband of 60 years to Connie. Adoring father of Susan (Scott) Kushner and Nancy (Mark) Wasserman. Proud grandfather of Max Kushner, Jessica, z'l, Melissa and Andrew Wasserman. Brother of Caroline Resnick and uncle to Jane and Robert (Barbara) Resnick and their children. AJ will be remembered as a compassionate and caring friend to many. A great lawyer and proud Korean War Veteran. His warmth and caring will be missed by all. Donations may be made to Fairfield High School Scholarship, referring to the Jessica Wasserman Fund.
GOLDSTEIN--CONNIE and ALLEN. In the secret space of dreams, when the secrets are all told, and the petals all unfold, I will dream of you my dearest loves. Caroline

GODLESKI--Peter Paul, 96, of Wilkes-Barre, PA, died September 22, 2014. A WWII tank driver in the Normandy Invasion and General Patton's 3rd Army, he is survived by his wife of 59 years, Elvira; daughter, Linda, Professor at Yale School of Medicine; son Peter, orthopedic surgeon in Florida; granddaughters, Kimberlea Kristy and Calina Moreland; daughter-in-law, Stephanie Moreland. He lived life to the fullest, just last week traveling 1000 miles to cheer on his granddaughter, Kimber Kristy, at her American Idol audition, where he was greeted by Ryan Seacrest and the celebrity judges.

GELLER--Norman, 93, on September 24, 2014, of Boca Raton and Hillsdale, NY. His was a life fully and well lived, and he made the world a better place as a person of intelligence, dignity, grace, humor, and wisdom. Founding partner of Lord, Geller, Federico & Einstein; Trustee of the Boca Raton Museum of Art for over 25 years. Proud member of the Army Air Force in WWII. He leaves Edith, his wife of 68 years, his sons Eric and Douglas and their wives, Cathy and Sandi-Jo; grandchildren Jamie (Dustin), Jessalyn (Ray), Lucas, Elizabeth, and Julia, and great-grandchildren Sasha, Logan, and Matty. No services. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Boca Raton Museum of Art, 501 Plaza Real, Boca Raton, FL 33432.

GEISER--Jeanne S.,92, wife, companion, and friend of Hank Geiser, passed away on September 25th in their home. She will be missed by her husband Hank, her daughters Lori, Karla, Robin and Sameth, her step-daughters Lisabeth and Kristina, her grandchildren and step-grandchildren and great-grandchildren. She was a special and good woman, beloved by all. Services today at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 12:30pm. Contributions, in lieu of flowers, can be made to the Martha Stewart Center at Mt. Sinai Hospital.
GARAVELLI--Giancarlo. On August 17, 2014 we suffer the lost of our dear brother Giancarlo Garavelli, owner of former restaurant Bravo Gianni on the upper east side. The sisters: Anita and Clementina.

FISHMAN--Ethel (Grossman), 88 years old. Mother of BJ and Peter. Proud mother-in- law to her guardian angels Cindy and her sister Susan. Aunt and cousin to many loved ones and special person to everyone she met. She graduated from City College in 1946 and completed her Masters at SUNY Empire State in 1989. Retailing major, retailing professional at A&S in downtown Brooklyn, then associate professor at Fashion Institute of Technology. She loved learning, traveling, meeting people and life. Admired for her knowledge, sense of style, sense of humor and positive outlook. She passed away quietly and peacefully; exactly how she wanted. We will miss her every day for the rest of our lives.

FELDER--Sara, 92, passed away on Tuesday, September 24th. Born in Ohio, Sara was a graduate of the Cleveland Institute of Music, where she was also on the String faculty, the beginning of her lifelong career as violin teacher to scores of students. A longtime resident of New Jersey, Sara's participation in community events included many performances with her string quartet and piano accompanist. A gifted decorator and homemaker, she cherished beautiful things and always maintained an impeccable household open to her many friends, including her book club group of forty years. Sara immersed herself in Torah study and other activities at Temple Sinai of Bergen County, where she was honored to be asked to sing the Haftarah every year during Rosh Hashanah services. Pre-deceased by Marvin, her devoted husband of 66 years, and sister Bessie, she is survived by children Joan and Mitchell (Susan), grandsons Justin and Sam, and sister Rose. Services will be held at 11:30am on Sunday, September 28th at Temple Sinai of Bergen County, 1 Engle Street, Tenafly, New Jersey.

FEINBERG--Mortimer, 93, of Tamarac, FL passed of natural causes in his sleep late Tuesday evening. Beloved father, father-in-law, grandfather, great-grandfather, brother-in-law and uncle, he will be dearly missed by grandchildren Alissa and Zach Miller and Erin and Brent Rogol, and son-in-law John Miller. Morty -- known to many as "Poppy" -- was a loving father and active and involved grandfather -- always with a camera in hand. He was a wonderful husband to Shirley, to whom he was married for 67 years. She was his greatest passion and together they enjoyed later years of travel, golf, and social life with friends in Long Island and Florida. He was a successful entrepreneur, growing and running his father's company Milton Feinberg Trucking along with his brother Jerry. He was an avid sports fan, and held season tickets to the New York Giants for decades. He loved food and people and lighthearted mischief. He lived a rich, long life surrounded by a big family that he loved and loved him dearly. He is finally reunited with the love of his life Shirley and their darling daughter Joan.

FEINBERG--Mortimer "Morty", 93, passed away peacefully at home. He is preceded by his wife of 65 years Shirley, daughter Joan and daughter-in-law Jo. He is survived by his children Jay, Judy, Larry and John. Grandchildren Marc, Mindy, Lisa, Zach, Alissa, Erin, Brent, Arianna, Jordanna and Chuck and seven great-grandchildren. He was loved by his family and will be remembered always. -The Feinbergs

ELLEN--Max, died peacefully in his sleep on September 9 at the age of 88. Born to a family of theatrical artists in Hamburg, Germany, he was a Holocaust survivor, arriving as a refugee in NYC on December 3rd, 1941. A charismatic and handsome man, he was a gifted and successful classically trained violinist, who played with all the great jazz and pop stars for decades: everyone from Ella Fitzgerald to Mel Torme to James Brown. He was also a player and contractor on countless movie soundtracks and TV jingles. A devoted and loving husband, father, grandfather and friend, he is predeceased by his beloved wife, Leslie, and survived by his adoring children and their spouses, Caroline and Rick, Danny and Antonella, and grandchildren Max and Lucy.

EFFRON--Sadie, 107, resident of Poughkeepsie passed away in her home on September 26. She was predeceased by her husband William. She is survived by her sons Jack (Rita), Ira (Dana), Michael (partner Carole), several grandchildren and great-grandchildren. She and her late husband founded Efco Products. She was the oldest living graduate of Marist College and active in local philanthropy. Services are under the direction of William G. Miller Funeral Home, 371 Hooker Ave., Poughkeepsie, NY.

DEAN--Charles R.,passed away peacefully at home aged 89 surrounded by his family on September 26. Chuck graduated from Harvard in 1946 also serving for three years in the Navy aboard the USS Sargent Bay during WWII. In 1960 he received his Ph.D. in Economics from Columbia University. He was a true renaissance man in addition to having his own economic consulting firm, he was a photographer, carpenter, jeweler, sailor, chef, gardener, book-a-day reader, and our Google before there was a Google. He is survived by his beloved wife of 48 years, Betsy Dean, his daughters Merrick, Peggy and Judy, sons Ky and David, three sons-in-law, four grandsons and a great granddaughter. He will be deeply missed by all his friends and extended family. There will be a memorial service on Tuesday, October 14, at 11:30am at The New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, New York, NY.

COLEMAN--Dr. Enid, 69 of New York City, passed away, peacefully, September 21, 2014. Loving daughter of Chester and Beatrice Coleman. Survived by her brother, Dr. Martin E. Coleman (Gail), niece Alina and nephew, Joe Pelusi (Laura), cousins and friends. She excelled with her diagnostic skills in Emergency Medicine at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. She was a tap dancer, musician, ice skater, avid reader, knitter, needle pointer, lover of antique handkerchiefs, New York City Historian, ballet dancer, Yankee fan and a loyal friend. She loved the theater, laughter and had a zealous dedication to learning and the arts. Donations may be made in her name to: Ovarian Cancer Research Fund at 14 Penn Plaza, Ste. 1710, NY, NY 10022. (212)-268-1002.

CHESBROUGH--Herb. Newport Festivals Foundation is saddened at the passing of its Executive Director, Herb Chesbrough. Herb was a wonderful person who provided expert guidance to our non-profit organization. Our condolences to his wife, Kathy, his children and grandchildren. We will miss him greatly. George Wein, Chairman, Board of Directors and Staff

CATER--William B.,Sr., 87, passed away September 13 in West Caldwell, NJ. Bill lived in Millburn, NJ for many years. Bill was the epitome of what a sweet, loving, gentle, kind, brilliant and strong man should be. He was a devoted husband and father. Prior to retirement, Bill was senior partner at Brundage, Story & Rose and chairman and governor of the Investment Counsel Association of America. He was past President of the Board of the New Jersey Symphony and a life trustee. Bill is survived by his loving wife, Bonnie Cater, his children, Bill Cater, Jr., Chip Cater, Sue Jukosky, and their mother, June Cater, step-children, Susan Bellotti, Robert Bosonac, Robin Vadurro, and Leslie Lewis, and many grand and great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 2pm on October 4, at Community Congregational Church, 200 Hartshorn Drive, Short Hills, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Music Education Fund of the NJ Symphony Orchestra, 60 Park Place, Newark, NJ 07102.

CARTER--John Mack. John Mack Carter, the storied magazine editor who headed the nation's top three women's magazines, including a 20-year stint at Good Housekeeping, died September 26, 2014 at his home in Bronxville, NY, after a lengthy battle with Parkinson's disease. He was 86 years old. Carter spent six decades in magazines and was the editor who shaped a new agenda for women's magazines in the pre-feminist era. He edited McCall's, then Ladies' Home Journal and ultimately Good Housekeeping--the top women's titles at the time--and is the only person in publishing history to have headed all three. In the early 1970s, a group of women stormed Carter's office at Ladies' Home Journal, holding him hostage for 11 hours as they demanded and negotiated changes in the magazine. The event garnered national media attention and Carter responded by taking magazines in a direction that reflected women's changing roles and needs. "There was more discrimination than I thought,: he later said. "I didn't push our women readers far enough in their self-awareness." In another interview he stated, "Power is the big issue that divides men and women. Men hold power, women want power, but men are reluctant to give it--any of it--away." His magazines reflected his ever-evolving consciousness and remained an advocate for women for the rest of his career, speaking out on issues ranging from equal rights to sexual harassment. "John Mack Carter was a giant in our industry," said Steven R. Swartz, president and CEO, Hearst Corporation. For decades he led some of this country's most widely read magazines, he mentored a generation of writers and editors, and his hugely successful Good Housekeeping helped fuel the growth of today's Hearst Corporation." "John Mack Carter was one of the most successful and influential editors of his time," said William R. Hearst III, chairman of the board, Hearst Corporation. "He was a leader in every aspect of the business and he will be missed by the entire Hearst family." "When John Mack became editor of Good Housekeeping, he faced a formidable challenge of invigorating the magazine without alienating its loyal core readers," said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., executive vice chairman and former CEO, Hearst Corporation. "Along with modernizing its content, he had a solution in 1975 that is today's industry standard: Put celebrities on the cover. The idea was revolutionary at the time and massive, immediate circulation growth followed. His vision and leadership played an important role in the growth of this company. We will all miss John Mack's unparalleled passion--and most of all, his friendship." "After leading Good Housekeeping to unprecedented success, John Mack Carter went on to generate future magazine growth at Hearst by inspiring the launch of new titles," said Gilbert C. Maurer, director and former COO, Hearst Corporation. "Over the years, so much of what I came to recognize as the standards for great magazine publishing I learned from John. His knack for perceiving unfilled needs in the marketplace was uncanny. And no one ever wrote a better cover line." A Murray, KY, native who attended Murray State University before transferring to the University of Missouri where he earned his master's in journalism in 1949, Carter remained loyal to his roots. He received an honorary Doctor of Letters degree from Murray State University in 1971. Advertising Age once dubbed Carter the "bluegrass evangelist," yet he was the consummate New York media luminary, working on more than a dozen established magazines. When Carter left Good Housekeeping in 1994, he helped to conceive and launch new titles for Hearst as president of Hearst Magazines Enterprises. Carter played a pivotal role in launching Country Living, Victoria, SmartMoney and Marie Claire, among other titles. Carter came to Hearst in 1975 from American Home Publishing Company where he was chairman and editor in chief of American Home magazine. Under his leadership at Good Housekeeping from 1975 to 1994, the magazine won two National Magazine Awards. In 1989, Carter received the Henry Johnson Fisher Award from MPA The Association of Magazine Media and in 2000, he was inducted into the American Society of Magazine Editors' Hall of Fame. In addition to his editorial and executive duties, Carter wrote a monthly column on magazines for Adweek for nine years. He hosted the cable television program, Good Housekeeping: A Better Way. He also found time to author and co-author a number of books, including 1975's How to Be Outrageously Successful with Women: A Guide to Surviving the Sexual Revolution, with Lois Wyse, and The Good Housekeeping Illustrated Book of Pregnancy and Baby Care (1990). While still in high school, Carter became a reporter for the Murray Ledger & Times, where he continued to contribute until he completed his graduate degree. He was offered $50 a week by Better Homes and Gardens to be an assistant editor, his first foray into women's magazines. He left Better Homes and Gardens for a commission as an ensign in the U.S. Navy and served two tours during the Korean War on the minesweeper U.S.S. Toucan before being honorably discharged as a lieutenant. Carter then took a job as managing editor at Household Magazine in Topeka, Kan., before heading to his ultimate destination of New York City. A Bronxville, N.Y., resident for 47 years, Carter is survived by his wife of 66 years, Sharlyn Reaves Carter; his children, Jonna Carter and John Mack Carter II; son-in-law John R. Low; daughter-in-law Victoria Carter; and four grandchildren, John Mack Carter III, Christina Victoria Carter, Kathleen Elizabeth Carter Low and Christopher Ryan Carter Low. He is also survived by his twin sister, Carolyn Carter Reagan; brother-in-law Johnny Reagan; nieces Jan Reagan Fuqua and Lyn Reagan Ryan; and nephews Danny Grant, David Grant, Dean Grant and Donald Grant. There will be a funeral for family and friends in Bronxville, N.Y., next week. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Andrus Early Learning Center (65 Main Street 3rd Floor, Tuckahoe, NY 10707; Alessandra Rose 914-965-3700 ext. 1241).

BREWER--Hugh Cleland "Jerry", Jr.,formerly of Wilton and Darien CT, Twin Bridges, MT, and Ocala, FL, died peacefully, surrounded by his family, on September 13. He was 89. Mr. Brewer graduated from Taft school and attended Harvard College. He served in WWII, 75th Infantry Division, and fought in the Battle of the Bulge. His banking career began at First National City Bank (Citibank); he retired from Bankers Trust Company. He was predeceased in 2005 by his wife of 49 years, Diana Burkett Brewer. He had five children: Hugh Cleland Brewer III; Daryln Brewer Hoffstot; Jeffrey Stott Brewer; Jennifer Brewer Giem; and David Mitchell Brewer, and twelve grandchildren. Contributions may be made in his memory to: Smile Train, www.smiletrain.org.

BLOCH--Donald. The Board of Directors, Faculty and Staff are deeply saddened by the loss of Donald Bloch, our director for 18 years, from 1972-1990. We extend our sincerest condolences. The Ackerman Institute for the Family

BLANK--Robert Gray, 94. February 24, 1920 - September 25, 2014, of Long Island, NY. Beloved husband of 72 years to Joan, the love of his life. He will be dearly missed by his children, Lois and Rob, grandchildren Chris, Budd and Robbie, great-grandchildren, family, and many friends whose lives he enriched.

BARRETT--Mary B.,100, of Goshen, NY on September 19, 2014. Devoted wife of late Arthur L. Barrett, loving mother of David and Assemblymember Didi Barrett, and adoring grandmother of Alec and Annabel. Born in Paterson, NJ, Mary served in WWII as Second Lieutenant, Womens Army Corps. Educated at Montclair State and Harvard, she began teaching English in 1934 and retired as Professor Emerita at SUNY Orange to travel, make quilts and write poetry.

APPLEBAUM--Lila Roth, 83, graduated Smith College, founded Applebaum Associates Inc. Survived by daughters Lynn, Amy, Jo, their spouses, and grandchildren Graham, Rachel, Maggie, Gabriel. Donations to Children's Health Fund. Memorial to be held in late October.

ANDRES--Jane Madeleine, of Dobbs Ferry, NY, passed away on September 9, 2014. Jane was the daughter of the late Charles and Grace Andres. She was predeceased by siblings Charles, John and Grace, and is survived by 12 nieces and nephews. Jane graduated from Rosemont College and pursued a career in advertising, fashion and home furnishings. Jane held positions with Vogue, Harper's Bazaar and Gourmet magazines, Doyle Dane Bernbach, and Wedgewood. In her later years Jane worked for the Church of the Sacred Heart in Dobbs Ferry. Jane was a true New Yorker who enjoyed reading and travel. Mass of the Christian Burial will be held at 10am on Saturday October 4, 2014 at the Church of the Sacred Heart, Dobbs Ferry, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Sacred Heart Food for the Hungry, 18 Bellewood Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, NY 10522.

ROSENFELD--Lawrence, 90, passed away Friday, September 26 at home in Concord, MA. Born in New York, Larry was a graduate of Queens College (BS, Phi Beta Kappa) and received a Ph.D. in Applied Mathematics from Harvard University. Larry served as a Naval Officer on the U.S.S. Chicago in the Pacific Campaign during WWII. A resident of Concord, MA since 1951, He was a money manager who ran his own private investment funds. In addition to an accomplished career in money management, Larry was widely recognized as one of the key developers of the stock picking programs used by The Value Line Service. He was also a proud resident of Argyle. Nova Scotia where he built his dream house on a cliff overlooking the ocean. He was the devoted husband to Ruth, who died in 2007 and the proud father of Faith, Eric, Jan, Amy and their spouses, partners and of his grandchildren, Jamie, Alison, Taran and Leif. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to the Ruth Rosenfeld Oncology Educational Endowment Fund, c/o Mass. General Hospital Bethke Center at Emerson Hospital, 133 ORNAC, Concord, MA 01742 For the online guestbook or to share a memory please visit: www.concordfuneral.com Concord Funeral Home, Concord, MA. 978-369-3388.

ROOB--Rona. It is with profound sorrow that we mourn the loss of former Museum of Modern Art colleague and dear friend, Rona Roob. Rona's abiding love for the Museum went back to the 1960s when she began working for MoMA's first director, Alfred Barr. Her devotion and commitment to the Museum found permanent expression with the establishment of the Museum Archives in 1989 which she directed until her retirement in 1998. Rona's knowledge of the Museum was unparalleled. She could recall historic details about MoMA's artworks, people and events with uncanny accuracy and was a tireless champion for the preservation of MoMA's legacy, as her many publications attest. Rona had tremendous energy and verve, and always demonstrated unstinting loyalty to MoMA along with a passion for modern art. Her love for her family and her generosity to friends was deeply felt. To her daughters Nancy and Helen and their families, we send our heartfelt sympathy. Agnes Gund and Karen Davidson

ROOB--Rona, 75, died peacefully in Manhattan on September 26 after a courageous battle with cancer. Rona's life revolved around her family, the world of modern art, and a close circle of friends. She was devoted to and complemented her gentle husband of 52 years, Richard, who passed away on June 2. She enjoyed nothing more than spending time with her two daughters and their husbands--Nancy Roob and Lukas Weinstein, and Helen and Marc Jerome--and her five grandchildren: Hanna, Ella, Sophie, Lucy and Sam. Born in New York City, Rona graduated from Barnard College, majoring in Art History, and later earned a Master's in Library Science at Columbia University. She had a life-long love of modern art, and The Museum of Modern Art was her second family. She first worked at MoMA in the 1960s, as secretary to Alfred H. Barr, then Director of the Museum Collections. Barr and his wife, Marga, profoundly influenced her life. In the 1980's Rona helped to build The Museum of Modern Art Archives Records Management Program, which was formerly established as a separate department in 1989 with Rona as the founding Archivist. She was named Chief Archivist in 1996, and upon her retirement in 1998, the position of Rona Roob Museum Archivist was established. Rona embodied the archives: She was passionate about preserving MoMA's institutional history, loved facts and details, and had an extraordinary capacity to organize and retain large amounts of information. She made many presentations and wrote numerous articles, including "A Noble Legacy," considered the definitive article on MoMA co-founder Lillie Bliss, "1936: The Museum Selects an Architect," and "The Rockefeller Vision and the Making of The Museum of Modern Art." Rona was a trustee emerita of the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution, and a member of MoMA's Trustee Committee on Archives, Library and Research, the Advisory Committee of the Frick Center for the History of Collecting, and the board of trustees of Guild Hall. She was also a member of the Century Association and Cosmopolitan Club. Her family and friends greatly mourn her loss. Funeral services will be private. Notes of sympathy may be sent to the Family of Rona Roob at her home address. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Rona Roob Archives Fund at MoMA.

MIZRACH--Eleanor B.,on September 25, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Devoted mother of Richard and Isabel. MIRMAN--Paul Steven, Esq.,of Brooklyn, NY, died September 27, 2014, after a fierce battle against the multiple sclerosis and its effects that plagued him for the last 23 years. Mr. Mirman grew up in East New York, attended Thomas Jefferson High School, Brooklyn College, and Brooklyn Law School. He was proud to have been a plaintiff's personal injury attorney and to have represented significant numbers of injured New Yorkers since his admission to the New York State Bar in March, 1969. His original office was in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn, where his name was emblazoned across the top of the corner building at Rockaway Parkway and Flatlands Avenue. Mr. Mirman's down-to-earth, magnetic personality drew thousands of New Yorkers to him for representation. He was one of the first lawyers in New York City to take advantage of attorney advertising, which he did on the subways, buses, in print, and on radio and television. Numerous young lawyers came through his office, learning from him to litigate, try cases, and most importantly to stand up and fight for their clients. In addition to his wife, the former Michele Turchin, Mr. Mirman is survived by their children, Phoebe and Matthew; by John and Lawrence, sons of his first marriage; his brothers Ronald, Alvin, and Leonard Mirman; and four grandchildren. The funeral service will be held Monday, September 29, 2014, at 12:45pm at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY. (718) 445-0300. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society http:// www.nationalmssociety.org/ The family will be accepting visitors at the home of Michele Mirman on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, September 29 through October 1, 2014, from 4pm-8 pm.

FISHMAN--Ethel (Grossman), 88 years old. Mother of BJ and Peter. Proud mother-in- law to her guardian angels Cindy and her sister Susan. Aunt and cousin to many loved ones and special person to everyone she met. She graduated from City College in 1946 and completed her Masters at SUNY Empire State in 1989. Retailing major, retailing professional at A&S in downtown Brooklyn, then associate professor at Fashion Institute of Technology. She loved learning, traveling, meeting people and life. Admired for her knowledge, sense of style, sense of humor and positive outlook. She passed away quietly and peacefully; exactly how she wanted. We will miss her every day for the rest of our lives.

ELLEN--Max, died peacefully in his sleep on September 9 at the age of 88. Born to a family of theatrical artists in Hamburg, Germany, he was a Holocaust survivor, arriving as a refugee in NYC on December 3rd, 1941. A charismatic and handsome man, he was a gifted and successful classically trained violinist, who played with all the great jazz and pop stars for decades: everyone from Ella Fitzgerald to Mel Torme to James Brown. He was also a player and contractor on countless movie soundtracks and TV jingles. A devoted and loving husband, father, grandfather and friend, he is predeceased by his beloved wife, Leslie, and survived by his adoring children and their spouses, Caroline and Rick, Danny and Antonella, and grandchildren Max and Lucy.

Zipper--Gerald Jerry, 84, died on September 28, felled by a debilitating brain injury after years of fighting cancer. Born in Brooklyn, NY he lived his adult life in Manhattan and Garrison, NY. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Sheila, his adored sons Michael and Andrew, daughter-in-law Christine, and beloved grandchildren Noah, Zachary, Phoebe and Calvin. A gifted poet, he was published both nationally and internationally. He was an insurance industry entrepreneur and past Deputy Superintendent of Insurance for New York State. Jerry complemented his extensive knowledge of History with an active life in New York City politics. Funeral services will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, on Wednesday, October 1 at 11:30am.

WALSH--Catherine M.,on September 26, 2014. Devoted daughter of the late Thomas F. and Catherine A. (nee Tynion). She is survived by her Godson Donald W. Tynion II; cousin Kathleen Smorto (nee Walsh); numerous cousins and dear friends. She was Trustee of her beloved parish, Our Lady of Angels in Brooklyn; Lector, Eucharistic Minister, and Lady Grand Cross of the Holy Sepulcher. She earned her BA and MA from St. John's University; taught Math at John Jay High School (retired); and enjoyed close friendships with Marion Sinnott and cousins Mary Jane McDonald and Eileen Tynion. Visiting: Tuesday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial: Wednesday 10:30am at Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church. In lieu of flowers, please donate to: Our Lady of Angels Parish, 7230 4th Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11209.

SCHULMAN--Steven Robert, passed away on September 27, 2014 after a long illness. Steven was born in Chicago on April 1, 1951 and was the son of the late Robert and Lois Schulman of Sarasota. He spent his childhood in Highland Park, Illinois and graduated from North Shore Country Day School in 1969. From the time he was a young boy, Steven had a great love of nature and wildlife. He received his B.S. in Forestry from University of Montana in 1973 and his Master's in Forestry from Harvard University in 1974. He then headed to the School of Forestry and Environmental Studies at Yale University. where he earned his PhD in 1980. His post Doctoral research included a NATO Fellowship in the Department of Zoology at Cambridge University and a N.I.M.H. Fellowship in the Department of Biology at Princeton University. During his academic career, Steven maintained a strong interest in the stock market and decided to apply his analytical skills to a career on Wall Street where his first job was modeling stock options. Steven held senior positions at Merrill Lynch and UBS in London and New York, and retired from his position as Global Head of Risk Management at Merrill Lynch in 2001. Steven spent the last ten years with his wife and best friend, Laurie, in Bradenton, Florida enjoying nature and spending time with their children. His greatest pleasure in life was watching his children and their cousins enjoy the outdoors together at their yearly summer vacations. Steven had many interests and hobbies; his favorite was playing classical and flamenco guitar. Steven will long be remembered as a lighthearted, kind, and generous soul. He is survived by his wife of 22 years, Laurie; daughters, Emily Schulman of New York, NY and Alexandra Schulman of Banbury, England; sons, Nicholas Schulman of Arlington, VA and Spencer Schulman of Bradenton, FL; sister, Gwen Schulman of Sarasota, FL; brother, David Schulman, his wife, Margot and their daughter, Allison of Falls Church, VA. His niece, Casey Schulman, daughter of David and Margot Schulman predeceased Steven. Visitation will be on Thursday, October 2, 2014 from 4:00-6:00pm followed by a Funeral Service at 6:00pm at Brown & Sons Funeral Homes & Crematory 43rd Street Chapel, 604 43rd Street West, Bradenton FL 34209. Burial will be at Prairie Creek Conservation Cemetery in Gainesville, FL. Donations in Steven's memory may be made to The Natural Resources Defense Council. Condolences to: brownandsonsfuneral.com.

ROOB--Rona. The Board and staff of Studio in a School mourn the loss of our dear friend Rona Roob. We extend our deepest sympathies to her daughters Nancy Roob and Helen Jerome and their families.

PLACZEK--Beverley R.,101, of New York City, died September 28. Pre-deceased by husband Adolf Placzek, survived by daughter Sylvia Brewda of Maryland, grandson Ian Barkley-Yeung of California and two great-grandsons. A celebration of her remarkable life is being planned.

MELTSNER--Barbara, of Manhattan and Seaview, Fire Island passed away on September 28th after a battle with cancer. A trained nurse, she worked in the operating room at Roosevelt Hospital in New York and also served as the school nurse at the Bank Street School. She turned her love and passion for food into a career, teaching cooking to children, running a successful catering company, and helping write and produce several community cookbooks. She is survived by her husband of 54 years, Edward, her children Michael and Jim, daughters-in-law Nathalie Robbins and Lisa Kleine, five loving grandchildren, a sister, Jackie Freedman, and several nieces and nephews. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell on Madison Avenue at 11:30am today.

MANGOLD--George I.,D.O. died September 28, 2014, at the age of 95 in Boca Raton, FL. He was the wonderful and adored husband of Pearl for 68 years, loving and proud father of Karen (Richard) and Robert (Joan), devoted grandfather of four, honored uncle, and friend to many. George was an osteopathic physician practicing in Manhattan for over 40 years before retiring to Silver Spring, MD and Boca Raton, FL. Happy in retirement, he pursued his many interests: cello, oil painting, travel, literature, and classical music. George always had a funny, kind, and friendly word for everyone. He was loved and will be missed. Donations may be made to Cystic Fibrosis Foundation or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

LIBMAN--Peter. The Hofstra community is deeply saddened by the passing of former Dean of Students Peter Libman on September 27, 2014. Dean Libman was an integral part of the campus community, serving as a mentor, educator and advisor to countless students during his more than seven years at Hofstra University. He left the University in the summer of 2014 to focus full-time on his health. He became a tireless advocate for pancreatic cancer research, lobbying Congress with the Pancreatic Cancer Network and leading a team called "Pete's Pride" that raised more than $15,000 for the 2013 Lustgarten Pancreatic Cancer Walk at Jones Beach. Dean Libman was among the most visible administrators at Hofstra, responsible for programs and services that cover the breadth of campus life including new student orientation and residential programs, multicultural and international student services, commuting student affairs, student leadership activities and recreation and intramural sports. Dean Libman came to Hofstra from the School of the American Ballet in 2007. He also held student affairs positions at Columbia University, Barnard College and Clemson University, where he earned a Master's degree in education. He also was a participant in the New York City Board of Education Leadership Academy and earned an advanced certificate in educational administration from Baruch College. To honor the memory of Dean Libman, all Hofstra University flags were lowered to half-staff on Monday, September 29 and will be raised again on Thursday, October 2. Janis M. Meyer Chair, Hofstra University Board of Trustees Stuart Rabinowitz President, Hofstra University

JACOBY--Doris. Congregation Rodeph Sholom notes with sorrow the death of our longtime, devoted member, Doris Jacoby, wife of the late Henry J. Jacoby. JACOBY--Doris G.,on September 26, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Henry J. Jacoby, sister of Annette Goodman Mark, Joann Goodman Imohiesen, the late Robert Goodman and the late William Goodman. Mother of Ruth Ellen Jacoby Barnert, Karen Jacoby Zovic, and Jean Jacoby Bentley. Grandmother of Matthew Jacoby Barnert, Michelle Celeste Zovic, Nicholas Henry Zovic, Barritt Wolff Jacoby Bentley, Emma Rose Bentley Jacoby, and great-grandmother of Benjamin Henry Lyon Kalebarn. Of complications from congestive heart failure, peacefully at home. As a young woman, she was a concert pianist, trained by Diller and Quayle, while at the same time a first class athlete at The Dalton School, qualifying in swimming and also dancing in the Isadora Duncan School. She earned her Bachelor's Degree in Music at Ohio State University before returning to New York City and marrying Henry J. Jacoby who succeeded her father as Chairman of the Board of Grow Tunneling Corporation, a construction firm in New York City, building many public projects, including major work on the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels and the Bronx Water Tunnel. While raising three of her own children, she was also devoted to other children in the community. A woman of many talents, she served as President of the Walden School PTA, President of the Rodeph Sholom Parents Association, President of the Goddard Riverside Neighborhood Day Care Center, and teacher of English to Spanish speaking students. Active in the Young Concert Artists Guild of New York, she also provided homes for them during their auditions. We will always love and miss her. A funeral service will be held Tuesday, September 30, 2014, 11:15am at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83 St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Smile Train.

HOTCHKISS--Jane Ellsworth, June 23, 1932 - September 26, 2014. Born in New York City, Jane Ellsworth Hotchkiss, a resident of Hobe Sound, FL and longtime resident of Bernardsville, NJ and Fishers Island, NY, died on Friday, September 26th at her daughter's home in Lakeville, CT. In addition to her husband of 59 years, Winchester Fitch Hotchkiss, she is survived by their three children, Winch- ester Fitch Hotchkiss, Jr., Leslie Hotchkiss Arndt and Mary Hotchkiss Harvey. Her seven beloved grandchildren include Leslie W. Hotchkiss, Winchester F. Hotchkiss, III, Ashton H. Harvey, Alexander S. Harvey, Duncan M. Harvey, Sarah E. Arndt and Hannah R. Arndt. Mrs. Hotchkiss attended the Chapin School, Foxcroft School and Smith College. As a noted miniaturist with the late Kathleen Pitney, she created prize winning dioramas at shows in New York and Philadelphia. Funeral services will be Thursday, October 9th at St. John's Church in Salisbury, CT at 11:30am. A private burial will be on Fishers Island, NY at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Ellsworth Memorial Health Center, PO Box 2003, Springfield, VT 05156.

HARRIS--Shirley D.,98, on September 27, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Jack M. and loving mother of the late Jay David Harris. A charitable woman who was a friend to many. She will be missed by all who knew her. Funeral service Wednesday, October 1st, 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. (at 81st St.). Interment to follow at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY.

GOLDSTEIN--Malcolm, 89, died in Manhattan on September 27 after a long illness. Born in Huntington, WV, son of Jack A. and Lydia Cohen Goldstein, he attended Governor Dummer Academy in Byfield, MA and graduated in 1949 from Princeton, interrupting his studies to serve in World War II. After earning a PhD in English literature at Columbia University, Dr. Goldstein taught at Stanford University before joining the English Department at Queens College, CUNY, where he taught until his retirement in 1991. Dr. Goldstein specialized in 20th-century American theater and wrote several acclaimed books: "The Art of Thornton Wilder, The Political Stage: American Drama and Theater of the Great Depression," and "George S. Kaufman: His Life, His Theater," a biography a New York Times reviewer called "an admirable accomplishment." Dr. Goldstein's other passion was art. His sharp and judicious eye enabled him to amass on a limited budget an impressive collection of contemporary drawings and prints that included works by Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, Claes Oldenberg, Sherrie Levine, Susan Rothenberg and Chuck Close. A devoted member of the Century Association, he also collected and on one occasion exhibited prints by members of the club. His final book, appropriately, was "Landscape with Figures: A History of Art Dealing in the United States." Although Dr. Goldstein leaves no survivors, his friends will always remember the generosity with which he shared his extensive knowledge, his steadfast interest in their lives and offspring, his infectious good humor and, most of all, his unfailing kindness.

FITZGERALD--David Thomas, born on November 9, 1932, died September 20, 2014. Beloved husband of Barbara Wells and father to Catherine Anderson, Tara Neeld, Brendan and Timothy Fitzgerald. Step family: Karen and Johnny Rodriguez, Christopher Wells. Retired Assistant Deputy Commissioner, HRA, NYC.

ELLEN--Max, died peacefully in his sleep on September 9 at the age of 88. Born to a family of theatrical artists in Hamburg, Germany, he was a Holocaust survivor, arriving as a refugee in NYC on December 3rd, 1941. A charismatic and handsome man, he was a gifted and successful classically trained violinist, who played with all the great jazz and pop stars for decades: everyone from Ella Fitzgerald to Mel Torme to James Brown. He was also a player and contractor on countless movie soundtracks and TV jingles. A devoted and loving husband, father, grandfather and friend, he is predeceased by his beloved wife, Leslie, and survived by his adoring children and their spouses, Caroline and Rick, Danny and Antonella, and grandchildren Max and Lucy.

Zipper--Gerald Jerry, 84, died on September 28, felled by a debilitating brain injury after years of fighting cancer. Born in Brooklyn, NY he lived his adult life in Manhattan and Garrison, NY. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Sheila, his adored sons Michael and Andrew, daughter-in-law Christine, and beloved grandchildren Noah, Zachary, Phoebe and Calvin. A gifted poet, he was published both nationally and internationally. He was an insurance industry entrepreneur and past Deputy Superintendent of Insurance for New York State. Jerry complemented his extensive knowledge of History with an active life in New York City politics. Funeral services will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, on Wednesday, October 1 at 11:30am.

WRISTON--Kathryn Dineen. Syracuse University and its Board of Trustees mourn the loss of its dear friend and benefactor. Kathy was a remarkably accomplished attorney, businesswoman and philanthropist. An honorary member of Syracuse University's College of Law Board of Advisors, she, along with her brother, Bob, a university trustee, and sister, Carolyn were instrumental in the realization of the College's new home, Dineen Hall. It was named in honor of their parents, Robert Emmet Dineen and Carolyn Bareham Dineen. Our heartfelt condolences to their entire family.

WRISTON--Kathryn "Kathy" Dineen of New York City, Sherman, CT and Boynton Beach, FL, passed away suddenly on Sunday morning, September 28, 2014, from complications from a fall at Deer Pond Farm, her house in Sherman, CT. Kathy is predeceased by her beloved husband, Walter B. Wriston, former CEO of Citibank, who passed away in 2005. Kathy's greatest joy in life was the time she spent with Walter working on Deer Pond Farm which they planned to have maintained as a nature preserve. Kathy was born in Syracuse, NY, on March 1, 1939, to the late Robert Emmet Dineen and Carolyn Bareham Dineen. She is survived by her loving sister, the Honorable Carolyn Dineen King, of the 5th Circuit United States Court of Appeals, and devoted brother, Robert E. Dineen, Jr. She is predeceased by the cherished brother, Laurence Joseph Dineen, who died of leukemia at age 7 years. She is also survived by Walter's daughter, Catherine "Cassy" Wriston Quintal, her husband, Richard Quintal and their children, Christopher W. Quintal, his wife, Sara, and Barbara Catherine "Katy" Quintal, all of whom she cared for dearly. In addition, she is survived by her brotherin-law, the Honorable Thomas M. Reavley, her sister-in-law, Jeanne C. Olivier, and three nephews, James D., Philip D. and Stephen E. Randall and two grand-nieces. She spent her childhood years in Syracuse and also in Milwaukee, WI. She later attended and graduated from Smith College in 1960 and from the University of Michigan Law School in 1963. In her early career, she practiced law at the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling LLP. Later in her professional career, she served on the corporate boards of Federated Department Stores, Goodyear, Northwestern Mutual, Southern Pacific, Stanley Works, Union Carbide and WR Grace & Co. and on the boards of professional organizations, including the American Arbitration Association and the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. She also served as a trustee of the Financial Accounting Foundation, the Practising Law Institute, Fordham University and the John A. Hartford Foundation. During the last decade of her life, she spent a tremendous amount of her time in support of many charitable causes. As her many friends and family know, her personal and financial support spanned many causes, such as nature conservation, medical research, educational institutions such as the Fletcher School of Tufts University, Syracuse University College of Law and Hobart and William Smith Colleges, and programs to feed the elderly and poor. She was one of the founders of the Matthew 25 Project, an organization established to assist the elderly in Sherman, CT. Calling hours will be from 4pm to 7pm on Friday, October 3, 2014 at the Lillis Funeral Home at 58 Bridge St, New Milford, CT 06776. On Saturday morning, October 4, 2014 at 11am, there will be a Mass of Christian Burial at the Holy Trinity Church at 15 Route 37, Sherman, CT 06784. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the charity of your choice or to the following charities that Kathy supported: Lustgarten Foundation at 1111 Stewart Avenue, Bethpage, New York 11714, an organization whose mission is to advance the scientific and medical research related to the diagnosis, treatment, cure and prevention of pancreatic cancer which claimed the life of her husband; Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center at 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10065; Sherman Library at 1 Sherman Center, P.O. Box 40, Sherman, CT 06784 which she generously supported; or Matthew 25 Project at P.O. Box 361, Sherman, CT 06784, an organization that she founded.

WISE--Cynthia, 69, died suddenly on Friday, September 26 in New York City, with her sister Barbara and niece Francesca at her side. After earning a B.A. at Connecticut College for Women and a M.A. at Northwestern University, Cynthia began her distinguished career at the African-American Institute, where she directed student and high-level educational programs for French-speaking African countries. She then lived in the Ivory Coast and Mauritania, where she directed various economic development programs. She later had a second career as a legal assistant and worked for many years at Kleinberg, Kaplan, Wolfe & Cohen, P.C. where she was employed at the time of her death. Beloved for her quick humor, keen intelligence and kindness, Cynthia had a deep curiosity for other cultures and customs coupled with a love of travel and adventure. An avid lover of the arts, she was an officer of the Snarks Amateur Theater Company and thoroughly took full advantage of the cultural and culinary riches of New York. She will be deeply missed by her sister Barbara Wise, brother-in-law Robert Wilson, her daughter Helena Cullinan, granddaughters Olive and Minnie, her nieces Cristina Ciarrocchi and Francesca Ciarrocchi, and her many friends. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, October 7th at 3pm, at the Marble Collegiate Church, 29th Street and Fifth Avenue, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research or Bide-a-Wee Pet Welfare Organization.

WEITZNER--I. James, M.D.,on September 29, 2014. Beloved husband for 73 years to Doris. Devoted father of Renee, John and Emily. Dear grandfather of Amy, Nancy, Sandra, Marlena and Faith. Service Thursday, October 2, 2014, 9:30am at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to Jewish United Fund.

SZAPIRO--Frances Rudow, born February 7, 1918. Beloved wife of late Josiel Szapiro; adored mother of Elinor, Miriam and Laura; and of sons-in-law Bruce, Ray and Terry. Best grandma ever of Manora, Josh and Anna. Remedial reading teacher. Created a home that was welcome hub to all, and all who entered became her family. Vibrant, joyful, irrepressibly optimistic, stoic, sharp-witted, caring, generous. Words fall short. There's no replacing her. Memorial Service at Riverside Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY on Thursday, 11:30am. Shiva following burial until 9:00pm at her home. Donations in her memory may be made to Givat Haviva or American Jewish World Service.

SHAW-HOGAN--Norma, died September 27, 2014 at the age of 81. Long-time resident of Riverdale with many devoted friends in New York City, Florida and Chicago. Former head of Regulatory Affairs at NYC Health & Hospitals Corp., from which she retired in 1996. Survived by daughter Robin Shaw and her sisters Barbara and Teresa. Viewing: Ortiz Funeral Home, 4425 Broadway, Manhattan, on Friday, October 3, 2014, 2pm-9pm. Funeral Mass: St. Gabriel's Church, 3250 Arlington Ave., Riverdale, on Saturday, October 4, 10am.

SCHULMAN--Steven Robert, passed away on September 27, 2014 after a long illness. Steven was born in Chicago on April 1, 1951 and was the son of the late Robert and Lois Schulman of Sarasota. He spent his childhood in Highland Park, Illinois and graduated from North Shore Country Day School in 1969. From the time he was a young boy, Steven had a great love of nature and wildlife. He received his B.S. in Forestry from University of Montana in 1973 and his Master's in Forestry from Harvard University in 1974. He then headed to the School of Forestry and Environmental Studies at Yale University. where he earned his PhD in 1980. His post Doctoral research included a NATO Fellowship in the Department of Zoology at Cambridge University and a N.I.M.H. Fellowship in the Department of Biology at Princeton University. During his academic career, Steven maintained a strong interest in the stock market and decided to apply his analytical skills to a career on Wall Street where his first job was modeling stock options. Steven held senior positions at Merrill Lynch and UBS in London and New York, and retired from his position as Global Head of Risk Management at Merrill Lynch in 2001. Steven spent the last ten years with his wife and best friend, Laurie, in Bradenton, Florida enjoying nature and spending time with their children. His greatest pleasure in life was watching his children and their cousins enjoy the outdoors together at their yearly summer vacations. Steven had many interests and hobbies; his favorite was playing classical and flamenco guitar. Steven will long be remembered as a lighthearted, kind, and generous soul. He is survived by his wife of 22 years, Laurie; daughters, Emily Schulman of New York, NY and Alexandra Schulman of Banbury, England; sons, Nicholas Schulman of Arlington, VA and Spencer Schulman of Bradenton, FL; sister, Gwen Schulman of Sarasota, FL; brother, David Schulman, his wife, Margot and their daughter, Allison of Falls Church, VA. His niece, Casey Schulman, daughter of David and Margot Schulman predeceased Steven. Visitation will be on Thursday, October 2, 2014 from 4:00-6:00pm followed by a Funeral Service at 6:00pm at Brown & Sons Funeral Homes & Crematory 43rd Street Chapel, 604 43rd Street West, Bradenton FL 34209. Burial will be at Prairie Creek Conservation Cemetery in Gainesville, FL. Donations in Steven's memory may be made to The Natural Resources Defense Council. Condolences to: brownandsonsfuneral.com.

ROSENFELD--Lawrence. The Queens College community and Foundation Board fondly remember Lawrence Rosenfeld who passed away on September 26, 2014. Larry graduated from Queens College in 1947 with a Bachelor's Degree in Math. He joined the board in 1987 and worked tirelessly on behalf of Queens College students. We are forever grateful for his devotion, generosity, and kind spirit. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his children Faith, Eric, Jan, and Amy, and his wonderful grandchildren. Larry will be deeply missed but his fine legacy will live forever in our hearts. Queens College Foundation Board of Trustees
ROOB--Rona. We mourn the passing of Rona Roob, a long-time member of the Guild Hall Board of Trustees. The Trustees of Guild Hall

MURPHY--Sheila T.,died at her home on September 28th. She was born in Yorkville, NYC, graduated from Lawrence Academy, the College of New Rochelle and received a Masters in Education from New York University. She married her beloved Francis T. Murphy on July 4, 1959. She is survived by her husband and five children, Timothy and his wife, Pamela; Eileen and her husband, Jeffrey Forsyth; Kathleen and her husband, Lance Scott; Sheila and her husband, Michael Sproule; Annemarie and her husband, Kevin Casey; and her brother Thomas Casey. MARTIN--Thomas J.,JD, 71, of Katonah, on September 28, 2014. VP and General Counsel of New York Medical College (retired). Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah.

Manzi--Frances 57, on Sept. 26. Born in Worcester, MA. Survived by 2 sisters, Susan and Janice; brother Arthur; 2 nephews; brother-in-law Harold Cohen. Memorial service in NYC to be announced. Donations to: crowdrise.com/GodsLoveWeDeliver-HelpBuild/fundraiser/ForFrances2014

HIRSCH--Bernard "Bud", 85, passed away peacefully on September 29, 2014. He worked as a television executive for both CBS and NBC from the '50s to the '90s, and, after retirement, traveled the world. He enjoyed travel, food, and his family. He will be missed. He leaves behind his brother (Herbert), two sons (Peter and Richard), three daughters-in-law (Jill, Diane, Bridgette), five grandchildren (Katharine, David, Noah, Rebecca, Graham) and his loving wife Peggy. Services will be at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, 3:30pm on Sunday October 5th.

GRIFFO--William Paul. Beloved son of Drs. Yvona and William Griffo and brother Michael ("BRO") passed suddenly and peacefully on September 25, 2014. Born on Saturday, May 18, 1996, he was currently a senior at Poly Prep Country Day School where he was a proud and loyal teammate on the varsity soccer, ice hockey and Lacrosse teams. In 2011, he graduated from St. David's School in New York City. William is survived by his beloved aunt, uncle and two cousins (Capitani family) in Staten Island, New York as well as a cousin, uncle and aunt (Kolar family in Prague, Czech Republic. His devoted sole surviving grandparent is Mary Ann Griffo. He was predeceased by maternal grandparents, Zdenka and Vladimir Kolar of Prague. William, this summer contributed community service at Marist Brothers Camp, an organization devoted to a dignified life for developmentally challenged adults. Contributing his humor, joy and talents as a counselor brought great happiness to William. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Marist Brothers Center at Esopus Mid Hudson Valley Camps PO Box 197, Esopus, NY 12429 (esopuscamps.com). Visitation at Frank E Campbell 1076 Madison Ave (81st ST) on Thursday, October 2, 2014 from 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial at The Church of Saint Catherine of Siena, 411 East 68th Street, Friday 10am.
DEVOE--Raymond F. Jr.,Thank you, Ray, for the many many years of wisdom, erudition, and laughter. Heidi Fiske

DELAPINE--Maryellen "Mel," 64, of Estero, FL passed away on September 29, 2014. She is survived by her beloved husband, Tom; her daughter, Denise (George Leibel) and her son, Tommy (Angela). Mel was also the devoted and loving grandmother to Ali, Brooklin, Taylor and Thomas Delapine and Melissa Michalak. After being diagnosed with Breast Cancer in 1997 Mel became a fierce and tireless advocate for women's health, active on the Community Outreach Board of the Linda Creed Breast Cancer Foundation, Advisory Board of the Breast Cancer Center of Excellence at the University of Pennsylvania, Community Ambassador for the American Cancer Society, Field Coordinator of the National Breast Cancer Coalition, and a member of the Committee on Education of the Florida Breast Cancer Coalition. In 2010, she became a Lung Cancer Advocate for the Alliance for Clinical Trials in Oncology. Mel was also a grant reviewer for the Department of Defense Breast Cancer Research Program, Komen for the Cure, NYS Board of Health, State of California Breast Cancer Research Program, the LiveStrong Foundation, Cochrane Collaboration, American Cancer Society, Department of Defense Lung Cancer Research Program, and the Cancer Prevention Research Institute of Texas. Her infectious personality, devotion, selflessness and sense of humor will be sorely missed by everyone in her family as well all of her volunteer colleagues throughout the country. There will be a private family service. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Linda Creed Breast Cancer Foundation, P.O. Box 40607 Philadelphia, PA 19107 (http://www.lindacreed.org). Please visit www.fullermetz.com to leave the family a condolence.

CONNAUGHTON--Rev. Msgr. Lawrence M.,who was a priest of the Archdiocese of New York since his ordination in 1970 by then Archbishop Terrance Cardinal Cook at the Cathedral of St. Patrick, died September 29. He was appointed a Prelate of Honor of His Holiness, Reverend Monsignor in August 1990 and at the time of his passing was pastor of St. John Nepomucene Church and administrator of St. John the Martyr Church in Manhattan, where he had served since 2012. He was 70. Born to the late Frank and Elizabeth Connaughton, in West Brighton, Staten Island, NY on April 24, 1944, he attended Sacred Heart Elementary School and St. Peter's High School before St. Joseph's Seminary in Yonkers, NY. For the next 44 years he served in a number of parishes throughout the Archdiocese and also held a number of administrative roles within the Archdiocese of New York during his priesthood. Most notably he was Dean of Students and Procurator to St. Joseph's Seminary (1983-1988), Vice Chancellor and Director of Priest's Personnel (1988-1990) and Executive Director of Development in the early 1990's. He was also a trustee of the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation since 1990. He was predeceased by his sister Maura E. Mannion (Raymond P.) of Suffern, NY and is survived by his siblings John F. (Anne) of Trumbull, CT and Kathleen Cleary (Dennis) of Astoria Queens, NY along with nine nieces and nephews and eleven great nieces and nephews. The family will receive visitors at the Church of St. Joseph in the Yorkville neighborhood of Manhattan (404 East 87th St.) on Wednesday, October 1, 3pm 7pm. The Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Thursday, October 2 at 10am at the Church of St. Joseph with burial to follow at St. Peter's Cemetery in Staten Island. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that memorial gifts be made to Catholic Relief Services (crs.org) PO Box 17090, Baltimore, MD 21297-0303 or Catholic Near East Welfare Association (cnewa.org), 1011 1st Ave, New York, NY 10022-4195.

CARTER--John Mack. The Board of Directors and staff of Susan G. Komen Greater NYC note with sadness the passing of John Mack Carter. John was the visionary co-founder of the Komen NYC Race for the Cure. His legacy endures in the continued success of the Race and the Greater NYC Affiliate of Susan G. Komen, today the largest of the Komen affiliates. We are indebted to his commitment to ending breast cancer.

WRISTON--Kathryn Dineen. The Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center community mourns the loss of Kathryn Dineen Wriston, a gracious and caring friend who inspired us with her deep commitment to causes that enhanced the well-being of others. Having experienced the devastating toll exacted by cancer in the lives of her husband Walter and her brother Laurence, she devoted her remarkable energy to promoting advanced scientific research in areas that pose the greatest challenge, endowing the Walter B. Wriston Chair in Pancreatic Cancer Research and the Laurence Joseph Dineen Chair in Leukemia Research with Special Emphasis on Leukemia in Children and Young People. In this, as in everything she did, Kathryn Wriston combined the vision and intelligence that informed her professional career with an extraordinary sense of compassion, and the work she has made possible at the Center will have a profound and enduring impact. We extend our sincere condolences to her sister, her brother, and all her family. Douglas A. Warner III Chairman, Boards of Overseers and Managers; Craig B. Thompson, M.D. President and CEO

WRISTON--Kathryn. Weill Cornell Medical College mourns its longtime donor and friend, Kathy Wriston, a champion of pancreatic cancer research and medical education. Kathy generously endowed the Walter B. Wriston Professorship of Pancreatic Cancer Research in memory of her beloved husband, Walter. Kathy strongly believed in the importance of educating medical students in geriatric medicine and was dedicated to the Medical Student Training in Aging Research program. We will miss her warm spirit, passion for medicine and knack for asking hard, inspiring questions. Dr. Laurie H. Glimcher, Dean, Weill Cornell Medical College

WRISTON--Kathryn "Kathy" Dineen of New York City, Sherman, CT and Boynton Beach, FL, passed away suddenly on Sunday morning, September 28, 2014, from complications from a fall at Deer Pond Farm, her house in Sherman, CT. Kathy is predeceased by her beloved husband, Walter B. Wriston, former CEO of Citibank, who passed away in 2005. Kathy's greatest joy in life was the time she spent with Walter working on Deer Pond Farm which they planned to have maintained as a nature preserve. Kathy was born in Syracuse, NY, on March 1, 1939, to the late Robert Emmet Dineen and Carolyn Bareham Dineen. She is survived by her loving sister, the Honorable Carolyn Dineen King, of the 5th Circuit United States Court of Appeals, and devoted brother, Robert E. Dineen, Jr. She is predeceased by the cherished brother, Laurence Joseph Dineen, who died of leukemia at age 7 years. She is also survived by Walter's daughter, Catherine "Cassy" Wriston Quintal, her husband, Richard Quintal and their children, Christopher W. Quintal, his wife, Sara, and Barbara Catherine "Katy" Quintal, all of whom she cared for dearly. In addition, she is survived by her brotherin-law, the Honorable Thomas M. Reavley, her sister-in-law, Jeanne C. Olivier, and three nephews, James D., Philip D. and Stephen E. Randall and two grand-nieces. She spent her childhood years in Syracuse and also in Milwaukee, WI. She later attended and graduated from Smith College in 1960 and from the University of Michigan Law School in 1963. In her early career, she practiced law at the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling LLP. Later in her professional career, she served on the corporate boards of Federated Department Stores, Goodyear, Northwestern Mutual, Southern Pacific, Stanley Works, Union Carbide and WR Grace & Co. and on the boards of professional organizations, including the American Arbitration Association and the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. She also served as a trustee of the Financial Accounting Foundation, the Practising Law Institute, Fordham University and the John A. Hartford Foundation. During the last decade of her life, she spent a tremendous amount of her time in support of many charitable causes. As her many friends and family know, her personal and financial support spanned many causes, such as nature conservation, medical research, educational institutions such as the Fletcher School of Tufts University, Syracuse University College of Law and Hobart and William Smith Colleges, and programs to feed the elderly and poor. She was one of the founders of the Matthew 25 Project, an organization established to assist the elderly in Sherman, CT. Calling hours will be from 4pm to 7pm on Friday, October 3, 2014 at the Lillis Funeral Home at 58 Bridge St, New Milford, CT 06776. On Saturday morning, October 4, 2014 at 11am, there will be a Mass of Christian Burial at the Holy Trinity Church at 15 Route 37, Sherman, CT 06784. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the charity of your choice or to the following charities that Kathy supported: Lustgarten Foundation at 1111 Stewart Avenue, Bethpage, New York 11714, an organization whose mission is to advance the scientific and medical research related to the diagnosis, treatment, cure and prevention of pancreatic cancer which claimed the life of her husband; Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center at 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10065; Sherman Library at 1 Sherman Center, P.O. Box 40, Sherman, CT 06784 which she generously supported; or Matthew 25 Project at P.O. Box 361, Sherman, CT 06784, an organization that she founded.
WEITZNER--I. James, MD. We can never thank you for your loving care and devotion to our family for over three generations. Jerry, Bobby, Adriane, Ellen, Barry and Family

WEITZNER--I. James, M.D.,on September 29, 2014. Beloved husband for 73 years to Doris. Devoted father of Renee, John and Emily. Dear grandfather of Amy, Nancy, Sandra, Marlena and Faith. Service Thursday, October 2, 2014, 9:30am at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to Jewish United Fund.

SZAPIRO--Frances Rudow, born February 7, 1918. Beloved wife of late Josiel Szapiro; adored mother of Elinor, Miriam and Laura; and of sons-in-law Bruce, Ray and Terry. Best grandma ever of Manora, Josh and Anna. Remedial reading teacher. Created a home that was welcome hub to all, and all who entered became her family. Vibrant, joyful, irrepressibly optimistic, stoic, sharp-witted, caring, generous. Words fall short. There's no replacing her. Memorial Service at Riverside Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY on Thursday, 11:30am. Shiva following burial until 9:00pm at her home. Donations in her memory may be made to Givat Haviva or American Jewish World Service.
STERLING--Robert L. The Officers and Directors of the New England Society in the City of New York are deeply saddened by the loss of Past President Sterling on September 22, 2014.

SAPIR--Tamir. With profound sadness we note the passing of this builder of our community, creative real estate leader, and dear friend. RINGLER--Rita Dorothy, on October 1, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, loving mother of Rhonda (Anthony) Cutler and Steven (Susan) Ringler. Cherished grandmother of Eric (Amanda), Andrew, Lilah, Jack, and Noah. Graveside services 1:30pm Friday at Mount Ararat Cemetery. Route 109 and Southern State Parkway, Lindenhurst, NY 11757. REIS--Dr. Max Walter. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the passing of Dr. Max Walter Reis, who served as the President of the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology from 1986 through 1990. He was also a member of the Technion International Board of Governors and a vice chairman from 1984 through 1986. A leader in Israeli industry, science and technology, Dr. Reis was a director at Oridion Systems Ltd., and at B. Gaon Holdings Ltd., and a member of the Advisory Board of Catalyst Investments L.P. Prior to his presidency, he served as senior vice president of Israel Chemicals Ltd., board member of Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, chairman of PAMA, and chairman of Israel Desalination Industries. To Dr. Reis' family, we extend our deepest sympathies. American Technion Society Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Jeff Richard, Executive Vice President Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Emeritus

MURRY--Patricia Ann (nee Brown). With great sadness we announce the peaceful passing of Patricia. Born January 20, 1929 in New York, New York, she passed away on Tuesday, September 30, 2014 in her 85th year. Beloved wife for 51 years of Paul Murray, and much loved mother of Timothy (Kimberly Curran), Carolyn and Patrick (Janis Fryer). Proud grandmother of Meghan and Aden Murray and Emma and Clare Murray. She was affectionately known as Grandmere by her grandchildren. Pat was predeceased by her parents, John Carney Brown and Dorothy Lehane Brown, her sister Jane Farrelly, brother-in-law Edmund Farrelly and her brother Dr. William T. Brown. She will be sadly missed by her sister-in-law Arline Brown, many nieces and nephews and dear friends (Eta Cooper). Online condolences may be made at www.turnerporter.ca.

HANNUM--Susan W.,age 72, of Lancaster, PA, died on Wednesday, October 1, 2014, peacefully of natural causes, at The Glen at Willow Valley, in Lancaster, PA. Born in New York, NY, she was the daughter of Mrs. Charlotte D. White, formerly of Hobe Sound, FL, and Siasconset, MA; and Mr. Woodward W. White, formerly of Baltimore, MD. Susan was a loving and devoted wife to William E. Hannum II since their marriage in Rome, NY, on June 9, 1962, until he passed on February 15, 2013. In their 51 years together, Susan and Bill lived in Lewiston, ME, Falmouth, ME, Alexandria, VA, and Charlottesville, VA. Susan was a loving, devoted mother and grandmother, as well. And she will be remembered for the spirit and laughter she brought to the communities she embraced, from St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Falmouth to St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Ivy, VA. Susan is survived by her daughter Kirke H. Lisk and her husband Steve of Lancaster, PA; her son, William E. Hannum III and his wife Sara of North Andover, MA; and her grandchildren Catherine H. Hannum, Elinor W. Hannum, Charlotte D. Hannum, Fisher B. Lisk, and William E. Lisk. A memorial service will be held on Nantucket, MA, at an as yet undetermined date. The interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that memorial contributions be made to American Diabetes Association, www.diabetes.org, or the Alzheimer's Association, www.alz.org. Friends may send condolences to the family at www.thegroffs.com. Online condolences may be posted on our Web site: www.thegroffs.com. The Groffs Family Funeral & Cremation Services, Inc., 528 West Orange Street, Lancaster, PA 17603 717-394-5300.

EISENBERG--Joanne. Jo, you have been my best friend and the sister I never had. You will live in my heart and I will love you forever. To Sid, Jolie, Denise, Gary, Jason, Max and Tyler, you were her life and love of life. Edie

CONNAUGHTON--Rev. Msgr. Lawrence M.,who was a priest of the Archdiocese of New York since his ordination in 1970 by then Archbishop Terrance Cardinal Cook at the Cathedral of St. Patrick, died September 29. He was appointed a Prelate of Honor of His Holiness, Reverend Monsignor in August 1990 and at the time of his passing was pastor of St. John Nepomucene Church and administrator of St. John the Martyr Church in Manhattan, where he had served since 2012. He was 70. Born to the late Frank and Elizabeth Connaughton, in West Brighton, Staten Island, NY on April 24, 1944, he attended Sacred Heart Elementary School and St. Peter's High School before St. Joseph's Seminary in Yonkers, NY. For the next 44 years he served in a number of parishes throughout the Archdiocese and also held a number of administrative roles within the Archdiocese of New York during his priesthood. Most notably he was Dean of Students and Procurator to St. Joseph's Seminary (1983-1988), Vice Chancellor and Director of Priest's Personnel (1988-1990) and Executive Director of Development in the early 1990's. He was also a trustee of the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation since 1990. He was predeceased by his sister Maura E. Mannion (Raymond P.) of Suffern, NY and is survived by his siblings John F. (Anne) of Trumbull, CT and Kathleen Cleary (Dennis) of Astoria Queens, NY along with nine nieces and nephews and eleven great nieces and nephews. The family will receive visitors at the Church of St. Joseph in the Yorkville neighborhood of Manhattan (404 East 87th St.) on Wednesday, October 1, 3pm 7pm. The Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Thursday, October 2 at 10am at the Church of St. Joseph with burial to follow at St. Peter's Cemetery in Staten Island. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that memorial gifts be made to Catholic Relief Services (crs.org) PO Box 17090, Baltimore, MD 21297-0303 or Catholic Near East Welfare Association (cnewa.org), 1011 1st Ave, New York, NY 10022-4195.

CHAPIN--Donald H.,85, of Rye, NY and Nantucket, MA, formerly of Larchmont, NY, Washington D.C. and Naples, FL, died on September 30, 2014. Loving husband for 63 years of Barbara; cherished father of Patricia O'Donnell (Chas), Stephen Chapin (Deborah), Susan Lenane (Brian), Andrea Crowley (Ed), Thomas Chapin (Betsy) and Daniel Chapin. Adored and adoring grandfather of 13 and great-grandfather of five. A CPA who graduated from Williams College and Wharton School of Business, Don had a long career as a partner at Arthur Young & Co. in its offices in New York and Stamford, CT and as its managing partner in Europe. Strongly committed to public service, he was President of the Mamaroneck School Board. In his second career he served at the General Accounting Office as the Chief Accountant and Assistant Comptroller General. Don loved Nantucket, football, Greek philosophy, ice cream, swimming in the ocean, classic movies, blueberry pancakes, good books and more than anything else, his family. In his memory, they ask that those who knew him dip their toes in the ocean, pet a dog, laugh at a good joke, enjoy friends and family and make a contribution to the charity of their choice.

BROWN--Peter Megargee. The Trustees of the Riot Relief Fund are deeply saddened by the death of our good friend and distinguished colleague. Peter served the Fund for over half a century as Trustee, President, Chairman and Trustee Emeritus in the support of New York City Police Officers, Firefighters and their families. His capacity for friendship was boundless and we will miss his wise counsel. Howard W. Burns, Jr. Esq., Pres. and Trustee, Douglas S. Bell, Sec. and Trustee, Walter L. Stratton, Esq., Treas. and Trustee, Trustees: J. Peter Coll, Jr., Esq. Robert B. Fiske, Jr., Esq., Lawrence S. Huntington, Christopher B. Huntington, Henry J. Kennedy, Esq., William M. Manger, Jr., Thomas F. Munno, Esq., The Reverend Dr. Thomas F. Pike, Ms. Kate Scheuring Quinn, Andrew E. Roosevelt, Samuel W. Seymour, Esq., Daniel K. Wiig, Esq.

ASCHENDORF--Gladys. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Gladys Aschendorf, beloved wife of the late Jack Aschendorf. Gladys leaves behind a loving family who will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. Our heartfelt condolences go out to Gladys's beloved children, Ellen (Robert Shasha), Kenneth (Wilma), and Steven; her grandchildren; and entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

ANAGNOS--Zographia "Jo," nee Gabriel, of Ft Lee, NJ. and Halcott Center, NY, died peacefully at her home on September 30. Jo was born March 26, 1930 in Scranton, PA and raised in New York City. She was a loving wife, mother and grandmother. She is survived by her husband of 60 years, Alexander, her children George (Melanie), Maria Pierce (Bob) and Steve (Vicky). Jo was a beloved grandmother to Alexandra, Steven, Johnny, Michael, Tommy, Christine, Alexander and Arianna. She is also survived by her brother, George. She is predeceased by her parents, Efstratios and Maria and by her sister, Athena Amaro. Jo was a talented artist, loved classic movies, the music of Frank Sinatra and spending time in Halcott Center. Jo touched the lives of many with her smile, grace, generous spirit and optimism. Visitation will be Thursday, October 2 from 5-9pm at A.K. Macagna Funeral Home, 495 Anderson Ave, Cliffside Park, NJ 07010. Funeral Services will be held at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church, 10 Mill Rd., New Rochelle, NY, Friday, October 3, at 11am. Donations may be made to the Greek Division of the Ronald McDonald House, 405 E 73 St, New York City, 10021.
