ZANDER--Lester P.,on October 1, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Loving father of Gary and Robin, Ronald and Ellen, Stuart and Lauren. Cherished grandfather of Brian and Jeremy, Matthew and Stacey, Max and Benjamin. Devoted brother of Sylvia and Bernie Leibel. Services 12 Noon Sunday at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

SILVERMAN--Cara on September 22, 2014. Beloved daughter of Marilyn and the late Dr. Frederick Silverman, cherished sister and sister-in-law of Marjorie and David Ridl, Frank and the late Ellen Scanga. Dear aunt to Edward Ridl, Daniel and Christopher Scanga. Service Sunday, October 5, 2014, 11am at Knollwood Park Cemetery.

SABET--Iraj, 83, on September 8, 2014, in Vancouver, Canada. Founder of Pepsi and Television of Iran. Philanthropist, humanitarian, member of The Baha'i World Faith. Graduate of Horace Mann, Wharton and Harvard. Survived by Hormoz, Rosemarie, Nika, Sina, Tina, Taj, Reja, Aram, Karim, Serena, Nicholas, Andre, Aryavash, Yasmeen and Habib. Donations to: www.tahirih.org Condolences to gulfny@aol.com

ROOB--Rona. The Board and staff of the Archives of American Art mourn the loss of longtime Trustee and friend Rona Roob and send our deep sympathy to her daughters, Nancy Roob and Helen Jerome, and their families.

RINGLER--Rita Dorothy, on October 1, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, loving mother of Rhonda (Anthony) Cutler and Steven (Susan) Ringler. Cherished grandmother of Eric (Amanda), Andrew, Lilah, Jack, and Noah. Graveside services 1:30pm Friday at Mount Ararat Cemetery. Route 109 and Southern State Parkway, Lindenhurst, NY 11757. For information contact Riverside Nassau North Chapels, (516) 487-9600.

HOWARD--Mildred, 96, died September 27, 2014 in Shelburne, VT. Loving mother of Laurence Howard (Crystal); Willa Kravitz; grandchildren: Dana Freeman (Andy), Vanessa Violette (Lance), David Kravitz, Heather Doyle (Matt); and great grandchildren: Flynn, Callahan, Xavier, Oscar, Isadore, Hannah, Joshua. At the age of 60 Mildred graduated sum cum laude from Queens College. A career woman, retiring at age 84 and world traveler, she shared her love of travel with the entire family. She was a dedicated health care professional, serving as Administrator of the Department of Pathology and Laboratory Medicine at City Hospital Center, Elmhurst, New York; Administrator of the Radiology Department, Mt. Sinai Hospital; Administrator of the Department of Medicine at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY; an integral part of the Nephrology Department at the University of Miami School of Medicine and the University of California in Los Angeles. Mildred served on the Board of the Godwin Ternbach Museum at Queens College (a museum established by her sister and brother-in-law, Anna and Joseph Ternbach). Contributions in her memory may be sent to the Godwin Ternbach Museum, Queens College, 65-30 Kissena Blvd., 405 Klapper Hall, Flushing, NY 11367 or a charity of the donor's choice.

GOTTSCHO--Oscar A.,83, died on September 23 in Bernardsville, NJ. Born in Munich, Germany, he came in 1938 to the United States, where his family settled in Washington, DC. He attended Sidwell Friends School in Washington, DC, Harvard College, and the University of Virginia School of Law. Between college and law school, he was commissioned an officer in the U.S. Army and served in Germany as commander of a battalion responsible for a 280 mm gun. After clerking for the U.S. Tax Court, he embarked on a legal career focused on U.S. tax law, particularly its international aspects. At one time, he served in the U.S. Department of the Treasury, and for many years he was tax counsel at Bankers Trust. He was also a passionate environmentalist, serving as trustee of the Association for the Protection of the Adirondacks and the Upper Raritan Watershed Association. He derived great pleasure from putting one foot in the front of the other on mountain trails, especially in the High Peaks of the Adirondacks and the Presidential Range of New Hampshire's White Mountains. He was a member of the Ausable Club, the Harvard Club of New York City, the Lake Club, the Metropolitan Club of the City of Washington, and the Somerset Hills Country Club. He was married to Margaret Farrelly of Mendham, NJ, who predeceased him. He leaves four children, Christopher, of Washington, DC, Mathilde, of New York, NY, and Jonathan and Nicholas, of Bernardsville, NJ, and a sister, Marie Taylor Groenweghe, of St. Louis, MO. A funeral service will be held Saturday, October 4, at 11am at the Church of St. John on the Mountain in Bernardsville, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to the Gottscho Environmental Stewardship Fund, Sidwell Friends School, 3825 Wisconsin Ave, NW, Washington, DC 20016.

GANSBERG--Selma, Age 92, passed away peacefully on October 1, 2014. Born on August 27, 1922 in the Bronx, NY to Hyman and Rebecca W. Beloved wife of the late Seymour, they were married on August 27, 1944. She was a fashion model during the 1940's and worked for 30 years in sales for Saks Fifth Avenue in Garden City, L.I. and Palm Springs, CA. Seymour served proudly during World War II as a navigator in the United States Air Force. Selma and Cy raised their children in Merrick, Long Island and lived their dream in Palm Springs for 32 years. They remained married for more than 69 years until Seymour's passing on December 26, 2013. Selma is survived by her loving children, Jeffrey (Julianne) and Andrew (Anne Marie); four grandchildren, Brad (Leigh), Tara Vogel (David), Amy DaRosa (Eric) and Michael (Liz), step-granddaughters Erin and Jessie; and three great grandchildren, Jessie Vogel, Riley Vogel and Sydney Gansberg. Please send donations to: MJHS Hospice, 39 Broadway, Suite 200, New York, NY 10006. Memorial services will be held on Tuesday, October 7th at 11:00am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY 10024.

DAY--Donald. The Union for Reform Judaism and the World Union for Progressive Judaism mourn with profound sorrow the passing of Don Day, of Buffalo, NY, chairman of the URJ board of trustees from 1979 to 1983 and chairman of the WUPJ board of trustees from 1988 to 1995, as well as an extraordinary Reform Movement leader for more than four decades. We extend deepest condolences to his wife Edythe (Edy) and their children and grandchildren. May his memory be for a blessing. Stephen Sacks, Chairman, URJ Rabbi Rick Jacobs, President, URJ Michael Grabiner, Chairman, WUPJ Rabbi Daniel H. Freelander, President, WUPJ

CHAPIN--Donald H.,85, of Rye, NY and Nantucket, MA, formerly of Larchmont, NY, Washington D.C. and Naples, FL, died on September 30, 2014. Loving husband for 63 years of Barbara; cherished father of Patricia O'Donnell (Chas), Stephen Chapin (Deborah), Susan Lenane (Brian), Andrea Crowley (Ed), Thomas Chapin (Betsy) and Daniel Chapin. Adored and adoring grandfather of 13 and great-grandfather of five. A CPA who graduated from Williams College and Wharton School of Business, Don had a long career as a partner at Arthur Young & Co. in its offices in New York and Stamford, CT and as its managing partner in Europe. Strongly committed to public service, he was President of the Mamaroneck School Board. In his second career he served at the General Accounting Office as the Chief Accountant and Assistant Comptroller General. Don loved Nantucket, football, Greek philosophy, ice cream, swimming in the ocean, classic movies, blueberry pancakes, good books and more than anything else, his family. In his memory, they ask that those who knew him dip their toes in the ocean, pet a dog, laugh at a good joke, enjoy friends and family and make a contribution to the charity of their choice.

BORELLO--Joseph, age 92. Joe, or Uncle Joe to his family, brought kindness, joy and intelligence to everyone who knew him. Many did not know of his proud service in the U.S. Navy during WWII, or his impressive doctoral and post-doctoral degrees. Despite the demands of his psychologist career, Joe was a true renaissance man, with strong interests in archeology, music, literature and fine food. Those who were blessed to be family, friend or running companion remember Joe as a man who always saw the glass as half full. We miss him dearly.

BITTMAN--Robert, Professor of Chemistry and Biochemistry at City University and Queens College, passed away on October 1 after a long battle with cancer. He is survived by his wife Marlene, children Mark and Lana Bittman, sister Judy Boston and her husband George, brother Eric and his wife Sandy Sulsky, step-son Scott Aronson, step-daughter Lauren Aronson and her husband Rob Hendin, grand-children Matthew and Sarah Hendin and nieces Rachel and Sarah Bittman. Services will be held on Sunday, October 5th at 12 Noon at Temple Sinai of Roslyn, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights.

MILNE--Jeanne Hoenig. 1 yr. ago at home on 10/1/13/. B. NYC 1/30/30. Barnard School. Grad. 1954 - Bryn Mawr University. M. 1959, Robert D. Milne (D.1970). Survived by children Douglas P. and Victoria A.L. Advocate for hearing impaired, Travel Agent, Jewelry Designer, avid traveler, beloved wife and Mother. We miss you Mom.
MARROW--Adele. In loving memory of Adele Jane Marrow, 30 years ago today.

STEADMAN--Richard, our beloved son, brother, uncle, nephew and great-uncle left this earth on September 29, 2014. Richard was born on April 21, 1948 in Oklahoma City to Harold and Jean Steadman. Richard is survived by his father, his sister and brother-in-law, Nancy and Harold Rodgers, his brother Dr. Sid Steadman; many nieces and nephews; a large extended family and many friends. Richard graduated from Harvard University in 1971 and spent a number of years in the publishing and advertising business in New York. He returned to Texas in 1980 and went to work for AT&T and spent 33 years as a senior manager.

PEARLMAN--Leonard D.,Born December 7, 1919, son of Albert and Ida Pearlman passed away peacefully in his own home on October 3rd. Leonard lived a colorful and spirited life of 94 years. Throughout his life he engaged in various professional activities including working in the family painting business, real estate development and private investing. He was an avid skier, tennis player, swimmer and storyteller who took pride in repeating his jokes. Leonard was a very loving and devoted father, brother, uncle, grandfather and friend. Leonard is survived by his brother, Herbert, his sister, Doris, his children, Manny, Andrew, Janie, his son-in-law Mark, and his grandchildren Emily, Zachary, Jacob, Joshua and Jordan. There will be a private family graveside service on Sunday October 5. The family will be sitting Shiva on Monday from 2.00pm to 8.00pm, and Tuesday from 4:00pm to 8:00pm at the home of Manny Pearlman, 350 East 79th Street, as well as on Tuesday from 2:00pm-8:00pm at the home of Janie and Mark Pollack, 239 Barton Avenue, Melville, New York 11747.

MELCHNER--Susan. To a woman who fought her cancer with a vengeance. Our heartfelt sympathy to Richard, Brenda, Leanne and Chuck, Jason, Gordon and Andie, Breena, Guy. To my courageous friend of 54 years, rest in peace. Leslie and Bernie

MELCHNER--Susan Kaye, 73, daughter of Dr. Martin and Ruth Kaye passed away peacefully in her NYC home October 3. She is survived by her husband of 51 years Richard, children Leanne Rettig and husband Charles, Jason, and Gordon and wife Andrea, sister Brenda Pace and adored grandchildren Breena and Guy. Susan was a high-school Spanish teacher, successful real estate broker and avid bridge player. She loved life and lived every single day to the fullest. Donations in Susan's memory may be made to The Lustgarten Foundation and/or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Funeral on Sunday, October 5, 1pm, Plaza Funeral Home, 630 Amsterdam Avenue.

LIEBERMAN--Richard. October 5, 2014. Husband of Barbara. Beloved father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Funeral service October 5, 2014 at Congregation Emanu-El, 2125 Westchester Avenue E, Rye, NY. Donations: Connecticut Children's Medical Center.

KREIGER--Michael, beloved husband of Shelley Green Kreiger, adored father of Rachel (Rich) Albert, Sarah (Marc) Damelin, Deborah (Adam) Rosenzweig and the late Adam Kreiger: Fun-loving grandfather of Aviva, Micha, Naomi, Leah and Hal. We send our love and hugs to all our cousins. The Schefler, Spiera, Taitz and Silver cousins.

GLICKMAN--Ralph. Beloved husband of Joan. Adored father of Rachel, Diane and Sam Yellis and Sarah and Steven Greenstein. Cherished grandfather of Barbara, David, Rebecca, Brenner and Sophie. Most valued friend to so many. We are heart broken, but we know...Love gives more than death can take away. Services Sunday 11am at the Jericho Jewish Center 430 North Broadway Jericho L.I.

FRIED--David, On October 2nd. Son of the late Solomon and Estelle Fried. Beloved husband of Ruth. Father of Esther Ana Rosa and husband Keith Robinson, Jessica and Rebecca Fried. Brother of Richard Fried and wife Beth. Grandfather of Bethany, Marcus, Ana, Ella, Caleb and the late Leah. Loving nephew, uncle, cousin and friend to scores. Service: Sunday, October 5, 11am, Riverdale Temple, Bronx, NY. Donations: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

Carbonell--Evelyn (Porges), 90, of Coconut Grove, FL and New Canaan, CT died September 21, 2014. Born July 10, 1924 in NYC, Evy had a passion for languages and earned degrees from City College of New York. She mastered French and Spanish and was conversant in her parents' native Hungarian. Evy worked as a speech specialist at Ohio University and at Purdue, where she met her husband of 62 years, the late Dr. Robert J. Carbonell. They settled in Stamford, CT where they raised five children and Evy taught ESL and foreign languages. They ultimately retired to Florida and spent recent summers in Connecticut near their family. Evy was predeceased by her husband and is survived by her children and their spouses: Armando (Jean), Robert (Patricia), Margaret (Greg), John (Cheryl), and Julie (Bo); grandmother of sixteen and great-grandmother of three. The loss of Evy's beautiful spirit leaves a void in the hearts of those whose lives she touched. A memorial service was held in New Canaan. Donations may be sent to STAR, Inc., www.starct.org

BELTZER--Herman, age 87, passed away on October 3, 2014. Born in Manhattan and raised there and in Watervliet, NY, he was a longtime resident of Brooklyn and more recently of Hartsdale. He enlisted and proudly served in the US Navy during World War II. A trained attorney, he spent his distinguished career as a senior financial executive at Revlon Corporation, United Brands Corporation and Milstein Properties Corporation. Devoted son of the late Carl and Rose, adoring husband of over 60 years to Cynthia, beloved father of Howard and Alison, and cherished grandfather of Clifford and Miranda. He was a unique combination of strength and determination on the one hand, but also of profound kindness, sweetness and decency on the other. He was a towering figure in the lives of all he touched, and will be deeply missed. Funeral services on Sunday, October 5 at 2pm at Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, 295 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY.

APPLEBAUM--Miles Benjamin, Age 21, on October 2, 2014. Beloved son of Shari and Edward, devoted brother to Max and Hannah. Grandson of Sandra and Stanley Applebaum and Irene Fried. A well liked resident of Armonk, graduate of Byram Hills High School, varsity cross country and track runner, and junior at Temple University, Boyer College of Music and Dance. Miles was a talented guitarist with a passion for music, nature, and all living creatures. He struck a deep chord in all of us. His was a most untimely passing. Miles will be deeply missed by his family and all those who's lives that he touched. Services will be Sunday, October 5, 2014, 11:30am at Congregation B'nai Yisrael, 2 Banksville Road, Armonk, NY. Donations in his memory can be made to The Lagond Music School NAMI Spring Lake Ranch.

WRISTON--Kathryn. The Women's Forum of New York records with sorrow the death of our longtime member Kathryn Wriston, an attorney and director of corporate and non-profit boards. Deepest sympathy is extended to her family. Ami Kaplan, President Rita B. Crotty, Executive Director

WISE--Cynthia, 69, died suddenly on Friday, September 26 in New York City, with her sister Barbara and niece Francesca at her side. After earning a B.A. at Connecticut College for Women and a M.A. at Northwestern University, Cynthia began her distinguished career at the African-American Institute, where she directed student and high-level educational programs for French-speaking African countries. She then lived in the Ivory Coast and Mauritania, where she directed various economic development programs. She later had a second career as a legal assistant and worked for many years at Kleinberg, Kaplan, Wolff & Cohen, P.C. where she was employed at the time of her death. Beloved for her quick humor, keen intelligence and kindness, Cynthia had a deep curiosity for other cultures and customs coupled with a love of travel and adventure. An avid lover of the arts, she was an officer of the Snarks Amateur Theater Company and thoroughly took full advantage of the cultural and culinary riches of New York. She will be deeply missed by her sister Barbara Wise, brother-in-law Robert Wilson, her daughter Helena Cullinan, granddaughters Olive and Minnie, her nieces Cristina Ciarrocchi and Francesca Ciarrocchi, and her many friends. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, October 7th at 3pm, at the Marble Collegiate Church, 29th Street and Fifth Avenue, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research or Bide-a-Wee Pet Welfare Organization.

WILLINGHAM--Helene Rothenberg, 94, passed away on September 23rd. Born in Brooklyn, she graduated from Barnard College in 1941 and worked for the OWI during World War II. She retired from a career in New York City Government in 1987. She was a wonderful cook, who loved to travel and a powerful influence on those that loved her or knew her well. Her grandchildren, Brian, Andy and Elizabeth and her son, Tom, survive her.

WIEST--Ellen. A native New Yorker deeply loved and cherished passed away on October 1, 2014 in Santa Monica, California. She is survived by her husband Gil, sons Edward (wife Andrea), Philip, Mitchell, and grandchildren Henry, Alice, and May. Ellen was a faculty art teacher at The McBurney Westside School as well an accomplished award winning potter. Ellen's work as an artist and teacher was marked by the importance of stretching finding new solutions - in a word growth. This had been the underlying criteria for herself and her students. Ellen also taught at the United Nations International School where she was an open and friendly person whose enthusiasm spilled over into the staff room. She was a fountain of creative ideas in many media and presented the children with exciting and exacting tasks. As an informed, intelligent, energetic sensitive person, Ellen's concerns for her students went beyond the studio and into their life as people in a community. Ellen was a highly competent studio manager and expert in the knowledge of school studio technology and safety. She was an ingenious problem solver in the sometimes tricky area of ceramics. Her contacts in the city's ceramics community were invaluable. She will be sorely missed by all who knew her and crossed her path.

WEISSMAN--Esther Brakarsh, of Riverdale NY. February 26, 1925 to September 22, 2014. She was loved by all who knew her and will be missed by her family: sons, Keith, Abby and Matthew; daughter-in-law Kristen Benson; grandchildren Roxanne, Greg and Raphael; and the entire Brakarsh family: Jack and Sylvia; Daniel, Diane and Hannah; and Jonathan, Barbara and Sam

WALLING--Mary Alice, 72, passed away on September 26 at Mount Sinai Hospital after suffering a brain aneurism. Mary lived an extraordinary life which took her through several careers and locations. She grew up in Millburn, NJ and graduated from Millburn High school. She graduated from Manhattanville College in Purchase, NY and moved to Manhattan in the mid 1960's. She worked in book publishing, spent a year in Munich, Germany and returned to New York City to pursue opportunities as a dancer on Broadway. This included a road tour with The National Touring Company production of "Coco" with Katherine Hepburn as well as stints in The Bahamas and Puerto Rico. Following her dancing career she earned her MBA from Columbia Business School in 1978. She was employed by CBS for a period before taking a position as Corporate Treasurer with Sotheby's where she worked for many years in New York City and London. Later she became the Chief Operating Officer of the Jewish Museum in New York City and retired in 2011. At the time of her death she was working part time with the Electronic Arts Intermix, a nonprofit arts organization. Mary had a broad range of interests including travel, sports, theater and international affairs. She was an avid skier and tennis player. Mary was predeceased by her parents Alfred and Alice Walling of Millburn, New Jersey and by her brother John Walling of Muskegon, Michigan. She is survived by her brother Michael Walling of Kansas City, Missouri, her nieces Martha Ellinwood of Westport, Connecticut, Amy Engel of San Diego, California and her nephew Mark Walling of Kansas City, Missouri. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held at The Greenwich Village Funeral Home in New York City on November 1st at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to 350.org, The North Shore Animal League or Career Transition for Dancers.
WALKER--James W. June 24, 1941 September 28, 2014. An all-around wonderful guy. He will be missed terribly. Donations to the San Diego Food Bank. Harriet and Michael

SULLIVAN--John William. John "Jack" William Sullivan, 95, passed away peacefully at his home in Wilbraham, Massachusetts on September 23, 2014 with family and loved ones by his side after a brave fight against cancer. He was born in Johnson City, New York, in 1919 and was a star athlete at Johnson City High School before attending Colgate University, where he received a B.A. Summa Cum Laude and an M.A. in English. He loved Colgate and was proud to have played on the baseball team and the football team with Andy Rooney; he was captain of a strong basketball team that featured All American Ernie Vandeweghe. He was the last surviving member of the 1943 Phi Gamma Delta pledge class. As was true for many of his classmates, his time at Colgate was interrupted by service in the U.S. Army during World War II. He was in the Pacific and European theatres and was a Captain and Operatives Officer of the 52nd AAA Brigade in Europe. Following his graduation from Colgate, he was a high school teacher and coach before he entered the Federal Bureau of Investigation, where he served as a Special Agent for almost 30 years. He was predeceased by his wife Claire Welch and four brothers and sisters. He is survived by his son John (Jay) William Jr., his daughter-in-law Jane Hemenway Sullivan, and two grandchildren, Elizabeth Caroline and John William III, all of New York City. He was a loving grandfather, engaging storyteller, lover of poetry and dear neighbor and friend. We will miss him dearly. Memorial contributions may be made to Colgate University, 13 Oak Drive, Hamilton, New York 13346.

STREAR--Sheryl, of Manhattan and Monroe Township, NJ, passed away on September 25, 2014. Born and raised in the Lower Eastside, she attended Seward Park High School, where she was a New York State Regents Scholarship winner, and CCNY receiving her BA and MA degrees. Fluent in Yiddish and German, it allowed her to communicate with family members who escaped Hitler. She had an unbelievable command of the spoken and written English language and was admired for her knowledge of political, historical, social, financial and literature based topics. Her teaching career began at JHS71M and Seward Park High School prior to joining Tottenville High School. She was also the Assistant Director of three (NYC) Board of Education supervisory programs, "Teacher to Assistant Principal," "Principal as Curriculum Leader" and "The High School Principals Center of the New York Alliance for The Public Schools." A thirty year survivor of head and neck cancer, she volunteered for twenty years at Sloan-Kettering. A member of MENSA, life member of "The Society of Sloan-Kettering," AMIT, UFT, SPOHC as well as numerous other organizations. She leaves behind her devoted husband of fifty-four years, Mitchell; daughter, Margot (Darryl Grayson): son Andrew (Joan), and grandchildren Eric, Brittany and Julie.

STAFFIN--H. Kenneth, PhD Chemical Engineer, Professor, semi-retired Founder and CEO of Procedyne Corp., died suddenly, but peacefully September 30, 2014. He was 85 years old. His family, friends and colleagues worldwide will miss the influence of his calm demeanor in problem solving, creativity, quest for knowledge, and optimism. His professional accomplishments, his carpentry skills, love of boating, love of people and life, led to an extraordinary lifetime. He will continue to be an inspiration for his loving wife of 62 years, children, grandchildren, great grandchild and to many of those who knew him. Donations in his memory can be made to the Perlmutter Cancer Center.

SILVERMAN--Cara on September 22, 2014. Beloved daughter of Marilyn and the late Dr. Frederick Silverman, cherished sister and sister-in-law of Marjorie and David Ridl, Frank and the late Ellen Scanga. Dear aunt to Edward Ridl, Daniel and Christopher Scanga. Service Sunday, October 5, 2014, 11am at Knollwood Park Cemetery.

SHERRID--Gillian, 96, passed away peacefully at her home in Manhattan on September 26. Born Goldie Shameson in Shargorod, Ukraine, Gill came to the U.S. as a small child and her story is part of the Ellis Island Oral History Project. She was an assistant principal in the New York City public schools. Endowed with a marvelous curiosity, intelligence and will, she was President of the Metropolitan Branch of the Womens' League for Conservative Judaism, a member of its national board, and its representative as an NGO at the UN. She was also president of the sisterhood of Sutton Place Synagogue, where she was the first adult woman to become bat mitzvah. She is predeceased by her beloved husband Samuel and her two sisters, Mollye and Faye. She is survived and mourned by her daughter Pamela, her son Mark, and her daughter-in-law Beverley, as well as her grandchildren Molly, Gregory, Eloise, and Lucie.

SCHLESINGER--Ethel, passed away on October 2, 2014 at 82 years. Dear sister of the late Murry (Beverly), beloved aunt of Diana (Rob) and Matthew (Leah). A memorial gathering will be held at her home on October 18 from 1pm to 5pm.

ROOB--Rona. The Board and staff of the Archives of American Art mourn the loss of longtime Trustee and friend Rona Roob and send our deep sympathy to her daughters, Nancy Roob and Helen Jerome, and their families.

PEARLMAN--Leonard D.,Born December 7, 1919, son of Albert and Ida Pearlman passed away peacefully in his own home on October 3rd. Leonard lived a colorful and spirited life of 94 years. Throughout his life he engaged in various professional activities including working in the family painting business, real estate development and private investing. He was an avid skier, tennis player, swimmer and storyteller who took pride in repeating his jokes. Leonard was a very loving and devoted father, brother, uncle, grandfather and friend. Leonard is survived by his brother, Herbert, his sister, Doris, his children, Manny, Andrew, Janie, his son-in-law Mark, and his grandchildren Emily, Zachary, Jacob, Joshua and Jordan. There will be a private family graveside service on Sunday October 5. The family will be sitting Shiva on Monday from 2.00pm to 8.00pm, and Tuesday from 4:00pm to 8:00pm at the home of Manny Pearlman, 350 East 79th Street, as well as on Tuesday from 2:00pm-8:00pm at the home of Janie and Mark Pollack, 239 Barton Avenue, Melville, New York 11747.

PEARLMAN--Kenneth D.,84, of NYC. Much beloved husband of Sara Levin Pearlman, passed away September 26, 2014, at Calvary Hospital. A private funeral was held September 29th at Sharon Gardens Cemetery. OSTWALD--Laura. Died at age 86 on September 22, 2014. Born in Germany, she fled to the United States in 1940 in order to escape Nazi persecution. MELCHNER--Susan Kaye, 73, daughter of Dr. Martin and Ruth Kaye passed away peacefully in her NYC home October 3. HOTCHKISS--Jane Ellsworth, June 23, 1932 - September 26, 2014. Born in New York City, Jane Ellsworth Hotchkiss, a resident of Hobe Sound, FL and longtime resident of Bernardsville, NJ and Fishers Island, NY, died on Friday, September 26th at her daughter's home in Lakeville, CT. In addition to her husband of 59 years, Winchester Fitch Hotchkiss, she is survived by their three children, Winch- ester Fitch Hotchkiss, Jr., Leslie Hotchkiss Arndt and Mary Hotchkiss Harvey. Her seven beloved grandchildren include Leslie W. Hotchkiss, Winchester F. Hotchkiss, III, Ashton H. Harvey, Alexander S. Harvey, Duncan M. Harvey, Sarah E. Arndt and Hannah R. Arndt. Mrs. Hotchkiss attended the Chapin School, Foxcroft School and Smith College. As a noted miniaturist with the late Kathleen Pitney, she created prize winning dioramas at shows in New York and Philadelphia. Funeral services will be Thursday, October 9th at St. John's Church in Salisbury, CT at 11:30am. A private burial will be on Fishers Island, NY at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Ellsworth Memorial Health Center, PO Box 2003, Springfield, VT 05156.

GOLDSTEIN--Malcolm, 89, died in Manhattan on September 27 after a long illness. Born in Huntington, WV, son of Jack A. and Lydia Cohen Goldstein, he attended Governor Dummer Academy in Byfield, MA and graduated in 1949 from Princeton, interrupting his studies to serve in World War II. After earning a PhD in English literature at Columbia University, Dr. Goldstein taught at Stanford University before joining the English Department at Queens College, CUNY, where he taught until his retirement in 1991. Dr. Goldstein specialized in 20th-century American theater and wrote several acclaimed books: "The Art of Thornton Wilder, The Political Stage: American Drama and Theater of the Great Depression," and "George S. Kaufman: His Life, His Theater," a biography a New York Times reviewer called "an admirable accomplishment." Dr. Goldstein's other passion was art. His sharp and judicious eye enabled him to amass on a limited budget an impressive collection of contemporary drawings and prints that included works by Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, Claes Oldenberg, Sherrie Levine, Susan Rothenberg and Chuck Close. A devoted member of the Century Association, he also collected and on one occasion exhibited prints by members of the club. His final book, appropriately, was "Landscape with Figures: A History of Art Dealing in the United States." Although Dr. Goldstein leaves no survivors, his friends will always remember the generosity with which he shared his extensive knowledge, his steadfast interest in their lives and offspring, his infectious good humor and, most of all, his unfailing kindness.

GELLER GERSHMAN-- Bonnie, 68, passed away Sunday with her family at her side. She was a resident of Ridgefield, CT. Bonnie was Vice President Marketing at Conde Nast and Executive Vice President Marketing at Woman's Day before becoming a leading nutritional consultant when she created Personal Management Group, with offices in Connecticut and New York, and clients worldwide. Bonnie loved dance, music, entertaining, riding horses, pilates, interior design, and creating beautiful gardens. She was the loving wife of Laurence Gershman, beloved daughter of Marilyn Sussman of Del Rey Beach, FL, devoted stepmother of Jon Gershman (Andrea Gershman), Amy Singer (Joseph Singer), adored grandmother ("GB") of Sienna and Jacob Singer, and the dearly loved sister of Jacalyn Roberts, Michelle Roberts, Craig Roberts (Patricia). In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Cancer Treatment and Wellness Center, Northern Westchester Hospital.

GANSBERG--Selma, Age 92, passed away peacefully on October 1, 2014. Born on August 27, 1922 in the Bronx, NY to Hyman and Rebecca W. Beloved wife of the late Seymour, they were married on August 27, 1944. She was a fashion model during the 1940's and worked for 30 years in sales for Saks Fifth Avenue in Garden City, L.I. and Palm Springs, CA. Seymour served proudly during World War II as a navigator in the United States Air Force. Selma and Cy raised their children in Merrick, Long Island and lived their dream in Palm Springs for 32 years. They remained married for more than 69 years until Seymour's passing on December 26, 2013. Selma is survived by her loving children, Jeffrey (Julianne) and Andrew (Anne Marie); four grandchildren, Brad (Leigh), Tara Vogel (David), Amy DaRosa (Eric) and Michael (Liz), step-granddaughters Erin and Jessie; and three great grandchildren, Jessie Vogel, Riley Vogel and Sydney Gansberg. Please send donations to: MJHS Hospice, 39 Broadway, Suite 200, New York, NY 10006. Memorial services will be held on Tuesday, October 7th at 11:00am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY 10024.

FRIED--David, On October 2nd. Son of the late Solomon and Estelle Fried. Beloved husband of Ruth. Father of Esther Ana Rosa and husband Keith Robinson, Jessica and Rebecca Fried. Brother of Richard Fried and wife Beth. Grandfather of Bethany, Marcus, Ana, Ella, Caleb and the late Leah. Loving nephew, uncle, cousin and friend to scores. Service: Sunday, October 5, 11am, Riverdale Temple, Bronx, NY. Donations: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

FRENCH--Connie of Darien, CT passed away peacefully at home on September 28, 2014 at age 98. She was the devoted mother of three daughters, Vickie Morris, Stephanie French and Deborah French, five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Her beloved husband William T. French passed 18 years ago. Connie loved her long-time volunteer work at the Fresh Flower Program at Society of Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

DAY--Donald. The Union for Reform Judaism and the World Union for Progressive Judaism mourn with profound sorrow the passing of Don Day, of Buffalo, NY, chairman of the URJ board of trustees from 1979 to 1983 and chairman of the WUPJ board of trustees from 1988 to 1995, as well as an extraordinary Reform Movement leader for more than four decades. We extend deepest condolences to his wife Edythe (Edy) and their children and grandchildren. May his memory be for a blessing. Stephen Sacks, Chairman, URJ Rabbi Rick Jacobs, President, URJ Michael Grabiner, Chairman, WUPJ Rabbi Daniel H. Freelander, President, WUPJ

CHASE--Dr. Richard Allen, age 81, died peacefully on Tuesday, September 2nd in New York City after a valiant battle with Alzheimer's Disease. Beloved brother of Howard E. Chase, brother-in-law of Jo Ann Chase, and favorite uncle of Andrew and Darinka Chase, John Chase, and Adam and Emma Chase. Dr. Chase was an Associate Professor of Psychiatry at The Johns Hopkins School of Medicine and taught psychiatry to a generation of medical students and residents. He founded a research and toy development company called Environmental Programs, Inc in Baltimore, MD. (which later became The Child Growth and Development Corp. and finally Learning Pathways, Inc in New York City).The research, done with hundreds of children testing toy prototypes, led to breakthroughs in understanding infant and toddler behavior and learning patterns. This research resulted in a remarkable collection of Playpath Child Development toys and three books: The First Wonderous Year; Your Toddler: and Your Preschooler. For a number of years, the toys and books were sold through The Johnson and Johnson Baby Products Co. and successor licensees. Dr. Chase devoted a significant portion of his career to researching how children play and learn. He was a prolific author, lecturer, scholar, and philanthropist. A memorial gathering to celebrate Dr. Chase's life will be announced at a later date.

CHAPNICK--Raymonde, 77, died Monday, September 29, 2014. Devoted wife for 52 years of Benjamin; loving mother of John and Asra; adoring grandmother of Sabiel, Daria and Deen. She leaves all of us who knew her feeling grateful to her for her presence, her cheer, and her love, and with the warm glow we have in our hearts from having known her.

CHAPIN--Donald. The family of Carleton and Mona Dukess, including their children, spouses, and grandchildren, will greatly miss Don, our dear friend of over forty years. He was an extraordinary man, whose kindness, intelligence, honor and humor touched us all, and his loss will be deeply felt.

Their generosity and commitment to the children and families we serve has strengthened us all. Our deepest condolences to Sharlyn, their loving family and hosts of friends who will miss him always.

BOK--John Fairfield, Age 84, of Beacon Hill, Boston, on September 27, 2014. Husband of Joan (Toland) Bok. BITTMAN--Robert. Shelter Rock Tennis Club mourns his loss and extends sympathy to his family.

BITTMAN--Robert, Professor of Chemistry and Biochemistry at City University and Queens College, passed away on October 1 after a long battle with cancer. He is survived by his wife Marlene, children Mark and Lana Bittman, sister Judy Boston and her husband George, brother Eric and his wife Sandy Sulsky, step-son Scott Aronson, step-daughter Lauren Aronson and her husband Rob Hendin, grand-children Matthew and Sarah Hendin and nieces Rachel and Sarah Bittman. BERNSTEIN--Lewis H.,passed away suddenly on September 22, 2014 surrounded by those who loved him. Cherished son of the late Tillie (nee Friedman) and Ralph Bernstein, brother of the late Vivian Blackman. Born April 27, 1935 in Brooklyn, NY, he was a graduate of Columbia College with an MBA from Columbia University. He was a founder of the Gerald J and Dorothy R Friedman New York Foundation for Medical Research serving as an officer on its Board of Directors for 18 years. Instrumental in establishing the Friedman Diabetes Institute at Beth Israel Medical Center now part of Mount Sinai, the Friedman School of Nutrition Science and Policy at Tufts University, the international Friedman Fellows Program. He also helped to name Manhattan Theater Club's Samuel J Friedman Theater on Broadway. Prior to that he was a leading buyer of men's clothing at Federated Department Stores and President of Metro Wholesale Corporation and Eton Gifts Ltd. He is survived by George Serrano, his husband and partner of 46 years, cousins Dorothy and Jane Friedman of New York, sisters and brothers-in-law Luz Maria, Hector Ruiz, Maria Bassett Serrano, their children, grandchildren and by many cousins in the United States, the United Kingdom and Israel. He is lovingly remembered by his cherished friends, David Golante, Sandra D. O'Connor, Edwin Hydeman and Maxine Ostrow. A sweet, kind, gentle soul, a brilliant and generous man, Lew will be forever in the hearts of his family and friends. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date.

BELTZER--Herman, age 87, passed away on October 3, 2014. Born in Manhattan and raised there and in Watervliet, NY, he was a longtime resident of Brooklyn and more recently of Hartsdale. He enlisted and proudly served in the US Navy during World War II. A trained attorney, he spent his distinguished career as a senior financial executive at Revlon Corporation, United Brands Corporation and Milstein Properties Corporation. Devoted son of the late Carl and Rose, adoring husband of over 60 years to Cynthia, beloved father of Howard and Alison, and cherished grandfather of Clifford and Miranda. He was a unique combination of strength and determination on the one hand, but also of profound kindness, sweetness and decency on the other. He was a towering figure in the lives of all he touched, and will be deeply missed. Funeral services on Sunday, October 5 at 2pm at Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, 295 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY.

BASS--Elaine. November 4, 1935 - October 3, 2014. Age 78. Beloved wife of Marvin, Sister to Arthur Meisnere, Mother to Saralyn, Pamela and David, Grandmother to Rebecca, Gregory, Benjamin, Emily, Carolyn, Sophie, Sam and Lily. A memorial service will be held at 2 pm on October 5 at Temple Beth Abraham, 25 Leroy Ave, Tarrytown, NY. Donations can be made to Planned Parenthood or Nassau County Coalition Against Domestic Violence.

AUERBACH--Harold, 94, died on September 28 at his home in New Rochelle, NY. He is survived by his beloved wife of 67 years, Shirley and his cherished sons Eric and Marc as well as many nieces and nephews who he adored. He was predeceased by his dear sister Helen. Born in Poland on June 29, 1920, the son of the late Ida and Eliazer Auerbach, he came to the United States in 1938. He served in the US Army from 1942 to 1945 in New Guinea and the Philippines. He owned a successful commercial air conditioning business from 1951 until his retirement in 2004. Harold was on the board of AMIC of Westchester and was a primary force in the founding of the Clearview School. He was a long-time member of the board of Opengate Inc. serving as Chairman for several years. He was instrumental in developing Opengate as an outstanding facility for the developmentally disabled. Harold was a warm, generous person who will be missed by all who knew him. Donations in Harold's memory may be made to Opengate Inc., 357 Main Street, PO Box 419, Armonk, NY 10503.

SINGER--Alan G.,beloved husband of Eleanor, father of Lawrence and Emily, grandfather of Rebecca, Quinton, Isaac and Elizabeth, brother of Natalie, and uncle of David, Laurie, and Natalie, died on October 1 of complications of pancreatic cancer. He was born in 1925. After serving in the infantry in World War II and playing in an Army band, he studied music at Queens College and New York University. An avid amateur clarinetist, composer, and arranger, he taught instrumental music in the New York public schools before joining IBM as a programmer and systems analyst. After retirement he moved to Ann Arbor, where his wife joined the University of Michigan as a Research Professor. He was a long-time member of the Washtenaw Community Concert Band and also volunteered at the Ann Arbor Hands-on Museum. There will be no services. Contributions in his memory may be made to wccband.org or aahom.org.

SILVERSHEIN--Joyce. The Hunter Dinosaurs mourn the loss of Joyce Silvershein, a special educator who lived her life improving the lives of New York City public school children and the teachers who teach them. Teaching all children to read, especially those who struggled, was the singular guiding force in her long, dedicated, committed career in the field of special education. Nothing could stop Joyce from demanding and implementing best practices to those students who need it most. She will be missed daily, and as her legacy grows, her job will not be done until all children are able to contribute in a meaningful way to our society. With love, Debbie, Diana, Linda, Mary, Melie, Midge, Phyllis, Ruth, Susan and Judy

SHERRID--Gillian, 96, passed away peacefully at her home in Manhattan on September 26. Born Goldie Shameson in Shargorod, Ukraine, Gill came to the U.S. as a small child and her story is part of the Ellis Island Oral History Project. She was an assistant principal in the New York City public schools. Endowed with a marvelous curiosity, intelligence and will, she was President of the Metropolitan Branch of the Womens' League for Conservative Judaism, a member of its national board, and its representative as an NGO at the UN. She was also president of the sisterhood of Sutton Place Synagogue, where she was the first adult woman to become bat mitzvah. She is predeceased by her beloved husband Samuel and her two sisters, Mollye and Faye. She is survived and mourned by her daughter Pamela, her son Mark, and her daughter-in-law Beverley, as well as her grandchildren Molly, Gregory, Eloise, and Lucie.

RAIFFA--Pearl, beloved sister, aunt and grand-aunt, died peacefully at home on Friday, October 3rd. She was 95. Pearl retired from The New York Times after many years working as an executive secretary, and was a great lover of the newspaper. Born and raised in the Bronx, she became the primary breadwinner of her family after the premature death of her father, and worked selflessly to advance the education and careers of her younger brothers. She is survived by her brother, Howard, sister-in-law Estelle, nephews and nieces Mark, Judy, Janet and Jonathan, and their four children. Services Sunday 2:15pm at "The Riverside" 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

POTLER--Cathy, in Brooklyn, NY, September 21, 2014. Executive Director, New York City Board of Correction. Beloved daughter of Harold and Arlene Potler; partner of Martin Vega; mother of Natan and "adopted" son, Damian; sister of Andrew and his wife Marcia; and aunt of Hannah. Memorial services: November 1, 2014, 1-3pm, Eisner & Lubin Auditorium, Kimmel Center, NYU, 60 Washington Square South. Memorial website: www.cathypotler.org. Contributions can be made in her name for Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer research at Memorial Sloan-Kettering (http://www.mskcc.org/giving)

PEARLMAN--Leonard D.,Born December 7, 1919, son of Albert and Ida Pearlman passed away peacefully in his own home on October 3rd. Leonard lived a colorful and spirited life of 94 years. Throughout his life he engaged in various professional activities including working in the family painting business, real estate development and private investing. He was an avid skier, tennis player, swimmer and storyteller who took pride in repeating his jokes. Leonard was a very loving and devoted father, brother, uncle, grandfather and friend. Leonard is survived by his brother, Herbert, his sister, Doris, his children, Manny, Andrew, Janie, his son-in-law Mark, and his grandchildren Emily, Zachary, Jacob, Joshua and Jordan. There will be a private family graveside service on Sunday October 5. The family will be sitting Shiva on Monday from 2.00pm to 8.00pm, and Tuesday from 4:00pm to 8:00pm at the home of Manny Pearlman, 350 East 79th Street, as well as on Tuesday from 2:00pm-8:00pm at the home of Janie and Mark Pollack, 239 Barton Avenue, Melville, New York 11747.

MAGARIL--Cynthia, on October 5, 2014, at age 84. Devoted mother and mother-in-law of Robert and Anne Mass, Douglas Mass and Beth Fisher, Alison and Salvatore Bommarito, Erica and Kevin Penn; beloved grandmother of Daniela, Benjamin, Emily, Davey and wife Heather, Andy, Becca, Katie, Teddy, Ann, Spencer, Maddie, Schulyer, and Wesley; and adored sister of Norman Silverman. A woman of great warmth, optimism, humor and beauty, she always saw the best in others and brightened up the lives of family and friends. In her final years, her strength and courage were an inspiration to all who knew her. May her memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Funeral services will be held on Monday, October 6, at 11:00am, at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Avenue, NY, NY 10022. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Mount Sinai Medical Center, either on-line: philanthropy.mountsinai.org/ (designated to Head & Neck Priorities), or mailed to the Mount Sinai Development Office at One Gustave L. Levy Place, Box 1049, New York, NY 10029 in either case, with a notation that the donation is in memory of Cynthia Magaril.

KESSLER--Sidney. We mourn the passing of our beloved, Sidney Kessler at 91 years of age. He was the devoted husband to the late, Gloria for 57 years; loving father to Alison, Jerry and Eric and their spouses, Arthur, Ann and Marcia; adoring grandfather to Marc, Howard, Beth, Craig, Barry, Scott, Jason and Brandon and great-grandfather to Sienna, Tyler, Gregory, Garren, Ian and Maya. Sid loved life, his family and friends. His gentle spirit, kindness and sense of humor touched all who knew him. He will remain in our hearts forever.

JACKSON--Zara Ofsevit, 89, July 31, Somers, NY. Survived by her husband Samuel Jackson, sons, Robert Ofsevit, Samuel Ofsevit, his wife Sharon and their sons, Alec and Jordan; daughter, Alisa Eilenberg, her husband Adam and their sons Phillip and Raphael; predeceased by her first husband Irving Ofsevit. Dune dweller, artist, social worker, always sought knowledge, self-improvement. We miss Zara dearly.

EPPS--Roselyn Payne, M.D. The Board of Directors of Mutual of America Life Insurance Company, together with its officers and employees, mourn the passing of their colleague and friend, Roselyn Payne Epps, M.D. Dr. Epps was an esteemed member of the Board of Directors since 1992 and served with distinction on the Audit, Executive, Long-Range Planning, Product and Marketing and Technology Committees. She was appointed Chair of the Technology Committee in 2001 and in that role was a passionate advocate of the ever increasing importance of technology to the continued success of Mutual of America. Roselyn Epps was an accomplished physician and was recognized nationally and internationally for her life's work in pediatrics and the public health sector. She was the first African American National President of the American Medical Women's Association and was recognized in 2013 with the W. Montague Cobb Lifetime Achievement Award, presented by the W. Montague Cobb National Medical Association Institute, in recognition of her extraordinary commitment to academic excellence, the health of the poor and underserved, quality education and national leadership in medicine. During these past 22 years, Dr. Epps played a major role in Mutual of America's development and growth. We who were privileged to have known her will long remember her strength of character, her dedication to service and her commitment to the mission of Mutual of America. Her wisdom and enthusiasm as well as her warmth and friendship will be greatly missed. William J. Flynn Chairman Emeritus Thomas J. Moran Chairman, President and CEO Mutual of America Life Insurance Company

BASS--Elaine. November 4, 1935 - October 3, 2014. Age 78. Beloved wife of Marvin, Sister to Arthur Meisnere, Mother to Saralyn, Pamela and David, Grandmother to Rebecca, Gregory, Benjamin, Emily, Carolyn, Sophie, Sam and Lily. A memorial service will be held at 2 pm on October 5 at Temple Beth Abraham, 25 Leroy Ave, Tarrytown, NY. Donations can be made to Planned Parenthood or Nassau County Coalition Against Domestic Violence.

YASEEN--Leonard C. Even after 25 years in the "ago," the memories of Leonard have yet to tarnish. Rather, polished by our own fading faculties, they glow softly - suggesting that his passage is no more than an extended visit to Steven in Providence. My father - founder and patriarch - we think of you this day, and thank you for the intellectual, social, and material benefits which the family enjoys due to your foresight. Thanks for catching Mom, as well. She did good work. Roger Yaseen, on behalf of his sister, for their children, and myriad grandchildren.

WILLIAMS--Douglas, of Cold Spring Harbor, Long Island, and New York City died October 1, 2014 at age 96. During a long business career, Mr. Williams was associated with Goodbody & Co., and Legg Mason Wood Walker. Following his retirement in 1990, Mr. Williams joined the Board of the Maine Sea Coast Mission Society, where he was an honorary member at the time of his death. He also served on the boards of the Madison Square Boys & Girls Club and the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities. Previously he was President of the Trustees and Elder of the Madison Ave. Presbyterian Church and President and Trustee of the Community Service Society. He was Vice-Chairman and Trustee of Teachers College-Columbia University, and President of the St. Nicolas Society. He was a member of the Yale Club, Union Club, Century Association, The Downtown Association, and an enthusiastic chorus member of the Blue Hill Troupe. Born in New York City in 1918, he attended the Buckley and Choate-Rosemary Hall Schools, and graduated Yale in 1940. As a U.S. Army 1st Lieutenant, he served in the China-Burma-India theater 1942-1945. Mr. Williams was predeceased by his son, Johnston de Forest Williams in 1969, and by his wife of 65 years, Priscilla de Forest Williams in 2006. His survivors include his daughter, Page Dwyer of Wilmington, DE; his grandson David Dwyer (Suzanne) of Cold Spring Harbor, NY; his granddaughter Claudia Knapick (Gary) of Manlius, NY; and four grandchildren: Emily Page Ockert and Henry, George and Alice Knapick, all of Manlius, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Maine Sea Coast Mission Society, Bar Harbor, ME (www.seacoastmission.org). A memorial service is planned at a future date.

KARLEN--Roland Newton. Beat Generation playwright, elder statesman of AM radio ad men, and life-long New York mensch Roland Newton Karlen died, in acceptance of the inevitable, at his home on September 20 at age 87. Raised during the Depression by a Zionist Socialist father and a kosher-keeping mother who nevertheless made him bacon sandwiches "for his health", Rolly was of the opinion that his childhood in Morningside Heights was nearly perfect. In addition to the hide-and-seek games at Grant's Tomb, Boy Scouts on 103rd Street, and playing stickball on Riverside Drive, there was an after-school job at the 57th Street Cafeteria owned by his uncle, Atlantic City turf accountant Willie "Wallpaper" Kanowitz. Rolly's only significant absence from his beloved New York came at the end of WWII courtesy of the U. S. Army draft. The G. I. Bill equipped Rolly with a bachelor's degree in English from Hunter College and a calling. The starving playwright co-founded Newton Advertising, giving New Yorkers of a certain age a Castro Convertible jingle they can never, ever get out of their heads. Later, upon achieving independent success as a one-man ad agency (which continues today as Karlen Williams Graybill), Rolly became the Karlen family's greatest benefactor, supporting distantly related scholars, undiscovered artists, free spirits, and genial ne'er-do-wells. In his retirement, Rolly had several professional readings of his early plays, which dealt with Freudian theories of self and time travel. Another milestone in the happy history of Rolly's life on Earth occurred on October 16, 2013 when, at age 86, he walked across the Brooklyn Bridge for the first time in his life. The trek would have taken half as long if he hadn't stopped every few minutes to pronounce that this view, or the one a few paces further, was the most terrific, most beautiful view of New York, of civilization, or of humanity that he'd ever seen. Rolly is survived by a legion of family and friends who have to figure out how to live in a world without him.

HOLDER--Geoffrey. Symphony Space extends its deepest sympathy to the family of Geoffrey Holder, celebrated dancer, artist, and husband to our esteemed board member Carmen de Lavallade. We will miss his extraordinary artistry and kind spirit.

GOLDMAN--Ralph. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of Ralph Goldman, longtime head of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee and a unique American Jewish leader. His service to the Jewish people was unmatched over many decades. His passion and joy for the important work he did every day were inspiring. Whether it was Israel, Jews in the Soviet Union or the smallest Jewish community in remote places around the globe, Ralph cared and did something about it. On his death, we celebrate his life. We will miss him. Barry Curtiss-Lusher, National Chair Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

GOLDMAN--Ralph. The World Jewish Congress family joins the international Jewish community in mourning the passing of Ralph Goldman, the long-time extraordinary leader of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, whose tenure covered historic times, most notably gaining JDC access to Jewish communities behind the iron curtain as well as to Soviet Jewry. He had a lifelong commitment to serving the Jewish people. A proud Zionist, appointed by Ben Gurion as his liaison appointee to the American Jewish community, Ralph was deeply dedicated to the success of Israel as the homeland of the Jewish people and played a key role in its establishment during the war of independence. We will ever be inspired by his life's work. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ronald S. Lauder, President Robert Singer, CEO

GOLDMAN--Ralph. The leadership and staff of the Jerusalem Foundation deeply mourn the passing at age 100 of a wonderful human being, Ralph I. Goldman, cherished and loyal friend of the late Mayor Teddy Kollek and among the Founders and Members of the Board of Directors of the Jerusalem Foundation. Alan Hassenfeld, Chairman US Board

GOLDMAN--Ralph. The Officers, Board of Directors, and worldwide staff of The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn with great sadness the passing of our esteemed Honorary Executive Vice President and senior advisor, Ralph I. Goldman. A legendary figure who dedicated his long and illustrious career to serving Israel and the Jewish people, Ralph has been a keystone of our organization for over four decades and an iconic symbol of international Jewish communal service. Born in Ukraine on September 1, 1914, the same year that JDC was founded in New York, Ralph celebrated his 100th birthday with us this year and was still working for JDC at his death in Israel on October 7. Ralph served two terms and a total of 11 years as JDC's Executive Vice President (1976-85; 1986-88), orchestrating our reentry into most of Eastern Europe and what was then still the Soviet Union, and seizing every opportunity to jumpstart a revitalization of Jewish life throughout the former Communist bloc. The life-sustaining assistance and Jewish connections provided today to that region's million+ Jews through 161 JDC-supported Hesed welfare centers, some 200 Jewish community centers, and hundreds of Jewish learning opportunities are a testament to his vision and pioneering efforts, as are the leadership training and regional initiatives that he launched or inspired in Latin America and Europe and the ties he solidified with more isolated Jewish communities in North Africa and India. Prior to his association with JDC, Ralph was an early builder of the State of Israel, engaging in pivotal events in the pre-State years and becoming a senior aide and trusted advisor to Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion, a life-long confidant of Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek, and a moving force in the establishment of Israel's community centers and other social, cultural, and educational institutions that continue to enrich life there and throughout the Jewish world. Ralph viewed Israel as the "fulcrum" for JDC's global operations, with a pivotal role to play in what he firmly believed was "a single, intertwined Jewish world." As JDC's Associate Director-General in Israel from 1968-76, Ralph oversaw a reorganization of operations, the relocation of JDC headquarters from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, and the establishment of an association--in partnership with the government--responsible for the development of comprehensive, innovative services for seniors. Ralph helped found and shape two social research institutes in Israel that have gained international renown, and he pioneered JDC's role as an effective instrument of the world Jewish community in responding to global disasters and supporting development needs. The recipient of numerous honorary degrees and awards, including the French Legion of Honor, Ralph seemed proudest of the Ralph I. Goldman Fellowship established by our Board in 1987, and he eagerly mentored a new generation of communal leaders. Ralph was predeceased by his beloved wife, Helen, and by his son, David Ben-Rafael, a senior Israeli diplomat killed in the March 1992 bombing of the Israeli Embassy in Argentina. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children: Judy and Yaakov, Naomi, and Elisa, and to the entire Goldman family. JDC's programs in 70+ countries today are Ralph's living legacy, and his indefatigable spirit will continue to inspire us for decades to come. Donations in tribute to Ralph can be made at support.jdc.org/ralphgoldman fund or by mail to: JDC; 711 Third Avenue; New York, NY 10017. May his memory be for a blessing. Penny Blumenstein President Dr. Irving A. Smokler Chairman of the Board Alan H. Gill Chief Executive Officer

CLAYTON--Robert C. Dad, we are remembering you and honoring Mom on your 60th wedding anniversary. Bill and Tracie

WINIKOFF--Marcia Koch, 91. We mourn the passing of Marcia Winikoff who died on October 4th, Yom Kippur, Shabbat. The devoted wife of Stanley for 68 years, Marcia was a vibrant, selfless, loving and charitable woman whose family and friends meant everything to her. This tremendous loss is shared by her children: Amy, Linda Kreisler (Ken) and the late Ellen; her grandchildren, Samantha and Eli; her nieces and nephews and extended family. Services were held on Monday.

WERTH--Murrell Rickards, of Norfolk, died October 7, 2014 at 91 years. She is survived by her husband, Matthew Fontaine Maury Werth, Jr., sons, Garrett Rickards Bowden of New York City, and Sidney Lee Bowden, of Dorset, Vermont and her grandsons, Austin and Tanner Bowden. Murrell was the daughter of Everingham Rickards and Frances Payne Murrell. Her mother was the first graduate of Sweet Briar College in 1910. She had one brother, Garrett Rickards, who was killed in World War II on Okinawa in the South Pacific. Murrell attended Sweet Briar College, from which she graduated in 1944. She married Sidney Bowden, Manager of Wilder Theaters, and had two sons, Garrett Rickards Bowden and Sidney Lee Bowden. Murrell moved to New York's Upper East Side in 1958 where her sons attended The Browning School. She was a member of The Colony Club, the Colonial Dames, St. James Church, and did fundraising work for both her church and the Yorkville Community Association where she was two-time chairwoman of their historic charity ball. She also joined the New York Skating Club. She later served on the board of directors of the Knickerbocker Greys and was a member of the board of "Dancers" and belonged to "Waltzers". While attending St. Bartholomew Church, Murrell met and married Carl Theodore Chadsey. She worked as a travel agent for Gotham Travel. During this time she made numerous trips to Norfolk to visit her ailing mother until her mother's death in 1993. After which she moved back to Norfolk and restored and redecorated her home in Ghent. During her lifetime, Murrell was a benefactor of many cultural and charitable organizations, including the Chrysler Museum, Physicians for Peace, Church of the Good Shepherd, and many others. She was a member of the Norfolk Yacht and Country Club. She also studied Art in Provence, France, Mexico, New York and Norfolk. Online condolences may be made at www.hdoliver.com.

GORDON--Arlene. The board of directors and staff of Lighthouse Guild are deeply saddened by the death of our former board member and colleague, Arlene R. Gordon. GORDON--Arlene R.,died peacefully on October 6, 2014 at the age of 91. Arlene made a difference in countless lives. A distinguished social worker from her days as a field case worker, to serving as the Associate Executive Director of The Lighthouse, to forming a women's group at her assisted living residence she worked and fought for people overcome all obstacles: physical, personal, or societal, so as to realize their full potential. A co-author of "Accounting--A Social Institution . . . " she advocated for measuring the social value of service. Blind since 1967, she not only advocated for the blind and those with low vision, but taught the sighted to see in the largest sense. She listened closely, always learned, never hesitated to teach. Arlene had a deep, devoted relationship with her late husband Daniel. Arlene was the loving mother of Andrew, mother-in-law to Jane, and grandmother of Eric. She was a devoted aunt and great aunt. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Arlene R. Gordon Research Institute at the Lighthouse Guild, 111 East 59th Street, NY, NY 10022. Memorial: Friday, October 10, 11:15am at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

GOLDMAN--Ralph. We mourn and celebrate our hero, who personally mentored, championed and inspired each of us with his lifetime of vision and service to Israel, the Jewish people, the arts, and humanity. The 1987-2015 Ralph I. Goldman Fellows

GOLDMAN--Ralph. The Officers, Board of Directors, and worldwide staff of The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn with great sadness the passing of our esteemed Honorary Executive Vice President and senior advisor, Ralph I. Goldman. A legendary figure who dedicated his long and illustrious career to serving Israel and the Jewish people, Ralph has been a keystone of our organization for over four decades and an iconic symbol of international Jewish communal service. Born in Ukraine on September 1, 1914, the same year that JDC was founded in New York, Ralph celebrated his 100th birthday with us this year and was still working for JDC at his death in Israel on October 7. Ralph served two terms and a total of 11 years as JDC's Executive Vice President (1976-85; 1986-88), orchestrating our reentry into most of Eastern Europe and what was then still the Soviet Union, and seizing every opportunity to jumpstart a revitalization of Jewish life throughout the former Communist bloc. The life-sustaining assistance and Jewish connections provided today to that region's million+ Jews through 161 JDC-supported Hesed welfare centers, some 200 Jewish community centers, and hundreds of Jewish learning opportunities are a testament to his vision and pioneering efforts, as are the leadership training and regional initiatives that he launched or inspired in Latin America and Europe and the ties he solidified with more isolated Jewish communities in North Africa and India. Prior to his association with JDC, Ralph was an early builder of the State of Israel, engaging in pivotal events in the pre-State years and becoming a senior aide and trusted advisor to Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion, a life-long confidant of Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek, and a moving force in the establishment of Israel's community centers and other social, cultural, and educational institutions that continue to enrich life there and throughout the Jewish world. Ralph viewed Israel as the "fulcrum" for JDC's global operations, with a pivotal role to play in what he firmly believed was "a single, intertwined Jewish world." As JDC's Associate Director-General in Israel from 1968-76, Ralph oversaw a reorganization of operations, the relocation of JDC headquarters from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, and the establishment of an association--in partnership with the government--responsible for the development of comprehensive, innovative services for seniors. Ralph helped found and shape two social research institutes in Israel that have gained international renown, and he pioneered JDC's role as an effective instrument of the world Jewish community in responding to global disasters and supporting development needs. The recipient of numerous honorary degrees and awards, including the French Legion of Honor, Ralph seemed proudest of the Ralph I. Goldman Fellowship established by our Board in 1987, and he eagerly mentored a new generation of communal leaders. Ralph was predeceased by his beloved wife, Helen, and by his son, David Ben-Rafael, a senior Israeli diplomat killed in the March 1992 bombing of the Israeli Embassy in Argentina. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children: Judy and Yaakov, Naomi, and Elisa, and to the entire Goldman family. JDC's programs in 70+ countries today are Ralph's living legacy, and his indefatigable spirit will continue to inspire us for decades to come. Donations in tribute to Ralph can be made at support.jdc.org/ralphgoldman fund or by mail to: JDC; 711 Third Avenue; New York, NY 10017. May his memory be for a blessing. Penny Blumenstein President Dr. Irving A. Smokler Chairman of the Board Alan H. Gill Chief Executive Officer

BUCHMAN--Joyce, surrounded by her devoted family, passed away peacefully at home on October 8, 2014. Joyce was born in Manhattan on January 13, 1938. She died of colon cancer. She will be missed by her husband of 52 years, Joel Buchman, her son, Jonathan, her daughter, Jennifer Buchman Lynn, her daughter-in-law, Lisa, her son-in-law, Jesse Lynn, and her sister, Joni Evans. Joyce adored her three grandchildren, Max, Amanda and Claudia. Joyce graduated from Hunter College and the New York Institute of Finance and over the course of 50 plus years enjoyed a successful career in finance. She began at the investment bank of White Weld & Co., later joined the firm of F. Eberstadt & Co., and in 1974, joined the investment advisory firm Peter. B. Cannell & Co. where she rose to the position of Executive Vice President and Director. Funeral services will be held on Friday, October 10, 2014 at 9:30am at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st St.) in New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to City Meals-on-Wheels of NYC in Joyce's memory.

ANNENBERG LA VEA-- James Annenberg La Vea (Levee), scion to the Annenberg publishing and media fortune, died on October 4, 2014 at the age of 75 from multiple aggressive cancers. Mr. La Vea received a Masters Degree in 19th Century Comparative Literature from Syracuse University and a J.D. from the University of Minnesota, where he passed the Bar. When he received his inheritance, Mr. La Vea fondly recalled his mother's words, which were: "Don't give until it pinches, give until it hurts," and with a sizable percentage of that inheritance, he immediately established the James Annenberg La Vea Charitable Foundation. Those who knew Mr. La Vea well know that nothing gave him more pride and joy than his philanthropic work. With a deep belief that children are our future leaders, he tirelessly supported children's causes, including those established to combat childhood hunger and disease, as well as those that provide for civic education and leadership. Mr. La Vea also believed that there is a strong link between the way we treat animals and the way we treat each other. This led to his passion for supporting wildlife and domesticated animal charities, including those that benefit and protect tigers, leopards, cheetahs, rhinoceros, elephants, as well as homeless dogs and cats. Surviving him are loved ones Jill Genson and Randolph Genson of Boca Raton, FL, Deborah Casperino and Monica Casperino of Fort Lauderdale, FL and Alice Levit Levee of Bal Harbor, FL. Funeral services will be held at 11:30am on Friday, October 10, 2014 at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., New York City. A celebration of Mr. La Vea's life will be held in Boca Raton, FL at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, 699 Prince St., Alexandria, VA, 22314.

SIEGEL--David Donald, Died on October 9th, at his home in North Egremont, MA, after a series of health problems. He was born on October 18th, 1931, in Brooklyn, NY. David attended New York City public schools and was a bright but unmotivated student at Brooklyn College, where he majored in Romance Languages. He received a draft notice on the day of the Korean War armistice, and served his country for two years in Stuttgart, Germany, translating French documents. David described his peacetime military service as a turning point in his life. After returning home, he enrolled at St. John's University Law School, where he graduated at the top of the class of 1958. In 1962 the New York State Legislature enacted the Civil Practice Law and Rules, which reorganized the law of New York civil ligation. David quickly found his professional niche. He transformed arcane subjects with clarity, concision, and, most remarkably, humor. The bench and bar came to rely on his writings as indispensable to the practice of law. In the years that followed, he was in wide demand as a lecturer and expert in the areas of New York Civil Procedure, Conflict of Laws, and Federal Jurisdiction. David's premier publication was his treatise, New York Practice, which has been the definitive text on New York civil procedure from its original publication in 1978 until today, now in its fifth edition. He brought meticulous scholarship and lucidity to all his writing, including the Bar Association's New York State Law Digest and his own Siegel's Practice Review, which he first published in 1993. David edited the former for thirty-seven years, and the latter from 1993 to 2014. His practice commentaries for McKinney's Consolidated Laws of New York have been cited by the United States Supreme Court and have been extensively relied on by New York courts, including more than 250 citations by the Court of Appeals. He served as Professor of Law at Albany Law School from 1972 until his retirement as Distinguished Professor in 2007. David also taught at St. John's University, and was a visiting professor at New York University and Cornell University Law Schools. At Albany Law, he created a scholarship fund for Law Review students, which has provided financial support for 126 students to date. David was a revered mentor to scores of students and lawyers, as well as family members and friends. David was renowned for his quick wit, infectious sense of fun, and generous soul, all of which were in full force until his final hours. David is survived by his wife of nearly 45 years, Rosemarie Duffy Siegel, and two daughters, Sheela Clary of West Stockbridge and Rachel Siegel of Great Barrington. His five grandchildren, Cecelia, Fiona, George, Donal and Patrick were the lights of his later life. He was predeceased by his father, Harry Siegel, in 1976, and his mother, Ida Scharaga Siegel, in 1980. An interfaith memorial service will be held at St. James Church in Chatham, NY, at 1pm on October 19th. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Albany Law School Law Review, in Memory of Professor David D. Siegel.

SCHEINMAN--Bonnie. The Woodmere Club deeply regrets the passing of our good friend and longtime member Bonnie Scheinman. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to her family and friends. Board of Governors The Woodmere Club

ROSENFELD--Edith. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Edith Rosenfeld, and extend sincere condolences to her family. James Dreyfus, President

OKIN--Milton, of Rye, NY, died peacefully at 99, on October 7, 2014. Milt was a food biochemist at the frontier of the health food revolution. He bought and expanded American Diet-Aids transforming it into a successful company pioneering natural products. He later co-founded US Health Club, a first entry in direct sales of health supplements and health aids. He originated the name "Weight Watchers," which he sold to the company now bearing that name. He chaired the PELL Committee in its vigorous fight against the FDA's attempts to destroy the vitamin and health food industry when it was still in its infancy. Milt married Rose Baltowsky and remained deeply in love with her until her death in 1988. They had three adoring children to whom Milt was a hero, an inspiration and a major source of their values and ideals. He was a generous, forward thinking, idealistic man who gave unstintingly of his time and money to charitable causes. He and Rose, through "Women to Women" were largely responsible for the initial funding of the first battered women's shelter in Jerusalem. He loved opera, ballet and theatre, played tennis until 90 and exercised daily. After Rose's death, Milt fell in love with and married June Stanley. She and Elaine Reid, their housekeeper, lovingly cared for Milt in his last years. He is survived by his wife June, three children, Robert, Nicki (Gerard) and Kenneth (Elaine), two step children Billy (Bonnie), Johanna (Richard), five grandchildren, five step grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. He was pre-deceased by his granddaughter Jennifer.

O'HARA--John A. (Jack) March 09, 1928 October 01, 2014, died peacefully in Greenwich, CT following a prolonged illness. Jack served as President and CEO of The Reader's Digest Association from 1979 thru 1984. He is survived by his brother Sydney O'Hara and his wife Maureen who live in Argyll, Scotland and their two sons Neil and Gavin, residing in England. A memorial service will be held on November 12, 2014 at 11:00am at the Greenwich Country Club.
