McENIRY--Philip L.,66, died October 4, 2014, in New City, NY. A resident for over 30 years of Pomona, N.Y., he is survived by his siblings, David W. and Roger S. McEniry and Catherine E.M. Sullivan; by his sister-in-law Carolyn Acosta, his brother-in-law David E. Sullivan, and his former sister-in-law Courtney Johnson McEniry; and by Roger's partner Karen P. Riley. He also leaves seven nieces and nephews, Tessa, Grace, Andrew, and Eloise McEniry and John, Thomas, and Peter Sullivan; numerous cousins; and some good friends he considered family. He grew up in Scarsdale, NY, the son of the late Murray W. and Catherine M. McEniry, graduated from Scarsdale High School, Class of 1966, and Bowdoin College, Class of 1970, and received an M.B.A. from the University of Rochester in 1972. He worked in finance and accounting in New York City and its environs until retiring in 2010. Memorial to be held at the Michael J. Higgins Funeral Home, 73 North Liberty Drive, Stony Point, NY, at 2:30 on Saturday, October 18. Family and friends welcome. Contributions in his memory may be made for the Joe Raso Hospice Residence to United Hospice of Rockland (hospiceofrockland.org), 11 Stokum Lane, New City, New York 10956.

MARGOLIUS--Laura, passed away peacefully at home on October 9, 2014 at age 93. She will be dearly missed by her devoted husband of 67 years, Edwin; daughter Betsy Kirschbaum and son-in-law Ned Kirschbaum; son Rabbi Marc Margolius and daughter-in-law Rabbi Ayelet Cohen; five grandchildren Max, Sam, Galia, Meital and Ziv; and her nieces, nephew, and grand-nieces and nephews. Laura graduated from Cooper Union in 1942, and had a flourishing career as a painter, ceramicist, and printmaker. Her prize-winning work was exhibited across the country, including the Brooklyn Museum, and is in many private and corporate collections. Aside from her family, her art was her life. Funeral services Sunday, October 12, 12:30pm at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. (91st St.). Donations to Laura Miller Margolius '42 Memorial Fund at Cooper Union, c/o Joseph McDonald, 30 Cooper Square, 8th Fl, NYC NY 10003.

MANSFIELD--Thomas. Trevor Day School shares heartfelt condolences. The Headmaster of The Day School from '65-'78, Tom was a founding father of our school, and a true visionary behind all that is at our core. He will be missed. Sally Rocker, Board President Scott Reisinger, Head of School

KOPLIK--Marilyn S.,81, died peacefully after a long illness on October 1, 2014. Fearrington Village, NC; formerly of Lakeridge, CT; and Roslyn, NY. Born July 9, 1933, Brooklyn, NY to Frank and Bella Stein. Survived by her daughter, Caryn B. Koplik; brother and sister-in-law, Alan and Shelly Stein; nephews and their families, Captain (US Navy) Lawrence J., Robin, and Ariel Stein; David and Heather Stein, and Alex Dalpe; and nieces (nee Haber) and their families; Linda Drucker, Sharon Pasternack, Carol Zimmerman, and Ellen Lerman. Her son, Richard T. Koplik, died in April, 1992. Husbands, Herbert S. Koplik and A. Stuart Hanellin predeceased her. Graduated Brooklyn College ('54), magna cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa; NYU Graduate School of Public Administration ('55) MPA with distinction; C.W. Post College, Palmer Graduate School of Library Science ('72) MLS. In 1988, retired from Sachem Public Library, after eighteen years as a reference librarian. In 1998, retired from NY Institute of Technology, as director of four branch libraries. The family extends a special thank you to the staff of Hillcrest Convalescent Center, Durham, NC for the wonderful care and kindness shown to Mrs. Koplik. We also thank Beth Rickman, CNA for her consistent and careful attention, gracious spirit, and good cheer. A celebration of Marilyn's life -- The Gathering Place, Fearrington Village, 3pm, Friday, October 17th. Donations may be made at www.donorschoose.org/In-Memory-of-Marilyn-S.-KoplikHall-Wynne Griffin Chapel is serving the family.

Weill, Chairman; Robert Battle, Artistic Director; Masazumi Chaya, Associate Artistic Director; Judith Jamison, Artistic Director Emerita

GREENBERG--Eulalia Beloved mother, grandmother, sister, aunt and friend passed away peacefully on September 28, 2014. Eulalia (aka Lali and YaYa) lived an admirably happy and full life, with accomplishments that were far ahead of her time. Born on May 26, 1933 to Pere Virgili Fortuny and Eulalia Elias Virgili in Esparreguera, Spain, Eulalia was one of a handful of women to graduate from Barcelona University School of Law in 1957. She became Spain's first female Fulbright Scholar, for which she was awarded a fellowship to Luxembourg School of Comparative Law in 1958. There, she met her future husband, Michael H. Greenberg, who was studying law at Harvard University. The following year, she received a grant to further study international comparative law at New York University, where she earned a Masters. Eulalia and Michael were married on June 11, 1960, and moved to Michael's hometown of Brooklyn. After the birth of their two sons, Peter and Edward, they moved to Freeport, Long Island and then to Baldwin, where their children grew up, and later to Great Neck when Peter and Edward were away in college. Eulalia dedicated herself to raising their children while her husband pursued his illustrious law career. She also worked part-time doing Spanish-English legal translations, simultaneous court translation, and taught Adult Education English as a second language. After their sons were grown and living in Manhattan, Eulalia and Michael moved to the Upper East Side of Manhattan. There Eulalia filled her life with her passions, such as spoiling her grandchildren, hostessing her signature Paella parties, engaging in Catalan cultural events, and watching many different types of sporting events. Eulalia loved taking long strolls in Central Park, and going to Broadway shows, Lincoln Center, and Manhattan's many museums and restaurants. She enjoyed traveling frequently with her children and grandchildren on family vacations, and to visit her family in Barcelona and the surrounding towns in Catalonia, Spain. After her husband of 47 years passed away in 2008, Eulalia recovered from her loss and continued to live a vibrant and independent life, always determined to learn and adapt to the changing world. Until her final days, she stayed in touch with her friends and family in both the U.S. and Spain with daily emails and text messages. Eulalia will be forever remembered for her beauty - both inside and out, her selfless dedication to her family, her cosmopolitan elegance, strong will, fun and loving spirit, and unfaltering kindness. She will be especially missed by her adoring sons, Peter and Edward; her daughters-in-law, Carolina and Kate; and her grandchildren, Lauren, Nicky, Jordan, Emily and Isabella. Eulalia also leaves behind her family in Spain, including her loving brother, Jose Maria, sister-in-law, Luisa, and their children and grandchildren. A gathering to celebrate Eulalia's life will be held at her apartment (239 E. 79th St., Apt. 13P) on Saturday, October 11 from 2:00pm to 6:00pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Catalan Institute of America catalaninstituteofamerica.org.

BUZIO--Lidya. Artist and ceramist, died of cancer on September 30, 2014 at her Greenport, Long Island home at age 65. Buzio's work was widely acclaimed in the ceramics field and was seen in major museum exhibitions across the country. Inspired by the buildings and skyline of lower Manhattan, her most noted ceramic vessels combining cylinders, cones, and hemispheres twist and juxtapose the rooflines, architectural details, and water towers of the city into a magical panorama that captures the urban scene. Born in Uruguay, in 1948, she studied with artists of the Taller Torres-Garcia in Montevideo. Buzio moved to New York City in 1971. In the 1990s, she moved to the North Fork of Long Island. Buzio's ceramics are in the Brooklyn Museum, Museum of Fine Arts Houston, the Smithsonian National Museum of American Art in Washington, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, the Fine Arts Museum of San Francisco, the Nelson-Atkins Museum, the Everson Museum, the Victoria & Albert in London, many other museums and private collections. She is survived by her sister, Cecilia de Torres, her brothers Carlos and Julio Buzio, her husband Dan Pollock, and numerous cousins, nieces and nephews.
Buchman--Joyce. Our dear friend. So many laughs, So many good times. We'll miss you. Karen and Joel Zimmer and Family

BUCHMAN--Joyce, surrounded by her devoted family, passed away peacefully at home on October 8, 2014. Joyce was born in Manhattan on January 13, 1938. She died of colon cancer. She will be missed by her husband of 52 years, Joel Buchman, her son, Jonathan, her daughter, Jennifer Buchman Lynn, her daughter-in-law, Lisa, her son-in-law, Jesse Lynn, and her sister, Joni Evans. Joyce adored her three grandchildren, Max, Amanda and Claudia. Joyce graduated from Hunter College and the New York Institute of Finance and over the course of 50 plus years enjoyed a successful career in finance. She began at the investment bank of White Weld & Co., later joined the firm of F. Eberstadt & Co., and in 1974, joined the investment advisory firm Peter. B. Cannell & Co. where she rose to the position of Executive Vice President and Director. Funeral services will be held on Friday, October 10, 2014 at 9:30am at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st St.) in New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to City Meals-on-Wheels of NYC in Joyce's memory.

AIZER--Charles, died Monday, October 6, 2014, in New York City, from complications of pneumonia. Born Saleh Aizer, in 1925, the eighth of nine children of Hanina Abdullah and Shaul Aizer, in Baghdad, Iraq. With his late brother Naim, he established and operated a multi-national film distribution and exhibition company, and developed elegant theatres which became artistic and social centers in Baghdad. After seeing all his family members safely out of Iraq, he settled in New York from which he operated a chain of retail stores in medium size American cities. Charles was unfailingly gracious and kind, brilliant, perceptive, wise, and effortlessly good. He loved his family and friends, the United States of America, Arabic music, and Central Park. He is survived by his wife Rosemary, nee Duffy, daughter Anna, son Anthony, daughter-in-law-Juliet, son-in-law Pedro Dal Bo, grandchildren Manuel, Carlos and Luis Dal Bo, Oliver and Celia Aizer, and many nieces and nephews, all of whom, as well as his friends and acquaintances loved and were loved by him. Donations to "Central Park Conservancy", marked 'In memory of Charles Aizer", mailed to Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60th Street, New York, NY 10022, are being accepted, and will be much appreciated by the family. A gathering of family and friends in gratitude for and in celebration of his life will be scheduled in the near future.

SCHWARZ--Richard. In Memoriam. We all miss you very much. Love, Ronnie

ROSENFELD--Edith Anne Englander, passed away on October 9, 2014, She was 83. Born in New York City to the late Jules and Clara Englander, she grew up and lived most of her adult life in Larchmont before moving to Rye Brook several years ago. Edith graduated from Mamaroneck High School, Class of '48, and from Mount Holyoke College, Class of '52, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. An avid reader, she devoted the bulk of her time to her family. In addition she worked on behalf of Hadassah and the Mount Holyoke Alumni Association. She was a member of the Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck for 49 years. Beloved wife of Jerome Rosenfeld, loving mother of David (Julia), Andrew (Susan) and Amy Cummings (William), cherished grandmother of Sarah, Brooke (Alan), Jessica, Joshua, Elizabeth, Michael, Rachael, Justin (Tassia), Sandra, Alicia and Sean, dear sister of Alan Englander (Linda). A funeral service will be held 11am Sunday at Zion Memorial Chapel 785 E. Boston Post Rd. Mamaroneck, NY 914-381-1809, followed by interment at Mt. Eden Cemetery in Hawthorne. For more information; www.zionchapel.com In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to: www.nationalmssociety.org/ donate or www.ccfa.org

PEYSER--Peter A.,former Member of Congress from Westchester, Rockland and The Bronx and former Mayor of Irvington, died on October 9 at his home in Irvington. He was 93 years old. Mr. Peyser was first elected to Congress in 1970 as a Republican. He filled the vacancy left by Richard L. Ottinger (D), who left his House seat to pursue a run for the Senate. In 1972, Peyser fought off Ottinger's comeback attempt in one of the most hard-fought House elections of its time in New York. When Ottinger returned to Congress in 1974 from a neighboring district, the two became close collaborators on behalf of Westchester. In 1976, Peyser attempted to unseat Senator James L. Buckley (C) in a statewide GOP primary. His quixotic campaign ended in defeat. In 1977, Peyser announced he had become a Democrat. In 1978, he ran for his old congressional seat as a Democrat and won. He was re-elected in 1980. In 1982, redistricting eliminated his seat and forced him to run against popular Congressman Ben Gilman (R) in a district highly favorable to Gilman. Mr. Gilman won that race and Peyser departed the Congress on January 3, 1983. During his decades of public service, he always focused on trying to make government work for people. Quality education and good, family wage jobs were issues to which he applied his abundant energy. In addition to his service in Congress from 1971-1977 and 1979-1983 and as Irvington Mayor from 1962-1970, Mr. Peyser served as President of the Irvington PTA, on the Board of Trustees of his beloved Colgate University, on the Vestry of St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Irvington and on the Board of Trustees of Children's Village. Mr. Peyser was born in Cedarhurst, Long Island on September 7, 1921. He graduated from the Dwight School in Manhattan and went on to Colgate University. He was in the class of 1943, but his class accelerated their studies so they could graduate in December of 1942 and enter the armed forces. He served in the Army infantry in World War II and saw action in major European theater battles such as the Battle of the Bulge, Hurtgen Forest, Remagen Bridge engagement and others. After returning home, he served in the National Guard as a Captain in the 7th Regiment. Mr. Peyser worked in the insurance industry after the war, eventually running his own agency of the Mutual of New York company. When his congressional career ended in 1983, he started a new career in the financial sector and at the end of his life was still working for the Gabelli Asset Management Company. He and the Peyser family have been most grateful to the company's founder Mario Gabelli for his support and friendship. Mr. Peyser is survived by his wife of 64 years, the former Marguerite Richards and his five children: Penny of Woodland Hills, CA; Safi Abheeti of Novato, CA; Peter of New York City; Jim of Milton, MA, and Tom of Richmond, VA. All of the Peyser children graduated from Irvington High School. He is also survived by five grandchildren. His passing leaves a void for all of his family that can never be filled. The public is invited to a viewing on Sunday, October 12 from 2pm to 5pm at the Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home in Dobbs Ferry, NY and to the funeral service on Monday, October 13 at 3pm at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Irvington, NY. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers or other gifts, the family asks that donations be made in Mr. Peyser's name to the International Rescue Committee www.rescue.org or to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research: www.michaeljfox.org

MARGOLIUS--Laura, passed away peacefully at home on October 9, 2014 at age 93. She will be dearly missed by her devoted husband of 67 years, Edwin; daughter Betsy Kirschbaum and son-in-law Ned Kirschbaum; son Rabbi Marc Margolius and daughter-in-law Rabbi Ayelet Cohen; five grandchildren Max, Sam, Galia, Meital and Ziv; and her nieces, nephew, and grand-nieces and nephews. Laura graduated from Cooper Union in 1942, and had a flourishing career as a painter, ceramicist, and printmaker. Her prize-winning work was exhibited across the country, including the Brooklyn Museum, and is in many private and corporate collections. Aside from her family, her art was her life. Funeral services Sunday, October 12, 12:30pm at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. (91st St.). Donations to Laura Miller Margolius '42 Memorial Fund at Cooper Union, c/o Joseph McDonald, 30 Cooper Square, 8th Fl, NYC NY 10003.

LOIGMAN--Mark D.,M.D.., 49, died October 10, 2014, in Greenwich, CT. A resident of Larchmont, NY, he is survived by his wife, Andrea Glenn Loigman, his children, Vivienne Hope Glenn Loigman and Georgia Glenn Loigman, his parents, Dr. Barry and Mrs. Carol Loigman, brother, Robert S. Loigman, and sister-in-law Lynda Loigman, by his sister-in-law Elissa Zodicoff, his brother-in-law Howard Zodicoff, and his inlaws, Rhoda and Brian Glenn. He grew up in North Caldwell, NJ, graduated from West Essex High School, Class of 1984, received his undergraduate degree from the University of Pennsylvania, class of 1988, received his medical degree from Albert Einstein College of Medicine in 1995 and received his M.B.A. from the Zicklin School of Business at Baruch College in 2004. He worked in private practice as a psychiatrist in New York City. Funeral service to be held at Larchmont Temple in Larchmont, NY on Sunday, October 12, 2014 at 11am. Family and friends welcome. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Greenwich Hospital Development Office, Attention: Jim Wright, for Greenwich Hospital Palliative Care Services, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT 06830.

KOLBRENER--Barbara, died Wednesday October 8 in her sleep. She was 76 years old. Barbara was born to Abraham and Anna Blumstein in 1938 and grew up in Forest Hills, Queens. Barbara attended Skidmore and Finch Colleges, graduating with distinction from Finch. She married Jack Kolbrener in 1960 and together had three children William, Meri, and Michael. Barbara then received a Masters Degree in Special Education from Hofstra University and taught for over thirty years at Harbor Hill Elementary School in the Roslyn School District. She was a beloved teacher who dedicated her career to advocating on behalf of children with special needs. Barbara taught students in both the Public School and as a private tutor. She had a gift for helping the hard to reach and hard to teach. She is survived by her husband, three children, thirteen grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. Funeral will be held on October 12, 2014 at 11:30am at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffers Memorial Chapel in Forest Hills, Queens. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Barbara's memory to Reading is Fundamental - www.rif.org. Please list Barbara@Kolbrener.com as the Honoree email address.

GOURARY--Marianne. In the late afternoon of Thursday, October 2nd, Marianne Gourary died at age 93 in her Manhattan home. Marianne and her twin brother were born in Munich, Germany in 1920. Marianne and her brother witnessed Hitler and the early stages of Nazism rising in Germany. Their parents, Ernst and Marta Wilmersdoerffer, died of illness in 1929 and 1931. Marianne's brother went to England and Marianne was sent to the International School of Geneva. After graduating in 1941, she attended the University of Geneva, studying biology. She left before completing her studies to marry Orazio Frugoni and after a few more years in Europe, they both immigrated to New York in 1949. Friends have described Marianne as a force of nature. When she was a young woman in Switzerland, her nickname was "La Bise," the fierce wind that blows off Lake Geneva. Her comments could be acerbic, and her observations astute. She spoke her mind and the truth as she saw it. She also won many people over with her charm, intelligence, elegance and concern. She had many friends who were very important to her. She was a most considerate traveler and guest. Marianne always appreciated beauty. She loved classical music and opera and attended many cultural events. At home the radio was always on with classical music. She and her second husband, Paul Gourary, created a beautiful home in Manhattan that was filled with art and books where she hosted many fine dinners for friends. Marianne spent many summers in Provincetown where she loved to take a daily swim in the bay. Time spent there with family and friends was a source of joy and relaxation. She was a resolute and devoted mother who was very proud of her daughter Corinne and her son John. She had a strong affection for cats and especially appreciated their company during the later years of her life. She was curious, researching and collecting books on many subjects. She was proud to be a citizen of the United States, a Democrat and a New Yorker. As she weakened during the last year of her life, she found great pleasure in the beauty of the trees and flowers in Central Park. Marianne leaves behind her daughter, Corinne Frugoni, her son John Gourary, his wife and children, Jennifer, Justin and Julia, her sister-in-law and nephew and nieces in England, June Wilmers, Peter Wilmers, Catherine Wilmers and Brigit Wilmers, their partners, Carol, Graham, David, along with their children and childrens' children. She was preceded in death by her twin brother, John Wilmers, her first husband, Orazio Frugoni, her second husband, Paul Gourary, her first cousin Eugen Merzbacher and her nephew's son, Harry Wilmers. Gratitude is expressed to the people who enabled Marianne to live comfortably and safely in her home including Stella, Karen Glasser, the staff of 45 East 85th Street and the VNA Hospice. Donations may be sent to The Humane Society of New York City, Bide-A-Wee Pet Welfare Organization or Marianne's favorite radio station WQXR.

DAVIDOWITZ--Edward. We cherish your friendship and love and are so grateful that you made our world a better place. Hugs and kisses. Susie, Anne and Sohiel, Karen and Andy, Danielle, Tamara, Alexis and Matthew

DAVIDOWITZ--The Honorable Edward M.,81, retired Justice of The Supreme Court of The State of New York, passed away after a long illness on October 10, 2014. He lived a life dedicated to family, friends and the law. Ed was a graduate of the Ethical Culture School, Fieldston, Allegheny College and Cornell Law School. He also served as a Lieutenant in the United States Air Force. He began his career in law as an Assistant District Attorney under Frank Hogan. After a brief time in private practice, Ed returned to public service as a Special Assistant Attorney General in The New York State Special Prosecutor's Office. In 1985 he was appointed to the Bronx Supreme Court as an Acting Supreme Court Justice of the Court of Claims, and ultimately appointed Justice of the Supreme Court of the State of New York. Upon retirement, he continued working in the Bronx Supreme Court as a Judicial Hearing Officer. He was also honored to serve as Co-chair of the New York Tribal Courts Committee whose mission is to foster an understanding and improve cooperation between the Tribal and State justice systems. Ed loved helping young Assistant District Attorneys and Defense Lawyers become the best lawyers possible. Both always wanted to try cases before him and looked forward to his willingness to mentor. His passion for law and teaching led him to co-author a book on the practice of criminal law: Foundation Evidence, Questions and Courtroom Protocols. He also wrote The Practice of Criminal Law under the CPLR and Related Civil Procedure Statutes. He was a member of the New York State and City Bar Associations. He also was a board member of Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, NY and a member of Quaker Ridge Golf Club in Scarsdale, NY. Ed was a kind, generous, gentle and fair person beloved by many. Family was paramount in his life, and he leaves behind a loving wife, Ellen, of fifty three years, three sons; James (Laurie), Robert (Cheryl Bennett) and John, along with five cherished grandchildren; Cleo, Jonas, Tess, Adler and Edison. Nothing gave Edward greater joy than time spent with his family. Funeral services will be held at Westchester Reform Temple on Monday, October 13, 2014, 11am at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Leukemia Fighters c/o of Dr. Ellen K. Ritchie, 520 East 70th Street, Box 403, New York NY 10021.

CARSWELL--Lois Passed suddenly on October 8, 2014. Lois Carswell, nee Malakoff, was committed to the Brooklyn community she loved. Her decades-long career at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden began as a volunteer in the Women's Auxiliary. She was elected a trustee in 1985 and ultimately retired as Chairman Emeritus after leading the Garden from 1989-98. Her true passion was the annual plant sale, which she co-chaired for over 40 years, even after retirement, with her good friend Lucille Plotz. Lois also founded the Coalition of Living Museums in 1980 to facilitate funding for a broad range of statewide cultural institutions. Her sharp intellect (Radcliffe '53) and dogged determination were key assets in all aspects of her life, from the boardroom to the tennis court and bridge table, where she was a master. Lois treasured family summers at the lake in Magog, Quebec, and walks with her black Standard Schnauzer. She was patient and loving, a loyal friend and a devoted mother. Predeceased by Donald, her husband of 48 years, Lois is survived by her children Anne, Alex and Bob, as well as grandchildren Phillip, Tom, Julia and James, all of whom will miss her immeasurably. A celebration of her life will be held at the BBG at a future date.

BALSAM--Barbara Baron, 71, died unexpectedly after a brief bout with lung cancer on October 9, 2014. Born December 7, 1942, in Brooklyn, NY to Sydney and Sylvia Baron. Survived by her beloved husband, Michael, brothers Eric, Richard, and Daniel, and daughters Lisa Solinga (Steven) and Jennifer Hirsch (Steven); adoring Bubbe to her grandchildren Anna, Sarah, Lucy, and Noah. Barbara attended NYU and went on to a successful career in finance until her retirement in 2010. In retirement Barbara was an avid reader, enjoyed working at her synagogue thrift shop, seeing shows on Broadway, and frequent visits with her grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your local chapter of the National Alliance on Mental Illness. Family will be receiving visitors between the hours of 3pm to 7pm on Sunday and Monday at the home of Lisa and Steven Solinga in New Rochelle, NY.

WINIKOFF--Marcia Koch, 91. We mourn the passing of Marcia Winikoff who died on October 4th, Yom Kippur, Shabbat. The devoted wife of Stanley for 68 years, Marcia was a vibrant, selfless, loving and charitable woman whose family and friends meant everything to her. This tremendous loss is shared by her children: Amy, Linda Kreisler (Ken) and the late Ellen; her grandchildren, Samantha and Eli; her nieces and nephews and extended family. Services were held on Monday.

WILLIAMS--Douglas, of Cold Spring Harbor, Long Island, and New York City died October 1, 2014 at age 96. During a long business career, Mr. Williams was associated with Goodbody & Co., and Legg Mason Wood Walker. Following his retirement in 1990, Mr. Williams joined the Board of the Maine Sea Coast Mission Society, where he was an honorary member at the time of his death. He also served on the boards of the Madison Square Boys & Girls Club and the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities. Previously he was President of the Trustees and Elder of the Madison Ave. Presbyterian Church and President and Trustee of the Community Service Society. He was Vice-Chairman and Trustee of Teachers College-Columbia University, and President of the St. Nicolas Society. He was a member of the Yale Club, Union Club, Century Association, The Downtown Association, and an enthusiastic chorus member of the Blue Hill Troupe. Born in New York City in 1918, he attended the Buckley and Choate-Rosemary Hall Schools, and graduated Yale in 1940. As a U.S. Army 1st Lieutenant, he served in the China-Burma-India theater 1942-1945. Mr. Williams was predeceased by his son, Johnston de Forest Williams in 1969, and by his wife of 65 years, Priscilla de Forest Williams in 2006. His survivors include his daughter, Page Dwyer of Wilmington, DE; his grandson David Dwyer (Suzanne) of Cold Spring Harbor, NY; his granddaughter Claudia Knapick (Gary) of Manlius, NY; and four grandchildren: Emily Page Ockert and Henry, George and Alice Knapick, all of Manlius, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Maine Sea Coast Mission Society, Bar Harbor, ME (www.seacoastmission.org). A memorial service is planned at a future date.

SIEGEL--David. Our profession, our committee, indeed, the entire state, has lost a great educator, humorist, and human being. The Advisory Committee on Civil Practice to the Chief Administrative Judge of the Courts of the State of New York George F. Carpinello, Chair

SIEGEL--David Donald, Died on October 9th, at his home in North Egremont, MA, after a series of health problems. He was born on October 18th, 1931, in Brooklyn, NY. David attended New York City public schools and was a bright but unmotivated student at Brooklyn College, where he majored in Romance Languages. He received a draft notice on the day of the Korean War armistice, and served his country for two years in Stuttgart, Germany, translating French documents. David described his peacetime military service as a turning point in his life. After returning home, he enrolled at St. John's University Law School, where he graduated at the top of the class of 1958. In 1962 the New York State Legislature enacted the Civil Practice Law and Rules, which reorganized the law of New York civil ligation. David quickly found his professional niche. He transformed arcane subjects with clarity, concision, and, most remarkably, humor. The bench and bar came to rely on his writings as indispensable to the practice of law. In the years that followed, he was in wide demand as a lecturer and expert in the areas of New York Civil Procedure, Conflict of Laws, and Federal Jurisdiction. David's premier publication was his treatise, New York Practice, which has been the definitive text on New York civil procedure from its original publication in 1978 until today, now in its fifth edition. He brought meticulous scholarship and lucidity to all his writing, including the Bar Association's New York State Law Digest and his own Siegel's Practice Review, which he first published in 1993. David edited the former for thirty-seven years, and the latter from 1993 to 2014. His practice commentaries for McKinney's Consolidated Laws of New York have been cited by the United States Supreme Court and have been extensively relied on by New York courts, including more than 250 citations by the Court of Appeals. He served as Professor of Law at Albany Law School from 1972 until his retirement as Distinguished Professor in 2007. David also taught at St. John's University, and was a visiting professor at New York University and Cornell University Law Schools. At Albany Law, he created a scholarship fund for Law Review students, which has provided financial support for 126 students to date. David was a revered mentor to scores of students and lawyers, as well as family members and friends. David was renowned for his quick wit, infectious sense of fun, and generous soul, all of which were in full force until his final hours. David is survived by his wife of nearly 45 years, Rosemarie Duffy Siegel, and two daughters, Sheela Clary of West Stockbridge and Rachel Siegel of Great Barrington. His five grandchildren, Cecelia, Fiona, George, Donal and Patrick were the lights of his later life. He was predeceased by his father, Harry Siegel, in 1976, and his mother, Ida Scharaga Siegel, in 1980. An interfaith memorial service will be held at St. James Church in Chatham, NY, at 1pm on October 19th. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Albany Law School Law Review, in Memory of Professor David D. Siegel.

ROSENTHAL--Dr. Alfred E. M.D.,94, of Bayonne, NJ, died peacefully at home on October 11, 2014. Born in the Bronx, he lived the remainder of his life in Bayonne after moving there at the age of six. Alfred graduated from Bayonne High School at the age of 16, Johns Hopkins University in 1940 and NYU Medical School in 1944. He served as a Lieutenant in the Navy in World War II and the Korean War. He established a practice in internal medicine and cardiology in Bayonne from which he served the community for more than forty years. He was president of the medical staff at Bayonne Hospital and served as a clinical professor. Alfred served as President of the Bayonne Jewish Community Center and the Bayonne Mental Health Center and headed Bayonne's United Jewish Appeal. He remained active and engaged in the community his whole life, enjoying, along with his wife Ethel, fine restaurants, the Metropolitan Opera, the Philharmonic, the New York City Ballet and concerts at Tanglewood near his home in Lenox. He also embraced current culture, joining Facebook and watching the Daily Show in his nineties. Alfred was predeceased by his parents Emma and Louis Rosenthal, his brother Herbert and loving wife of more than fifty nine years, Ethel (nee Preminger). He is survived by his daughters Lynn Rosenthal (Herb Fineburg), and Cathy Frankel (Marc) and son David Rosenthal (Leslie) and six adoring grandchildren, Clare and Miles Fineburg, James and Elise Rosenthal, and Jeremy and Lucas Frankel. Donations may be made to CurePSP, the American Macular Degeneration Foundation and the Bayonne Jewish Community Center. 1-866-473-3700 for information.
ROSE--James P.,passed peacefully in New York City on September 30. He brought great pleasure to friends around the world. www.applebee-mcphillips.com for memorial information.

RAFIELD--Eileen Nagel, passed away peacefully at her home in Manhattan on Tuesday, October 7, 2014, at age 81, after a long and debilitating illness. After almost 30 years of a loving marriage, Eileen and her husband, Philip I. Rafield, became ill at the same time and she followed him in death by 16 months. Eileen was born in New York City on March 25, 1933 to Dorothy Nagel. After her husband's death, Dorothy married Sidney Morenstein and, after Dorothy's death, Sidney married Sarah Ain. Eileen adored her step-parents and they adored her. Eileen attended the University of Michigan for her bachelor's degree. She spent most of her 40+ year career (from 1958-1997) as Director of Human Resources at Jewish Child Care Association of New York where she established herself as a knowledgeable and hardworking professional. For the fifteen years before she retired from JCCA she served as second in command, as Associate Executive Director of the Agency. She was in the forefront of women's entry into executive level positions in non-profit organizations. Eileen worked closely with UJA Federation and received that agency's awards for her community service. During her time at JCCA, she attended the Wurtzweiler School of Social Work and obtained an MSW in social work administration. Eileen was known as a no-nonsense role model and mentor of the younger social workers interested in moving into administration. She was admired for her executive style, as well as her compassion, commitment and advocacy for the agency's clients. She was seen as very smart and fair-minded. On a personal level, she loved spending time with her many friends and shared fun outings and cultural events with them. Eileen was always well dressed and groomed. She was a role model for high-end fashion, loved shopping for a bargain, always chic and professional. Throughout her life Eileen was a true New Yorker and avid patron of the arts. She loved the New York Public Library, was a voracious reader of the books in its circulating library, and attended its lectures and exhibits. She loved the opera, ballet, theatre, dance, the Philharmonic, art galleries and museums. Eileen's love of everything life had to offer, her graciousness and determination defined her character. She was married in 1984. Her husband was a Navy Korean War veteran, an engineer and computer consultant who shared Eileen's love of history, reading and the arts. In his late 70's, Phil was awarded his second Master's Degree, in archaeology and subsequently was engaged to research and write a paper by the U.S. National Park Service, Department of the Interior, on artifacts found on Ellis Island and the Island's very early history. After her retirement in 1997, Eileen attended the New School's Institute for Retired Professionals and reveled in history courses, particularly those pertaining to Russian History and the Civil War. Eileen is survived by a close cousin, Martha Morenstein, and several close friends. A graveside service will be 11am today October 12th at Westchester Hills Cemetery, 400 Saw Mill River Road, Hastings-on-Hudson, New York. Donations may be made to The New York Public Library or to breast or ovarian cancer charities.

PROFFITT--Ruth S. 84, died on October 6. Beloved daughter of Ruth and Charles Proffitt. A graduate of The Chapin School in 1947 and Vassar College in 1951. Following service in the Central Intelligence Agency, Miss Proffitt joined the faculty and administration of The Chapin School for 46 years, where she taught mathematics in the middle school, was Head of Lower School, Head of Middle School, and Assistant Head Mistress. Her heart, which never left her fourth-grade mathematics classroom, was always filled with pride when she met her former students, who were more than ready to tell her about the exciting things they were doing. Upon her retirement in 1999 she continued to serve the school on the Alumnae Board. Ruthie Proffitt was a loyal Mets fan. She will be missed by family, friends, and generations of former students. Service at St. James Church, 71st and Madison Avenue at 3pm on Thursday, November 6. Memorial contributions may be made to The Chapin School, 100 East End Avenue, NYC, NY 10028.

PEYSER--Peter A.,former Member of Congress from Westchester, Rockland and The Bronx and former Mayor of Irvington, died on October 9 at his home in Irvington. He was 93 years old. Mr. Peyser was first elected to Congress in 1970 as a Republican. He filled the vacancy left by Richard L. Ottinger (D), who left his House seat to pursue a run for the Senate. In 1972, Peyser fought off Ottinger's comeback attempt in one of the most hard-fought House elections of its time in New York. When Ottinger returned to Congress in 1974 from a neighboring district, the two became close collaborators on behalf of Westchester. In 1976, Peyser attempted to unseat Senator James L. Buckley (C) in a statewide GOP primary. His quixotic campaign ended in defeat. In 1977, Peyser announced he had become a Democrat. In 1978, he ran for his old congressional seat as a Democrat and won. He was re-elected in 1980. In 1982, redistricting eliminated his seat and forced him to run against popular Congressman Ben Gilman (R) in a district highly favorable to Gilman. Mr. Gilman won that race and Peyser departed the Congress on January 3, 1983. During his decades of public service, he always focused on trying to make government work for people. Quality education and good, family wage jobs were issues to which he applied his abundant energy. In addition to his service in Congress from 1971-1977 and 1979-1983 and as Irvington Mayor from 1962-1970, Mr. Peyser served as President of the Irvington PTA, on the Board of Trustees of his beloved Colgate University, on the Vestry of St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Irvington and on the Board of Trustees of Children's Village. Mr. Peyser was born in Cedarhurst, Long Island on September 7, 1921. He graduated from the Dwight School in Manhattan and went on to Colgate University. He was in the class of 1943, but his class accelerated their studies so they could graduate in December of 1942 and enter the armed forces. He served in the Army infantry in World War II and saw action in major European theater battles such as the Battle of the Bulge, Hurtgen Forest, Remagen Bridge engagement and others. After returning home, he served in the National Guard as a Captain in the 7th Regiment. Mr. Peyser worked in the insurance industry after the war, eventually running his own agency of the Mutual of New York company. When his congressional career ended in 1983, he started a new career in the financial sector and at the end of his life was still working for the Gabelli Asset Management Company. He and the Peyser family have been most grateful to the company's founder Mario Gabelli for his support and friendship. Mr. Peyser is survived by his wife of 64 years, the former Marguerite Richards and his five children: Penny of Woodland Hills, CA; Safi Abheeti of Novato, CA; Peter of New York City; Jim of Milton, MA, and Tom of Richmond, VA. All of the Peyser children graduated from Irvington High School. He is also survived by five grandchildren. His passing leaves a void for all of his family that can never be filled. The public is invited to a viewing on Sunday, October 12 from 2pm to 5pm at the Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home in Dobbs Ferry, NY and to the funeral service on Monday, October 13 at 3pm at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Irvington, NY. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers or other gifts, the family asks that donations be made in Mr. Peyser's name to the International Rescue Committee www.rescue.org or to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research: www.michaeljfox.org

PALATINUS--John. It is with great sadness that the Palatinus Trust announces the death of John Palatinus on September 22, 2014 after a brief illness. An iconic pioneer in the field of male physique photography from the 1950's, designer, stylist, raconteur, and major supporter of the dance, John will be profoundly missed by his family and friends. In recognition of his tireless efforts on behalf of LGBTQ rights, he was awarded the Stonewall Lifetime Achievement Award in 2011. John was pre-deceased by his life partner of 48 years, Jack Alexander. At John's request, there will be no formal memorial services. Gifts in his memory can be made to his beloved American Ballet Theatre: https://support.abt.org/johnpalatinus. Or gifts can also be sent to: American Ballet Theatre c/o Major Gifts 890 Broadway, FL 3, New York, NY 10003. Please include "in memory of John Palatinus" in the memo section. For gift questions contact the ABT at Majorgifts@abt.org or (212) 477-3030 ext 1108.

O'CONNELL--James B.,of Darien, CT, died October 1 at Stamford Hospital. Born May 7, 1923, in Cambridge, Massachusetts, the eighth of nine children of William H. O'Connell and Catherine T. O'Connell. He was a writer, editor, executive, singer and world traveler. He is survived by his loving wife of 36 years, Beatrix W. O'Connell; son James W. O'Connell; son Andrew O'Connell and daughter-in-law Sharon A. Levine and their daughters Molly O'Connell and Jenny O'Connell; son Patrick M. O'Connell and daughter-in-law Maggie Baird and their son Finneas O'Connell and daughter Billie O'Connell; stepson Timothy B. Yarrow and his wife Elizabeth Raven Walters and their daughter Camille Yarrow and son Garrett Yarrow; stepdaughter Suzanne E. Yarrow and her son Andrew Yarrow-Escaladas; and brother Paul E. O'Connell. His first marriage was to Jean S. O'Connell, who died in 1975. He was a 1944 graduate of Harvard, served in the U.S. Army Signal Corps in China, edited several magazines in New York, and was an executive at IBM for 27 years, serving as director of public affairs. He lived in Westport, CT, from 1954 through 1978. Donations may be made via the Jim O'Connell tribute page on the Alzheimer's Association website. Memorial service: Temple Ohabei Shalom, 1187 Beacon Street, Brookline, MA, at 3pm, Sunday, October 19.

MEAD--Ruth Flint Fitchet, age 89, died October 6, 2014 at Harvest Hill Retirement Center in Lebanon, New Hampshire. The daughter of Roger Flint and Alice Lauterbach Flint of Newton Centre, Massachusetts, she was a nationally ranked junior pairs figure skater who represented The Skating Club of Boston. A graduate of the Chapel Hill School in Waltham, Massachusetts and a member of the class of 1946 at Wellesley College, she married Duncan Maclellan Fitchet of Newton in 1945. During their 47 year marriage they lived in Great Neck, New York, Wellesley Hills, Massachusetts and Winnetka, Illinois before retiring to Etna, New Hampshire. She later married Edwin Chester Mead of Hanover, New Hampshire who predeceased her in 2010. An intrepid traveler, gardener, animal lover and sports enthusiast, she was an active volunteer for several organizations during her lifetime. She leaves behind her daughter Lynn Fitchet Filipski (Mark) of New York City; her grandchildren Russell Gates Filipski of New York City, Sarah Barnes Filipski of Winston-Salem, North Carolina and Margaret Maclellan Fitchet; and four nieces. Her son Duncan Maclellan Fitchet Jr. (Jane) of Etna, New Hampshire predeceased her in September 2014. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in her name can be made to the Upper Valley Humane Society, 300 Old Route 10, Enfield, NH 03748.

MANSFIELD--Thomas. Trevor Day School shares heartfelt condolences. The Headmaster of The Day School from '65-'78, Tom was a founding father of our school, and a true visionary behind all that is at our core. He will be missed. Sally Rocker, Board President Scott Reisinger, Head of School

LOIGMAN--Mark D.,M.D.., 49, died October 10, 2014, in Greenwich, CT. A resident of Larchmont, NY, he is survived by his wife, Andrea Glenn Loigman, his children, Vivienne Hope Glenn Loigman and Georgia Glenn Loigman, his parents, Dr. Barry and Mrs. Carol Loigman, brother, Robert S. Loigman, and sister-in-law Lynda Loigman, by his sister-in-law Elissa Zodicoff, his brother-in-law Howard Zodicoff, and his inlaws, Rhoda and Brian Glenn. He grew up in North Caldwell, NJ, graduated from West Essex High School, Class of 1984, received his undergraduate degree from the University of Pennsylvania, class of 1988, received his medical degree from Albert Einstein College of Medicine in 1995 and received his M.B.A. from the Zicklin School of Business at Baruch College in 2004. He worked in private practice as a psychiatrist in New York City. Funeral service to be held at Larchmont Temple in Larchmont, NY on Sunday, October 12, 2014 at 11am. Family and friends welcome. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Greenwich Hospital Development Office, Attention: Jim Wright, for Greenwich Hospital Palliative Care Services, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT 06830.

LESLIE--Catherine McIntire, died on October 5 at her home of 19 years in Fox Hill Village in Westwood, MA. Affectionately known as "Mackie," she was 96 years old. She led a full and wonderful life raising her family in Englewood, NJ, summering on Fishers Island, NY, traveling extensively, and participating in numerous educational, civic, and historical organizations. Mackie was predeceased by her second husband of 27 years, banker George Robert Leslie. She is survived by her children H. Ashley Smith, Jr. of Lenox, MA; Catherine S. Leonard of Simsbury, CT; Patricia S. Perron of Parker, CO; and William T.M. Smith of Londonderry, VT, 10 grandchildren and 16 great-grandchildren. She was dearly loved by her family and many friends. She will be remembered for her insight and incredible zest for life.

KOPLIK--Marilyn S.,81, died peacefully after a long illness on October 1, 2014. Fearrington Village, NC; formerly of Lakeridge, CT; and Roslyn, NY. Born July 9, 1933, Brooklyn, NY to Frank and Bella Stein. Survived by her daughter, Caryn B. Koplik; brother and sister-in-law, Alan and Shelly Stein; nephews and their families, Captain (US Navy) Lawrence J., Robin, and Ariel Stein; David and Heather Stein, and Alex Dalpe; and nieces (nee Haber) and their families; Linda Drucker, Sharon Pasternack, Carol Zimmerman, and Ellen Lerman. Her son, Richard T. Koplik, died in April, 1992. Husbands, Herbert S. Koplik and A. Stuart Hanellin predeceased her. Graduated Brooklyn College ('54), magna cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa; NYU Graduate School of Public Administration ('55) MPA with distinction; C.W. Post College, Palmer Graduate School of Library Science ('72) MLS. In 1988, retired from Sachem Public Library, after eighteen years as a reference librarian. In 1998, retired from NY Institute of Technology, as director of four branch libraries. The family extends a special thank you to the staff of Hillcrest Convalescent Center, Durham, NC for the wonderful care and kindness shown to Mrs. Koplik. We also thank Beth Rickman, CNA for her consistent and careful attention, gracious spirit, and good cheer. A celebration of Marilyn's life -- The Gathering Place, Fearrington Village, 3pm, Friday, October 17th. Donations may be made at www.donorschoose.org/In-Memory-of-Marilyn-S.-KoplikHall-Wynne Griffin Chapel is serving the family.

KOLBRENER--Barbara, died Wednesday October 8 in her sleep. She was 76 years old. Barbara was born to Abraham and Anna Blumstein in 1938 and grew up in Forest Hills, Queens. Barbara attended Skidmore and Finch Colleges, graduating with distinction from Finch. She married Jack Kolbrener in 1960 and together had three children William, Meri, and Michael. Barbara then received a Masters Degree in Special Education from Hofstra University and taught for over thirty years at Harbor Hill Elementary School in the Roslyn School District. She was a beloved teacher who dedicated her career to advocating on behalf of children with special needs. Barbara taught students in both the Public School and as a private tutor. She had a gift for helping the hard to reach and hard to teach. She is survived by her husband, three children, thirteen grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. Funeral will be held on October 12, 2014 at 11:30am at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffers Memorial Chapel in Forest Hills, Queens. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Barbara's memory to Reading is Fundamental - www.rif.org. Please list Barbara@Kolbrener.com as the Honoree email address.

KOKICH--Iva Withers, on October 7th, 2014. Loving mother and grandmother. Service 2pm, October 23rd, St. Thomas Church, 1 West 53rd St, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Actors' Fund Homes, 155-175 W. Hudson Avenue, Englewood, NJ 07631.

KAHN--Marion, of Manhasset NY, lost her battle with Pancreatic Cancer on October 11, 2014. Loving wife of Elliott, caring mother of Stephen (Brigitte) and Jeffrey, adoring Grammie to Martine, Andrew, Sydney, Robert, James, and Gracie. She fought the good fight and will be missed by all who knew her. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations please be made to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research.

HOLCOMB--Anne, on October 9 2014. Beloved wife of the late John, loving mother of Russell and the late John and Susan Guimaraes. Mother-in-law of Jeanne and Mary Beth. Grandmother of eight great grandmother of 10. Dear friend of Ann Powell and Dorothy Bhola. Employed at Merrill Lynch 1961 to 1994. Viewing at The John J. McManus Funeral Home 4601 Avenue N Brooklyn, Sunday and Monday 2-4pm and 7-9pm Funeral Mass Tuesday at 9:30am at St Thomas Aquinas RC Church Burial to follow at St John's Cemetery.

GOURARY--Marianne. In the late afternoon of Thursday, October 2nd, Marianne Gourary died at age 93 in her Manhattan home. Marianne and her twin brother were born in Munich, Germany in 1920. Marianne and her brother witnessed Hitler and the early stages of Nazism rising in Germany. Their parents, Ernst and Marta Wilmersdoerffer, died of illness in 1929 and 1931. Marianne's brother went to England and Marianne was sent to the International School of Geneva. After graduating in 1941, she attended the University of Geneva, studying biology. She left before completing her studies to marry Orazio Frugoni and after a few more years in Europe, they both immigrated to New York in 1949. Friends have described Marianne as a force of nature. When she was a young woman in Switzerland, her nickname was "La Bise," the fierce wind that blows off Lake Geneva. Her comments could be acerbic, and her observations astute. She spoke her mind and the truth as she saw it. She also won many people over with her charm, intelligence, elegance and concern. She had many friends who were very important to her. She was a most considerate traveler and guest. Marianne always appreciated beauty. She loved classical music and opera and attended many cultural events. At home the radio was always on with classical music. She and her second husband, Paul Gourary, created a beautiful home in Manhattan that was filled with art and books where she hosted many fine dinners for friends. Marianne spent many summers in Provincetown where she loved to take a daily swim in the bay. Time spent there with family and friends was a source of joy and relaxation. She was a resolute and devoted mother who was very proud of her daughter Corinne and her son John. She had a strong affection for cats and especially appreciated their company during the later years of her life. She was curious, researching and collecting books on many subjects. She was proud to be a citizen of the United States, a Democrat and a New Yorker. As she weakened during the last year of her life, she found great pleasure in the beauty of the trees and flowers in Central Park. Marianne leaves behind her daughter, Corinne Frugoni, her son John Gourary, his wife and children, Jennifer, Justin and Julia, her sister-in-law and nephew and nieces in England, June Wilmers, Peter Wilmers, Catherine Wilmers and Brigit Wilmers, their partners, Carol, Graham, David, along with their children and childrens' children. She was preceded in death by her twin brother, John Wilmers, her first husband, Orazio Frugoni, her second husband, Paul Gourary, her first cousin Eugen Merzbacher and her nephew's son, Harry Wilmers. Gratitude is expressed to the people who enabled Marianne to live comfortably and safely in her home including Stella, Karen Glasser, the staff of 45 East 85th Street and the VNA Hospice. Donations may be sent to The Humane Society of New York City, Bide-A-Wee Pet Welfare Organization or Marianne's favorite radio station WQXR.

GOLDMAN--Ralph. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Ralph Goldman. Goldman served as the Executive Vice President of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) for 11 years, and helped orchestrate reentry into most of Eastern Europe, seizing every opportunity to revitalize Jewish life. He inspired many with his dedication to international Jewish communal service. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children, Judy and Yaakov, Naomi, and Elisa, and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

GOLDMAN--Lucille. Lucille Goldman, nee Goldberg, was born on February 12, 1926 and died on October 6, 2014 at her home in Madison, CT. She died as she lived, on her own terms. She was a forward-thinking, dignified, and beautiful woman with a wicked sense of humor. Harry and Helen Goldberg raised Lucille and her loving sister, Cynthia, in Brooklyn, NY. Lucille attended Midwood High School and New York University. For 40 years she was a loving wife to Saul Goldman who predeceased her by nine years. Her children, Donna Meryl Kenton, of Manhattan, NY, and Gary Scott Kenton, of Rhinebeck, NY, her daughter-in-law Laura R. Linder, and her grandson, Malcolm Mullin Kenton, will miss her deeply, as will her nephews, Stephen, Richard, and James Carr and their families, of Phoenix, AZ.

Golden--Gloria Ehrenthal, 89, October 10, 2014. A "word person," Gloria spent most of her career with Woman's Day Magazine. She was predeceased by her husband of 62 years, Jerome C. Golden, and is survived by children David (Harriet), Nancy (Nel), and Bill (Drew), four grandchildren, sister Barbara Ehrenthal, and brother Robert (Pauline) Ehrenthal and many friends, in New York and Florida.

GERMAIN--Shelia, nee Kettle. Loving wife of the late Lawrence. Devoted sister of Eileen Lynch of Bailieboro County, Cavin, Ireland. Also survived by many nieces and nephews of the Germain, Lynch and Kettle families. Visiting Hours: Tuesday, 2pm-4pm and 7pm-9pm at Plaza Memorial Chapel at 91 Street. Interment: Wednesday at Westchester Hills Cemetery. For service location call 212-769-4400.

GAUBATZ--Kathryn Ball, December 14, 1941, passed away on Friday. She was predeceased by the loves of her life; husband John, and son Daniel. She was a lover of education, travel, art, tropical plants, and Early Music. Her passion was The Miami Bach Society. She is survived by her sisters Judith Ball of Pompton Lakes, NJ and Jancy Ball of Syracuse, NY and by scores of loving friends, family and countless musicians all over the world, who were touched by her graciousness and generosity of spirit.

FRANCO--Patricia L.,of Chestnut Park, Brighton, MA, formerly of Denver, CO passed away peacefully on October 4, 2014. Patricia was married to Frank Franco (deceased) for 67 years and together they had children James (Ellen) of Brookline, MA, Esther (deceased) (Charles Hinkle), Emily of Denver, Thomas (Allison) of Brooklyn, NY, Paul (Jill) of Brunswick, ME, Joseph (Brenda) of Newton, MA. Loving grandchildren; Benjamin, Matthew, Brett Stineman; Patrick, Nicholas, Julian, Grace, Clare, Sam, Patricia, Peter, Sophia, and great-grandchild Audrey Esther Stineman. Patricia completed high school in Greeley, NE and was a graduate of St. Mary of the Woods College and received her Master's Degree in Social work from the University of Nebraska. She was beloved by all and retained her cheerful, calm and accepting disposition to the end. Services will be held at Christ the King Church, Denver, October 11, 2014. Services through Archdiocese of Denver Mortuary, www.archdenmort.org.

EDELMAN--Judith, died suddenly at age 91 on October 4. Architect and community activist. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Marc and Alexandra Neuber and Joshua and Cristina Santolaria, sister and sister-in-law of Joan and Benjamin Gitlow, grandmother of Gabriel, Daniel, Sarah, Benjamin, Oskar, Ander, Julen and David, great-grandmother of Kyla and Leo. In lieu of flowers, donations to Housing Works. There will be no funeral. A memorial gathering will be announced.

DOUGLAS--Lewis W. Jr.,90, passed away at his Denver home surrounded by family on October 4, 2014. Pete was born to Lewis Williams Douglas and Peggy Zinsser Douglas in New York City on June 13, 1924. Raised between Arizona and New York, he graduated from Yale University in 1948 after serving as an officer in the United States Air Force in the capacity of Navigator-Bombardier during WWII. Mr. Douglas was President of the Christiana Oil Corporation from 1953 to 1964. In 1964, Pete formed privately held real estate development firm, Douglas Development, but reentered the energy business founding Stanley Energy in 1985. Unwilling to retire, both intellectually and physically, Pete remained active, involved and engaged until his death. He was a dedicated philanthropist and active member of his community, offering his time as a trustee to multiple schools, director of hospitals, and also serving on the Governing Board of HealthOne. Mr. Douglas served as a Commissioner of the Advisory Commission on Public Diplomacy in President George H.W. Bush's administration. Pete was especially committed to the First American Corporation where he was a director from 1961 to 2013. An avid lover of the arts, Pete received the Mary Belle Grant Award in 2006, an honor he cherished. However, his greatest passions were his family and friends with whom he built lasting connections, based on humility, compassion, and humor. He laughed loud and often with all he met. Pete recently celebrated his 36th wedding anniversary with his devoted wife, Melinda Stanley Douglas of Chicago by whom he is survived. His legacy lives on through his three adoring children: Lewis W. Douglas III, Jesse Douglas and Justin S. Douglas, and his five grandchildren. Memorial service will be held in Pete's honor Monday, October 13, at 3:30pm in Saint John's Cathedral, 1350 Washington Street, Denver, CO 80203. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the church.

DILLON--Celia, 97, died peacefully October 5 at home in Great Neck. Beloved wife of Milton survived by son Donald, daughters-in-law Phyllis and Louse, grandchildren Alex, Sam and Hannah and granddaughter-in-law Laura. A private ceremony is planned. In lieu of flowers contributions to favored charities are suggested.

DEUTSCH--Irwin F.,82, died September 8th after a prolonged illness. Mr Deutsch attended the University of Paris, graduated from Amherst College and received his law degree from Columbia University in 1957. He was legal assistant to Senator Herbert Lehman, SEC attorney, Assistant council to the Comptroller of Currency and a partner in Upham, Meeker, & Weithorn, New York City from 1962-76. A resident of Florida, Mr. Deutsch was a member of the Palm Beach Civic Association and the Metropolitan Club. He is survived by his beloved wife Ingrid R. Deutsch.

DENEBRINK--Joyce Ann, passed away July 30, 2014 at her San Francisco apartment. She requested that no services be held and her ashes be scattered in New York, Hawaii, and Paris. Born July 28, 1936, the daughter of Fannie McCook Denebrink and Vice Admiral Francis Compton Denebrink, Joyce graduated from Punahou School in 1954 and Stanford University in 1958. Joyce pursued her interests in writing, publishing, and design both in New York and San Francisco. Always a critical, thoughtful, and independent thinker, Joyce was intelligent and well informed, avidly reading the Sunday New York Times every weekend. She chose her friends with care and rewarded them with loyalty, generosity, and compassionate concern for their well being. No one selected gifts more thoughtfully and presented them more beautifully. She received the kindness of others with modesty, gratitude, and grace. Joyce displayed courage and resolve throughout an extended illness. In the years preceding her death, she was especially grateful for the support of Sam and Sophia Kats, Kenneth Albrecht, Robert Sass, and Andrea Rechtin and Bruce Johnston. She is survived by relatives and many friends on the East and West Coasts.

DAVIDOWITZ--Edward. Though you were our cousin, we really felt that you were our brother. For more than 50 years you brought joy, laughter, wisdom and beautiful friendship into our lives. You were so very special to us. Don and Judy

DAVIDOWITZ--Honorable Edward. The Board of Directors and the members of Quaker Ridge Golf Club are saddened by the passing of our beloved and esteemed member of more than 42 years, Honorable Edward Davidowitz. Ever the consummate gentleman, his presence will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Ellen and his entire family in their time of sorrow. Marc Friedman, President
DAVIDOWITZ--The Honorable Edward. Kind, generous, courageous, insightful. Friend of 50 years. Our life will not be the same without you. Much Love, Jane and Steve

DAVIDOWITZ--The Honorable Edward M.,81, retired Justice of The Supreme Court of The State of New York, passed away after a long illness on October 10, 2014. He lived a life dedicated to family, friends and the law. Ed was a graduate of the Ethical Culture School, Fieldston, Allegheny College and Cornell Law School. He also served as a Lieutenant in the United States Air Force. He began his career in law as an Assistant District Attorney under Frank Hogan. After a brief time in private practice, Ed returned to public service as a Special Assistant Attorney General in The New York State Special Prosecutor's Office. In 1985 he was appointed to the Bronx Supreme Court as an Acting Supreme Court Justice of the Court of Claims, and ultimately appointed Justice of the Supreme Court of the State of New York. Upon retirement, he continued working in the Bronx Supreme Court as a Judicial Hearing Officer. He was also honored to serve as Co-chair of the New York Tribal Courts Committee whose mission is to foster an understanding and improve cooperation between the Tribal and State justice systems. Ed loved helping young Assistant District Attorneys and Defense Lawyers become the best lawyers possible. Both always wanted to try cases before him and looked forward to his willingness to mentor. His passion for law and teaching led him to co-author a book on the practice of criminal law: Foundation Evidence, Questions and Courtroom Protocols. He also wrote The Practice of Criminal Law under the CPLR and Related Civil Procedure Statutes. He was a member of the New York State and City Bar Associations. He also was a board member of Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, NY and a member of Quaker Ridge Golf Club in Scarsdale, NY. Ed was a kind, generous, gentle and fair person beloved by many. Family was paramount in his life, and he leaves behind a loving wife, Ellen, of fifty three years, three sons; James (Laurie), Robert (Cheryl Bennett) and John, along with five cherished grandchildren; Cleo, Jonas, Tess, Adler and Edison. Nothing gave Edward greater joy than time spent with his family. Funeral services will be held at Westchester Reform Temple on Monday, October 13, 2014, 11am at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Leukemia Fighters c/o of Dr. Ellen K. Ritchie, 520 East 70th Street, Box 403, New York NY 10021.

DANES--Elizabeth "Lisa" G. of New York City passed away earlier this year at her family home in Albany, NY. Born October 14, 1968, she was the daughter of George C. Danes (Sophia Socaris) and Margaret Lazarou Danes. She is survived by brothers Stratton (Elizabeth), Christopher (Jessica), nieces and nephews Alexander, Emma, George S., George J, William, and Charlotte. She was Godmother to George S., Charlotte, Zephyros Shah, Massimo and Alessandro Lecavalier, and Elizabeth "BJ" Lazarou. Elizabeth graduated cum laude from the Georgetown University School of Foreign Service with a degree in international politics. She was a Rotary Scholar at the University of Strasbourg in France and then continued graduate work at the College of Europe in Bruges. She began her career at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development in London as a consultant to start-up companies in Eastern Europe and Russia. She then progressed to Foreign & Colonial Investment Trust; was a principal at Capital Z Investment Partners; a partner in MVision Private Equity Advisers; and, in 2011, founded her own investment firm, Urbane Point. Through her extensive travels around the world, Elizabeth developed strong networking ties and close friendships. Her friends remember Elizabeth as a mentor who nurtured and celebrated their successes, both in their personal lives and in their careers. She was well-known for her generosity and delighted in selecting unique and elaborate gifts. She had an adventurous spirit, was passionate about the outdoors and hiking, spiritual disciplines, yoga and pilates, travel, fine foods, and her Irish Jack Russell terrier, Mandala. Elizabeth managed and researched her decade-long confrontation with cancer with tenacity and determination. She served as a board member of the Young Survival Coalition offering knowledge and support to other young women diagnosed with breast cancer. Her ashes will be scattered at Martha's Vineyard where a memorial bench has been erected overlooking the Vineyard Sound and the Elizabeth Islands. A private celebration of her life will be held in New York to honor her birthday and her incredible life's journey. Donations in her name may be made to NYU Langone Medical Center at: giving.nyumc.org/ci or by mail to NYULMC Office of Development, One Park Ave., 17th Floor, NYC, NY 10016.

CARSWELL--Lois Passed suddenly on October 8, 2014. Lois Carswell, nee Malakoff, was committed to the Brooklyn community she loved. Her decades-long career at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden began as a volunteer in the Women's Auxiliary. She was elected a trustee in 1985 and ultimately retired as Chairman Emeritus after leading the Garden from 1989-98. Her true passion was the annual plant sale, which she co-chaired for over 40 years, even after retirement, with her good friend Lucille Plotz. Lois also founded the Coalition of Living Museums in 1980 to facilitate funding for a broad range of statewide cultural institutions. Her sharp intellect (Radcliffe '53) and dogged determination were key assets in all aspects of her life, from the boardroom to the tennis court and bridge table, where she was a master. Lois treasured family summers at the lake in Magog, Quebec, and walks with her black Standard Schnauzer. She was patient and loving, a loyal friend and a devoted mother. Predeceased by Donald, her husband of 48 years, Lois is survived by her children Anne, Alex and Bob, as well as grandchildren Phillip, Tom, Julia and James, all of whom will miss her immeasurably. A celebration of her life will be held at the BBG at a future date.

BUZIO--Lidya. Artist and ceramist, died of cancer on September 30, 2014 at her Greenport, Long Island home at age 65. Buzio's work was widely acclaimed in the ceramics field and was seen in major museum exhibitions across the country. Inspired by the buildings and skyline of lower Manhattan, her most noted ceramic vessels combining cylinders, cones, and hemispheres twist and juxtapose the rooflines, architectural details, and water towers of the city into a magical panorama that captures the urban scene. Born in Uruguay, in 1948, she studied with artists of the Taller Torres-Garcia in Montevideo. Buzio moved to New York City in 1971. In the 1990s, she moved to the North Fork of Long Island. Buzio's ceramics are in the Brooklyn Museum, Museum of Fine Arts Houston, the Smithsonian National Museum of American Art in Washington, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, the Fine Arts Museum of San Francisco, the Nelson-Atkins Museum, the Everson Museum, the Victoria & Albert in London, many other museums and private collections. She is survived by her sister, Cecilia de Torres, her brothers Carlos and Julio Buzio, her husband Dan Pollock, and numerous cousins, nieces and nephews.

BROWN--Peter M.,92, died on September 25. He was a former Assistant US Attorney and head litigator at Cadwalader, Wickersham, and Taft. He is survived by his wife Alexandra Stoddard, his sister Mrs. Charles P. Stetson, four children, and four step children. A memorial service will be held at The Church of the Heavenly Rest on October 18 at 5pm.

BOUTWELL--Jane P.,age 86, who was born in Washington, DC but lived her adult life in New York City, died October 3, 2014 in Springfield, VA, shortly after moving from her home in Brooklyn Heights. She suffered from dementia. Her parents were William D. and Olga H. Boutwell. Jane graduated from Western High School in Washington, DC and then went to the University of Wisconsin-Madison where she received her BA in history. Her first job was with Henry Luce's "The March of Time." She then entered the Foreign Service and was posted to Italy for four years. In 1961, she started work at The New Yorker Magazine where she wrote for Talk of the Town and had a specialty in music, art and ballet. Jane is survived by a number of cousins and many friends. As she wished, Jane will be cremated and her ashes taken to her beloved Fire Island. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her name to the Metropolitan Opera. A memorial will be held starting at 5pm on November 15th.

BAUER--Dolores D'Amico, of Summerville, SC, formerly of Manhattan, passed away September 24, 2014. Dolores (Dodie) was born in Mahanoy City, PA. After High School, she traveled to New York to attend Nursing School. She settled there for her adult life, moving to South Carolina five years ago to live with her niece Marie (Joe) Rodgers and family. She was predeceased by her husband Robert F. Bauer and her brother Frank (Vivian) D'Amico. She is survived by two sisters in Pennsylvania along with many nieces and nephews. Interment will be in Pennsylvania. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to St. Jude's Children Hospital.

BARR--Howard Sheldon, 92, of New York City, on October 7, 2014. He was born on March 31, 1922, in Milwaukee, WI; the son of Frank and Mary Bahr. Mr. Barr began studying piano at an early age and spent long hours practicing and listening to music. He graduated from North Division High School and went on to the Juilliard School in New York City, which was interrupted by World War II. Mr. Barr served in the Army from 1942 to 1945, completing his Bachelor's Degree at Juilliard after the war. He went on to perform as a piano accompanist for a variety of opera singers and small ballet companies until he began work as a pianist for American Ballet Theater in the late 1960s. He became the principal pianist for ABT where he worked for over 40 years and was renowned in the ballet world. Mr. Barr also appeared as a pianist in the ballet-themed movie "The Turning Point." He is preceded in death by his brother Chester Bahr and is survived by his sisters Eileen Chudnow, Diane Lilly and Sherri Pincus; as well as numerous beloved nieces and nephews. Mr. Barr was an avid reader, opera lover and traveler. One of his favorite destinations throughout his years of travel with ABT was Japan. Graveside funeral services are being held in Milwaukee on Sunday, October 12. A memorial gathering in New York City will be held at a later date. Contributions in his memory preferred to American Ballet Theater, New York, NY or donor's favorite charity.

BARRETT--Loretta A.,one of America's outstanding editors, publishers and literary agents, died peacefully in Manhattan on Saturday morning, October 4th. Mass will be held at 10am on Tuesday, October 14, at The Church of St. Francis Xavier, 46th West 16th Street, NYC. A celebration of her life will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, Loretta wished that donations be made to Reading is Fundamental, P.O. Box 33728, Washington, DC 20033.

BARANGER--Michel, on October 1, 2014, at 87, in Tucson. Physicist, avid hiker, former resident of Boston. Survived by Martin, Harold (Meg Anderson), Anne Baranger (John Hartwig), four grandchildren. Memorial service in Tucson in December. More information at legacy.com.

BALSAM--Barbara Baron, 71, died unexpectedly after a brief bout with lung cancer on October 9, 2014. Born December 7, 1942, in Brooklyn, NY to Sydney and Sylvia Baron. Survived by her beloved husband, Michael, brothers Eric, Richard, and Daniel, and daughters Lisa Solinga (Steven) and Jennifer Hirsch (Steven); adoring Bubbe to her grandchildren Anna, Sarah, Lucy, and Noah. Barbara attended NYU and went on to a successful career in finance until her retirement in 2010. In retirement Barbara was an avid reader, enjoyed working at her synagogue thrift shop, seeing shows on Broadway, and frequent visits with her grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your local chapter of the National Alliance on Mental Illness. Family will be receiving visitors between the hours of 3pm to 7pm on Sunday and Monday at the home of Lisa and Steven Solinga in New Rochelle, NY.

ASHIDA--Margaret E. Age 58, Latham, NY and San Francisco, CA, passed suddenly on October 5th, 2014 while vacationing in Indonesia. Predeceased by her parents Dr. Sachio Ashida, PhD, and Dr. Margaret Elenore Elliott Ashida, PhD. Survived by sister Janet Yoshie Ashida Johnson (Don), and nephew Alan Genji Ashida Johnson, US aunts Jennie Bridge (Steve), Stephanie Keyes, and many relatives in Japan. For more information about her memorial service and contributions in her memory go to http://www.forevermissed. com/margaret-ashida.

ALPERN--Libbie (Roginsky), 99 next month, on October 6, 2014. A warm, funny, former Girl Singer on road and radio, later wed 70 years to the late Jerome, survived by son David, his wife Sylvia, many loving friends and relatives.

AIZER--Charles, died Monday, October 6, 2014, in New York City, from complications of pneumonia. Born Saleh Aizer, in 1925, the eighth of nine children of Hanina Abdullah and Shaul Aizer, in Baghdad, Iraq. With his late brother Naim, he established and operated a multi-national film distribution and exhibition company, and developed elegant theatres which became artistic and social centers in Baghdad. After seeing all his family members safely out of Iraq, he settled in New York from which he operated a chain of retail stores in medium size American cities. Charles was unfailingly gracious and kind, brilliant, perceptive, wise, and effortlessly good. He loved his family and friends, the United States of America, Arabic music, and Central Park. He is survived by his wife Rosemary, nee Duffy, daughter Anna, son Anthony, daughter-in-law-Juliet, son-in-law Pedro Dal Bo, grandchildren Manuel, Carlos and Luis Dal Bo, Oliver and Celia Aizer, and many nieces and nephews, all of whom, as well as his friends and acquaintances loved and were loved by him.
