SCHWESINGER--Kent Stanley, passed away quietly on the morning of February 28, 2012 in New York City. Kent was 64 years of age. Kent was born in Manila, Republic of the Philippines on April 15, 1948 to Edmund Arno Schwesinger Sr. and his beloved wife, Dora Helene Axthelm Schwesinger. Kent was the youngest of their four sons. He began his academic career as a kindergartner at the notable American School in Manila. He remained a part of the American School's expatriate student body for many years before leaving to study in America. He later returned to Manila in order to graduate with his fellow school mates at Abad Santos High School. Upon graduation, Kent returned to the United States to attend Maine Central Academy completing his studies in 1970. Kent went on to become a citizen of the United States and was a resident of New York City for over forty years. Throughout his career, Kent worked for three companies with headquarters in the City. With that said, Kent's heart was in helping those in need. He was an active member of St. Peter's Lutheran Church on Lexington Avenue and 53rd Street. And it was at St. Peter's, Kent found the labor he loved. Kent was a devoted and long-time volunteer in the church's kitchen where the homeless of NYC would come for their meals. He worked wholeheartedly with humility serving each individual with dignity and a quiet grace. He leaves behind a legacy of service. Kent was preceded in death by his parents - Edmund Schwesinger Sr., a major stockholder of Benguet Exploration Gold Mine in Baguio, Philippines and Dora Helene Axthelm Schwesinger, the daughter of the Mayor of Coburg, Germany and the owner of a major manufacturer of toys with offices in both London and Germany. He is survived by his elder brothers: Edmund Jr. of Greenwich, CT - retired partner of PricewaterhouseCoopers; Davis, of Pine City, NY worldwide air gun distributor; and Henry, of Naples, Florida a broker at Merrill Lynch. As well as two cousins, Wolfgang Eckstein, the retired head of the German Fashion Union and Winfried Eckstein, an investor in commodities both of Munich, Germany. His brothers, cousins, long-time sailing comrades at Indian Harbor Yacht Club in Greenwich, CT and countless members of the NYC homeless community will sorely miss him. A memorial service will be held at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Manhattan on October 16th at noon. Pastor Armadus Derr will personally officiate the service. After interment, participants are invited to join at a nearby restaurant for lunch. Cousins Fred Forster and Wolfgang Eckstein, are traveling from Germany to attend the service.

TRAVERS--Muriel, died peacefully at Weill-Cornell Medical Center on Saturday, October 11, 2014. 92 years of age, she was predeceased by her husband, Lester, after a marriage of 56 years. Ever the elegant woman, she will always be lovingly remembered by her daughter and son-in-law, Joan and Dr. William Schneider, her son and daughter-in-law, James and Francine Travers, her granddaughters and their spouses, Jessica and Danny Brown, and Jaclyn and Andrew Singer, and her great-grandchildren, Charlie and Ceiia Singer and Henry and George Brown. Contributions in her memory can be sent to Meals on Wheels.

PROFFITT--Ruth S. 84, died on October 6. Beloved daughter of Ruth and Charles Proffitt. A graduate of The Chapin School in 1947 and Vassar College in 1951. Following service in the Central Intelligence Agency, Miss Proffitt joined the faculty and administration of The Chapin School for 46 years, where she taught mathematics in the middle school, was Head of Lower School, Head of Middle School, and Assistant Head Mistress. Her heart, which never left her fourth-grade mathematics classroom, was always filled with pride when she met her former students, who were more than ready to tell her about the exciting things they were doing. Upon her retirement in 1999 she continued to serve the school on the Alumnae Board. Ruthie Proffitt was a loyal Mets fan. She will be missed by family, friends, and generations of former students. Service at St. James Church, 71st and Madison Avenue at 3pm on Thursday, November 6. Memorial contributions may be made to The Chapin School, 100 East End Avenue, NYC, NY 10028.

PISTRANG--Joseph, age 91, beloved husband for 68 years of Judy (Abramson), passed away on October 11, 2014 in Amherst, Massachusetts. Joe was born on February 28, 1923 in Brooklyn, New York. In addition to Judy, he is survived by his three children and their spouses: Betsy and son-in-law David Mullins, Nancy and son-in-law Chris Barker, and Jim and daughter-in-law Barbara. Additionally he is survived by six grandchildren, Dan, Debbie, David, Jessie, Michael, and Anna, and two great-grandchildren, Kira and Thalia. After service in the Navy in WWII, Joe became a professor of Civil Engineering at the City College of New York, where he worked on projects to improve the New York City highway system and was a dedicated and inspirational teacher for 42 years. Joe was a wonderful husband, father and grandparent, who was deeply loved and will be missed by all. Donations in Joe's name may be made to the Central Park Conservancy in New York City or to the Valley Light Opera in Amherst Massachusetts.

KOKICH--Iva Withers, on October 7th, 2014. Loving mother and grandmother. Service 2pm, October 23rd, St. Thomas Church, 1 West 53rd St, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Actors' Fund Homes, 155-175 W. Hudson Avenue, Englewood, NJ 07631.

KAHN--Marion. There's death, but first there's life. Marion lived life to the fullest and managed an unusual blend of stoicism and passion her last two years. She succumbed to a terrible adversity with grace, courage and dignity. She will not be totally gone. The magic of her presence will never fade for those who knew her. It is not what you gather but what you scatter in life, that tells a lot about you. Marion has scattered much into our hearts so there will always be a piece of her there. Those of us who saw her in the last few weeks were happy to say I love you and hear her say it back. I know for us it was enough. We will miss you, our dear friend. Carol and Arnold Wolowitz

INGBERG--Jean, our dear friend, wife of the late Bernard Ingberg passed away on Wednesday, October 8th, 2014. We deeply mourn the loss of this compassionate lady. Funeral services will be held at Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx, NY at 10:30am, on Tuesday, October 14, 2014. From Her Many Friends

KAHN--Marion, of Manhasset NY, lost her battle with Pancreatic Cancer on October 11, 2014. Loving wife of Elliott, caring mother of Stephen (Brigitte) and Jeffrey, adoring Grammie to Martine, Andrew, Sydney, Robert, James, and Gracie. She fought the good fight and will be missed by all who knew her. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations please be made to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research.

FOX--Cecile, died peacefully in her home on October 11, 2014 at the age of 91. She is predeceased by her husband, Herman Katz, her brother, Albert Fox and her parents, Harry and Lillian Fox. She is survived by many loving family members and friends. Funeral services will be held on Monday, October 13 at 11:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 West 76th Street, New York.

ETTINGER--Ann, on October 11, 2014. Predeceased by her husband Sidney, brother Jim, twin George, firstborn son Ike-and the Lower East Side gang. Survived by her son Bob Apfel and his wife Jill. Annie, you were so good and decent; everyone who knew you loved you and held you in high regard. We will miss you terribly. Service Wednesday, October 15, 3pm at "The Riverside", 76 St. at Amsterdam Ave.

DAVIDOWITZ--The Honorable Edward M. "Judgie". With heavy hearts we celebrate 50 years of friendship, trips abroad, Quaker Ridge, family events and countless rounds of golf together. We know you are at peace. See you down the road. Our Love Always, The Rittmasters

DAVIDOWITZ--Edward. Though you were our cousin, we really felt that you were our brother. For more than 50 years you brought joy, laughter, wisdom and beautiful friendship into our lives. You were so very special to us. Don and Judy
DAVIDOWITZ--The Honorable Edward. Kind, generous, courageous, insightful. Friend of 50 years. Our life will not be the same without you. Much Love, Jane and Steve

CARSWELL--Lois Passed suddenly on October 8, 2014. Lois Carswell, nee Malakoff, was committed to the Brooklyn community she loved. Her decades-long career at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden began as a volunteer in the Women's Auxiliary. She was elected a trustee in 1985 and ultimately retired as Chairman Emeritus after leading the Garden from 1989-98. Her true passion was the annual plant sale, which she co-chaired for over 40 years, even after retirement, with her good friend Lucille Plotz. Lois also founded the Coalition of Living Museums in 1980 to facilitate funding for a broad range of statewide cultural institutions. Her sharp intellect (Radcliffe '53) and dogged determination were key assets in all aspects of her life, from the boardroom to the tennis court and bridge table, where she was a master. Lois treasured family summers at the lake in Magog, Quebec, and walks with her black Standard Schnauzer. She was patient and loving, a loyal friend and a devoted mother. Predeceased by Donald, her husband of 48 years, Lois is survived by her children Anne, Alex and Bob, as well as grandchildren Phillip, Tom, Julia and James, all of whom will miss her immeasurably. A celebration of her life will be held at the BBG at a future date.

BURR--Samuel Ethan. August 9th, 1986 to October 10th, 2014. Sam died peacefully in his sleep on the morning of October 10th. His solar presence illuminated all those with whom he crossed paths. He was the treasured son of Howard Burr and Marguerite Shore, cherished brother of Daisy Burr, nephew of Christine Burr Correa, Randall and Mary Burr, Robin and James Smith, Alison and Richard Dundy, James and Beryl Shore, cousin of Andrew Correa, Kenneth, Dana and Jennifer Loiselle, Josephine Defusco, and Jacob and Madeline Shore. Sam was a graceful, inquisitive and insightful writer, moving songwriter and singer, and lover of animals and beauty in all forms. Family and friends may visit the Swan Funeral Home, 80 E. Main St., Clinton on Wednesday, October 15 from 3-6pm. There will be a private burial at Indian River Cemetery, Friday, October 17th 10am, and a memorial service and reception at Trinity Church, Wall Street, New York, NY, Saturday, October 18th 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Clinton Animal Control, 860-669-1777. For online condolences, please visit: www.swanfh.com.

SHEA--James K. On the first anniversary of James K. Shea's passing, his family remembers him lovingly and celebrates his life. Jim was born on February 21, 1933 in Baldwin, NY, and died on October 13, 2013, at age 80, in Stony Brook, NY. He was a Navy radioman, a skilled stereotyper for The New York Times for 32 years, and a vice president of the stereotypers' union. He also owned several businesses, including James K. Shea Real Estate in Smithtown, NY. He finished the Boston Marathon at age 46, and later competed with several Long Island senior league softball teams until he was 79. He is survived and terribly missed by his three children, eight grandchildren, three great-grandchildren, his sister, four brothers, and many other relatives and friends who loved him dearly.

SCHWESINGER--Kent Stanley, passed away quietly on the morning of February 28, 2012 in New York City. Kent was 64 years of age. Kent was born in Manila, Republic of the Philippines on April 15, 1948 to Edmund Arno Schwesinger Sr. and his beloved wife, Dora Helene Axthelm Schwesinger. Kent was the youngest of their four sons. He began his academic career as a kindergartner at the notable American School in Manila. He remained a part of the American School's expatriate student body for many years before leaving to study in America. He later returned to Manila in order to graduate with his fellow school mates at Abad Santos High School. Upon graduation, Kent returned to the United States to attend Maine Central Academy completing his studies in 1970. Kent went on to become a citizen of the United States and was a resident of New York City for over forty years. Throughout his career, Kent worked for three companies with headquarters in the City. With that said, Kent's heart was in helping those in need. He was an active member of St. Peter's Lutheran Church on Lexington Avenue and 53rd Street. And it was at St. Peter's, Kent found the labor he loved. Kent was a devoted and long-time volunteer in the church's kitchen where the homeless of NYC would come for their meals. He worked wholeheartedly with humility serving each individual with dignity and a quiet grace. He leaves behind a legacy of service. Kent was preceded in death by his parents - Edmund Schwesinger Sr., a major stockholder of Benguet Exploration Gold Mine in Baguio, Philippines and Dora Helene Axthelm Schwesinger, the daughter of the Mayor of Coburg, Germany and the owner of a major manufacturer of toys with offices in both London and Germany. He is survived by his elder brothers: Edmund Jr. of Greenwich, CT - retired partner of PricewaterhouseCoopers; Davis, of Pine City, NY worldwide air gun distributor; and Henry, of Naples, Florida a broker at Merrill Lynch. As well as two cousins, Wolfgang Eckstein, the retired head of the German Fashion Union and Winfried Eckstein, an investor in commodities both of Munich, Germany. His brothers, cousins, long-time sailing comrades at Indian Harbor Yacht Club in Greenwich, CT and countless members of the NYC homeless community will sorely miss him. A memorial service will be held at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Manhattan on October 16th at noon. Pastor Armadus Derr will personally officiate the service. After interment, participants are invited to join at a nearby restaurant for lunch. Cousins Fred Forster and Wolfgang Eckstein, are traveling from Germany to attend the service.

ZUNZ--Lyonel E.,93, of Fort Lee, NJ and Stockbridge, MA, passed away at New York- Presbyterian Hospital on October 12, 2014. Mr. Zunz was born and raised in Hudson County, NJ. He lived for many years in Teaneck, NJ and moved 20 years ago to Fort Lee, NJ. He also spent much of his time in his cherished second home in Stockbridge, MA. He was married to his late wife, Sylvia, for 58 years. He is survived by his loving daughters, Sharyn Zunz of Durham, NH and Gail Zunz of Lexington, MA; and his beloved partner of 10 years, Rosalind Mann. He was senior counsel and a past partner for Blank Rome LLP Counselors at Law in New York. He attended NYU and Columbia University Law School where he was on Law Review. Lyonel was loved by all who knew him for his concern for others, sense of humor and support of many philanthropic causes. He was the Chairman of the Board of Trustees for the Community School in Teaneck, NJ whose mission is to meet the educational needs of learning disabled children. His 45 years of service to the school was recognized when their Community High School was named in his honor. Concern for the health and well-being of others was paramount to Lyonel. He supported numerous programs at the New York-Presbyterian Hospital as well as many other health-related charities. A funeral service will be held at 11am on Wednesday at Gutterman and Musicant Funeral Home, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ (201-489-3800). Interment to follow at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Following the interment, family and friends are invited to the Zunz home at 1500 Palisade Avenue, 12C, Fort Lee, NJ. Shiva may be observed on Thursday evening 7-9pm and Friday from 11am-4pm. In Lyonel's memory, a donation may be made to: The Community School, 11 W. Forest Ave, Teaneck, NJ 07666 or New York Presbyterian Hospital, 654 W. 170 Street, NY, NY. 10032, co Dr. Steven J. Corwin, for the support of geriatric medicine.

WOOD--John Cotton, of the Kendal Community in Kennett Square, PA, died on October 9th at age of 97. Funeral service 10:30am, Saturday November 1, 2014 at the Episcopal Church of the Advent 401 N. Union St., Kennett Square, PA 19348. Foulk & Grieco Funeral Home Inc. (610-869-2685) of West Grove. Condolences at: www.griecocares.com

THOMPSON--Elisabeth J. "Betsy", 75, Advertising Art Buyer of New York City, on September 2, 2014. She is survived by her brother, Hugh Roy Thompson, of Oreland, PA; a nephew, David J. Wikoff, and his wife, Janet M. of Renssalaer, NY. Friends are invited to attend a private Remembrance in Glenside, PA, October 24, 4-8pm. Interment will be in Woodlawn Cemetery., Bronx, NY. Donations may be made to any SPCA.

TANNENBAUM--Bernard. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Bernard Tannenbaum, beloved father of Bonnie Eisler (Clifford). Bernard leaves behind a loving family who will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. Our heartfelt condolences go out to Bonnie and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

SHANE--Rita. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Rita Shane, who sang 68 performances with the company in eight roles, most frequently the Queen of the Night in Mozart's "Die Zauberflote," in which she made her Met debut in 1973. We offer our sincerest condolences to her friends and family. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

SCHEIBER--Walter, died at his home in Gaithersburg, MD, October 8, 2014. Born January 31, 1922, in New York City to Israel Ben and Augusta Scheiber, Mr. Scheiber served as Executive Director of the Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments from 1966-1991 and as City Manager of Rockville, MD, from 1958-1964. He is survived by his wife, Barbara Scheiber, four children, and 12 grand- and great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Saturday, October 25, 2pm at 777 N. Capitol St, NE, Washington, DC.

PROFFITT--Ruth S. 84, died on October 6. Beloved daughter of Ruth and Charles Proffitt. A graduate of The Chapin School in 1947 and Vassar College in 1951. Following service in the Central Intelligence Agency, Miss Proffitt joined the faculty and administration of The Chapin School for 46 years, where she taught mathematics in the middle school, was Head of Lower School, Head of Middle School, and Assistant Head Mistress. Her heart, which never left her fourth-grade mathematics classroom, was always filled with pride when she met her former students, who were more than ready to tell her about the exciting things they were doing. Upon her retirement in 1999 she continued to serve the school on the Alumnae Board. Ruthie Proffitt was a loyal Mets fan. She will be missed by family, friends, and generations of former students. Service at St. James Church, 71st and Madison Avenue at 3pm on Thursday, November 6. Memorial contributions may be made to The Chapin School, 100 East End Avenue, NYC, NY 10028.

KOHN--Vera Sharpe, a resident of Princeton, died of complications from a stroke on October 12, 2014 at the age of 86. She was born and raised in New York City. She received a BA in Modern European History and Political Science from Mount Holyoke College, and a Licence from L'Institute des Hautes Etudes Internationales at the University of Geneva. She married Immanuel Kohn on July 22, 1950 and attended Yale Law School with him for one year, where she was one of eight women in a class of approximately 180 law students, before her first child was born. After law school, her husband joined the law firm Cahill Gordon & Reindel, where he eventually became Chairman of the Executive Committee. The couple lived for a short time in Brooklyn, New York, and from 1954 to 1968 in Westchester, New York, where she taught at the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry and later commuted to Manhattan to work in the Office of Public Information of the United Nations' Secretariat. They moved to Princeton in the summer of 1968, where she volunteered at the Stony Brook Millstone Watersheds Association, working on the preservation of open space and farmland for several years. She was a Docent at the Princeton University Art Museum and on the Board of the Princeton University Concert Committee. She was a member of the Metropolitan Opera Club, the Harvard Club, the Nassau Club, the Present Day Club, and the Bedens Brook Club. Immanuel Kohn, her husband of 62 years, passed away in March 2013. She is survived by four children, Gail, Peter and wife Margaret, Sheila, Robert and wife Susan, and six grandchildren, Megan, Emily, Michael, Jason, Sarah, and Katherine. Burial services will be private. The family requests that any gifts in Vera's honor be sent to the Institute for Advanced Study, the Princeton University Art Museum or the Princeton University Chamber Concerts.

KLINE--Eugene M.,on October 10, 2014 at 100 years of age. The Partners, Associates and Staff of Phillips Nizer mourn the passing of our esteemed partner, colleague and friend, Eugene Kline. We are eternally grateful for Gene's wise counsel, advice and encouragement over his 71 year affiliation with our firm and will remember with fondness celebrating his Centennial Birthday last May. Phillips Nizer, LLP

KLINE--Eugene M.,known to all as Gene, having survived just a few months past his 100th birthday, died quietly on the afternoon of Friday, October 10, 2014, at his home at Atria of Rye Brook. The cause was congestive heart failure, complicated by pneumonia. Always proud of his graduation from DeWitt Clinton High School, Eugene attended Columbia College, where he was coxswain and Phi Beta Kappa. He went on to Columbia Law School, from which he graduated in 1935 as a James Kent Scholar. Gene practiced law for just shy of 80 years, with a brief interruption for military service during World War II. On September 17, 2014, he forthrightly announced his retirement from the law firm of Phillips Nizer LLP, where he had practiced since 1943. He was the consummate lawyers' lawyer, frequently consulted by colleagues seeking technical advice about knotty legal issues. His dedication to the law was leavened by a lifelong love of jazz, art, the ballet, and the New York Football Giants. Gene was beloved as well as respected. He was married for 70 years to the artist Harriet Kline, who died in 2010. Though predeceased by his son Robert, Gene is survived by his granddaughter Lisa and by Robert's widow, Georgann Kline Ohsman. Gene is also survived by his son Thomas and grandchildren Andrew, Emily, and Daniel. Gene was laid to rest in a private ceremony on Sunday, October 12, 2014, at Mount Carmel Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that a donation be made to the New York City Ballet, David H. Koch Theater, 20 Lincoln Center, New York, NY 10023 or the Museum of Modern Art, 11 W 53rd St, New York, NY 10019.

GUTCHESS--Jocelyn Fleming, an economist and a civic leader, died at her home in Hanover, NH of leukemia on September 18, 2014. Jocelyn was predeceased by her husband in 2000. She is survived by her daughter, Susan, and Susan's wife, Helen Ingalls. A memorial service celebrating her life will be held at the Methodist Meeting House in Sandwich, NH at 2pm on October 18, 2014. For Obituary and Guestbook: mayhewfuneralhomes.com

GORDON--Arlene R.,JBI International (the Jewish Braille Institute) grieves the passing of our longtime Board Member and friend. Her wisdom and grace will be sorely missed. Our thoughts are with her family and all those whose lives she touched. Judy E. Tenney, Chairman of the Board Dr. Ellen Isler, President and CEO. Israel A. Taub, Vice President and CFO

GABRILOVE--Dr. J. Lester. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member, former board member and honorary trustee, Dr. J. Lester Gabrilove and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl and President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City

GABRILOVE--Jacques Lester, died October 12th, in his 98th year of life: active, outgoing and engaged until the end. Lester attended Townsend Harris High School, City College, and NYU School of Medicine. He completed his internship and residency in Internal Medicine at the Mount Sinai Hospital and subsequently pursued a fellowship at Yale University. Throughout his post-graduate academic and clinical career, he was continuously affiliated with the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, and he remained a tireless supporter and promoter of that institution's growth and evolution. His path breaking research made keystone contributions to the present day field of endocrinology and he earned wide recognition and appreciation for his pioneering work in this nascent discipline. In acknowledgement, the Division of Endocrinology, Diabetes and Bone Diseases was named in his honor. He also established an annual prize in recognition of scientific excellence and character as well as a lecture series, which served to engage renown practitioners from throughout the world with the Endocrine Division. A man of impeccable character, warmth and understated grace, he was animated by perpetual curiosity and insightful intelligence and he served as an inspiring mentor to many. He was civic minded and contributed to his community in numerous ways, serving on the Board of Trustees of Central Synagogue and as a long time member of the Lotos Club. Intensely loyal and devoted to his family, he was the beloved husband of the late Hilda Weiss Gabrilove, cherished father of Janice L. Gabrilove and the late Sandra Gabrilove Saltzman, adored grandfather to Mark and Matthew Dirzulaitis and father-in-law and friend to Michael Dirzulaitis. Services will be held at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Avenue, on Wednesday at 10:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Hilda & J. Lester Gabrilove Division of Endocrinology Fund at Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai.

FOX--Cecile. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Cecile Fox, whose generosity helped millions of people in need in New York and around the world. We extend our condolences to Cecile's family and friends. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

ETTINGER--Ann, on October 11, 2014. Predeceased by her husband Sidney, brother Jim, twin George, firstborn son Ike-and the Lower East Side gang. Survived by her son Bob Apfel and his wife Jill. Annie, you were so good and decent; everyone who knew you loved you and held you in high regard. We will miss you terribly. Service Wednesday, October 15, 3pm at "The Riverside", 76 St. at Amsterdam Ave.

DAVIDOWITZ--Hon. Edward The Board of Trustees of Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, along with its Administration and staff mourn the passing of our dear friend and trustee. Ed served on the Blythedale Board for more than 30 years. He was a passionate advocate for children's healthcare and an active Board member whose wisdom and guidance were invaluable. We extend our condolences to his wife, Ellen and his entire family. Owen Gutfreund, Chair, Board of Trustees Larry Levine, President and CEO

DANIELS--Harvey, age 89 on October 11, 2014. Predeceased by adored wife Natalie. Beloved father of Stuart (Ismene) and Andrew. Cherished grandfather of Alexander and Peter. Erasmus Hall, NYU graduate. WWII Veteran. Philanthropist, entrepreneur and businessman. A most amazing gentleman who taught above all that kindness, compassion and a passion for life were the right morals to live by. Interment private. Celebration of his life to be arranged in New York and Palm Beach. In lieu of flowers, please make contribution in his name to the charity of your choice.

ALLEN--William Hayes, beloved father of Edwin, Neal and Kent, cherished father-in-law of Wendy Allen and Karen Tanner Allen, adored grandfather of eight, died on Saturday, October 11, 2014, of pulmonary fibrosis at his retirement home in Washington, DC, eight days short of his 88th birthday. His late wife, the former Joan Webster Emmett, predeceased him in 2005 after a marriage of 55 years. A brilliant lawyer, graduating first in his class from Stanford Law School in 1956, he served as chief law clerk to Chief Justice Earl Warren. His decades-long career encompassed both the practice of law as partner at Covington & Burling and teaching at Stanford, Cornell and Howard Law Schools as well as his beloved Deep Springs College - which he also served as chairman of its board of trustees - in the high desert of his native California. He drafted the first open housing act to be enacted south of the Mason-Dixon Line and argued four cases before the United States Supreme Court. His keen mind, gentle curiosity and humility all defined his life. He will be profoundly missed by family, friends, and generations of former students and colleagues. A celebration of his life will be held at a future date. Contributions in his memory can be made to Deep Springs College; HC 72 Box 45001; Dyer, NV 89010-9803.

ZUNZ--Lyonel E. The attorneys and staff of Blank Rome LLP mourn the loss of our beloved Senior Counsel, who served for many years as Managing Partner of the predecessor of our New York office, Tenzer, Greenblatt, Fallon & Kaplan. Lyonel oversaw the significant growth of Tenzer Greenblatt, while maintaining its spirit of family through his warmth and caring. We were awed by his extraordinary legal ability. We were inspired by his communal and philanthropic work, including as Chair of the Community School, which named its High School in his honor, and for the Berklee College of Music, where he dedicated a Scholarship in memory of his late wife, Sylvia. Our hearts go out to his daughters, Sharyn and Gail, and to his friend and companion, Roz. We hope they will be comforted by the memory of a wise and gentle man who touched the lives of so many. BLANK ROME LLP

SHIELDS--Claire Corroon, of New York, NY and Ocean Ridge, FL died on October 11, 2014. Mother of Judi McCarty, grandmother of two, great grandmother of three, and sister of Jack Corroon. SCHEIBER--Walter, died at his home in Gaithersburg, MD, October 8, 2014. Born January 31, 1922, in New York City to Israel Ben and Augusta Scheiber, Mr. Scheiber served as Executive Director of the Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments from 1966-1991 and as City Manager of Rockville, MD, from 1958-1964. He is survived by his wife, Barbara Scheiber, four children, and 12 grand- and great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Saturday, October 25, 2pm at 777 N. Capitol St, NE, Washington, DC.

SALZMAN--Emanuel, on October 14, 2014. Beloved husband of Gloria. Loving father of David and Debi. Devoted father-in-law of Abby and Mark. Cherished grandfather of Julie, Jessica, Jacob, Dana and Barry. Services today Wednesday, October 15, 2014 at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. www.riversidenassaunorth chapels.com

OSHRIN--Edward. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the untimely death of our member, Edward Oshrin. We will miss his integrity and courage, his devotion to family, friends and community. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his beloved wife, Ying Li-Oshrin, their sons, Matthew and Jonathan, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Martin Flumenbaum, President

OSHRIN--Edward J.,age 53, passed away peacefully on October 13, 2014 with his family at his side. Beloved husband of Ying Li, loving father of Matthew and Jonathan. Devoted son of Martin and the late Corrine. Dear brother of Andrew. Services at "The Riverside", 180 West 76th St., NYC today at 11:15am.

O'BRIEN--Terence J.,70, died October 13, 2014. A former IRS Executive. Beet- hoven was his hero, risotto was his specialty, and Italy earned his heart. New York City born and raised, he found happiness in Atlanta. Survived by his wife, Mary Ann O'Brien (Casalaspro). HMPattersonOglethorpe.com

KOHN--Vera Sharpe, a resident of Princeton, died of complications from a stroke on October 12, 2014 at the age of 86. She was born and raised in New York City. She received a BA in Modern European History and Political Science from Mount Holyoke College, and a Licence from L'Institute des Hautes Etudes Internationales at the University of Geneva. She married Immanuel Kohn on July 22, 1950 and attended Yale Law School with him for one year, where she was one of eight women in a class of approximately 180 law students, before her first child was born. After law school, her husband joined the law firm Cahill Gordon & Reindel, where he eventually became Chairman of the Executive Committee. The couple lived for a short time in Brooklyn, New York, and from 1954 to 1968 in Westchester, New York, where she taught at the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry and later commuted to Manhattan to work in the Office of Public Information of the United Nations' Secretariat. They moved to Princeton in the summer of 1968, where she volunteered at the Stony Brook Millstone Watersheds Association, working on the preservation of open space and farmland for several years. She was a Docent at the Princeton University Art Museum and on the Board of the Princeton University Concert Committee. She was a member of the Metropolitan Opera Club, the Harvard Club, the Nassau Club, the Present Day Club, and the Bedens Brook Club. Immanuel Kohn, her husband of 62 years, passed away in March 2013. She is survived by four children, Gail, Peter and wife Margaret, Sheila, Robert and wife Susan, and six grandchildren, Megan, Emily, Michael, Jason, Sarah, and Katherine. Burial services will be private. The family requests that any gifts in Vera's honor be sent to the Institute for Advanced Study, the Princeton University Art Museum or the Princeton University Chamber Concerts.

KLINE--Eugene M.,known to all as Gene, having survived just a few months past his 100th birthday, died quietly on the afternoon of Friday, October 10, 2014, at his home at Atria of Rye Brook. The cause was congestive heart failure, complicated by pneumonia. Always proud of his graduation from DeWitt Clinton High School, Eugene attended Columbia College, where he was coxswain and Phi Beta Kappa. He went on to Columbia Law School, from which he graduated in 1935 as a James Kent Scholar. Gene practiced law for just shy of 80 years, with a brief interruption for military service during World War II. On September 17, 2014, he forthrightly announced his retirement from the law firm of Phillips Nizer LLP, where he had practiced since 1943. He was the consummate lawyers' lawyer, frequently consulted by colleagues seeking technical advice about knotty legal issues. His dedication to the law was leavened by a lifelong love of jazz, art, the ballet, and the New York Football Giants. Gene was beloved as well as respected. He was married for 70 years to the artist Harriet Kline, who died in 2010. Though predeceased by his son Robert, Gene is survived by his granddaughter Lisa and by Robert's widow, Georgann Kline Ohsman. Gene is also survived by his son Thomas and grandchildren Andrew, Emily, and Daniel. Gene was laid to rest in a private ceremony on Sunday, October 12, 2014, at Mount Carmel Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that a donation be made to the New York City Ballet, David H. Koch Theater, 20 Lincoln Center, New York, NY 10023 or the Museum of Modern Art, 11 W 53rd St, New York, NY 10019.

JOSEPHSON--Joseph T.,passed away on October 8, 2014, from complications of pancreatic cancer. He was born on December 2, 1960, and graduated from the Dalton School in 1978, Princeton in 1982 and Columbia Business School in 1988. He worked as an investment banker and was most recently a founding partner of Union Square Advisors. He was the son of Ingrid Josephson and Marvin Josephson, founder of ICM, a talent agency. He is survived by his son, David and daughter, Zoe. Donations in his memory should be made to The International Rescue Committee. A memorial service will be private.
GABRILOVE--J. Lester. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, J. Lester Gabrilove, and send condolences to his family.
GABRILOVE--J. Lester, MD Our family was blessed to be part of your world for the past thirty years. We mourn your loss as we celebrate your life. Alice Levine and Alex Kirschenbaum.

GABRILOVE--J. Lester, MD. The faculty and staff of the Department of Medicine and Division of Endocrinology at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai mourn the passing of J. Lester Gabrilove, MD. He was one of the fathers of modern endocrinology who made enormous contributions to medicine at Mount Sinai for more than seven decades. Our deepest condolences go to his daughter Janice L. Gabrilove, MD, his son-in-law Michael Dirzulaitis, and his two grandsons, Matthew and Mark.

GABRILOVE--J. Lester, MD. We, at the Mount Sinai Health System, are deeply saddened by the passing of our friend and longtime colleague, J. Lester Gabrilove, MD, one of the most beloved and outstanding physicians in the history of Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. Dr. Gabrilove, considered one of the fathers of modern endocrinology, greatly advanced the study of endocrinology during a career that spanned more than 70 years. He co-authored "The Human Adrenal Gland" and "Diseases of the Endocrine Glands;" published more than 170 papers in national and international journals; and impacted generations of faculty and trainees. He was a role model who inspired numerous endocrine fellows and faculty who regarded him as a master clinician-educator. Dr. Gabrilove served as Chief of the Endocrine Clinic at The Mount Sinai Hospital for 20 years, and was instrumental in founding the Clinic as well as the Division of Endocrinology, where he also served as Acting Chief. In 2007, the division was renamed the Hilda and J. Lester Gabrilove Division of Endocrinology, Diabetes and Bone Disease in honor of Dr. Gabrilove and his wife. In 1995, in recognition of his lifelong contributions, he received the inaugural Distinguished Endocrinologist Award by the American College of Endocrinology. His inquiring mind--he published his last paper in his nineties--combined with his passion to advance clinical care, was a gift to his patients and the School of Medicine. We extend our deepest condolences to his daughter, Janice L. Gabrilove, MD, the James F. Holland Professor of Medicine (Hematology and Medical Oncology), and Professor of Oncological Sciences, at Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai; his son-in-law, Michael Dirzulaitis; and his two grandsons, Mark and Matthew, of whom he was very proud. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Mount Sinai Health System Kenneth L. Davis, MD, Chief Executive Officer and President, Mount Sinai Health System Dennis S. Charney, MD Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System

GABRILOVE--Jacques Lester, died October 12th, in his 98th year of life: active, outgoing and engaged until the end. Lester attended Townsend Harris High School, City College, and NYU School of Medicine. He completed his internship and residency in Internal Medicine at the Mount Sinai Hospital and subsequently pursued a fellowship at Yale University. Throughout his post-graduate academic and clinical career, he was continuously affiliated with the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, and he remained a tireless supporter and promoter of that institution's growth and evolution. His path breaking research made keystone contributions to the present day field of endocrinology and he earned wide recognition and appreciation for his pioneering work in this nascent discipline. In acknowledgement, the Division of Endocrinology, Diabetes and Bone Diseases was named in his honor. He also established an annual prize in recognition of scientific excellence and character as well as a lecture series, which served to engage renown practitioners from throughout the world with the Endocrine Division. A man of impeccable character, warmth and understated grace, he was animated by perpetual curiosity and insightful intelligence and he served as an inspiring mentor to many. He was civic minded and contributed to his community in numerous ways, serving on the Board of Trustees of Central Synagogue and as a long time member of the Lotos Club. Intensely loyal and devoted to his family, he was the beloved husband of the late Hilda Weiss Gabrilove, cherished father of Janice L. Gabrilove and the late Sandra Gabrilove Saltzman, adored grandfather to Mark and Matthew Dirzulaitis and father-in-law and friend to Michael Dirzulaitis. Services will be held at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Avenue, on Wednesday at 10:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Hilda & J. Lester Gabrilove Division of Endocrinology Fund at Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai.

DUNNE--Joan C. Born in New York City on September 8, 1922; died suddenly on October 10, 2014. Daughter of Richard and Elizabeth Dunne of Crestwood, NY. Began her long career in advertising in New York City in 1940. An accomplished pianist, embroiderer, genealogist and lover of languages from Arabic to Turkish. She is survived by her sister, Patricia A. O'Donnell, five nieces, two nephews, many cousins and their families as well as her lifelong friends, Marilyn Bender and Evelyn Ward. Read a book or look at a painting in her memory.

COWLEY--Geoffrey, 59, died of colon cancer on October 14, 2014. Geoff was a gentle, humble man with a shining intellect and an open heart. Throughout his 30-year career as a journalist and public health advocate, he made science and medicine vividly accessible to general readers, while championing health as a human right. As Newsweek magazine's health editor--a post he held from 1988 through 2006--he exhibited a special talent for simplifying complexity without sacrificing nuance. Whether he was explaining how memory works or reporting on health conditions in the world's poorest countries, he transformed facts into stories as engaging as they were learned. Later, as an associate New York City health commissioner, he helped the Bloomberg administration confront challenges ranging from HIV to smoking and obesity. More recently, as a national writer for msnbc.com, he deftly chronicled the long struggle to implement the Affordable Care Act. To Susan Pelzer, his wife of 30 years, Geoff was the light of the universe gathered in a lifetime. And to Colin Cowley, his 25-year-old son, Geoff was a loving friend and mentor, who consistently emphasized the value of curiosity and compassion. Geoff is survived by many family members who live in the west: his father, James Philip Cowley, his sister, Linda Clark, and her three daughters, his brother, Collin Cowley, and his three children, and the Jorgensen family. Geoff's family requests that any gifts in his honor be made to Doctors Without Borders.

ALLEN--William Hayes, beloved father of Edwin, Neal and Kent, cherished father-in-law of Wendy Allen and Karen Tanner Allen, adored grandfather of eight, died on Saturday, October 11, 2014, of pulmonary fibrosis at his retirement home in Washington, DC, eight days short of his 88th birthday. His late wife, the former Joan Webster Emmett, predeceased him in 2005 after a marriage of 55 years. A brilliant lawyer, graduating first in his class from Stanford Law School in 1956, he served as chief law clerk to Chief Justice Earl Warren. His decades-long career encompassed both the practice of law as partner at Covington & Burling and teaching at Stanford, Cornell and Howard Law Schools as well as his beloved Deep Springs College - which he also served as chairman of its board of trustees - in the high desert of his native California. He drafted the first open housing act to be enacted south of the Mason-Dixon Line and argued four cases before the United States Supreme Court. His keen mind, gentle curiosity and humility all defined his life. He will be profoundly missed by family, friends, and generations of former students and colleagues. A celebration of his life will be held at a future date. Contributions in his memory can be made to Deep Springs College; HC 72 Box 45001; Dyer, NV 89010-9803.

This document covers all modern American chemical munitions, including the mustard-filled M110. The United States is destroying its chemical M110 shells in accordance with the Chemical Weapons Convention Treaty. European-made M110 variants were part of Saddam Hussein’s chemical arsenal and wounded American and Iraqi troops from 2006 to 2010.

An unclassified summary of an Army report released to Congress in 2006 stated that since 2003 allied forces in Iraq had recovered about 500 chemical weapons. By that time chemical weapons recoveries were accelerating sharply; the number understated the actual number of chemical weapons found and has never been publicly updated.

SHIELDS--Claire Corroon, of New York, NY and Ocean Ridge, FL died on October 11, 2014. Mother of Judi McCarty, grandmother of two, great grandmother of three, and sister of Jack Corroon. Pre-deceased by her husbands Robert M. Smith and Joseph V. Shield. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Thomas More R.C. Church in Darien, CT on Friday, October 17, 2014 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to The Cottage, P.O. Box 2355, Darien, CT 06820.

ROSENBAUM--Judy, passed away peacefully in her home, as was her wish, on September 30th 2014. Her life was one of dedication to her mother, Dr. Bertha Rader, to her work, and to literature. She leaves behind wonderful children's stories and beautiful poems. Judy opened new paths in the world of literature to children and adults alike. She possessed a wealth of knowledge and could engage anyone in meaningful conversations on a myriad of topics, recalling even the smallest of details on everything, from fashion to sports. With her incredible memory, she was always generously ready to lend a helping hand, especially if it involved reading, writing, editing or researching. Always friendly and caring, Judy touched the hearts of everyone who met her. She leaves behind many friends including Zorka Hristova and Nina Argirova, in particular. Judy finally found her passageway to Narnia - may she reign there, happily, for eternity. We, on the other side of the wardrobe, will greatly miss her. Donations may be made to Books For Kids.

MELTON--Andrew J.,Jr., 94, former Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of Dean Witter died at his home in Tequesta, FL on October 15, 2014. Mr. Melton enjoyed a distinguished career on Wall Street. In 1946 he joined Smith Barney & Co. After 25 years with the firm he joined Dean Witter. In 1978 following the merger with Reynolds Securities Mr. Melton was named Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive of Dean Witter Reynolds. After Sears, Roebuck and Company purchased Dean Witter Reynolds in 1981, he became Chairman of Dean Witter Funds, a position he held until 1992. Raised in Bay Shore, NY, Mr. Melton graduated from Villanova University in 1942. He was commissioned an officer in the United States Marine Corps, serving in both the Pacific and Atlantic Campaigns during World War II. He was recalled to active duty in 1950 during the Korean Conflict. He was discharged from the Marine Reserves as a Major. Mr. Melton's engagement with the professional community included terms as President of the Investment Bankers Association and the Bond Club of New York. He also gave of his time and organizational talents to his local community. His positions included Commodore of the Bay Shore Yacht Club, President of the Southward Ho Country Club also in Bay Shore, N.Y. Since retirement he lived in Dorset, VT and Tequesta, FL. His greatest joy was following the activities of his very large family. The word patriarch describes his role and the respect he enjoyed. Mr. Melton was pre-deceased by his beloved wife of 55 years, Mary Ann Melton, as well as his five sisters and four brothers. He is survived by his loving companion, Barbara Fazio, and his eight children, Diana Melton Lemmen of Bremen, Germany; Andrew J. Melton III of New York, NY; Colonel Robert S. Melton, USMC (Ret) of Palm Beach Gardens, FL; Karen Melton Fox of West Palm Beach, FL; Marjorie Melton Field of Jupiter, FL; Sandra Melton Lessing of Cold Spring Harbor, NY; Michaelle Melton Stott of Riverside, CT; and, Edward L. Melton of Darien, CT. He is also survived by twenty-three grandchildren and thirteen great grandchildren. The family will receive friends at Taylor & Modeen Funeral Home, 250 Center Street, Jupiter on Friday, October 17th from 6:00pm until 8:00pm. A mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Christopher Church, 12001 SE Federal Hwy, Hobe Sound on Saturday, October 18th at 11:30am followed with military honors conducted by U.S. Marine Corps. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to St. Patrick's School, 9 North Clinton Ave., Bay Shore, NY 11706. For directions or to express online condolences please visit www.taylorandmodeen.com.

HARDY--John C.,91, dedicated artist, father and companion died October 10th. His passion for life was expressed in his wonderful paintings and all his loving friends and family. He is survived by his children Jacqueline Gadois, Andre Hardy, Mike Hardy, Elizabeth Beahm, Blanche Pedroza, four grandchilden, two great-grandchildren and life companion Joan Semmel. Memorial planned for November.

HARBER--Dr. Leonard C. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member, Dr. Leonard C. Harber and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl, President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City

FRIEDMAN--Bernard. It is with great sadness that we announce the death of Bernard Friedman. He passed peacefully at home in the presence of his family on Monday. Born in Brooklyn, NY in 1922, he was a veteran of World War II and an accomplished theatrical attorney. He joins his wife Loretta and is survived by his daughters Jessica and Jackie and his son-in-law Kevin Foran. The family will be available from 11:30 to 1pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel with a burial to follow at Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

FISHBEIN--T. Richard, passed away on the evening of October 14, 2014 at the age of 76. He leaves behind his beloved wife Dr. Estelle Bender after more than 33 years of marriage. He was the cherished stepfather of Melissa Bender, adored father-in-law of Ryan Goodman, dear brother of Peter (Bette), proud uncle of Stephen (Jennifer), Bruce (Sara), Gregory (Alicia), Emily, Michael, and fond great uncle to many. He was a special light in the lives of his grandchildren Ella and Ethan Goodman. He had an enduring passion for the life of the mind, and he lived his life with vigor (as he put it) through his family, his friends, his career, his activities, and his personal interests. Richard was a retired partner of Cortec Group, a private equity investment firm in New York. He served on Boards of both public and private corporations including the Polytechnic Institute of New York University, the National Academy Museum and School of Fine Arts, the Japanese Art Society of America, and NYC Seed. He was a devoted patron of the arts with a special place in his heart for the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Japanese Art Society of America. His philanthropic life involved other institutions including the Stanley M. Isaacs Neighborhood Center, Dartmouth College, and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. Richard traveled the world, most enjoying his times abroad in England, France, Italy, and Japan. He held an AB from Dartmouth College, an MBA from Harvard Business School, and a Diploma from the School of Advanced International Studies of Johns Hopkins University in Bologna, Italy. Funeral will be held Friday, October 17, 2014 at 11:00 AM at Fred E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave in New York. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to: Bender-Fishbein Endowed Scholarship at NYU Polytechnic School of Engineering, Attn: Judy Sager, Office of Development and Alumni Relations, 15 MetroTech Ctr, 6th Flr, Brooklyn, NY 11201.

EDELMAN--Judith, FAIA 1923 - 2014. Pioneering architect and founder of The Edelman Partnership / Architects with her husband Harold Edelman, FAIA. Teacher, Mentor, Partner, Course-setter, Critic, and Provider of Inspiration. You are missed. Andrew Knox & Randy Wood, Edelman Sultan Knox Wood /Architects

BRAUS--Jay Richard died October 15, 2014 in Lee, Massachusetts. He was a man of many enthusiasms and passions, marked by his zest for life, love of his family, love of art, travel, eating out, horse racing and making a great real estate deal. Until recently, he lived in Stockbridge, Mass. and Boca Raton, Florida. He died after a long battle with Alzheimer's Disease. Born in New York City in 1925, he graduated from NY public schools and Penn State, and served in the U.S. Navy. He was the founder and one of the principals in his Manhattan-based real estate firm, Jay R. Braus Co. Mr. Braus and his wife of 62 years, Jane Wolbarst Braus, raised their four children in Larchmont. Their art collection was displayed at the Berkshire Museum in a 2011 show, Collectors' Choice: Selections from the Jay and Jane Braus Collection. He is survived by his wife, Jane, his children Nancy (Richard Geidel), Pat (Edwin Lopez), Paul and Peter (Kaija Braus); grandchildren Molly, Janie (Joey Birchmore), Laura, Daniel, Jay, Nate and Henry; and great grandson Ben. Contributions in his memory can be made to the Food Bank of Western Massachusetts, 97 North Hatfield Road, Hatfield, MA 01038. A memorial service will be held at 10:30 a.m. Friday at Kimball Farms, 235 Walker St., Lenox, Mass.

BALLEN--Irving W. The Partners, Associates and Staff of McLaughlin & Stern, LLP record their deep sorrow at the loss of our esteemed former Partner, Irving Ballen. He was a lawyer of almost peerless talent and honor, and a gentleman of thoughtfulness and grace. For almost four decades he was an integral leader of our firm. For years to come, we will gratefully remember and honor his professional talents and personal warmth.

BALLEN--Irving W. With deep sadness, Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records the passing of its cherished and devoted long-time member, Irving Ballen. Irving served with distinction, both as a Trustee and as our General Counsel. With Natalie and the children, we share the grief of loss and bereavement. The beautiful qualities of Irving's life shall endure forever in the hearts of all who loved him. The Temple Emanu-El Family

BALLEN--Irving W.,died October 14th in his 97th year: full of life until the end. He died surrounded by his family and loved ones. Irving was born in Philadelphia to May and Mike Ballen, but spent his childhood and teenage years in his beloved Atlantic City, New Jersey. It was in Atlantic City that he developed his lifelong love of the ocean and remained a devoted swimmer until shortly before his death. Irving graduated Atlantic City High School, Syracuse University and Yale Law School. He proudly served as a U.S. Navy Captain in World War II, where he was stationed in the Pacific. After graduating from law school, he settled in New York where he raised a family with wife Adrienne Miller Ballen who passed away in 1972. He was the founding partner of McLaughlin, Stern, Ballen and Ballen with his identical twin, Frederick Ballen and practiced law until the age of 88. Irving was a compassionate man who loved people. He couldn't pass a person by who needed help, whether it was a meal or an encouraging word. He cherished his second wife of 39 years Natalie Ballen and was a devoted father to Roger (Lynda), Kate, Sian and stepfather to Steven (Janet) and Barbara (John). He was an adored grandfather to Paul, Amanda, Isobel, Alex, Olivia, William and step-grandfather to Alison, Douglas, Michael and Marcy. Irving will be missed terribly by family, friends and even those who encountered his smile as he walked daily to his favorite bench in Central Park. Services Sunday, October 19, 10am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th St. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Temple Emanu-El where he served as a trustee and General Counsel for many years.

ZICK--Mary S. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the loss of Mary S. Zick, beloved wife of Trustee John W. Zick. Mary was a cherished member of the Carnegie Hall family for more than three decades, and her presence at the Hall will be greatly missed. We express our sincere and heartfelt condolences to John and to the entire Zick family. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive and Artistic Director

ZICK--Mary Sutter. Of Key Largo, FL, beloved wife of nearly 66 years of John Walter Zick passed away on Monday afternoon. She is survived by her husband, two daughters Sharon Zick Rieger and Catherine Zick Manning, a daughter-in-law, Donna Poole Zick, two sons-in-law, Brian Louis Rieger and George Taylor Manning, six grandchildren and a great-granddaughter. Mary and John's son, John Walter Zick, Jr. predeceased his mother in 1998. Mary began her life in Evanston, Il as the daughter of Harry Blair Sutter and Elsie Paul Sutter. She attended Roycemore School and Northwestern University. Much of Mary's adult life was devoted to helping others through volunteer service. She served with the Junior League of Chicago as a Senior Vice President, the Garden Club of America, and the Greenwich Garden Club, where she was honored in 1986 with the Garden Club trophy for the most noteworthy accomplishment by a member during that year. Mary also worked with Greenwich Hospital Hospice Services, Girl Scouts, and as President of the Garden Group at Ocean Reef. She also volunteered to arrange flowers monthly for the Chapel at Ocean Reef. Mary co-founded the Winnetka Presbyterian Church and brought Lloyd John Ogilvie, later to become Chaplain of the United States Senate, to Winnetka to serve as its first pastor. Mary was often described as the most beautiful woman in the room, not only for her outer beauty but for her inner grace, beauty and love for others which shone through. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions can be made to the Medical Center Foundation at Ocean Reef, 50 Barracuda Lane, Key Largo, FL 33037 or to the Ocean Reef Chapel Foundation, P.O. Box 226, Saint Augustine, FL 32086.

SCHLANGER--Harold. Alpine Country Club, its Officers, Board Members and Staff deeply mourn the passing of their Member. We offer our deepest sympathy to the entire Schlanger Family. Alpine Country Club, David Kushner, President

RADEST--Howard.The Ethical Culture Fieldston community mourns the passing of our former director, who led the school from 1979 to 1991. A distinguished educator and author, Dr. Radest inspired hundreds of students and faculty who benefited from his insights into the teaching of ethical humanism. Our deepest condolences to his wife, Rita, and family. Damian J. Fernandez, Head of School, Robert A. Pruzan '81 & Paul T. Schnell '72, Board Co-Chairs

MOUNT--Isabel. Beloved mother, grandmother, and wife died peacefully in New York at the age of 86. A lifelong resident of the city, she proudly graduated from Barnard in 1950 and spent her life devoted to promoting non-profit institutions including The Museum of Modern Art, Museum of Primitive Art, American Museum of Natural History, National Medical Fellowships, and Teachers College, Columbia University. She loved the opera, the ballet, and art. An inveterate world traveler--from Africa to her most adored, France--she lived life to the fullest. She will be greatly missed. Christopher, Stephanie and Julian Mount.

KARP--David, 59, died suddenly in an automobile accident on October 14. Loving father of Daniel and Matthew. Devoted son of Eileen and the late Morris. Beloved brother of Howard and Fran. He and his incomparable sense of humor will be missed.

KAMMERER--Julie. It is with great sadness that The Society of Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center notes the death of their long-standing devoted Board member Julie Kammerer. Julie was a member of The Society's PEP Committee. She will be greatly missed. Martha Vietor Glass, President The Society of MSK

JACKSON--Susan Annabel, formerly Susan Rosenberg, born Fourteenth November 1959 in Bromley, Kent, died Fourteenth October 2014, in Santa Barbara, California, after a truly heroic battle against breast cancer, peacefully, and surrounded by family and friends. She is survived by her husband Ben Morahan, mother Elizabeth, and sister Caroline with Daniel and John. Services will be held privately. Susan enjoyed a long and highly successful career in independent film distribution, which included founding sales company Turtles Crossing and co-founding Freestyle Releasing, and apart from ignoring glass ceilings, she also thoroughly enjoyed Taos deep skiing, mad dog whispering, tournament tennis playing, cool disco dancing, the Big Island lolling, trying to be captain of everything, and thankfully also loving her devoted husband, Ben, who is really going to miss her. To all her friends, you have the family's fondest condolences. Meanwhile, Susan has taken a steep line down through the trees, and she will just have to wait for the rest of us at the bottom of the mountain. As usual.

GRAD--Frank P.,died at his home on October 14, 2014; he was 90. Born in Austria in 1924, Grad left his country on the Kindertransport with his sister to escape Nazism. After living with a family in England, he immigrated to the United States in 1939. The papers that recorded his arrival in New York list him as "stateless," but Grad wasted no time in making New York City his home. Although as a child he witnessed the horrors of anti-Semitism under Hitler, he rarely spoke of that experience, wanting instead to look forward to the promise of a bright future in America. A true son of his adopted city, he attended Eastern District High School, Brooklyn College, and Columbia Law School, where he earned an LL.B. in 1949. After a brief career in private practice, Grad returned to Columbia Law School to work for, and eventually direct, the influential Legislative Drafting Research Fund. He joined the full-time Columbia Law Faculty in 1969, teaching and publishing extensively on legislation, public health law, and environmental law. A dynamic and thoughtful force on the Columbia campus, Grad played a vital role in the recovery from the student unrest of 1968, leading the research and drafting team that recommended reforms to open the university's governance to greater student and faculty participation. His faculty colleagues remember him for his voluminous contribution to the law and to legal scholarship, his meticulous research, and his passion for public service. Grad, who served as a close adviser to Mayor John Lindsay, is credited with helping to establish the Housing Court in New York. A champion of public services for working-class New Yorkers, Grad drafted the New York City Health Code, the New York City Air Pollution Control Code, the New York City Housing Maintenance Code, the Model State Constitution, and the Model State and Regional Planning Law, among others. Grad also wrote the first comprehensive treatise on environmental law. He will be remembered by his friends and family for his wit, compassion and intellect. Grad was preceded in death by his sister and by his son, David Anthony Grad, who died in 2007. Grad is survived by his wife Lisa, his daughter Catharine A. Grad, and Catharine's two sons, Samuel Grad Oliver and James Grad Oliver. Funeral services will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, NYC, NY 10023, on Sunday, October 19, 2014, at 11:15am.

FLETCHER--James H.,of Williamsburg, VA and Manhasset, NY passed away quietly in his sleep October 9 2014. He is survived by wife Lynn, four daughters and five granddaughters. Upon graduating William & Mary College and Columbia Law, he formed the Manhasset Law firm of Molley, Fletcher & Dunne. He was a retired Air Force Colonel and a prominent leader in the community.

FISHBEIN--T. Richard, Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, T. Richard Fishbein. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn his passing. Joshua M. Davidson, Senior Rabbi John H. Streicker, President
FISHBEIN--T. Richard. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, T. Richard Fishbein, and send condolences to his family.

CARSWELL--Lois. The Board of Trustees, Volunteers, and Staff of Brooklyn Botanic Garden are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed Board Chair Emeritus, Lois Carswell. Lois began her decades-long career at BBG as a volunteer in the Auxiliary. Elected a BBG Trustee in 1985, Lois co-chaired the Conservatory Campaign, chaired and served on numerous important Board Committees, and chaired the Board of Trustees from 1989-98. For more than 40 years, she co-chaired the Garden's annual Plant Sale with her good friend and fellow Trustee Lucille Plotz. Among the many highlights of her service as Chair, Lois hosted then-current President Bill Clinton on a visit to the Garden. In recognition of her service, one of BBG's famed yellow magnolia hybrids was named for her, and today the lemon-yellow flowers of Magnolia "Lois" adorn spring gardens throughout Brooklyn and beyond. Lois was a legend in Albany having founded the statewide Coalition of Living Museums in 1980 and serving as its chair ever since; during her extraordinary leadership the CLM has brought hundreds of millions of dollars of support to operate Zoos, Botanical Gardens, Aquaria and other living museums across New York State. Lois' tremendous passion, vision, and accomplishments inspired all who knew her. She created a wide circle of friends and colleagues as part of her legacy at the Garden and will be deeply missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her children Anne, Alex, and Bob, and to her entire family. Frederick Bland, Board Chair Scot Medbury, President Frances Mendlow, Auxiliary President

FISHBEIN--T. Richard, passed away on the evening of October 14, 2014 at the age of 76. He leaves behind his beloved wife Dr. Estelle Bender after more than 33 years of marriage. He was the cherished stepfather of Melissa Bender, adored father-in-law of Ryan Goodman, dear brother of Peter (Bette), proud uncle of Stephen (Jennifer), Bruce (Sara), Gregory (Alicia), Emily, Michael, and fond great uncle to many. He was a special light in the lives of his grandchildren Ella and Ethan Goodman. He had an enduring passion for the life of the mind, and he lived his life with vigor (as he put it) through his family, his friends, his career, his activities, and his personal interests. Richard was a retired partner of Cortec Group, a private equity investment firm in New York. He served on Boards of both public and private corporations including the Polytechnic Institute of New York University, the National Academy Museum and School of Fine Arts, the Japanese Art Society of America, and NYC Seed. He was a devoted patron of the arts with a special place in his heart for the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Japanese Art Society of America. His philanthropic life involved other institutions including the Stanley M. Isaacs Neighborhood Center, Dartmouth College, and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. Richard traveled the world, most enjoying his times abroad in England, France, Italy, and Japan. He held an AB from Dartmouth College, an MBA from Harvard Business School, and a Diploma from the School of Advanced International Studies of Johns Hopkins University in Bologna, Italy. Funeral will be held Friday, October 17, 2014 at 11:00 AM at Fred E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave in New York. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to: Bender-Fishbein Endowed Scholarship at NYU Polytechnic School of Engineering, Attn: Judy Sager, Office of Development and Alumni Relations, 15 MetroTech Ctr, 6th Flr, Brooklyn, NY 11201.

BRAUS--Jay R.,Beloved cousin, partner and best friend of John Samuelson for more than 50 years. He was an astute art collector, prominent real estate investor and very bright in all he undertook. Most of all, he was a devoted husband, father, grandfather and great grandfather. He will be missed by the entire Samuelson family- John, Barbara, Charles, Franziska and Richard.

BRAUNSTEIN--Aaron. An interesting New York character left this world on October 10. Aaron was a loving father and grandfather. He brought the first boxing match to Israel. I will miss all of your wonderful stories about life. Please rest in peace and make the angels laugh. Yours, Babycakes

BERMAN--Hope A, passed away on October 14, 2014, at her home in New York City. Hope made a difference in countless lives as a distinguished social worker for over 40 years in the only city she ever lived. She was a true Philanthropist with an extra place in her heart for animals and the Yankees. She will be missed daily by her sister Billee Berman Litvack (Lenny), beloved aunt of Jack Litvack (Cheri), Debbie Kamensky-Zide (Mark), Gina Litvack (Peyton); cherished by great-nephews/nieces Michael Litvack (Megan), Christopher Litvack, Megan Litvack, Alexis Kamensky, Bari Kamensky, Ari Kamensky, Cooper Litvack, and Harper Litvack. Grateful for Cynthia Williams. In lieu of flowers, donations to an Animal charity of your choice. Family will hold a private graveside funeral, receiving visitors between the hours of 3pm and 7pm Monday, October 20th at the home of Hope Berman.
BALLEN--Irving. We mourn the passing of our trusted advisor and confidant, Irving Ballen. Our deepest sympathies go out to Natalie and the family. Carolyn and Bruce Silberstein

BALLEN--Irving. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Irving Ballen, and extend sincere condolences to his family. James Dreyfus, President

BALLEN--Irving W.,died October 14th in his 97th year: full of life until the end. He died surrounded by his family and loved ones. Irving was born in Philadelphia to May and Mike Ballen, but spent his childhood and teenage years in his beloved Atlantic City, New Jersey. It was in Atlantic City that he developed his lifelong love of the ocean and remained a devoted swimmer until shortly before his death. Irving graduated Atlantic City High School, Syracuse University and Yale Law School. He proudly served as a U.S. Navy Captain in World War II, where he was stationed in the Pacific. After graduating from law school, he settled in New York where he raised a family with wife Adrienne Miller Ballen who passed away in 1972. He was the founding partner of McLaughlin, Stern, Ballen and Ballen with his identical twin, Frederick Ballen and practiced law until the age of 88. Irving was a compassionate man who loved people. He couldn't pass a person by who needed help, whether it was a meal or an encouraging word. He cherished his second wife of 39 years Natalie Ballen and was a devoted father to Roger (Lynda), Kate, Sian and stepfather to Steven (Janet) and Barbara (John). He was an adored grandfather to Paul, Amanda, Isobel, Alex, Olivia, William and step-grandfather to Alison, Douglas, Michael and Marcy. Irving will be missed terribly by family, friends and even those who encountered his smile as he walked daily to his favorite bench in Central Park. Services Sunday, October 19, 10am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th St. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Temple Emanu-El where he served as a trustee and General Counsel for many years.

RACHLEFF--Dr. Alan (Gibby), Md. First year anniversary. Sailing, friends, baseball. For ever in our hearts.

STRAX--Ilene C. (nee Berman), Elkins Park, PA, on October 14, 2014. Partner of Howard Izes and former wife of Thomas Strax. Mother of Heller and Jeff Moses and Joshua and Kate Strax. Grandmother of Sophie and Kole Moses and Jonah and Seth Strax. Sister of Susan and Michael Hort. Funeral services at 11:30am, Sunday, "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made to the Rema Hort Mann Foundation, 153 Hudson Street, NY, NY 10013 or the Fox Chase Cancer Center, 333 Cottman Ave., Philadelphia, PA 19111.
SIMON--Irwin. Uncle Irwin, we will miss you. Karine and Brad Simon

SIMON--Irwin Joseph, died on October 16, 2014, three days after his 85th birthday. He is survived by his beloved wife Sydne, his four children, Dana (Steve), Valerie, Amy and Christopher (Jamie), his five grandchildren, Henry, Elsa, Alexandra, Colby and Wyomi and his brother Stanley (Ellen). He touched the lives of so many and will be sorely missed. Services will be held 10:30am Sunday at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway, Fair Lawn, NJ.

RATAJCZAK--David. Beloved Broadway and Big Band drummer Dave Ratajczak passed away after a courageous battle with Ocular Melanoma on October 3. He leaves behind a magnificent legacy of love, laughter, and music. Mr. Ratajczak performed and recorded with a wide variety of artists as well as many Tony award winning Broadway shows and film soundtracks. He is survived by his wife of 25 years, Amie Block Ratajczak, and his children Matthew and Emilie. A celebration of his life will be held on Monday, October 20 at 5pm at The Plymouth Church in Brooklyn Heights. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Ocular Melanoma Foundation or Eastman School of Music.

PELS--Donald A.,died peacefully on October 16, 2014 at his home in Manhattan. He was 86. Born January 23, 1928 to Herbert and Alice Pels of New Rochelle, NY, Mr. Pels was a graduate of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania and received a J.D. from New York University School of Law. He was a devoted husband and loving father, grandfather and brother. His friends and family will miss his intelligence, sharp wit, playfulness and his internal clock, which always knew when it was 5pm. Mr. Pels had a successful career in broadcasting, but his greatest business achievement was his vision about the future of cellular technology. As Chairman and President of Lin Broadcasting from 1969 1989, he transformed the company into a strategically important cellular pioneer. Prior to Lin, Mr. Pels was Chief Financial Officer at Capital Cities Communications, Inc. and before then, an executive at the American Broadcasting Company. After his retirement, Mr. Pels devoted himself to his passions: generously and quietly supporting projects in science, education, human rights, parks, the arts, and social policy issues such as compassion in dying. At the time of his death, Mr. Pels was a Director Emeritus of the New York Philharmonic and a Trustee Emeritus at Rockefeller University. He is survived by his wife, Wendy Keys; his children, Juliette Meeus, Valerie Pels and Laurence Pels; his grandchildren Natalie, Matthew, Rebecca and Cate; his sister Betty Schwartz and his sister-in-law Barbara Pels. Memorials may be made to Human Rights Watch or to The Friends of the High Line.

MOUNT--Isabel. Beloved mother, grandmother, and wife died peacefully in New York at the age of 86. A lifelong resident of the city, she proudly graduated from Barnard in 1950 and spent her life devoted to promoting non-profit institutions including The Museum of Modern Art, Museum of Primitive Art, American Museum of Natural History, National Medical Fellowships, and Teachers College, Columbia University. She loved the opera, the ballet, and art. An inveterate world traveler--from Africa to her most adored, France--she lived life to the fullest. She will be greatly missed. Christopher, Stephanie and Julian Mount.

MARASHINSKY--Myra, adored mother and grandmother, widely-known and respected realtor of Rockville Centre, NY, died on October 17, 2014, age 86, due to complications of breast cancer. Irreplaceable and an inspiration to all, she leaves a legacy of grateful first-time house-owners and deeply grieving family and friends. Funeral at Gutterman's, 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY, October 19th, 1pm. Donations, in lieu of flowers to: Stand Up For Cancer.
LaROSSA--James M.,My mentor, my friend. It was an honor to sit at your table. Jerry Shargel

KENNEDY--Donald M. The Attorneys and Staff of Kennedy Lillis Schmidt & English mourn the passing of founding Partner Don Kennedy and extend sincerest sympathy to his wife Ceil. Yardley & Pino Funeral Home 631-324-6515.

FLETCHER--James H.,of Williamsburg, VA and Manhasset, NY passed away quietly in his sleep October 9 2014. He is survived by wife Lynn, four daughters and five granddaughters. Upon graduating William & Mary College and Columbia Law, he formed the Manhasset Law firm of Molley, Fletcher & Dunne. He was a retired Air Force Colonel and a prominent leader in the community.

BRAUS--Jay R.,Beloved cousin, partner and best friend of John Samuelson for more than 50 years. He was an astute art collector, prominent real estate investor and very bright in all he undertook. Most of all, he was a devoted husband, father, grandfather and great grandfather. He will be missed by the entire Samuelson family- John, Barbara, Charles, Franziska and Richard.

BARKAS--Grace, almost 92, of Franklin Square and Boca Raton. Revered, loving wife to the late Arty. Beloved mother to Daryl, proud gram to Jana and husband Todd, great-grandma to Ari Grayson, Loving Sister to Marvin Leichtung and the late Arthur, adored sister-in-law to Carole and Jan. Precious aunt, cousin, friend. She meant a lot to many and everything to a special few.

FLASHLIGHT Written and illustrated by Lizi Boyd. 33 pp. Chronicle. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 7) 
 
This elegant wordless book captures the enduring appeal of the simple flashlight. In gouache illustrations on black pages, a child starts the evening in a tent, then ventures out, projecting pure white cones of light to reveal a delicately drawn riot of nocturnal creatures and other surprises. When he trips and drops his lamp, the animals join the fun. Even they know there is nothing quite as cool as shining that beam into the deepest dark of night.
