ZICK--Mary Sutter. Of Key Largo, FL, beloved wife of nearly 66 years of John Walter Zick passed away on Monday afternoon. She is survived by her husband, two daughters Sharon Zick Rieger and Catherine Zick Manning, a daughter-in-law, Donna Poole Zick, two sons-in-law, Brian Louis Rieger and George Taylor Manning, six grandchildren and a great-granddaughter. Mary and John's son, John Walter Zick, Jr. predeceased his mother in 1998. Mary began her life in Evanston, Il as the daughter of Harry Blair Sutter and Elsie Paul Sutter. She attended Roycemore School and Northwestern University. Much of Mary's adult life was devoted to helping others through volunteer service. She served with the Junior League of Chicago as a Senior Vice President, the Garden Club of America, and the Greenwich Garden Club, where she was honored in 1986 with the Garden Club trophy for the most noteworthy accomplishment by a member during that year. Mary also worked with Greenwich Hospital Hospice Services, Girl Scouts, and as President of the Garden Group at Ocean Reef. She also volunteered to arrange flowers monthly for the Chapel at Ocean Reef. Mary co-founded the Winnetka Presbyterian Church and brought Lloyd John Ogilvie, later to become Chaplain of the United States Senate, to Winnetka to serve as its first pastor. Mary was often described as the most beautiful woman in the room, not only for her outer beauty but for her inner grace, beauty and love for others which shone through. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions can be made to the Medical Center Foundation at Ocean Reef, 50 Barracuda Lane, Key Largo, FL 33037 or to the Ocean Reef Chapel Foundation, P.O. Box 226, Saint Augustine, FL 32086.

YOUNG--Michael Alan, Esq. June 27, 1946 - October 15, 2014. Survived by loving partner Harvey Alter and their dog Luca, sister Alison Bauer, brother Jon Young, nephew Scott Bauer, niece Dana Bauer. Cornell University and Columbia Law; Criminal defense and appellate attorney; Co-founder of International Aphasia Movement (IAM). Lived in NYC and Fire Island Pines. Email: aphasiamovement@aol.com for donation information.

TAMNY--Martin, passed away on October 18, 2014. He was born in the Bronx, attended George Washington High School, the City College of New York, Wolfson College at Oxford, and received his PhD from City University of New York in 1976. He was Professor of Philosophy and then a most cherished, principled and accomplished Dean of Social Sciences, then of Humanities and the Arts at CCNY while also teaching at the CUNY Graduate Center. His classes ranged over many areas of philosophy, but his central interests were in the philosophy and history of science. Among many other publications, he co-edited Isaac Newton's Trinity Notebook, an important early manuscript of Newton's. As Dean of Humanities, Martin navigated the division through one of the worst fiscal crises in CCNY's history, managing to strengthen it through far-seeing strategic initiatives, including the establishment of the K.D. Irani endowment in philosophy. Martin's distinguished accomplishments as a professor, writer, and administrator never took precedence over his evident humanity, which showed in his dealings with colleagues and friends, but was most apparent in his family. Deeply devoted to his wife Myrna, of more than fifty years who died in 2013, he was a warm, often funny and always present and supportive father to Mark and Tara. His death is a profound loss to them and to their spouses, Coleen and Matthew, and Martin's grandchildren, Ella, Ben and Toby.

STRAX--Ilene C. (nee Berman), Elkins Park, PA, on October 14, 2014. Partner of Howard Izes and former wife of Thomas Strax. Mother of Heller and Jeff Moses and Joshua and Kate Strax. Grandmother of Sophie and Kole Moses and Jonah and Seth Strax. Sister of Susan and Michael Hort. Funeral services at 11:30am, Sunday, "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made to the Rema Hort Mann Foundation, 153 Hudson Street, NY, NY 10013 or the Fox Chase Cancer Center, 333 Cottman Ave., Philadelphia, PA 19111.

SOLLINS--Susan. The family of Susan Sollins mourns the sudden death on October 13, 2014, of our beloved sister, aunt, and sister-in-law. She has left us with countless memories of a life well lived, filled with laughter and love. Susan conveyed her lifelong passion for the visual arts to all those who knew her, so that all of us from closest family to dearest friends and a constantly growing circle of colleagues and collaborators shared in the joys and discoveries of her ever-curious and inquiring eye for beauty, brilliance, and meaning in art. Above all, Susan cherished her family her mother and father, the late Sonya and Irving Sollins; her husband, the late Earle Brown; her brother and sister-in-law, James Sollins and Louise Eliasof; her sister, Marybeth Sollins; and her nephews and nieces-in-law and their children Andrew Farnsworth and Patricia Ryan, and Aja; Stephen Sollins and Rachel Devlin, and Jonah and Cady. At the time of her death, Susan was the Executive Director of ART21, Inc., and Producer, Director, and Curator of the groundbreaking Peabody Award-winning documentary television series, Art in the Twenty-First Century, broadcast nationwide on PBS and now in its seventh season. Her feature-length film, William Kentridge: Anything is Possible, also received a Peabody Award. Susan was the co-founder, with the late Nina Sundell, of Independent Curators Incorporated (ICI), now Independent Curators International, and was its Executive Director Emerita. She also served on the boards of the MacDowell Colony, the CBG Foundation, and at the time of her death was President of the Earle Brown Music Foundation. We will honor and celebrate Susan at a memorial gathering, which has not yet been scheduled. Contributions to ART21, 133 W. 25th St. #

SHEPARD--Joyce Ralph Allen. Our beloved Joyce was born in Grand Island, NE on December 6, 1923 and passed away peacefully, surrounded by her children, in Amherst, MA on October 11, 2014. She graduated from Duchesne College in Omaha, NE and then moved to New York City where she received a Masters in Performance in violin from Juilliard. Subsequently, she earned a Masters in Teaching from Columbia University and taught in the Rye, NY schools for many years. She then received a MS in Library Science from Long Island University and worked as a Media Specialist/ Librarian. The last 30 years of her life were spent in Coronado, CA, where she was active in the music community and served as an involved member of Planned Parenthood in San Diego. She was a lifelong violin performer and teacher. Music was her passion. She is survived by her five children, Jay, Jennifer, and Judy Allen; PJ and Leonard Shepard; her seven grandchildren; and three great-grandchildren. Donations may be made in memory of Joyce R. Shepard to Planned Parenthood of the Pacific Southwest or the Coronado Public Library, Coronado, CA.

ROSENBAUM--Judy, passed away peacefully in her home, as was her wish, on September 30th 2014. Her life was one of dedication to her mother, Dr. Bertha Rader, to her work, and to literature. She leaves behind wonderful children's stories and beautiful poems. Judy opened new paths in the world of literature to children and adults alike. She possessed a wealth of knowledge and could engage anyone in meaningful conversations on a myriad of topics, recalling even the smallest of details on everything, from fashion to sports. With her incredible memory, she was always generously ready to lend a helping hand, especially if it involved reading, writing, editing or researching. Always friendly and caring, Judy touched the hearts of everyone who met her. She leaves behind many friends including Zorka Hristova and Nina Argirova, in particular. Judy finally found her passageway to Narnia - may she reign there, happily, for eternity. We, on the other side of the wardrobe, will greatly miss her. Donations may be made to Books For Kids.

RATAJCZAK--David. Beloved Broadway and Big Band drummer Dave Ratajczak passed away after a courageous battle with Ocular Melanoma on October 3. He leaves behind a magnificent legacy of love, laughter, and music. Mr. Ratajczak performed and recorded with a wide variety of artists as well as many Tony award winning Broadway shows and film soundtracks. He is survived by his wife of 25 years, Amie Block Ratajczak, and his children Matthew and Emilie. A celebration of his life will be held on Monday, October 20 at 5pm at The Plymouth Church in Brooklyn Heights. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Ocular Melanoma Foundation or Eastman School of Music.

RADEST--Howard B.,of West Caldwell, New Jersey, passed away on October 11, 2014. Howard was born in Brooklyn, New York on June 29, 1928. Howard was the son of Louis and Golda Radest. He received his BA at Columbia University, MA in Philosophy and Psychology at the New School for Social Research and his PhD in Philosophy at Columbia University. Dr. Radest was a Professor of Philosophy and Director of the School of Human Studies at Ramapo College of New Jersey, Executive Director of The American Ethical Union, and Leader of the Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County, NJ. He was the founder and first chair of the University Seminar on Moral Education at Columbia University. Dr. Radest served as a member of the Mental Health Board of Bergen County (NJ), the Board of Managers of Bergen Pines County Hospital, Chair of the Bergen County Health and Welfare Council, and Vice President of the NJ State Welfare Council. He was Director of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School, was a founder and Dean of The Humanist Institute, a member of the National Council of Ethical Culture Leaders and Co-Chair of the International Humanist and Ethical Union. In addition he was a member of the Highlands Institute for American Religious and Philosophic Thought. Upon moving to South Carolina, he taught medical ethics and comparative religion at the University of South Carolina. While in South Carolina, he also served as Chair of the Ethics Committees and as Consulting Member, Emeritus, Bioethics Committee of the South Carolina Medical Association. Dr. Radest is the author of nine books and numerous articles on ethics, philosophy and religion. He also held many other Board memberships including Board Chair of The Ethical Community Charter School in Jersey City. Howard is survived by his loving wife of nearly 63 years, Rita; his two sons, Robert (and his wife Nora), and Michael (and his wife Karen); and five grandchildren, Joseph (Jes), Emma, Brendan, Kara and Colin. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, November 15, 2014 at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, New York, NY at 10:00am. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to The Humanist Institute; write "The Rita Radest Scholarship Fund" in the memo field. Please mail to The Humanist Institute, PMB #

PROCTOR--William Ross, of Sanibel, FL and Glen Spey, NY, died Monday October 6th. Mr. Proctor born in 1920 was the oldest son of William Ross Proctor Sr. and Joy Williams Proctor. He graduated from Pomfret School in 1939 and then served in World War II as First Lieutenant in the United States Army. He is survived by his wife of 25 years, Mary Jane Proctor, his four children Ross Proctor of Rochester, NY, Rich Proctor of Kailua, HI, Kate Brooks of Lawrenceville, NJ, and Liz Salguero of Wilton, CT and 13 loving grandchildren. PELS--Donald A.,died peacefully on October 16, 2014 at his home in Manhattan. He was 86. Born January 23, 1928 to Herbert and Alice Pels of New Rochelle, NY, Mr. Pels was a graduate of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania and received a J.D. from New York University School of Law. He was a devoted husband and loving father, grandfather and brother. His friends and family will miss his intelligence, sharp wit, playfulness and his internal clock, which always knew when it was 5pm. Mr. Pels had a successful career in broadcasting, but his greatest business achievement was his vision about the future of cellular technology. As Chairman and President of Lin Broadcasting from 1969 1989, he transformed the company into a strategically important cellular pioneer. Prior to Lin, Mr. Pels was Chief Financial Officer at Capital Cities Communications, Inc. and before then, an executive at the American Broadcasting Company. After his retirement, Mr. Pels devoted himself to his passions: generously and quietly supporting projects in science, education, human rights, parks, the arts, and social policy issues such as compassion in dying. At the time of his death, Mr. Pels was a Director Emeritus of the New York Philharmonic and a Trustee Emeritus at Rockefeller University. He is survived by his wife, Wendy Keys; his children, Juliette Meeus, Valerie Pels and Laurence Pels; his grandchildren Natalie, Matthew, Rebecca and Cate; his sister Betty Schwartz and his sister-in-law Barbara Pels. Memorials may be made to Human Rights Watch or to The Friends of the High Line.

PELS--Donald A. The trustees, faculty, students, and staff of The Rockefeller University mourn the loss of our cherished friend Donald A. Pels, an esteemed member of our Board of Trustees for more than two decades. Donald Pels joined The Rockefeller University Board of Trustees in 1993 and was elected Emeritus Trustee in 2003. Over the years, Don served on many Board committees, including Audit, Budget and Operations, Development, and Technology Transfer. His participation in the work of these committees and his commitment to advancing scientific research greatly strengthened the University. Early in his involvement at Rockefeller, Don took a leadership role by establishing the Pels Family Center for Biochemistry and Structural Biology. Through his gift creating the Pels Family Center, he helped recruit several outstanding early-career faculty, providing them with enhanced opportunities to share ideas and collaborate. Don was deeply interested in the young investigators he supported, and he derived enormous pleasure from meeting with them to learn about their work. Don's passion for scientific inquiry led him to establish the Pels Family Professorship, an endowed chair for a senior faculty member. Don and his wife, Wendy Keys, also supported many other initiatives at Rockefeller, including the Tri-Institutional Noon Concert Series. Beyond Rockefeller, Don will be remembered for his service on the boards of a number of prestigious institutions, including the Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center and the Philharmonic Symphony Society of New York, and his active engagement in the cultural life of New York City. Don will be greatly missed by the Rockefeller campus community. We send our heartfelt condolences to Don's beloved wife, Wendy; his three children, Juliette, Valerie and Laurence; and his entire family. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Russell Carson, Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Torsten Wiesel, President Emeritus Tarun Kapoor, Pels Family Professor

MOUNT--Isabel. Beloved mother, grandmother, and wife died peacefully in New York at the age of 86. She loved the opera, the ballet, and art. An inveterate world traveler--from Africa to her most adored, France--she lived life to the fullest. She will be greatly missed. Christopher, Stephanie and Julian Mount.

MORRIS--Alan R.,on October 17, 2014. Beloved husband of Sue. Loving father of David and Jonathan and his wife Sarah. Cherished grandfather of Emily and Hannah. A pioneer in the television and entertainment industries, he will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Memorial service Tuesday, October 21, 2014, 3:30pm at Frank E Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.

MELTON--Andrew J.,Jr., 94, former Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of Dean Witter died at his home in Tequesta, FL on October 15, 2014. Mr. Melton enjoyed a distinguished career on Wall Street. In 1946 he joined Smith Barney & Co. After 25 years with the firm he joined Dean Witter. In 1978 following the merger with Reynolds Securities Mr. Melton was named Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive of Dean Witter Reynolds. After Sears, Roebuck and Company purchased Dean Witter Reynolds in 1981, he became Chairman of Dean Witter Funds, a position he held until 1992. Raised in Bay Shore, NY, Mr. Melton graduated from Villanova University in 1942. He was commissioned an officer in the United States Marine Corps, serving in both the Pacific and Atlantic Campaigns during World War II. He was recalled to active duty in 1950 during the Korean Conflict. He was discharged from the Marine Reserves as a Major. Mr. Melton's engagement with the professional community included terms as President of the Investment Bankers Association and the Bond Club of New York. He also gave of his time and organizational talents to his local community. His positions included Commodore of the Bay Shore Yacht Club, President of the Southward Ho Country Club also in Bay Shore, N.Y. Since retirement he lived in Dorset, VT and Tequesta, FL. His greatest joy was following the activities of his very large family. The word patriarch describes his role and the respect he enjoyed. Mr. Melton was pre-deceased by his beloved wife of 55 years, Mary Ann Melton, as well as his five sisters and four brothers. He is survived by his loving companion, Barbara Fazio, and his eight children, Diana Melton Lemmen of Bremen, Germany; Andrew J. Melton III of New York, NY; Colonel Robert S. Melton, USMC (Ret) of Palm Beach Gardens, FL; Karen Melton Fox of West Palm Beach, FL; Marjorie Melton Field of Jupiter, FL; Sandra Melton Lessing of Cold Spring Harbor, NY; Michaelle Melton Stott of Riverside, CT; and, Edward L. Melton of Darien, CT. He is also survived by twenty-three grandchildren and thirteen great grandchildren. The family will receive friends at Taylor & Modeen Funeral Home, 250 Center Street, Jupiter on Friday, October 17th from 6:00pm until 8:00pm. A mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Christopher Church, 12001 SE Federal Hwy, Hobe Sound on Saturday, October 18th at 11:30am followed with military honors conducted by U.S. Marine Corps. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to St. Patrick's School, 9 North Clinton Ave., Bay Shore, NY 11706. For directions or to express online condolences please visit www.taylorandmodeen.com.

LUKE--Fanny C.,of Locust Valley, NY and New York City, NY on October 16th, 2014 age 91. Beloved wife of David L. III. Sister of Polly, Kay and Laura. Also survived by many nieces, nephews and extended family members. Service to be held at St. John's of Lattingtown, Friday, October 24th at 11am. Interment Private. Donations may be made to the Westover School (1237 Whittemore Rd., Middlebury, CT 06762-0847).

LUKE--Fanny, died on Thursday, October 16. She was born in Boston in 1923, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Curtis, formerly of Chestnut Hill and Manchester, MA. She was married in 1955 and is survived by her husband, David, her sisters, Polly, Kay and Laura, many nieces, nephews, and other equally devoted family members. She graduated from the Westover School in 1941. In 1943 she joined the United States Navy Waves and, after training, she was involved in the final modification of combat aircraft for U.S. Naval Forces in the Pacific Theatre, including the very planes which the man she later married was then flying in combat. She completed her military service in 1946. She subsequently attended Radcliff College, receiving a B.A. degree in 1951. She worked briefly for Houghton Mifflin and also for Harvard University, and then moved to New York. In New York she took courses at Bank Street College of Education and then devoted nearly 12 years to teaching young children primarily at the Episcopal School. From 19721980 she served on the Board of the Westover School. She was a member of the Board of the City Gardens Club and served as President of the Club for two years. She was active in her churches in New York and Locust Valley. Burial will be private in the Locust Valley Cemetery and a memorial service will be held at St. John's of Lattingtown Church, 325 Lattingtown Road, Locust Valley, NY, 11560 on October 24 at 11am, to be immediately followed by a reception at the Piping Rock Club, 150 Piping Rock Road, Locust Valley, NY, 11560. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts to the Westover School, 1237 Whittemore Road, Middlebury, CT, 06762, would be very welcome.
LaROSSA--James M.,My mentor, my friend. It was an honor to sit at your table. Jerry Shargel

LaROSSA--James M.,one of the most accomplished trial lawyers of his generation, died peacefully at his home in Manhattan Beach, CA, on October 15, 2014, after years of outsmarting a variety of illnesses. Affectionately known as "Jimmy" his entire life, he was born on December 4, 1931 in Brooklyn, NY. Jimmy served as a Marine Corps officer during the Korean War and was a former Assistant United States Attorney in the Eastern District of New York; following his public service, he went into private practice and represented many colorful figures in New York City and beyond. His professional accomplishments as a defense lawyer have been recorded numerous times in this newspaper and countless others. His lasting legacy comes from his rich and fulfilling relationships with his family and his countless devoted friends throughout the country. He touched many lives in his 82 years on this earth, and his family takes comfort in the love others are expressing in his memory. His children, grandchildren, and friends readily admit that it is difficult to imagine a world without this gregarious lover of life. Beloved father to James, Thomas, Nancy and Susan, cherished grandfather to Sofia, Gianni, Juliana and Xixi, adored brother to Dolores (Nelson), and loyal friend to many, many people. His final wish was for us to squeeze every last drop out of our lives. And we will. We love you Dad, we love you Pop-Pop, we love you buddy. Till we see you again.

JIBILIAN--Gerald "Gerry" A. 76, a 20 year resident of Chester, NJ passed away on September 12, 2014 surrounded by his loved ones. Gerry was born on March 30, 1938 in Toledo, OH. He graduated from Maumee High School in 1956 where he thrived as a student-athlete and became student council president. He graduated with Honors from Duke University in 1960 and received his Law Degree from the University of Michigan in 1963. While a student at U of Michigan, he met the love of his life, Jary Sue Ridout, and they were married December 26, 1965. Gerry started his long, outstanding career serving as the Assistant Law Director for the city of Toledo and soon after he became the youngest Chief Prosecutor in Toledo. From there he was named an Associate at the law firm of Colbourn, Yager, Smith & Falvey (1963-1969); Vice President and General Counsel of Ogden Foods (1969-1971); Executive Vice President of Schrafft's (1971-1973); Senior Attorney for American Home Products Inc. (later named Wyeth) (1973-1975); Assistant General Counsel of Wyeth Corp. (1985-1986); Associate General Counsel of Wyeth Corp. (1987-1991); Vice President and Associate General Counsel of Wyeth Corp. (1991-2002). Gerry was an active member of the Duke University Alumni Admissions Committee and the University Club in New York City. Following his retirement in 2002, Gerry and his wife travelled the world. Gerry is survived by his beloved wife of 49 years, Jary Sue; his son John F. Jibilian and his wife Antonia; three grandchildren; his sister Janice; and his Godchildren David and Jenny Zhang, and their son. His family and friends will miss his fine humor, generous spirit, warm smile, and the love he gave to all. Services will be held privately by the Family. Services by William J. Leber Funeral Home, 15 Furnace Road (Corner of Rt 206), Chester, NJ (908) 879-3090.

JARMEL--Irving, on September 29, 2014 in Summerlin, NV (formerly of Merrick, NY). Beloved husband of the late Roslyn Russo Jarmel. Loving father to Mark, Todd (deceased) and Ellin. JACKSON--Susan Annabel, formerly Susan Rosenberg, born Fourteenth November 1959 in Bromley, Kent, died Fourteenth October 2014, in Santa Barbara, California, after a truly heroic battle against breast cancer, peacefully, and surrounded by family and friends. She is survived by her husband Ben Morahan, mother Elizabeth, and sister Caroline with Daniel and John. Services will be held privately. Susan enjoyed a long and highly successful career in independent film distribution, which included founding sales company Turtles Crossing and co-founding Freestyle Releasing, and apart from ignoring glass ceilings, she also thoroughly enjoyed Taos deep skiing, mad dog whispering, tournament tennis playing, cool disco dancing, the Big Island lolling, trying to be captain of everything, and thankfully also loving her devoted husband, Ben, who is really going to miss her. To all her friends, you have the family's fondest condolences. Meanwhile, Susan has taken a steep line down through the trees, and she will just have to wait for the rest of us at the bottom of the mountain. As usual.

HARBER--Leonard, M.D. The Department of Dermatology of the Columbia University Medical Center and its faculty, residents and staff mourn the death of Leonard C. Harber MD, the Richard and Mildred Rhodeback Professor Emeritus of Dermatology and Professor Emeritus of Public Health. He served as chair of this department from 1973 to 1988. He received the A.B. degree from Johns University in 1949, the M.D. from NYU in 1953, and two M.S. degrees from NYU, in 1956 and 1959. In 1956-57 he was a Fulbright Scholar at the Finsen Institute in Copenhagen. In 1969-1970 he was a Guest Investigator at the Rockefeller University Hospital and in 1986-1987 he was a Visiting Scholar at Green College, Oxford University. Dr. Harber was a gifted and charismatic physician-scientist, educator and clinician and one of the leading academic dermatologists of his generation. He trained numerous residents and fellows who have achieved leadership positions around the world. Under his direction the Columbia department was recognized as a global center of excellence in the area of Photobiology, a discipline focused on studying the effects of sunlight on the skin. He and his collaborators made major contributions regarding human skin diseases associated with sun exposure including cutaneous porphyria and photoallergic reactions. During his tenure, Dr. Harber created one of the major centers in the world dedicated to using artificial light sources for treating human skin diseases such as psoriasis. He pioneered implementation of out-patient ambulatory day-treatment of patients with psoriasis. In addition to his academic accomplishments Len was an avid fisherman and a passionate oenophile and gourmet who traveled the world seeking out unique culinary experiences. He was a learned man of great intellectual depth and breadth and a wonderful raconteur. He has left an indelible legacy to the department and to Columbia University. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his loving wife, Rosalyn, sons Steven Harber (Lana) and Jonathan Harber (Maria), and four grandchildren (Oliver, Sophia, Grayson and James). Contributions in his memory can be made to the Leonard C. Harber Professorship of Dermatology, Department of Dermatology, Columbia University Medical Center, 161 Fort Washington Ave, 12th Fl, New York, NY 10032. David R. Bickers, M.D. Carl Truman Nelson Professor and Chairman
HARBER--Leonard C.,MD, was a master teacher, astute clinician, and loving family man. He was my role model from the beginning. Marc E. Grossman, MD

HARBER--Dr. Leonard Coleman, died peacefully at home on Sunday at the age of 87. A dedicated physician, scientist, teacher, husband, father and grandfather, Len was known for his pithy one-liners. These 'Harberisms' were funny in their oversimplification of life's trials but also showed his ever-present wisdom and humor. Len loved good wine, good food, fishing and especially his family. He will be missed by his wife of 52 years, Rosalyn; his two sons Steven and Jonathan; His daughters-in-law, Lana and Maria; And four grandchildren: Sophia, Oliver, Grayson and James. We will all miss Big Len. Donations can be made in his honor to the Leonard C. Harber Professorship of Dermatology at Columbia University Medical Center.
HABER--Gloria Millicent. March 3, 1928 - October 18, 2014. So long Mil. We loved you and will miss you.

GREENFIELD--Alan Jay M.D. age 70, of Boston, MA and Palm Springs, CA, passed away peacefully on October 9, 2014, ending a seven-year battle with kidney disease. He was a distinguished interventional and vascular radiologist at Massachusetts General Hospital and several other leading hospitals; a respected source of knowledge and recommendations for his colleagues; and a tech support resource for all during the infancy of personal computers. Alan was a reviewer for multiple journals, including the New England Journal of Medicine; a committee member and committee chairman of various radiology societies; wrote or contributed to over 60 refereed publications in radiology journals; and made numerous presentations for both clinical education and research symposia. He loved to teach, and mentored many medical students who are now in positions of prominence nationwide; his enthusiasm for vascular radiology attracted many young physicians to the field. Alan was born and raised in Highland Park, NJ where he graduated from Lafayette Elementary and Highland Park High Schools. He graduated from Rutgers University, where he was elected to the Phi Beta Kappa society, and earned his medical degree from Johns Hopkins University in 1969. He then served in the US Public Health Service at the National Institutes of Health. After completing his Residency and Fellowship at MGH, his 40 year medical career continued at MGH, Morristown (New Jersey) Memorial Hospital, Boston University Medical Center, and Tufts New England Medical Center. He returned to MGH in 2000 until he retired in 2013. He was an accomplished choral singer since his college days, performing and touring with a variety of groups including the Rutgers College Glee Club, Tanglewood Festival Chorus, Handel & Haydn Society, New York City and Boston Gay Men's Choruses, Chorus pro Musica and the New World Chorale. He will be fondly missed by his beloved husband, G.P. Paul Kowal, and their two devoted Maltese-Yorkies, Katy and Gaga; his beloved children, Jessica Greenfield (Hummel) and Ely Greenfield, and their mother Harriet Greenfield; his cherished grandchildren, Hannah and Theo Hummel, and Tavi and Emilia Greenfield; and his loving sister, Donna Greenfield Belser. A celebration of Alan's life will be held at Temple Israel of Boston on Sunday, November 23, 2014 at 1:30pm. Please send contributions in his memory to the MGH Division of Nephrology Renal Unit Research Fund, Bigelow 1008, 55 Fruit St., Boston 02114. This fund supports young investigators, who find it hard to get funding for their projects via the regular pipeline.

DANIELS--Harvey, age 89 on October 11, 2014. Predeceased by adored wife Natalie. Beloved father of Stuart (Ismene) and Andrew. Cherished grandfather of Alexander and Peter. CHARKIN--Selma. Age 101, died peacefully on October 12, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Norton (70 years), cherished mother of Eileen Weiler Judell (Robert) and the late Joy Ganney, adored grandmother of Pamela Weiler Grayson (Douglas) and Andrew Weiler (Cecilia) and Ryan Ganney, great-grandmother of Deanna, Jamie, Erica and Marcus, and loving sister of Phyllis Fure. A remarkable woman, she was blessed with many extraordinary qualities. She and her husband founded the Mayflower Wallpaper Company in White Plains. She was known for her philanthropy, educational volunteerism, and her leadership positions at The Lincoln Park Jewish Center. Her many honors included Westchester County's Executive declaring June 10, 2012 Selma Charkin Day, and a mention in the Congressional Record. Selma was always beautifully dressed, and dazzled everyone in the room, with her looks and personality. The way she lived her life was an inspiration to all. She will be greatly missed. A service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Sunday, October 19th at 10:00am. The family will receive on Sunday at the home of Eileen Judell, from 3-9pm.

CAVIOR--Warren Joseph, much loved husband, father and brother, died on October 13, 2014 in Ossining, NY, at age 85. Born in Boston and raised in Brookline, MA. Moved to New York City in the 1950s, where he was an editor at Forbes magazine and then a businessman and public relations executive. Formed his own public relations firm in the 1980s, which he ran until retirement in 2003. Survived by his wife of 45 years, Mariko Sanjo, daughter Mayu, son Samuel, grandsons Joel and Jacob, and brother Stephen. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to the Harvard College Fund or the UJA. For information: scavior@gmail.com.

CARSWELL--Lois. The Board of Trustees, Volunteers, and Staff of Brooklyn Botanic Garden are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed Board Chair Emeritus, Lois Carswell. Lois began her decades-long career at BBG as a volunteer in the Auxiliary. Elected a BBG Trustee in 1985, Lois co-chaired the Conservatory Campaign, chaired and served on numerous important Board Committees, and chaired the Board of Trustees from 1989-98. For more than 40 years, she co-chaired the Garden's annual Plant Sale with her good friend and fellow Trustee Lucille Plotz. Among the many highlights of her service as Chair, Lois hosted then-current President Bill Clinton on a visit to the Garden. In recognition of her service, one of BBG's famed yellow magnolia hybrids was named for her, and today the lemon-yellow flowers of Magnolia "Lois" adorn spring gardens throughout Brooklyn and beyond. Lois was a legend in Albany having founded the statewide Coalition of Living Museums in 1980 and serving as its chair ever since; during her extraordinary leadership the CLM has brought hundreds of millions of dollars of support to operate Zoos, Botanical Gardens, Aquaria and other living museums across New York State. Lois' tremendous passion, vision, and accomplishments inspired all who knew her. She created a wide circle of friends and colleagues as part of her legacy at the Garden and will be deeply missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her children Anne, Alex, and Bob, and to her entire family. Frederick Bland, Board Chair Scot Medbury, President Frances Mendlow, Auxiliary President

BROWN--Alice C. "Dede". Of Essex, Connecticut and Quogue, New York, died peacefully on October 5, 2014 in Essex, Connecticut. She was born on February 27, 1929 in Orange, New Jersey to Moreau Delano Brown and Alice Cordelia Barbour. She attended the Ethel Walker School, Class of 1947, and Smith College, Class of 1951. She spent her entire career at Morgan Guaranty Trust Co. of New York from which she retired, as one of the first female Vice Presidents, in 1989. Miss Brown was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club, the Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd, the Madison Ave Presbyterian Church in New York City, a member of the American Contract Bridge Club, a member of the Quogue Beach Club, the West Hampton Presbyterian Church and the Quogue Field Club. Her passions included spending time with her friends and family, the beach, playing bridge (a Bronze Life Master), tennis, skiing and travel. She was a dedicated volunteer serving as the first woman to become a President of the Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd. in 1975. She joined the BHT in 1956 and was currently serving as Honorary Chair. As a member of the Cosmopolitan Club for nearly 30 years, Miss Brown served on many committees: First Vice President on the Board of Governors 2000-2003, Treasurer on the Board of Governors 1996-1999, Classes Committee, Treasurer 2008-2010, Bridge Committee 2010-2013, the Building Committee, The Nominating Committee, Audit Committee and the Website Committee. She was also the first woman to be a Treasurer of the Quogue Field Club, a post she held for over ten years. Miss Brown is survived by a nephew, Thomas G. Brown, of Reno, Nevada, a niece, Elizabeth Brown Warters, of Newport News, Virginia, and a nephew, Adam H. Brown, of Monkton, Maryland and her cat, Winnie. Funeral services will be held on November 8, 2014 at 2pm at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue (at 73 Street), New York, New York. In lieu of flowers, Miss Brown's family requests that donations be made in her memory to either: The Blue Hill Troupe Fund at P.O. Box 286800, Yorkville Station, New York, NY 10128; The Essex Meadows Employees Fund at 30 Bokum Road Essex CT 06426; The Ethel Walker School at Fund for Walker's, Development Office, The Ethel Walker School, 230 Bushy Hill Road, Simsbury, CT 06070; or Smith College at The Smith Fund, P.O. Box 340029, Boston, MA 022410429.

BRAZIL--Gladys Hardy. In memoriam to Gladys Hardy Brazil, 85, who passed quietly on September 20, 2014 with her family at her bedside at Harvest Hill in the Elizabeth Hughes Care Unit in Lebanon, NH. She died of complications related to Alzheimer's disease. Gladys was born February 15, 1929, the eldest daughter of Loy and Lucy Pang Yao Chang (deceased). Loy Chang was Director General of Customs and Currency in the Nationalist Government of China. In 1940, Gladys, at the age of 12, was responsible for shepherding her mother and five siblings to Hawaii to avoid the threat of kidnapping of high government officials' families by occupying Japanese forces. Gladys attended Punaho School during the family's short stay in Hawaii. The family moved to Claremont, CA in 1941. There she attended the Girls Collegiate School and then went on to Sarah Lawrence College, class of 1950. She served as Student Body President in her senior year at Sarah Lawrence. Sarah Lawrence recognized Gladys with a lifetime achievement award in 2010. Her career achievements include TV production credits for the Tex and Jinx Show, and associate producer of the Edward R. Murrow radio show, This I Believe. Encouraged by Murrow, she applied for and received a Ford Foundation Fellowship to study Chinese communities in Southeast Asian countries. She was associate producer for the Life Magazine multimedia presentation, The World We Live In. She was the first staff member of the National Endowment for the Humanities and the first public member of NPR'S board of directors. President Carter appointed her senior executive in the U.S. Department of Education where she served as Deputy Director of the National Institute of Education. Other key positions included Undersecretary of Education in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and director of education and culture for the Ford Foundation. She was listed in the ninth edition of Prominent Women in America. In retirement, Gladys consulted for the College Board, Teachers College at Columbia University, and the Children's Defense Fund, as well as, sitting on the Board of Lincoln Center and the Advisory Board of NPR's This I Believe program. Gladys married twice, first to David Keith Hardy in 1958. They had two children, Brian and Kathryn. She was widowed in 1970. In 1981 she married Dr. Percy Brazil of Tarrytown, NY and later, Sherman, CT. In 2011 she moved to Hanover, NH and then to Harvest Hill in Lebanon, NH where she was an active member of the community until becoming ill in March of 2014. Gladys was a lifelong tennis player and fan of the game. Gladys is survived by: her two children by her first marriage and David's children, Sarah and Alistair, nine grandchildren, her husband Percy, and her sisters, Christine and Rosalind and her brothers, Arthur and Victor. Family gatherings will be held in Ireland and California. A memorial scholarship will be established in Gladys' name at Sarah Lawrence College.

BIRKHOFER--Wiley Thomas, July 7, 1987 September 30, 2014. Resident of Brooklyn, NY. Wiley Thomas Birkhofer passed away on September 30, 2014. Wiley was born in California on July 7, 1987 at Stanford Hospital, the first child of Wendell Wiley Birkhofer and Celeste Phaneuf Birkhofer. He grew up in Menlo Park, CA, where he attended Oak Knoll and Menlo Schools. Wiley flourished in academics and sports, especially basketball, soccer and lacrosse. He also became an avid skier, surfer and seeker of adventure. After graduating from Stanford University with his Bachelor of Arts degree in English in 2009, Wiley continued to pursue his love of writing. He completed his Master of Fine Arts degree in Creative Writing - Poetry at New York University in 2014. Wiley recently achieved his goal of becoming an English professor, and was teaching at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York City. He was planning to teach creative arts to underserved kids through Community-Word Project in the New York City School System. His work career also included teaching at Sacred Hearts School on Maui, Boys and Girls Club, and undergrad writing and poetry courses at NYU during his Master's program. While living in New York, his passion for creating art and music grew exponentially. Wiley made a lasting impression on many people. He deeply loved his family and countless friends. They will forever remember his uninhibited spirit, creativity, intellectual curiosity, sense of humor, sensitivity and compassion for others. Wiley is survived by his parents, sister Elise Marie Birkhofer and grandfather G. Wendell Birkhofer. A memorial service will be held at Stanford Memorial Church in California on Tuesday, October 21 at 2:30pm. The reception to follow will be a private gathering. The family suggests that donations can be made in Wiley's memory to the National Alliance on Mental Health: (namicalifornia.org) or Community-Word Project: (communitywordproject.org) in New York.

BALLEN--Irving W. The Partners, Associates and Staff of McLaughlin & Stern, LLP record their deep sorrow at the loss of our esteemed former Partner, Irving Ballen. He was a lawyer of almost peerless talent and honor, and a gentleman of thoughtfulness and grace. For almost four decades he was an integral leader of our firm. For years to come, we will gratefully remember and honor his professional talents and personal warmth.

TANNER--Robert E.,died suddenly October 13, 2014. He is survived by his wife Barbara, his children Max and Claire, daughter-in-law Gwen Torsky, his sisters Suzanne Pomakov and Lonnie Trimarche, his brothers Scott and Patrick Tanner, and nieces and nephews. Rob graduated from Sarah Lawrence College and Columbia Business School and began his career at Goldman Sachs. He then joined Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette, later Credit Suisse, First Boston. After retirement, he was free to explore museums and historical sites in the United States and France, and to amass a world-class music collection. Rob's family and friends will miss his enthusiasm and idiosyncratic sense of humor. A memorial service will take place at 11am Sunday, October 26th at the Brooklyn Historical Society, 128 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, NY.

TANANBAUM--Doris, of Harrison, New York died peacefully on October 18, 2014 at age 92. She is survived by her loving husband of 73 years, Stanley Tananbaum; devoted mother to Ricki Gail Conway and Andrew Tananbaum; grandmother to Laurence and Beth Zuriff, Bryan and Monica Zuriff, Zoe and Jon Bernstein, JoBeth Tananbaum and Tanner Tananbaum, and great-grandmother to Sophie, Jason, Alexa, Maxine, Jordana and Jasper Zuriff, and Gideon Bernstein. She was a woman ahead of her time in every sense. She was interested in fashion, poetry and early American antiques. Her entire extended family cherished her wisdom and unique style. She will be deeply missed, and her memory will be a blessing. A private service will be held on Monday, October 20th.

SOLLINS--Susan. The board, staff, and community of ART21 mourn the death of ART21's Founder and Executive Director Susan Sollins and commemorate her groundbreaking achievements. Susan was a visionary creative force and tireless advocate for contemporary art and artists. Resolute in her belief in the transformative power of art, Susan devoted her life to educating broad audiences about artists' ideas, lives, and creative processes. An artist and activist in her own right, she inspired countless people of all ages and backgrounds by capturing in films her unique rapport with artists. We at ART21 are honored to have had the privilege to work with such an extraordinary, kind, and courageous leader and mentor, whose impeccable standards and passionate vision were a daily inspiration. We will miss her profoundly as we carry on and honor her legacy.

SOLLINS--Susan. The board, staff, and community of Independent Curators International (ICI) mourn the untimely death of Susan Sollins. We join all who knew her to celebrate her creativity, leadership, and pioneering achievements in the arts. With prescient vision and a unique understanding of the fundamental role of curators, Susan founded ICI with Nina Castelli Sundell in 1975, heralding an unprecedented commitment to support contemporary art by connecting curators, artists, and art spaces across a global world of art. As Executive Director of ICI from 1975 to 1996, and Founder and Executive Director of Art21 since 1997, she was driven by a sense of civic purpose, steadfast in her belief in the power of art and artists to inspire millions. She will continue to inspire us every day.

SOLLINS--Susan. It is with profound sorrow that I mourn the loss of my dear friend, Susan Sollins. Susan was a visionary in the arts. She established two programs that flourish today: Independent Curators International (with her friend Nina Sundell) and Art21. Both were built with educational components that extend nationally as well as internationally. Susan had a superior tenacity and intelligence in creating these programs, and they have become more important than she had ever dreamed. Susan was deeply devoted to her family. She archived and supported the legacy of her late husband, the remarkable composer Earle Brown. And she was a wonderful friend to artists and those with whom she worked. Once you were her friend, you knew she would always be in your life. This was Susan's greatest gift to me. The art world and I have lost a very unique and outstanding person. I send my heartfelt sympathy to her siblings, James and Marybeth Sollins, and her entire family. Agnes Gund

SOLLINS--Susan. The family of Susan Sollins mourns the sudden death on October 13, 2014, of our beloved sister, aunt, and sister-in-law. She has left us with countless memories of a life well lived, filled with laughter and love. Susan conveyed her lifelong passion for the visual arts to all those who knew her, so that all of us from closest family to dearest friends and a constantly growing circle of colleagues and collaborators shared in the joys and discoveries of her ever-curious and inquiring eye for beauty, brilliance, and meaning in art. Above all, Susan cherished her family her mother and father, the late Sonya and Irving Sollins; her husband, the late Earle Brown; her brother and sister-in-law, James Sollins and Louise Eliasof; her sister, Marybeth Sollins; and her nephews and nieces-in-law and their children Andrew Farnsworth and Patricia Ryan, and Aja; Stephen Sollins and Rachel Devlin, and Jonah and Cady. At the time of her death, Susan was the Executive Director of ART21, Inc., and Producer, Director, and Curator of the groundbreaking Peabody Award-winning documentary television series, Art in the Twenty-First Century, broadcast nationwide on PBS and now in its seventh season. Her feature-length film, William Kentridge: Anything is Possible, also received a Peabody Award. Susan was the co-founder, with the late Nina Sundell, of Independent Curators Incorporated (ICI), now Independent Curators International, and was its Executive Director Emerita. She also served on the boards of the MacDowell Colony, the CBG Foundation, and at the time of her death was President of the Earle Brown Music Foundation. We will honor and celebrate Susan at a memorial gathering, which has not yet been scheduled. Contributions to ART21, 133 W. 25th St. #

SCHNESEL--Ernest N.,of North Egremont, MA and formerly of New York, NY passed away peacefully, surrounded by family, on October 18, 2014. He was born May 23, 1930 to Pauline and Samuel Schnesel and was a graduate of New York University. He was the beloved husband to his wife, Anne and loving father to his children, Frann Lefkowitz, Shari Keats (Kenneth), Jodi Klein (Howard) and David Schnesel and brother to Eleanor Aaron. He was adored by his nine grandchildren, Samantha, Alana, Jake, Emily, Samuel, Lauren, Gabrielle, Spencer and Rachel. He was a world traveler, art collector and philanthropist, serving on the board of Hospice of the Berkshires and Hevreh of Southern Berkshire. Donations may be made to the Lustgarten Foundation in Bethpage, NY. "He did it his way".

SCHAPIRO--Herb. January 20, 1929-October 17, 2014. Award-winning playwright, lyricist, poet and teacher. Dramatists Guild, PEN, BMI. Credits include Obie and Drama Desk Award and Tony Nominee for "The Me Nobody Knows," Stanley Drama Award for "A Little Something Before You Go." Other works include "Bring in the Morning," "That Strange Encounter of Wallenberg and Eichmann," "The Love Song of Saul Alinsky," "Teddy," "Leading Lady-Victoria Woodhull," and "The Knight was Made for Love." U.S. Army, 1952-54. Soul mate of Gail Richardson, beloved father of Mark Schapiro, Judith Nevard and Elizabeth Marsh. A noble servant of language and love, of boundless curiosity and compassion. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76st NYC, on Tuesday, October 21 at 1245pm.

RONAN--William J. Syracuse University and its Board of Trustees mourn the loss of their dear friend and benefactor. An honor student who went on to earn multiple advanced degrees, Dr. Ronan forever valued the undergraduate experience. His intellectual curiosity was matched by his yearning for adventure. As a student he traveled to Japan and after graduation in 1934, he explored China. He was awarded Syracuse University's highest alumni award, the Arents Medal, in 2008. He will be remembered for his personal warmth, humor and hospitality, as he reveled in discussion of current events even in his 101st year. Our heartfelt condolences to his entire family.

RONAN--Dr. William John, died just shy of his 102nd birthday at his home in West Palm Beach on October 15th. Born in Buffalo, New York on November 8th, 1912, Dr. Ronan's love of adventure and intellectual curiosity had him visiting the Great Wall of China by age 18. Dr. Ronan attended Syracuse University and subsequently received his doctorate at NYU, the start of a burgeoning career in academia and public service. Dr. Ronan became a professor and ultimately the Dean of NYU's School of Public Administration, the youngest person to achieve the post at the time. He was subsequently recruited to join the executive staff of Mayor Robert Wagner, and soon caught the attention of the man who would be a lifelong friend and colleague, Governor Nelson Rockefeller. With the Governor, Dr. Ronan made a lasting impression on the city of New York, creating the Metropolitan Transit Authority, of which he became the first Chairman and CEO in 1968. In 1974, he was appointed Chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, where he oversaw construction of the World Trade Center and served until 1977. Continuing his lifelong dedication to public service, Dr. Ronan continued his career as commissioner and subsequently Chairman of the UTDC until 1994. Dr. Ronan was a tour de force in his public life, and his achievements are numerous. But those close to him will best remember his warmth, wit, and special sparkle; Bill was a man with a huge heart. His dear wife, Elena Vinade, whom he married in 1939, predeceases him. He is survived by two daughters- Monica Ronan and Diana Quasha, three grandchildren- Devon, Grant and Weston, three great-grandchildren, and his partner Bette Machon. To borrow words from his favorite poem, "Invictus," He was the master of his fate, the captain of his soul.
RONAN--William J. In celebration of a life well lived, I will miss you terribly. Rest in peace. Your Daughter, Monica

REMNICK--Herbert S.,DDS., 91, formerly of Paterson, NJ, Glen Rock, NJ and Boca Raton, FL, currently of Parkland, FL., passed away on October 17, 2014 in Tamarac, FL. Beloved husband of 63 years to Geraldine (Rapfogel). Loving father to Barbara (Charles) Kaplan of Weston, FL., Joan (Kenneth) Schwartz of Burke, VA. Dr. Remnick graduated from NYU and Columbia University College of Dental Medicine. A Navy veteran, Dr. Remnick began his dental practice in 1953 in Paterson, NJ moving it to Glen Rock, NJ in 1964. Dr. Remnick served as an Associate Professor and also Chairman of Oral Histology at Fairleigh Dickinson University Dental School, Teaneck, NJ. He authored the book, Embryology of the Face and Oral Cavity. Upon closing of the FDU Dental School, he taught at Columbia University College of Dental Medicine, NY and then Nova Southeastern College of Dental Medicine, Davie, FL retiring in December 2013 at the age of 90. Funeral Service at Robert Schoem Memorial Chapel at 11am on Tuesday, October 21, 2014. Interment at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, NJ. Shiva will be observed in Weston, FL. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Dr. Remnick's memory can be made to Temple Emanuel of North Jersey, 558 High Mountain Rd., Franklin Lakes, NJ 07417.

His loving wife of 65 years, Marcia Mitchell Reese, his devoted daughter Nancy, his son David and daughter-in-law Catherine Sease, will miss him terribly. He was the best of the best. He loved his life and family and got great joy living in Manhattan and enjoyed everything the City has to offer. A memorial service with be announced at a future date.

PELS--Donald A. The trustees, faculty, students, and staff of The Rockefeller University mourn the loss of our cherished friend Donald A. Pels, an esteemed member of our Board of Trustees for more than two decades. Donald Pels joined The Rockefeller University Board of Trustees in 1993 and was elected Emeritus Trustee in 2003. Over the years, Don served on many Board committees, including Audit, Budget and Operations, Development, and Technology Transfer. His participation in the work of these committees and his commitment to advancing scientific research greatly strengthened the University. Early in his involvement at Rockefeller, Don took a leadership role by establishing the Pels Family Center for Biochemistry and Structural Biology. Through his gift creating the Pels Family Center, he helped recruit several outstanding early-career faculty, providing them with enhanced opportunities to share ideas and collaborate. Don was deeply interested in the young investigators he supported, and he derived enormous pleasure from meeting with them to learn about their work. Don's passion for scientific inquiry led him to establish the Pels Family Professorship, an endowed chair for a senior faculty member. Don and his wife, Wendy Keys, also supported many other initiatives at Rockefeller, including the Tri-Institutional Noon Concert Series. Beyond Rockefeller, Don will be remembered for his service on the boards of a number of prestigious institutions, including the Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center and the Philharmonic Symphony Society of New York, and his active engagement in the cultural life of New York City. Don will be greatly missed by the Rockefeller campus community. We send our heartfelt condolences to Don's beloved wife, Wendy; his three children, Juliette, Valerie and Laurence; and his entire family. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Russell Carson, Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Torsten Wiesel, President Emeritus Tarun Kapoor, Pels Family Professor
MOUNT--Isabel. The Society of the Silurians notes with sadness the passing of long-time member Isabel Mount.

KLASS--Phyllis, 87, died on October 18, 2014, wife of the late Felix Klass, Director of Licensing for the Celanese Corporation. Phyllis graduated from Syracuse University and received graduate degrees from both Sarah Lawrence College and Columbia University. She was admitted to practice before the United States Patent Office in 1960 and worked in that field for many years. Later she became interested in and studied medical genetics. She was an Assistant Professor of Clinical Genetics of the Weill Medical College of Cornell University upon retirement as well as a Senior Medical Consultant for the New York Academy of Medicine. Afterwards Phyllis, a resident of Scarsdale, NY for 45 years, supported the arts at Purchase College and was an avid bridge player at the Pickwick Bridge Club. She is survived by her children Steven and Janet, her brother and sister-in-law Michael and Lisa Rich, nieces and nephews.

ETZEL--Allister Adrian, born in Brooklyn NY, January 19th, 1927, son of the late Paul J. Etzel and Isabelle McAllister Etzel. He was also the grandson of the late James P. McAllister, founder of McAllister Tug, Inc. With family by his beside, Allister passed away on October 18th, 2014 at the Calvary Hospital in Bronx NY. He is survived by his wife Carol Silvaney, his sons Michael and Jay, his daughter Kate and her spouse Laura, his Grandchildren, Sarah and Maddie, his sister Suzanne Love, and his brother Gerard Etzel. A veteran of World War II having served in the Philippines, Allister graduated from Georgetown University in 1951 with a Bachelor of Science in Government. He moved to the Westchester area in 1965 where he raised his three children with his wife, the late Joan Mikkelsen Etzel. A Vice President for National Westminster Bank, Allister was a well-respected member of the Mount Kisco, NY community, and President of the Mount Kisco Lions Club. He also served as a volunteer for Northern Westchester Hospital. In 1997, Allister met Carol Silvaney. For the next 17 years they had a life filled with love, laughter, peace and adventure. They lived in Garth Woods in Scarsdale, NY where he was on the board of directors. During the last year of his life, Allister fought a long hard battle against cancer. Carol and his family were with him every step of the way, trying to overcome the odds. He lived his life with unparalleled grace, humility and humor, always the gentleman that touched so many. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society's Hope Lodge in New York, NY. Calling hours will be on October 21st at the Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Home in Scarsdale, NY from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. The Funeral will be on October 22nd, at 10:00am at the Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary Scarsdale NY where he was a parishioner.

BRAUN--Mildred, 91, of New York City, matriarch and heart of the family, died peacefully on October 18. Daughter of Joseph and Jennie Silverstein, sister of the late Ruth Sturm, widow of Jerry Braun, loving and devoted mother of Lynda (Bob Friedman), Ivy (Chuck Goldman), and Bradley Braun, and adoring grandmother of Jenny and David Braun-Friedman, Mildred was loved by all who knew her, with friends of all ages and ethnicities. After her husband's premature death, she earned the reputation as a successful businesswoman. Mildred was generous to a fault; she always bought items in threes, and if you liked something of hers, you would have one the next day. She will be sorely missed, as she missed David after his untimely death in 2007. Spend time with and hug your family today and you will be honoring Mildred.

BARRANCO-BYRNE--Maryanne, passed away early Friday after a long and courageous battle with illness. A beloved wife, mother, family member and friend she was also a highly accomplished Psychiatric Nurse Practitioner and Nursing Instructor. A 67 year-old native of Staten Island, Maryanne received her Bachelors from Niagara University and Masters in Nursing from New York University; she trained as a psychotherapist at New York Center for Psychoanalytic Training. She was associated with several fine hospitals and schools including the College of Mount Saint Vincent's in Riverdale. She was published widely in respected nursing journals. But Maryanne's most memorable affiliation was with the now closed Saint Vincent's Hospital in Greenwich Village. Beginning in 1990 she undertook a busy private practice and her patients knew her as ceaselessly empathetic and devoted to their mental health. Maryanne survived her mother, father and two brothers. Those closest she leaves behind will never forget the warmth, grace, unwavering love and kindness she blessed them with every day. They include her immediate family: her husband of 34 years, Kevin, son Matthew and daughter, Alexandra, as well as her younger sister Annella. A funeral mass will be held Monday, October 20th, at 11am at Saint Monica's Church on E. 79th Street. Donations in Maryanne's honor can be made to the '68 Memorial Nursing Scholarship Fund, Niagara University and the Hospice of Metropolitan Jewish Health Service.

TAMNY--Martin, passed away on October 18, 2014. He was born in the Bronx, attended George Washington High School, the City College of New York, Wolfson College at Oxford, and received his PhD from City University of New York in 1976. He was Professor of Philosophy and then a most cherished, principled and accomplished Dean of Social Sciences, then of Humanities and the Arts at CCNY while also teaching at the CUNY Graduate Center. His classes ranged over many areas of philosophy, but his central interests were in the philosophy and history of science. Among many other publications, he co-edited Isaac Newton's Trinity Notebook, an important early manuscript of Newton's. As Dean of Humanities, Martin navigated the division through one of the worst fiscal crises in CCNY's history, managing to strengthen it through far-seeing strategic initiatives, including the establishment of the K.D. Irani endowment in philosophy. Martin's distinguished accomplishments as a professor, writer, and administrator never took precedence over his evident humanity, which showed in his dealings with colleagues and friends, but was most apparent in his family. Deeply devoted to his wife Myrna, of more than fifty years who died in 2013, he was a warm, often funny and always present and supportive father to Mark and Tara. His death is a profound loss to them and to their spouses, Coleen and Matthew, and Martin's grandchildren, Ella, Ben and Toby.

SULTANIK--Kalman. The World Jewish Congress mourns the passing of our revered long-term Vice President, Kalman Sultanik. A leader of the Zionist movement, Kalman survived the Holocaust to avidly promote the cause of Israel and devote himself to helping the remnants of Polish Jewry. He believed in the preservation of historical memory to educate future generations and tirelessly taught the lessons of the Holocaust in the battle against anti-Semitism. His leadership in so many branches of the Jewish community highlight a lifetime of service. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. May his memory be for a blessing. Ronald S. Lauder, President Robert Singer, CEO

STURZA--Esther, was a loving woman that everyone will remember fondly and miss dearly. We send our condolences to all of her family; her children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. With Much Love, Roberto, Kaylin, Victor, Leon, Michaela, Michael, Laura, Douglas, Lauren, Joanna and Philippe

STURZA--Esther, 82, born in Williamsburg, died peacefully on October 20 in her home in Manhattan. SOLLINS--Susan. The MacDowell Colony is saddened by the death of our dear friend and board member, Susan Sollins. The board of directors, staff, and Fellows at MacDowell send our deepest condolences to Susan's family, and to her wide community of friends and colleagues. Susan's leadership, energy, enthusiasm, deep love for the arts, and passionate voice informed and enriched the national discussion about the state of artists today. Susan strived for the highest standards for herself and her colleagues and put her own creativity and shoulder to achieving them. She will be sorely missed. Her legacy will endure in her remarkable contributions to MacDowell, Art21, and Independent Curators International.

SOLLINS--Susan. A passionate, articulate spokesperson for the arts who helped us understand and appreciate the power of art. Susan was a steady presence over the years - an extraordinary person and a good friend who will be greatly missed. Carol and Arthur Goldberg

SOLLINS--Susan. It is with profound sorrow that I mourn the loss of my dear friend, Susan Sollins. Susan was a visionary in the arts. She established two programs that flourish today: Independent Curators International (with her friend Nina Sundell) and Art21. Both were built with educational components that extend nationally as well as internationally. Susan had a superior tenacity and intelligence in creating these programs, and they have become more important than she had ever dreamed. Susan was deeply devoted to her family. She archived and supported the legacy of her late husband, the remarkable composer Earle Brown. And she was a wonderful friend to artists and those with whom she worked. Once you were her friend, you knew she would always be in your life. This was Susan's greatest gift to me. The art world and I have lost a very unique and outstanding person. I send my heartfelt sympathy to her siblings, James and Marybeth Sollins, and her entire family. Agnes Gund

SOLLINS--Susan. The family of Susan Sollins mourns the sudden death on October 13, 2014, of our beloved sister, aunt, and sister-in-law. She has left us with countless memories of a life well lived, filled with laughter and love. Susan conveyed her lifelong passion for the visual arts to all those who knew her, so that all of us from closest family to dearest friends and a constantly growing circle of colleagues and collaborators shared in the joys and discoveries of her ever-curious and inquiring eye for beauty, brilliance, and meaning in art. Above all, Susan cherished her family her mother and father, the late Sonya and Irving Sollins; her husband, the late Earle Brown; her brother and sister-in-law, James Sollins and Louise Eliasof; her sister, Marybeth Sollins; and her nephews and nieces-in-law and their children Andrew Farnsworth and Patricia Ryan, and Aja; Stephen Sollins and Rachel Devlin, and Jonah and Cady. At the time of her death, Susan was the Executive Director of ART21, Inc., and Producer, Director, and Curator of the groundbreaking Peabody Award-winning documentary television series, Art in the Twenty-First Century, broadcast nationwide on PBS and now in its seventh season. Her feature-length film, William Kentridge: Anything is Possible, also received a Peabody Award. Susan was the co-founder, with the late Nina Sundell, of Independent Curators Incorporated (ICI), now Independent Curators International, and was its Executive Director Emerita. She also served on the boards of the MacDowell Colony, the CBG Foundation, and at the time of her death was President of the Earle Brown Music Foundation. We will honor and celebrate Susan at a memorial gathering, which has not yet been scheduled. Contributions to ART21, 133 W. 25th St. #

SCHAPIRO--Herb. January 20, 1929-October 17, 2014. Award-winning playwright, lyricist, poet and teacher. Dramatists Guild, PEN, BMI. Credits include Obie and Drama Desk Award and Tony Nominee for "The Me Nobody Knows," Stanley Drama Award for "A Little Something Before You Go." Other works include "Bring in the Morning," "That Strange Encounter of Wallenberg and Eichmann," "The Love Song of Saul Alinsky," "Teddy," "Leading Lady-Victoria Woodhull," and "The Knight was Made for Love." U.S. Army, 1952-54. Soul mate of Gail Richardson, beloved father of Mark Schapiro, Judith Nevard and Elizabeth Marsh. A noble servant of language and love, of boundless curiosity and compassion. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76st NYC, on Tuesday, October 21 at 1245pm.

RONAN--William. We at NYU Wagner mourn the loss of our former dean, William Ronan. A towering leader in public transportation and regional planning, he earned a doctorate at NYU, joined our faculty as a professor, and went on to serve as dean from 1953 to 1959. His work at NYU and his subsequent leadership as the first chairman of the MTA continue to benefit us and all New Yorkers. Scholar, teacher, dean, and pioneering public service leader - we are inspired by his work and honor his memory. Sherry Glied, Dean, NYU's Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service.

RONAN--Dr. William John, died just shy of his 102nd birthday at his home in West Palm Beach on October 15th. Born in Buffalo, New York on November 8th, 1912, Dr. Ronan's love of adventure and intellectual curiosity had him visiting the Great Wall of China by age 18. Dr. Ronan attended Syracuse University and subsequently received his doctorate at NYU, the start of a burgeoning career in academia and public service. Dr. Ronan became a professor and ultimately the Dean of NYU's School of Public Administration, the youngest person to achieve the post at the time. He was subsequently recruited to join the executive staff of Mayor Robert Wagner, and soon caught the attention of the man who would be a lifelong friend and colleague, Governor Nelson Rockefeller. With the Governor, Dr. Ronan made a lasting impression on the city of New York, creating the Metropolitan Transit Authority, of which he became the first Chairman and CEO in 1968. In 1974, he was appointed Chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, where he oversaw construction of the World Trade Center and served until 1977. Continuing his lifelong dedication to public service, Dr. Ronan continued his career as commissioner and subsequently Chairman of the UTDC until 1994. Dr. Ronan was a tour de force in his public life, and his achievements are numerous. But those close to him will best remember his warmth, wit, and special sparkle; Bill was a man with a huge heart. His dear wife, Elena Vinade, whom he married in 1939, predeceases him. He is survived by two daughters- Monica Ronan and Diana Quasha, three grandchildren- Devon, Grant and Weston, three great-grandchildren, and his partner Bette Machon. To borrow words from his favorite poem, "Invictus," He was the master of his fate, the captain of his soul.

REGAN--Edward V. "Ned" The entire Baruch College community is saddened by the death of Edward V. (Ned) Regan, president of Baruch College from 2000 to 2004, who passed away this past Saturday. Ned Regan's tenure as president of Baruch College was marked by significant increases in the SAT scores of incoming freshmen, dramatically improved graduation rates and recognition for having the most diverse student body in the nation each of those years. The most visible sign of change at Baruch was the opening of the Newman Vertical Campus in the fall of 2001. Also under Regan's leadership, Baruch launched the innovative and popular Executives on Campus program, putting successful alumni and other friends of the College into classrooms and mentoring relationships with current students. In response to growing financial reporting scandals, he drew on a lifelong commitment to fiscal responsibility and integrity to push for the establishment of the Center for Financial Reporting, now the Robert Zicklin Center for Corporate Integrity. Prior to his years at Baruch where he was a tireless and passionate advocate for the College and its mission, Regan was New York State comptroller from 1979 to 1993. Ned's energy, integrity and dedication to the College will be missed. Mitchel B. Wallerstein President, Baruch College

REGAN--Edward. The Association for a Better New York (ABNY) mourns the loss of our longtime member Ned Regan. His contributions to our city and state have been invaluable. He will be missed. William Rudin, Chairman Jennifer Hensley, Executive Director

OLCAY--Onder John, beloved husband, father and grandfather, died peacefully at home on October 17 after a valiant battle against prostate cancer. He was 77 years old. Born in Izmir, Turkey, John graduated from Robert College, Istanbul, and received an M.A. and an M.B.A. from the Wharton School. From early on, international finance was central to his career. As a vice president of the Bank of New York, he helped establish the bank's first international office, in London. As a partner at London's W. Greenwell & Co., he became one of the first members of the London Stock Exchange not born in the U.K. or Commonwealth. In 1974 he launched a pioneering joint effort with New York's Fischer Francis Trees & Watts to advise central banks and multinational companies on their U.S. dollar portfolios. This initiative led to long associations with central banks and monetary authorities around the globe. In 1983 he joined Fischer Francis Trees & Watts and rose to be vice chairman and managing director. Since the late 1960s John has advised Netherlands-based Aegon N.V., serving on the boards of its North American subsidiaries and then on the Aegon N.V. supervisory board. In recent years he has been an adviser to the Peterson Institute for International Economics, in Washington. He also was dedicated to the communities where he lived, advising nonprofit organizations in New York City; London; and Point O'Woods, New York. John loved soccer, classical music and opera, theater, fine food and the rugged beauty of the far north of Scotland. Throughout a career characterized by many enduring friendships, John especially enjoyed mentoring younger colleagues, always focusing them on the importance of ethics and integrity. The day before he died, he joined friends and colleagues at a symposium on ethics and the economy organized in his honor. There the Peterson Institute for International Economics announced an endowment for the O. John Olcay Annual Lecture on Ethics and Economic Policy. John is survived by his wife Phebe, daughters Margot and Charlotte, grandson Christopher Kaya, sister Nukhet and cousin Attila. His funeral will be held at Saint James' Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Ave., on Friday, October 24, at 3:30pm. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Peterson Institute for International Economics: O. John Olcay Annual Lecture on Ethics and Economic Policy.

The Jewish Theological Seminary joins the family in mourning the loss of Randie Malinsky, immediate past chair of JTS's Division of Religious Leadership Advisory Board and a member for 20 years. Randie's sincerity, passion, and exuberance for her varied interests, including her love of Judaism, art, and culture were contagious.
