Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO
MALINSKY--Randie. Bright star that you are, we will miss you forever. And a day. All our love, Ken & Susan Gordon & Family

MALINSKY--Randie. All of us at Perelson Weiner extend our thoughts, prayers and deepest sympathies to the family of Randie Malinsky as we mourn the loss of our long-time friend and client. Randie was actively involved in various philanthropic leadership roles not only through her own charitable trust, but also as a long-time board member of the I Waldbaum Family Foundation, and chair of JTS's Rabbinical School Advisory Board. Randie and her husband Aaron created a fellowship to provide stipends to First Year JTS Rabbinical School and H.L. Miller Cantorial School Students to enable students to put their full focus and time toward mastery of a challenging curriculum. Randie also held active roles with Children's Aid Society, the Jewish Lens, and the Eglevsky Ballet. Randie was a kind, generous and highly principled woman who treasured her family. She bravely fought her illness with dignity and strength and remained as always, a loving wife, mother and grandmother. Randie made this world a better place. She will be missed by all whose lives she touched, and we sincerely hope here family and friends will be greatly comforted by their memories of her.

MALINSKY--Randie W. A devoted daughter, sister, wife, mother, grandmother, friend, intellectual and philanthropist passed away on October 18, 2014 in her home. She was 64 and had waged a courageous fight against lung cancer. Randie was a true lover of life! She lived inside of each moment spontaneously and with great zest. Her intellectual curiosity had no bounds. Randie continually strived to learn more history, culture, religion and current events. She thoroughly immersed herself into her family life, as well as her professional career. Randie's quest for knowledge began at an early age. She received an MBA from Hofstra University and began a marketing career at American Home Products. Eventually, she joined the family business, Waldbaum's Supermarkets. At Waldbaum's, Randie was the buyer of ethnic and kosher foods that were delivered directly to stores, bypassing the warehouse. She was ahead of her time in utilizing direct store delivery, as well as promoting and introducing a vast array of varied ethnic products to the public. She developed marketing campaigns around the products, including food festivals, competitions and holiday calendars. Randie played a significant role in developing this unique niche market which is now emulated by some of the biggest supermarket chains in the world. In addition to her significant professional contributions, Randie devoted significant time and effort in pursuit of her many passions. She explored museums in the United States and abroad, the contemporary art scene, porcelain painting and jewelry design. She loved the theater, ballet and opera. Randie traveled around the world on great adventures alongside of her husband of 44 years, Aaron Malinsky. They shared a wonderful love story, having met on a blind date and been best friends every day since. Randie and Aaron were a true compliment to one another and shared great joy, as well as sorrow, holding hands through it all. Born to Bernice and Ira Waldbaum, Randie grew up with strong family values and a commitment to Jewish learning. Her greatest philanthropic devotion was to The Jewish Theological Seminary. Randie served as a member of the Board of the Rabbinical School at JTS since 1994 and as the Board's Chairperson since 2009. During her tenure she championed the development of the Pastoral Care program and created a connection with JTS and the Hebrew language program at Middlebury College. Most recently Randie and Aaron gifted a fellowship to the incoming classes of the Rabbinical School and the H.L. Miller Cantorial School and College of Jewish Music of JTS. The Malinsky Fellowship will provide a living stipend to first year rabbinical and cantorial students. Randie also served and supported several non-profit organizations including the Long Island Committee for Soviet Jewry, The Eglevsky Ballet, the Auschwitz Jewish Center, The Rhinelander Center of the Children's Aid Society, and the Jewish Lens. She served on the Art Collection Committee of the Jewish Museum and had provided a grant to Uniting Against Lung Cancer for continued research in the fight to cure lung cancer. Randie's most valuable treasure was her family. She is survived by her mother, Bernice Waldbaum, husband Aaron, children Carolyn, Benjamin, and David, daughter-in-law Rebecca, grandchildren Liam and Molly, siblings Martin Waldbaum, Arthur and Nadine Waldbaum, Nancy Waldbaum, Linda Malinsky, Debbie and David Orshevsky, five nieces, five nephews, many cousins and beloved friends. Her funeral service was held on Monday, October 20, 2014 at Park Avenue Synagogue.

HOFFLICH--Richard A. We mourn the passing of our dear partner and friend. Rosenbloom & Hofflich, LLP, Jerald Rosenbloom and Michele Catti

ETZEL--Allister Adrian, born in Brooklyn NY, January 19th, 1927, son of the late Paul J. Etzel and Isabelle McAllister Etzel. He was also the grandson of the late James P. McAllister, founder of McAllister Tug, Inc. With family by his beside, Allister passed away on October 18th, 2014 at the Calvary Hospital in Bronx NY. He is survived by his wife Carol Silvaney, his sons Michael and Jay, his daughter Kate and her spouse Laura, his Grandchildren, Sarah and Maddie, his sister Suzanne Love, and his brother Gerard Etzel. A veteran of World War II having served in the Philippines, Allister graduated from Georgetown University in 1951 with a Bachelor of Science in Government. He moved to the Westchester area in 1965 where he raised his three children with his wife, the late Joan Mikkelsen Etzel. A Vice President for National Westminster Bank, Allister was a well-respected member of the Mount Kisco, NY community, and President of the Mount Kisco Lions Club. He also served as a volunteer for Northern Westchester Hospital. In 1997, Allister met Carol Silvaney. For the next 17 years they had a life filled with love, laughter, peace and adventure. They lived in Garth Woods in Scarsdale, NY where he was on the board of directors. During the last year of his life, Allister fought a long hard battle against cancer. Carol and his family were with him every step of the way, trying to overcome the odds. He lived his life with unparalleled grace, humility and humor, always the gentleman that touched so many. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society's Hope Lodge in New York, NY. Calling hours will be on October 21st at the Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Home in Scarsdale, NY from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. The Funeral will be on October 22nd, at 10:00am at the Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary Scarsdale NY where he was a parishioner.

Andrew--John. The Reverend Canon John G. B. Andrew OBE, DD, January 10, 1931 October 17, 2014. The Rector, Wardens and Vestry of Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue, on behalf of the Parish, announce the death of their beloved Eleventh Rector (1972-1996), Canon John Andrew. Canon Andrew was born in Yorkshire, England, was a priest in the Church of England, and served as Domestic Chaplain to Archbishop of Canterbury Michael Ramsey. In 1972, he was called to be Rector at Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue, where he had a distinguished tenure in which his preaching, pastoral presence, and leadership of the liturgy drew large congregations to the Church, an achievement especially notable during an era of decline in the Episcopal Church. Canon Andrew and Organist and Master of Choristers, Dr. Gerre Hancock, were instrumental in the preservation and enrichment of the Anglican choral tradition in the United States through the Saint Thomas Choir School. He was awarded honorary degrees from several Episcopal/Anglican seminaries in recognition of his work. John Andrew was a friend and confidant of many church leaders both within and outside the Episcopal Church and Anglicanism. He was a particular friend of Terence Cardinal Cooke and was a promoter of ecumenical relations between the Anglican and Roman Catholic communions. He was a cherished member of the Saint Thomas family for over 40 years. Funeral services will be at Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue on Wednesday, November 5, 2014 at 5:30pm. Donations in lieu of flowers, may be made to the Canon John Andrew Memorial Fund. Please make checks payable to Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue at 1 West 53rd St.; New York, NY 10019-5496. The Reverend Canon Carl F. Turner, Rector William H. A. Wright II, Warden Kenneth F. Koen, Warden

WEISS--Jeffrey. It is with deep sorrow that we record the passing of our esteemed member, Dr. Jeffrey Weiss, and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Deborah, and their family. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Barry Swidler, President for the Board of Governors

WEISS--Jeffrey Neil, M.D.,of Muttontown, NY on October 20, 2014 at the age of 54 years. Beloved father of Samantha and Jared. Cherished son of Jesse and the late Frances. Loving brothers, Alan and Marc. Adored sisters-in-law, Denise, Frida, and Andrea. Precious uncle to Jon, Dan, Sarah, Matthew, Julie, Rachel, and Max. Jeff was a urologist and founding member of Integrated-Medical Professionals who was loved by his patients and his colleagues. Services will be held at Gutterman's in Woodbury on Wednesday, October 22, at 11:15am. Interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery. Donations, in lieu of flowers, to the American Heart Association.

WEINBERGER--Peggy. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of 885 Park Avenue Corporation are saddened by the loss of Mrs. Peggy Weinberger, who died at home on Monday morning October 20th. She and her first husband, James Foster, moved to 885 Park in 1950 and as original co-op board members, they set a tone of congeniality and neighborliness. Following Mr. Foster's death, Peggy married Dr. Howard Weinberger. They made an elegant, charming and sophisticated couple. Mrs. Weinberger's warm, generous and outgoing personality will be missed by residents and staff alike. Our sympathies to her family and many good friends.

TANANBAUM--Doris. The Jewish Theological Seminary joins the family in mourning the loss of Doris Tananbaum, longtime member of the JTS family and aunt to JTS Board of Trustee, Vice Chair Alan Levine. Doris was devoted to Judaism and JTS, and a partner in word and deed in the renovation of JTS's Kripke Tower. She is also survived by her husband Stanley and their children Ricki Conway and Andrew Tananbaum, grandchildren, and great grandchildren. May her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold M. Eisen, Chancellor Abby Joseph Cohen, Board Chair

WASSERMEN--Ronald, of NYC and Watermill, NY passed Saturday October 18 at Stoney Brook University Hospital. He had a great love of life exhibited by close friendships, quick witted humor and love of music and good cocktails. He is survived by his loving wife Terri, Uncle Marty, cousins and wonderful friends. Services Friday October 24th, at 9:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Stoney Brook University Pulmonary and Critical Care Fellowship Program.

TANANBAUM--Doris. Our beautiful Aunt Doris has passed away. She was a woman of exquisite taste and sensibility and was a source of love and warmth to all her family and friends. We will miss her terribly. Her beloved sister-in-law, Ida, waits to embrace her. Deedy and David, Karen and Jim, Julie and Rob, Patty
TANANBAUM--Doris. Fenway Golf Club expresses profound sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member Doris Tananbaum and extends sincere condolences to her entire family. Dr. Bruce Haber, President

TANANBAUM--Doris. My mother Doris 'Nan' Tananbaum lived a long and blessed life. She was a loving mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. She was unwavering in her beliefs, pioneering in her style and unquestionably authentic in every sense of the word. She is survived by her loving husband of 73 years, Stanley 'Skipper Tananbaum,' her children Andrew Tananbaum and Ricki Conway, her many grandchildren and great- grandchildren. We will miss you always. Andrew, Dorothy, JoBeth & Tanner Tananbaum; Jon, Zoe & Gideon Bernstein.

SULTANIK--Kalman: Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, mourns the passing of our dear friend and partner Kalman Sultanik, the quintessential Zionist idealist and leader. It was our privilege to work with Kalman through the years in the World Confederation of United Zionists, an organization that projects his ideal--and ours--of pluralistic, non-partisan Zionism. He was also a decades-long colleague and mentor in his roles at various World Zionist Congresses, at the Jewish Agency for Israel, during his years as chairman of the American Section of the World Zionist Organization and in the World Jewish Congress. We will carry his memory in our hearts forever. Marcie Natan National President, Hadassah

STURZA--Esther, 82, born in Williamsburg, died peacefully on October 20 in her home in Manhattan. Devoted mother of Jeffrey Sturza, Caren Constantiner, and Evan Sturza, and adoring grandmother and great-grandmother, Esther was deeply loved and appreciated by all. Grammy and her gracious wit will be sorely missed.

SOLLMANN--Robert Ekko, 87, of Redding, CT. With great joy and curiosity, he explored the entire world with his beloved wife at his side. Survived by his wife, Jean, son Robert Sollmann, Jr., and daughters Anne Ryder Ziebarth and Elizabeth Durling.

SOLLINS--Susan. The MacDowell Colony is saddened by the death of our dear friend and board member, Susan Sollins. The board of directors, staff, and Fellows at MacDowell send our deepest condolences to Susan's family, and to her wide community of friends and colleagues. Susan's leadership, energy, enthusiasm, deep love for the arts, and passionate voice informed and enriched the national discussion about the state of artists today. Susan strived for the highest standards for herself and her colleagues and put her own creativity and shoulder to achieving them. She will be sorely missed. Her legacy will endure in her remarkable contributions to MacDowell, Art21, and Independent Curators International.

SOLLINS--Susan. The family of Susan Sollins mourns the sudden death on October 13, 2014, of our beloved sister, aunt, and sister-in-law. She has left us with countless memories of a life well lived, filled with laughter and love. Susan conveyed her lifelong passion for the visual arts to all those who knew her, so that all of us from closest family to dearest friends and a constantly growing circle of colleagues and collaborators shared in the joys and discoveries of her ever-curious and inquiring eye for beauty, brilliance, and meaning in art. Above all, Susan cherished her family her mother and father, the late Sonya and Irving Sollins; her husband, the late Earle Brown; her brother and sister-in-law, James Sollins and Louise Eliasof; her sister, Marybeth Sollins; and her nephews and nieces-in-law and their children Andrew Farnsworth and Patricia Ryan, and Aja; Stephen Sollins and Rachel Devlin, and Jonah and Cady. At the time of her death, Susan was the Executive Director of ART21, Inc., and Producer, Director, and Curator of the groundbreaking Peabody Award-winning documentary television series, Art in the Twenty-First Century, broadcast nationwide on PBS and now in its seventh season. Her feature-length film, William Kentridge: Anything is Possible, also received a Peabody Award. Susan was the co-founder, with the late Nina Sundell, of Independent Curators Incorporated (ICI), now Independent Curators International, and was its Executive Director Emerita. She also served on the boards of the MacDowell Colony, the CBG Foundation, and at the time of her death was President of the Earle Brown Music Foundation. We will honor and celebrate Susan at a memorial gathering, which has not yet been scheduled. Contributions to ART21, 133 W. 25th St. #

SCHRADE-JAMES--Robelyn. The Allen-Stevenson School community mourns the loss of Ms. Robelyn Schrade-James, our beloved Magical Music Lady for over 25 years. Through her unique ability to make each person feel special, Ms. Schrade-James inspired generations of boys to love music. She enriched the lives of countless students, parents and colleagues, and she will remain in our thoughts and hearts forever. In gratitude, we send our sincerest condolences to her family. Mark I. Greene, President, Board of Trustees David R. Trower, Headmaster

SALZBANK--Julius, 97 Roslyn, NY October 19, 2014. Food Industry Pioneer and staunch supporter of Jewish causes. Devoted husband of the late Claire, and beloved father of Robert (Stephanie), Alan (Karen), Michael (Barbara). Loving grandfather of Yosef, Zev, Zach, Sara, Jackie and Lena. He will be sorely missed yet with us forever.

RONAN--Dr. William John, died just shy of his 102nd birthday at his home in West Palm Beach on October 15th. Born in Buffalo, New York on November 8th, 1912, Dr. Ronan's love of adventure and intellectual curiosity had him visiting the Great Wall of China by age 18. Dr. Ronan attended Syracuse University and subsequently received his doctorate at NYU, the start of a burgeoning career in academia and public service. Dr. Ronan became a professor and ultimately the Dean of NYU's School of Public Administration, the youngest person to achieve the post at the time. He was subsequently recruited to join the executive staff of Mayor Robert Wagner, and soon caught the attention of the man who would be a lifelong friend and colleague, Governor Nelson Rockefeller. With the Governor, Dr. Ronan made a lasting impression on the city of New York, creating the Metropolitan Transit Authority, of which he became the first Chairman and CEO in 1968. In 1974, he was appointed Chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, where he oversaw construction of the World Trade Center and served until 1977. Continuing his lifelong dedication to public service, Dr. Ronan continued his career as commissioner and subsequently Chairman of the UTDC until 1994. Dr. Ronan was a tour de force in his public life, and his achievements are numerous. But those close to him will best remember his warmth, wit, and special sparkle; Bill was a man with a huge heart. His dear wife, Elena Vinade, whom he married in 1939, predeceases him. He is survived by two daughters- Monica Ronan and Diana Quasha, three grandchildren- Devon, Grant and Weston, three great-grandchildren, and his partner Bette Machon. To borrow words from his favorite poem, "Invictus," He was the master of his fate, the captain of his soul.

(Ned) Regan, former New York State Comptroller, distinguished public servant, president of Baruch College 2000 to 2004. Mr. Regan subsequently served as Distinguished Professor of Public Affairs, teaching at Baruch, the Graduate Center and Macaulay Honors College at CUNY. The University expresses deepest condolences to his family. Benno Schmidt, Chairperson, Board of Trustees James B. Milliken, Chancellor

OSTROW--Ida. Our beloved mother died at home on October 20th. She inspired us to be our best selves by her example of kindness, a gratitude of life, caring and embracing everyone whose path she crossed. She loved opera, classical music, reading, cats and lively conversation. Above all, she cherished her family, friends and Jewish faith. Her academic accomplishments included Phi Beta Kappa membership at Brooklyn College and an MSW from Yeshiva University. In the last of her amazing 97 years, her refrain was "when I die, remember, I was a happy old lady." Those words are a great comfort to all who loved and cherished her. She is survived by her children Flora, Gary, Betsy and Pamela and grandchildren Briana and Rebecca. Services will be at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St., Wednesday, October 22 at 11:30am. Donations can be made to Ida Ostrow Memorial Scholarship Fund at www. BrooklynJewishCenter.org or National Council of Jewish Woman at www.ncjw.org

OLCAY--Onder John, beloved husband, father and grandfather, died peacefully at home on October 17 after a valiant battle against prostate cancer. He was 77 years old. Born in Izmir, Turkey, John graduated from Robert College, Istanbul, and received an M.A. and an M.B.A. from the Wharton School. From early on, international finance was central to his career. As a vice president of the Bank of New York, he helped establish the bank's first international office, in London. As a partner at London's W. Greenwell & Co., he became one of the first members of the London Stock Exchange not born in the U.K. or Commonwealth. In 1974 he launched a pioneering joint effort with New York's Fischer Francis Trees & Watts to advise central banks and multinational companies on their U.S. dollar portfolios. This initiative led to long associations with central banks and monetary authorities around the globe. In 1983 he joined Fischer Francis Trees & Watts and rose to be vice chairman and managing director. Since the late 1960s John has advised Netherlands-based Aegon N.V., serving on the boards of its North American subsidiaries and then on the Aegon N.V. supervisory board. In recent years he has been an adviser to the Peterson Institute for International Economics, in Washington. He also was dedicated to the communities where he lived, advising nonprofit organizations in New York City; London; and Point O'Woods, New York. John loved soccer, classical music and opera, theater, fine food and the rugged beauty of the far north of Scotland. Throughout a career characterized by many enduring friendships, John especially enjoyed mentoring younger colleagues, always focusing them on the importance of ethics and integrity. The day before he died, he joined friends and colleagues at a symposium on ethics and the economy organized in his honor. There the Peterson Institute for International Economics announced an endowment for the O. John Olcay Annual Lecture on Ethics and Economic Policy. John is survived by his wife Phebe, daughters Margot and Charlotte, grandson Christopher Kaya, sister Nukhet and cousin Attila. His funeral will be held at Saint James' Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Ave., on Friday, October 24, at 3:30pm. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Peterson Institute for International Economics: O. John Olcay Annual Lecture on Ethics and Economic Policy.

JENSEN--Patricia Murcott, passed away unexpectedly on October 9 in Delray Beach, Florida, her home for the past 28 years. Born in Brooklyn, NY on November 24, 1931 to Harry and Edith Murcott. Raised in Forest Hills, NY with summers spent in Hampton Bays, NY. Graduated from Forest Hills High School at the age of 15, then received her BA in Psychology from Adelphi University at the age of 19. Married Edward Jensen in 1950 and celebrated 57 years of an extraordinary union. While raising five children, Patricia returned to school for her master's degree and became a kindergarten teacher. For 27 years, she was a dedicated and beloved teacher at Mandalay Elementary School in Wantagh, NY, and Old Farms and Indian Hollow Elementary Schools in Commack, NY. Patricia was a resident of Wantagh, NY for almost 30 years, where she helped many of her children's friends with college counseling. She enjoyed traveling abroad and had visited more than twenty countries. She was also an avid reader and ardent supporter of the Wantagh Public Library and Delray Beach Public Library, and a member of the Delray Beach Club. Patricia loved to laugh and made a lasting impression on everyone she met. She was predeceased by her husband, Edward, and her brother, Harry. She will be greatly missed by her devoted sister, Doris; her best friend of 47 years, Ethel Lehrfeld Greenblatt; her dear friend, Natacha Louis; her children, Richard and Claudia Jensen of Brooklyn, NY, Kathleen Jensen and James Barnes of Atlanta, GA, Deborah and Peter Rice of Centreville, VA, Christopher and Christine Jensen of Riverside, CT, and Patricia Jensen and Paul Fehlner of Ridgewood, NJ; and eighteen loving grandchildren, Caroline Davis, Hilary Rice, Josh Barnes, Jace Davis, Ned Rice, Kirsten Rice, Meg Davis, Christian Jensen, Nick Jensen, Peter Jensen, Callie Jensen, Leigh Rice, Emily Jensen, Luke Jensen, Tommy Jensen, Andie Jensen, Kaj Jensen, and Kiri Jensen. A memorial service will be held in Greenwich, CT in November. Contributions may be made in her name to the Delray Beach Public Library, 100 West Atlantic Avenue, Delray Beach, FL 33444.

HERSKOWITZ--Marvin, (aka Mark Weston), passed away on October 20. Mark was an actor and playwright who performed on and off Broadway for decades along with numerous films including "The Taking of Pelham 123," "The Anderson Tapes," "Bananas" and "Ragtime." Along with his acting credits, Mark wrote numerous plays including "Beckworth" which won the 1999 Audelco Award and "Harry and Eddie" which had an off Broadway run in 2012. Other works included television commercials including Brylcreem, Schick and Kraft Foods. Mark is survived by his sons Mitchell and Franklin Delano along with his loving wife Linda. He will be greatly missed by all of us.

GOLDFARB--Michael. We join with our sister chapter in mourning the loss of Michael Goldfarb. His commitment to people with special needs and their families was instrumental in shaping our field. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Priscilla, and their sons Ben, Will and Abe, and the entire Goldfarb family. AHRC Nassau Board of Directors & President, Howard Jurist, Esq. Michael Mascari, Executive Director

GOLDFARB--Michael. The AHRC New York City Board of Directors, staff, membership, people supported and their families mourn the passing of AHRC New York City's former Executive Director, Michael Goldfarb, and extend sympathy to his beloved and bereaved family. Michael served as the Executive Director of AHRC for 36 years. His tireless efforts to improve the lives of people we serve transformed the organization and indeed the entire field of serving those with developmental disabilities. When he assumed leadership of AHRC 1975, the organization had 200 employees; nearly 40 years later, AHRC employs over 4,000. This remarkable growth is due in large part to the vision and dedication of a man who helmed the agency for over four decades--Michael Goldfarb. AHRC's growth and accomplishments over the past forty years could not have happened without him. Michael was a force to reckon with. His intelligence and vision were unsurpassed as were his deep caring and compassion for the people supported by AHRC and their families. His political savvy and ability to create change was always impressive, as was his ability to relate to the people supported by AHRC. People supported felt comfortable going over to him to ask questions and make requests and he never failed to respond to them with respect and with humor. Michael will be remembered for years to come. He has left an amazing legacy at AHRC New York City and was a driving force in New York State, greatly admired by his colleagues. Michael is survived by his wife, Priscilla who resides in Garrison New York, his sons Will, Abe and Ben, their wives and his grandchildren. Our sincerest condolences to all of them. Laura Kennedy, President AHRC New York City, President, NYSARC Inc. Gary Lind, Executive Director, AHRC New York City

GOLDFARB--Michael, died peacefully at home in Garrison, N.Y. October 19, 2014 after a brief illness. Born May 18, 1941 in Manhattan to Dr. William Goldfarb and Frances Lyons Goldfarb, Michael graduated from Bronx High School of Science, NYU and Brown University. He taught philosophy at Brooklyn College before beginning a career in human services, ultimately serving as executive director of AHRC, New York City chapter from 1975 until his retirement in 2011. Michael was a passionate advocate on behalf of people with developmental disabilities and devoted his career to ensuring their rights and opportunities. A man of principle, humor, sensitivity and a big heart, he leaves a legacy of love and cherished memories for his wife of 46 years, Priscilla Stevens Goldfarb; sons Will Goldfarb (Maria), Ubud, Bali; Ben Goldfarb (Nora Whalen), Minneapolis, Minn.; Abe Goldfarb (Jennifer Sherrill), Brooklyn, N.Y.; grandchildren LouLou, Emilia, Oliver and Isaac; sister Deborah Reichert (Walter), Salt Lake City, UT; numerous nieces, nephews, extended family, colleagues and friends. Services private. Donations may be made to AHRC NYC Foundation, 83 Maiden Lane, New York, NY 10038 or VNA of Hudson Valley Hospice, 540 White Plains Rd. Ste. 300, Tarrytown, NY 10591.

GOLDENBERG--Paul, the Cairo-born son of English and French parents, started his career working as a stage actor and a talent coordinator for the BBC in Egypt, where its said he discovered the young Yves Montand and gave him his start. Some years later he moved to Northern California and managed the hungry in San Francisco, advancing the careers of Tom Lehrer, Miriam Makeba, Woody Allen, Mort Sahl (whom he delighted in introducing as "the next President of the United States . . .") and a host of other young talents. He moved to New York in 1962 when Victor Lownes hired him as a Room Director at the Playboy Club, where he worked until becoming one of the managers of Manhattan's Carlyle Hotel. For over 30 years there he worked with such talents as Bobby Short, Woody Allen, Eartha Kit, Elaine Stritch and Barbara Carroll. He delighted in being a night manager at the grand hotel, welcoming Princess Diana, Elizabeth Taylor, Jack Nicholson, Warren Beatty and a host of world leaders and celebrities, making all of them feel at home. He was pre-deceased by his wife, Katharine Keast-Goldenerg. Friends may call Thursday, October 23, 2014, 12 to 1:30pm at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St.

de la RENTA--Oscar. The Directors of New Yorkers For Children mourn the loss and will forever cherish the memory of our beloved fellow Director, Oscar de la Renta. He joined the board soon after the organization was founded in 1996 and brought the children in New York City's child welfare system to the attention of the fashion industry and his legions of friends. More than any other individual he developed our capacity to raise funds and awareness for New York's most vulnerable children. For Oscar any child in need was his child, and that compassion led to actions that have changed outcomes for countless young lives. We send our heartfelt sympathy to his loving wife Annette and his children and grandchildren. The world has lost an extraordinary man, and we are grateful for all that he contributed throughout his life. Nicolas Scoppetta, Founder and President Emeritus, Eric Brettschneider, President Susan Burden, Vice President Susan Magazine, Executive Director The Board of Directors

de la RENTA--Oscar. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Animal Medical Center (AMC) mourn the loss of a dear friend, Oscar de la Renta, husband of longtime AMC Board member, Annette de la Renta. A legendary fashion designer and enlightened philanthropist, Mr. de la Renta was also a compassionate animal lover who frequently rescued stray dogs living near his home in Punta Cana in the Dominican Republic. With gratitude for his steadfast support of The Animal Medical Center over many decades, we extend our heartfelt sympathy to Annette, his family, and to all those who were touched by the warmth of his friendship.

de la RENTA--Oscar. The Trustees, Fellows, and staff of the Morgan Library & Museum mourn the death of Oscar de la Renta, husband of Trustee Annette de la Renta. We will greatly miss his luminous presence at Morgan occasions. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Lawrence R. Ricciardi, Pres. Peggy Fogelman, Acting Dir.

de la RENTA--Oscar. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn with great sadness the passing of Oscar de la Renta, who for more than 40 years was a steadfastly committed advocate and friend of this institution. Oscar believed in the Met as a place that brings joy and enlightenment to the people of New York and the world. His generous advice in many areas of the Museum was always intelligent, heartfelt, and candid. At The Costume Institute, the area he was most passionate about, he fostered countless collaborative relationships that benefited our exhibitions and activities greatly. Over the years, he championed the annual gala, along with other legendary figures including Diana Vreeland, Jane Engelhard, Eleanor Lambert, Pat Buckley, Bill Blass, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, and in recent years Anna Wintour. After he and Annette, a Trustee since 1981, married in 1989, the dedication they both demonstrated to the Museum flourished even more. Today, the Met's costume collection includes 72 of Oscar's creations, a tribute to his iconic stature as a designer. We remember him with affection as a wonderful colleague, mentor, and inspiration. We extend our deep condolences to Annette and the entire family. Daniel Brodsky, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director and CEO Emily K. Rafferty, President

de la RENTA--Oscar. It is with profound sorrow that the Board of Directors, members and friends of Queen Sofia Spanish Institute mourn the passing of Oscar de la Renta. His creativity, generosity and inspirational leadership as Chairman of the Institute will always be remembered. Her Majesty Queen Sofia, a frequent participant in the cultural activities of the Institute, laments the loss of a great personal friend, a friend of Spain, and an extraordinary artist. Oscar conceived three of the most memorable exhibitions in the Institute's history. Balenciaga, Spanish Master showed that the designer, a mentor of Mr. de la Renta's, found inspiration in Spain's culture and folklore. Joaquin Sorolla and the Glory of Spanish Dress combined Sorolla's paintings of Spanish villagers in regional costumes with the original dresses and jewelry depicted in the paintings. Fortuny y Madrazo: An Artistic Legacy, returned this artist to Spain and highlighted his paternal and maternal artistic influences. We at Queen Sofia Spanish Institute will be forever grateful to Oscar de la Renta. Our deepest condolences to Annette de la Renta and to the family.

de la RENTA--Oscar. The Trustees and Staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the loss of Oscar de la Renta, our great friend and the beloved husband of Trustee Annette de la Renta. He was a man of abundant warmth, graciousness, talent, and insight, and we are grateful for the deep devotion and generosity he and Annette have shown the Library over the years. We offer our heartfelt sympathies to all of his family and friends. Neil L. Rudenstine, Chairman; Samuel C. Butler, Catherine Marron, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairman Emeriti; Anthony W. Marx, President

de la RENTA--Oscar. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall celebrate the life of Oscar de la Renta, our dear friend and colleague and one of the world's most renowned fashion designers. Oscar joined the Carnegie Hall Board of Trustees in 1987, and served the Hall with grace and devotion for more than twenty-five years. In April 2014, we were honored to award him with the Carnegie Hall Medal of Excellence in recognition of his profound influence on business and philanthropy at an evening we will never forget. Oscar graciously co-chaired Carnegie Hall's historic restoration in 1986, which helped support our newly-restored concert halls. As Chair of several memorable Opening Night Galas and other major special events, he brought a heightened elegance, glamour, and sense of refinement, qualities that were reflected in all aspects of his life. We will always remember Oscar for his personal charisma and warmth, impeccable taste, generosity, and his deep love of music and Carnegie Hall. We express our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Annette, his son, Moises, and his family Eliza and Alex Bolen, Beatrice and David Phelps, and Natalie and Charles Reed, and all of his friends, and loved ones. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive and Artistic Director

de la RENTA--Oscar. CLEGG--George Francis, age 84, a native of Floral Park, NY and a former President of Monsanto Chemical, passed away at his home on Amelia Island, FL on Saturday evening, October 18, 2014. Services by Oxley-Heard Funeral Directors.

CARTER--Andrew M. Andrew M. Carter, an early leader in the field of active bond management and one of the best bondsmen of his time, died at his home in Boston on October 17, 2014. He was 74 years old. With his upbeat approach to life, gracious manner, dapper attire, curled moustache, and keen mind, Andy Carter had a style all his own. Mr. Carter spent his entire professional career in the financial sector and developed a much sought after expertise in bonds and fixed income. After a short stint on Wall Street, he noticed that while there were thousands of stock experts, there was a dearth of bondsmen, and he jumped at the opportunity this presented. Within a very short time, at age just 24, he was running Harvard University's $500 million bond portfolio. In 1972, he described his philosophy as "making sensible switches" and noted further, "It's sweaty work, yes, but there's nothing mystical about it." In 1968 Mr. Carter helped form the bond group for Wellington Management Company, which he grew to more than $500 million in assets; he then founded Standard & Poor's/Carter, Doyle in 1972. In 1975 he joined Jennison Associates, where he led the bond department, became senior vice president, and stayed until 1992 as he grew the fund to $10 billion in assets. He next served as president of the fixed income investment management firm Andrew M. Carter & Company LP and in 1998 became chairman and CEO of Hyperion Capital Management, where he continued as senior advisor until 2010. A former colleague of Mr. Carter considered him to be "one of the finest math guys" in the business, further stating, "Andy understands the math of bonds, the quirks of bonds." Mr. Carter so loved what he did that he refused to call it work. He was born on June 7, 1940, in Englewood, New Jersey. His mother, Pauline Humeston Carter, was president of her class at Abbott Academy and president of Dana Hall at Wellesley College. His father, Herbert Pratt Carter, graduated first in his class at The Loomis School in 1920 and went on to Princeton University and Harvard Law School. In 1986 Mr. Carter named the first constructed girls dormitory at The Loomis Chaffee School, in Windsor, Connecticut, in honor of his parents. Mr. Carter followed in his father's footsteps at Loomis, also graduating first in his class, and went on to Harvard College, where he graduated in three years with an A.B. in English Literature. He is survived by his wife, Renee Krimsier Carter, an accomplished flutist and faculty member at the New England Conservatory and Boston University, who also performs as principal flute of the Boston Pops Esplanade Orchestra; by his sister, Susan Pratt Carter of Englewood, New Jersey; and by James P. Carter, his son from his first marriage to Dale Marsha Peterson. Philanthropy and service marked Mr. Carter's life. He believed that "guiding children is the single best way to improve our collective future." He was a trustee at Loomis from 1986 to the present, where he served as vice chairman of the board and longtime chair of the Investment Committee. Few people loved the school more, and Mr. Carter gave generously of his time and money. In addition to gifts for the dormitory and for Sellers Hall, the school's office of admission, he also made a gift to name the development office in honor of his wife Renee Krimsier Carter and endowed an instructorship in music in memory of his brother, Thomas Benedict Carter, combining his love for the school with his love of music. He also served on boards for the William E. Simon Graduate School of Business Administration at the University of Rochester; The New England Conservatory, where he was also chair of the Investment Committee for many years; Manchester Capital Management; and the Dean's Advisory Committee of the Boston University School of Management; and as president of the Big Brother Association of Boston. A member of the Bonita Bay Club, Mr. Carter and his wife divided their time among homes in Boston; Bonita Bay, Florida; and Strafford, Vermont. Andy Carter had a roving intellect, and his interests included poetry, history, horses, golf, and music. He was particularly fond of A. E. Housman's poems. When Housman died, his family found a previously unpublished poem marked "For My Funeral." Mr. Carter read that poem at the funerals for his mother, father, and brother. The last stanza of that poem follows: "We now to peace and darkness, And earth and thee restore, Thy creature that thou madest And wilt cast forth no more." On Sunday, October 26, the family will hold calling hours from 2p.m. until 5p.m. at 10 Walnut Street in Boston, Massachusetts. On Saturday, November 8, a memorial service will take place at 11a.m. in the chapel of Founders Hall at The Loomis Chaffee School in Windsor, Connecticut, with a 10a.m. reception and a 12:30p.m. luncheon. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Loomis Chaffee School, 4 Batchelder Road, Windsor, CT 06095.

BERSHTEL--Ester, a survivor of the Holocaust, died on October 19, 2014, at the age of 94. Born in Przytyk, Poland, daughter of Sholem and Gitel Haberberg. Loving wife of the late Menashe. Beloved mother of Sara, Jack, and the late Ora; mother-in-law of Sharon Bershtel and the late Richard Brick; grandmother of Natan (Becky), Leora (Nick), Maya (Dan), Noah (Erin). She will be deeply missed by her family and many friends, including Amy, Cordelia, and Clare Johnson and Laura Slatkin.

BAUMSLAG--Gilbert. Distinguished Professor Emeritus, CCNY, died October 20, after a brief illness. Born in Johannesburg, South Africa, he earned his B.Sc. Honours (Masters) and D.Sc. from the University of Witwatersrand, and his Ph.D. from the University of Manchester. He has given keynote addresses in most conferences in infinite group theory on five continents. He worked with many mathematicians and had more than 30 doctoral students. He played tennis, golf and squash in adulthood but always regretted that he had not followed his first ambition, persuaded not to by his father who thought it frivolous: to play cricket for South Africa a game he followed throughout his lifetime. He first came to the U.S. to teach at Princeton and then moved on to NYU, CUNY, and Rice University before rejoining CUNY at City College in 1973 as Distinguished Professor, a classification limited to 175 and is described by CUNY as an exceptional scholar with an international reputation for scholarly and/or research excellence. He had several academic relationships including ETH in Zurich and the University of Warwick in the U.K. He was the author of more than 150 mathematical papers along with books and monographs. His research was supported for decades and for millions by the National Science Foundation. He was also the Founder and Director of the Center for Algorithms & Interactive Scientific Software (CAISS). He had a great fondness for Nantucket where he spent more than 25 years during school vacations and holidays writing papers, exploring problems on his famous 500lb blackboard installed on the office wall of his his beloved old house on Darling Street. He was enormously fond of many friends on Nantucket with whom he shared a lot of important and silly experiences. One such was playing cricket on Darling Street on a hot August night with four amateurs at the game.There were no winners. There were also no losers. He also loved having lunch at The Opera House where there was no rush, no impatience, and just great food, a great atmosphere, all under the guidance of the renowned Gwen Gaillard. And the always present lure of the Atlantic Ocean was not to be ignored. He loved the land of his birth and was truly happy when the government was transformed by the release of Nelson Mandela. He went to Johannesburg whenever possible for more than 40 years not only to see old friends but also to encourage math projects in the country. He is survived by his wife, Mary Kennedy Baumslag, Len Cohen of South Africa, his childhood partner in many misadventures; his well respected friend, Howard Siegel,M.D. and a lot of beloved friends and colleagues, in New York, on Nantucket and around the world; devoted and accomplished former students, several nieces and nephews, and a few remote blood relatives. No service is planned at this time.

Andrew--John. The Reverend Canon John G. B. Andrew OBE, DD, January 10, 1931 October 17, 2014. The Rector, Wardens and Vestry of Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue, on behalf of the Parish, announce the death of their beloved Eleventh Rector (1972-1996), Canon John Andrew. Canon Andrew was born in Yorkshire, England, was a priest in the Church of England, and served as Domestic Chaplain to Archbishop of Canterbury Michael Ramsey. In 1972, he was called to be Rector at Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue, where he had a distinguished tenure in which his preaching, pastoral presence, and leadership of the liturgy drew large congregations to the Church, an achievement especially notable during an era of decline in the Episcopal Church. Canon Andrew and Organist and Master of Choristers, Dr. Gerre Hancock, were instrumental in the preservation and enrichment of the Anglican choral tradition in the United States through the Saint Thomas Choir School. He was awarded honorary degrees from several Episcopal/Anglican seminaries in recognition of his work. John Andrew was a friend and confidant of many church leaders both within and outside the Episcopal Church and Anglicanism. He was a particular friend of Terence Cardinal Cooke and was a promoter of ecumenical relations between the Anglican and Roman Catholic communions. He was a cherished member of the Saint Thomas family for over 40 years. Funeral services will be at Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue on Wednesday, November 5, 2014 at 5:30pm. Donations in lieu of flowers, may be made to the Canon John Andrew Memorial Fund. Please make checks payable to Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue at 1 West 53rd St.; New York, NY 10019-5496. The Reverend Canon Carl F. Turner, Rector William H. A. Wright II, Warden Kenneth F. Koen, Warden

WERTHEIMER--Alfred, a New York photographer whose photographs of a 21-year-old Elvis Presley in 1956 are widely considered to be the definitive visual document of the soon-to-be "King of Rock and Roll," died on October 19th in his home in New York City. He was 85 years old. Mr. Wertheimer, who fled Hitler's Germany with his father Julius, his mother Katy, and his brother Henry in 1936, came to New York City and settled in an apartment on Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn. After graduating from high school in 1947 he was accepted at Cooper Union School of Art in Manhattan where he first photographed events with a camera his brother Henry had given him. In 1951 Wertheimer graduated college with a major in advertising design and the following year he was drafted into the Army. When he returned home to New York City in 1954, Wertheimer landed a job with fashion photographer Tom Palumbo who worked for Harper's Bazaar magazine and eventually began his own freelance photography business. In 1955 fate intervened when he was introduced to Ann Fulchino, a publicist at RCA, who asked Wertheimer to take photos of RCA's latest acquisition, a young singer named Elvis Presley. His last book, "Elvis and the Birth of Rock and Roll," was published in 2013. His publisher, Benedikt Taschen, said that, "Alfred Wertheimer took an assignment nobody else was interested in, to shoot an up-and-coming crooner from Memphis. He had the instinct to know that a revolution was coming and he followed Elvis on the road and elsewhere for another two weeks after his job for RCA was done. What came out of this is extraordinary in its intimacy and unparalleled in its scope. Al immortalized a young man in the very process of making history." Following his work with Elvis, Wertheimer continued for a number of years as a freelance photographer, eventually transitioning to documentary cinematographer, working as one of the principle cameramen of the film "Woodstock," as well as covering the 1960 Presidential campaigns of John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon. Wertheimer is survived by his nieces Pamela Wertheimer and Heidi Wohlfeld. Memorial Service will be held Friday, October 24th at 1pm at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York.

WEINBERGER--Peggy. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of 885 Park Avenue Corporation are saddened by the loss of Mrs. Peggy Weinberger, who died at home on Monday morning October 20th. She and her first husband, James Foster, moved to 885 Park in 1950 and as original co-op board members, they set a tone of congeniality and neighborliness. Following Mr. Foster's death, Peggy married Dr. Howard Weinberger. They made an elegant, charming and sophisticated couple. Mrs. Weinberger's warm, generous and outgoing personality will be missed by residents and staff alike. Our sympathies to her family and many good friends.

WASSERMAN--Ronald, of NYC and Watermill, NY passed Saturday October 18 at Stoney Brook University Hospital. He had a great love of life exhibited by close friendships, quick witted humor and love of music and good cocktails. He is survived by his loving wife Terri, Uncle Marty, cousins and wonderful friends. Services Friday, October 24th, at 9:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Stoney Brook University Pulmonary and Critical Care Fellowship Program.

TANANBAUM--Doris. My mother Doris 'Nan' Tananbaum lived a long and blessed life. She was a loving mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. She was unwavering in her beliefs, pioneering in her style and unquestionably authentic in every sense of the word. She is survived by her loving husband of 73 years, Stanley 'Skipper Tananbaum,' her children Andrew Tananbaum and Ricki Conway, her many grandchildren and great- grandchildren. We will miss you always. Andrew, Dorothy, JoBeth & Tanner Tananbaum; Jon, Zoe & Gideon Bernstein.

RECTOR--Tully F.,an award-winning producer and director of TV commercials during the 1950s and 60s, died on October 17th in Reston, VA. He was 90 years old. Mr. Rector was born in Adrian, TX, on June 25, 1924. After his family's cattle ranch was devastated by the Dust Bowl in 1931, he moved to Dearborn, MI, where his father and brothers found work in the Ford automotive plant. From 1943 to 1945, he served in the United States Army as a rifleman and combat engineer. Mr. Rector participated in the D-Day invasion and was later wounded in action. After World War II, he moved to Paris to attend art school at the Academie Julian and the Ecole des Beaux-Arts on the GI Bill. In 1953, Mr. Rector founded Group Productions with a partner. The company was one of the leading producers of animated and live-action television commercials for 18 years, some of which were included in the Museum of Modern Art's permanent collection of commercial media. Group Productions was sold to Westinghouse in 1971. Mr. Rector continued in semi-retirement to work as a free-lance producer and director. A keen horseman and fox hunter, he also imported sporting art from England and was involved in the restoration and sales of antique automobiles. Later he developed a line of leather luggage and helped start a retail clothier in Middleburg, VA, where he moved from New York in the mid-1980s and lived for the remainder of his life. He is survived by his beloved wife of twenty-five years, Karen Y. Jackson of Middleburg, VA, and three children from previous marriages: Kelly R. Klein, of New York City; Amy R. Hester, of Waxhaw, NC; and Tully F. Rector II, of Bonn, Germany.

RAVINETT--Ilana on October 21, 2014. Devoted mother of Eve. Beloved husband of Jeffrey Kleinberg. Loving daughter of Renee Castle and the late Lee Castle. Dear sister of Nancy Taub and the late Richard Castle, and brother-in-law of Jeffrey Taub. Adoring aunt of Andrew and Lauren Taub. Also survived by step children Rachel and Andrew Ginsburg and Trina and David Kleinberg and step grandchildren Ben, Jonah and Anna. Services Friday 11:30am at The Riverside 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

PRYOR--Sam, 1928-2014. Samuel F. Pryor III passed away on Friday, October 17 at the age of 86 surrounded by his family. He was born in Greenwich, CT, attended the Taft School, Yale University, and the University of Pennsylvania Law School. Sally Reese Pryor, his wife of sixty years, survives him as do his children, Sam, Kathy Burgeson, Dan, Joe and Ted, their spouses, and his nine grandchildren. He was a leader in law and philanthropy, a mentor to countless individuals, an author and adventurer. The funeral service will take place on Saturday, November 1st at 11am at St. Matthews Church in Bedford, NY. He served in the United States Marine Corps from 1953 to 1955, and joined the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell in New York City in 1956. He retired and became Senior Counsel in 1998. He was a dedicated volunteer throughout his life, assisted many philanthropic organizations working to help people and conserve the environment. He received the prestigious New York Governor's Award for Parks and Preservation, The Land Trust Alliance President's Award, and the Open Space Institute Conservation Award. He was chair of the World Rehabilitation Fund and chair emeritus of the Republican Majority for Choice until the time of his death. He is the author of two books, "Make It Happen," which is a biography of his late father, Samuel F. Pryor, Jr, and his own memoir, "My Interesting Life." In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Northern Westchester Hospital and the Westchester Land Trust.

OLCAY--Onder John, beloved husband, father and grandfather, died peacefully at home on October 17 after a valiant battle against prostate cancer. He was 77 years old. Born in Izmir, Turkey, John graduated from Robert College, Istanbul, and received an M.A. and an M.B.A. from the Wharton School. From early on, international finance was central to his career. As a vice president of the Bank of New York, he helped establish the bank's first international office, in London. As a partner at London's W. Greenwell & Co., he became one of the first members of the London Stock Exchange not born in the U.K. or Commonwealth. In 1974 he launched a pioneering joint effort with New York's Fischer Francis Trees & Watts to advise central banks and multinational companies on their U.S. dollar portfolios. This initiative led to long associations with central banks and monetary authorities around the globe. In 1983 he joined Fischer Francis Trees & Watts and rose to be vice chairman and managing director. Since the late 1960s John has advised Netherlands-based Aegon N.V., serving on the boards of its North American subsidiaries and then on the Aegon N.V. supervisory board. In recent years he has been an adviser to the Peterson Institute for International Economics, in Washington. He also was dedicated to the communities where he lived, advising nonprofit organizations in New York City; London; and Point O'Woods, New York. John loved soccer, classical music and opera, theater, fine food and the rugged beauty of the far north of Scotland. Throughout a career characterized by many enduring friendships, John especially enjoyed mentoring younger colleagues, always focusing them on the importance of ethics and integrity. The day before he died, he joined friends and colleagues at a symposium on ethics and the economy organized in his honor. There the Peterson Institute for International Economics announced an endowment for the O. John Olcay Annual Lecture on Ethics and Economic Policy. John is survived by his wife Phebe, daughters Margot and Charlotte, grandson Christopher Kaya, sister Nukhet and cousin Attila. His funeral will be held at Saint James' Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Ave., on Friday, October 24, at 3:30pm. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Peterson Institute for International Economics: O. John Olcay Annual Lecture on Ethics and Economic Policy.

O'BRIEN--Monsignor William B.,died October 19 at St. Pius X Church in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 90. Monsignor was a seminal figure in residential drug treatment and earned worldwide recognition and appreciation for his pioneering work in this field. That day over 50 years ago when he founded Daytop changed the way we view and treat addiction. He was also co-founder of the World Federation of Therapeutic Communities which he guided into a global movement establishing treatment programs in countries throughout the world. A trusted adviser to heads of state, as well as to His Holiness Pope John Paul II, Monsignor O'Brien helped shape policies that have radically improved treatment programs around the world. He was the author of the highly acclaimed book, "You Can't Do It Alone: The Daytop Way To Make Your Child Drug Free", published numerous papers in national and international journals, and inspired generations of treatment professionals. All the while he remained at heart a simple parish priest as deeply devoted to his parishioners at St. Brendan's in the Bronx as he was to the residents in treatment and their families. A truly extraordinary man of staggering faith, integrity, warmth, and loyalty whose impact on drug treatment has been profound and lasting. Monsignor O' Brien's enduring legacy will be his selfless dedication to saving young lives and his unswerving devotion to his church and God. A mass of Christian burial will be held at St. Pius X Church, 91 Secor Road, Scarsdale, NY, on Saturday, October 25 at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory may be made to St. Pius X Church.
MORRIS--Alan. Alan was a key figure in the O'Neill Center's development and success and a beloved and valued friend. He will be sorely missed. George & Betsy

MAYER--Rosemary, 71, on October 18, 2014. She was born and raised in Ridgewood, New York and lived in New York City for most of her life. She studied classics at St. Joseph's College and the University of Iowa and fine art at the School of Visual Arts and the Brooklyn Museum Art School. A prolific artist and writer who explored many media, she was most well-known for her sculptures and installations in the 1970s and 1980s and her involvement in the feminist art movement. Her translation of the diary of the Italian Mannerist artist Pontormo, which included a catalogue of her own work, was published in 1979. Recent projects involved illustrating Beowulf, the Epic of Gilgamesh, and the history of the women of the Roman Empire. She received grants from The National Endowment for the Arts, the New York Council on the Arts, and the Pollock-Krasner Foundation. She had solo exhibitions at A.I.R. Gallery, the Monique Knowlton Gallery, the Pam Adler Gallery, and others. She was a dedicated and inspired professor of art at LaGuardia Community College, where she taught for twenty years, and of writing at Long Island University (Brooklyn). Rosemary lived for forty years in a Tribeca loft, where she hosted many elaborate dinner parties and cultivated an impressive indoor garden, primarily from avocado pits. She is remembered and loved for her generosity, her wry sense of humor, her love of jewels and baubles, her devotion to art, her insatiable interest in art history and the history of women, and her pride in and support of her nieces and nephew. She is survived by her sister Bernadette Mayer (Philip Good); nieces Marie and Sophia Warsh, nephew Max Warsh (Alyssa Gorelick), grand-niece, Zola Ray, former brother-in-law Lewis Warsh (Katt Lissard); and a close network of friends.

LONERGAN--Joan Cameron Frail, beloved wife of the late Pierce James Lonergan, loving mother of Sinclair Berdan, Aimee (Francis) Coolidge, Katherine (Charles) Main, and Cameron (Tanya) Lonergan, sister of Irene (Charles) Hamm, survived by 11 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren, aunt of Liza and Charles Hamm. Joan graduated from Graham Eckes and attended Hood College. Later she volunteered as a docent at the Cincinnati Art Museum and was named a Judge Emeritus for the Garden Club of America. Joan passed away on Saturday, October 18, 2014 at the age of 80. Memorial service at the Church of the Redeemer, Cincinnati, OH, on Saturday, November 29, 2014 at 12 Noon. Memorials may be directed to the Cincinnati Art Museum. Gwen Mooney Funeral Home-Elden Good Chapel in charge of services. www.springgrove.org

LEIFER--Milton "Mike," on October 22, 2014 at age 95. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Loving father of Roberta Fisher and Joyce Leifer Schenck. Devoted father-in- law of Bob Fisher and James Schenck. Cherished grandfather of Michael, Lara, Graham and Ben. Special cousin of the late Dr. David Grob and family. Mike was very proud of his military service in the 94th Division during World War II, and a recipient of a Silver and two Bronze Stars. He had a successful business with his late brother Walter, Leifer Bros Steel. In his spare time he wrote a novel, "Murder on The Rocks," published by his family for his 90th birthday. He composed numerous songs and was known for his sense of humor and creative word play. Donations may be made in his memory to a Veteran's charity of your choice. Services 11am, Friday, October 24, 2014 at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 11021. www.RiversideNassauNorth Chapels.com

KLEIN--Arthur, The LeFrak Organization mourns the passing of Arthur Klein, a former long-time and devoted executive vice president and chief financial officer of the Company. From 1957 until his retirement in 1999, his dedication and hard work was an inspiration. His initiatives and work ethic influenced the Firm's early growth and success. The memory of his sound advice and good humor will be remembered and cherished by all of us who were associated with him. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Deborah, his children, and grandchildren.

KLEIN--Arthur, August 20, 1927 - October 21, 2014. 87 years old. Beloved husband of Debra, father of Andra and Sherri, grandfather of Lara and Marc. Executive Vice President of The Lefrak Organization from 1958-2000. Baruch City College graduate. Founding member Hollis Hills Jewish Center. Member of Boca West Country Club. Accomplished CPA and real estate businessman. A prince among men. Donations to Hollis Hills Jewish Center, 210-10 Union Turnpike, Hollis Hills, NY 11427. Funeral Thursday, 12:45pm at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, NY.

GOLDFARB--Michael. The AHRC New York City Board of Directors, staff, membership, people supported and their families mourn the passing of AHRC New York City's former Executive Director, Michael Goldfarb, and extend sympathy to his beloved and bereaved family. Michael served as the Executive Director of AHRC for 36 years. His tireless efforts to improve the lives of people we serve transformed the organization and indeed the entire field of serving those with developmental disabilities. When he assumed leadership of AHRC 1975, the organization had 200 employees; nearly 40 years later, AHRC employs over 4,000. This remarkable growth is due in large part to the vision and dedication of a man who helmed the agency for over four decades--Michael Goldfarb. AHRC's growth and accomplishments over the past forty years could not have happened without him. Michael was a force to reckon with. His intelligence and vision were unsurpassed as were his deep caring and compassion for the people supported by AHRC and their families. His political savvy and ability to create change was always impressive, as was his ability to relate to the people supported by AHRC. People supported felt comfortable going over to him to ask questions and make requests and he never failed to respond to them with respect and with humor. Michael will be remembered for years to come. He has left an amazing legacy at AHRC New York City and was a driving force in New York State, greatly admired by his colleagues. Michael is survived by his wife, Priscilla who resides in Garrison New York, his sons Will, Abe and Ben, their wives and his grandchildren. Our sincerest condolences to all of them. Laura Kennedy, President AHRC New York City, President, NYSARC Inc. Gary Lind, Executive Director, AHRC New York City

FREIREICH--Ronald, 71, of Atlanta, Georgia, died October 17, 2014 at Emory University Hospital. Born in Bronx, NY, to Rose and Leslie Freireich, he is survived by his loving wife of 48 years, Bonnie; daughter, Jennifer Shapiro; son, Garrett; grandchildren: Mackenzie, Kendall, and Daniel Shapiro, and Dylan and Reese Freireich; brother, Andrew Freireich; and sister-in-law, Tina Potter. Ronald was a dedicated cardiologist, father, husband, brother, friend and mentor. He will be dearly missed by all who knew and loved him. An online guestbook is available at www.edressler.com. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the charity of choice. Shiva will be held from 4:00 through 8:00pm today, Thursday, October 23, 2014 at 366 Broadway, Apt 8B, New York, NY. See more at: http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/atlanta/obituary.aspx?n=Ronald-Freireich&pid= 172860981#

DENBURG--Elsa. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Elsa Denburg. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved family. Stuart Albrecht, President Robert D. Lang, Secretary

de la RENTA--Oscar. The Directors of New Yorkers For Children mourn the loss and will forever cherish the memory of our beloved fellow Director, Oscar de la Renta. He joined the board soon after the organization was founded in 1996 and brought the children in New York City's child welfare system to the attention of the fashion industry and his legions of friends. More than any other individual he developed our capacity to raise funds and awareness for New York's most vulnerable children. For Oscar any child in need was his child, and that compassion led to actions that have changed outcomes for countless young lives. We send our heartfelt sympathy to his loving wife Annette and his children and grandchildren. The world has lost an extraordinary man, and we are grateful for all that he contributed throughout his life. Nicholas Scoppetta, Founder and President Emeritus, Eric Brettschneider, President Susan Burden, Vice President Susan Magazine, Executive Director The Board of Directors

de la RENTA. On behalf of the Board of Trustees, staff and volunteers of WNET, we are saddened at the passing of Oscar de la Renta, former Board member and a Life Trustee. His elegance, his passion and his ongoing generosity to WNET will live on through the projects and programs that he supported. Our thoughts are with his wife Annette and his entire family, and we join them in mourning the passing of a wonderful and gifted contributor to our community. James S. Tisch, Chairman Neal Shapiro, President and CEO

de la RENTA--Oscar. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Animal Medical Center (AMC) mourn the loss of a dear friend, Oscar de la Renta, husband of longtime AMC Board member, Annette de la Renta. A legendary fashion designer and enlightened philanthropist, Mr. de la Renta was also a compassionate animal lover who frequently rescued stray dogs living near his home in Punta Cana in the Dominican Republic. With gratitude for his steadfast support of The Animal Medical Center over many decades, we extend our heartfelt sympathy to Annette, his family, and to all those who were touched by the warmth of his friendship.

de la RENTA--Oscar. The Museum at FIT and the Couture Council mourn the passing of legendary designer Oscar de la Renta. In recognition of his accomplishments, the Couture Council presented him with its Artistry of Fashion Award in 2012. He will be remembered for his lasting contributions to fashion, his unerring taste, and sophisticated glamour. We were honored to consider him a friend.

de la RENTA--Oscar. President Joyce F. Brown, the Board of Trustees, and the faculty and students of the Fashion Institute of Technology mourn the passing of Oscar de la Renta, our longtime friend. His many visits to the college always inspired and moved the FIT community. In 2002 we were pleased to bestow on him an honorary doctorate in recognition of his remarkable contributions to fashion. His brilliance, elegance, and charm will continue to captivate students for generations to come.

de la RENTA--Oscar. The board of Venetian Heritage Inc., mourns the loss of its founding board member Oscar de la Renta. His faithful service to Venice has helped us in fund raising and publicizing the need that still exists for the preservation of Venetian Art and Architecture. We extend our deepest condolences to Annette and to the family. Lawrence Lovett, Founding Chairman; Pierre Durand, Chairman and President; Mrs. Donald K. Miller, Vice Chairman

de la RENTA--Oscar. The FIT Foundation notes with sorrow the passing of Oscar de la Renta, an icon of the fashion industry, a tireless and inspired creator, and a dedicated supporter of FIT. He leaves a timeless legacy of design, achievement, and generosity of spirit. He will be deeply missed.

BERSHTEL--Ester, a survivor of the Holocaust, died on October 19, 2014, at the age of 94. Born in Przytyk, Poland, daughter of Sholem and Gitel Haberberg. Loving wife of the late Menashe. Beloved mother of Sara, Jack, and the late Ora; mother-in-law of Sharon Bershtel and the late Richard Brick; grandmother of Natan (Becky), Leora (Nick), Maya (Dan), Noah (Erin). She will be deeply missed by her family and many friends, including Amy, Cordelia, and Clare Johnson and Laura Slatkin.

Andrew--John. The Reverend Canon John G. B. Andrew OBE, DD, January 10, 1931 October 17, 2014. The Rector, Wardens and Vestry of Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue, on behalf of the Parish, announce the death of their beloved Eleventh Rector (1972-1996), Canon John Andrew. Canon Andrew was born in Yorkshire, England, was a priest in the Church of England, and served as Domestic Chaplain to Archbishop of Canterbury Michael Ramsey. In 1972, he was called to be Rector at Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue, where he had a distinguished tenure in which his preaching, pastoral presence, and leadership of the liturgy drew large congregations to the Church, an achievement especially notable during an era of decline in the Episcopal Church. Canon Andrew and Organist and Master of Choristers, Dr. Gerre Hancock, were instrumental in the preservation and enrichment of the Anglican choral tradition in the United States through the Saint Thomas Choir School. He was awarded honorary degrees from several Episcopal/Anglican seminaries in recognition of his work. John Andrew was a friend and confidant of many church leaders both within and outside the Episcopal Church and Anglicanism. He was a particular friend of Terence Cardinal Cooke and was a promoter of ecumenical relations between the Anglican and Roman Catholic communions. He was a cherished member of the Saint Thomas family for over 40 years. Funeral services will be at Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue on Wednesday, November 5, 2014 at 5:30pm. Donations in lieu of flowers, may be made to the Canon John Andrew Memorial Fund. Please make checks payable to Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue at 1 West 53rd St.; New York, NY 10019-5496. The Reverend Canon Carl F. Turner, Rector William H. A. Wright II, Warden Kenneth F. Koen, Warden

PELS--Donald A. The Board, Co-Founders, and staff of Friends of the High Line mourn with much sorrow the loss of Donald A. Pels. Don and his beloved wife, Wendy Keys, were among our first supporters and have championed the High Line with vision, dedication, and inspiring generosity. Time spent with Don was always illuminating, sparked by his appreciation for thought-provoking art, beautiful parks, and funny stories. His gentle warmth as a husband, father, grandfather, brother, and friend touched all who knew him. His intellectual curiosity and sense of humor were as expansive as the Atlantic views that brought him such contentment. We will always treasure the friendship he gave us and the joyful times we shared. Catie Marron, Chair Mario J. Palumbo, Jr., Vice-Chair John H. Alschuler, Emeritus Chair Philip E. Aarons, Founding Chair Joshua David and Robert Hammond, Co-Founders

O'SULLIVAN--Margaret Mary, on October 21, 2014. Dedicated teacher for over 30 years at P.S.102 in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Dancer who performed with modern dance innovator Charles Weidman during the 1970s and reconstructed his works in the last ten years. Loving mother of Luke Amentas and Maura McConnell. Beloved daughter of Elizabeth O'Sullivan and the late Eugene. Proud "nana" to Colette. Also survived by loving family in Ireland. Visiting Friday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday, 9:30am at Our Lady of Angels, Brooklyn, R.C. Church.

OLCAY--Onder John, beloved husband, father and grandfather, died peacefully at home on October 17 after a valiant battle against prostate cancer. He was 77 years old. Born in Izmir, Turkey, John graduated from Robert College, Istanbul, and received an M.A. and an M.B.A. from the Wharton School. From early on, international finance was central to his career. As a vice president of the Bank of New York, he helped establish the bank's first international office, in London. As a partner at London's W. Greenwell & Co., he became one of the first members of the London Stock Exchange not born in the U.K. or Commonwealth. In 1974 he launched a pioneering joint effort with New York's Fischer Francis Trees & Watts to advise central banks and multinational companies on their U.S. dollar portfolios. This initiative led to long associations with central banks and monetary authorities around the globe. In 1983 he joined Fischer Francis Trees & Watts and rose to be vice chairman and managing director. Since the late 1960s John has advised Netherlands-based Aegon N.V., serving on the boards of its North American subsidiaries and then on the Aegon N.V. supervisory board. In recent years he has been an adviser to the Peterson Institute for International Economics, in Washington. He also was dedicated to the communities where he lived, advising nonprofit organizations in New York City; London; and Point O'Woods, New York. John loved soccer, classical music and opera, theater, fine food and the rugged beauty of the far north of Scotland. Throughout a career characterized by many enduring friendships, John especially enjoyed mentoring younger colleagues, always focusing them on the importance of ethics and integrity. The day before he died, he joined friends and colleagues at a symposium on ethics and the economy organized in his honor. There the Peterson Institute for International Economics announced an endowment for the O. John Olcay Annual Lecture on Ethics and Economic Policy. John is survived by his wife Phebe, daughters Margot and Charlotte, grandson Christopher Kaya, sister Nukhet and cousin Attila. His funeral will be held at Saint James' Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Ave., on Friday, October 24, at 3:30pm. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Peterson Institute for International Economics: O. John Olcay Annual Lecture on Ethics and Economic Policy.

O'BRIEN--Monsignor William B.,died October 19 at St. Pius X Church in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 90. Monsignor was a seminal figure in residential drug treatment and earned worldwide recognition and appreciation for his pioneering work in this field. That day over 50 years ago when he founded Daytop changed the way we view and treat addiction. He was also co-founder of the World Federation of Therapeutic Communities which he guided into a global movement establishing treatment programs in countries throughout the world. A trusted adviser to heads of state, as well as to His Holiness Pope John Paul II, Monsignor O'Brien helped shape policies that have radically improved treatment programs around the world. He was the author of the highly acclaimed book, "You Can't Do It Alone: The Daytop Way To Make Your Child Drug Free", published numerous papers in national and international journals, and inspired generations of treatment professionals. All the while he remained at heart a simple parish priest as deeply devoted to his parishioners at St. Brendan's in the Bronx as he was to the residents in treatment and their families. A truly extraordinary man of staggering faith, integrity, warmth, and loyalty whose impact on drug treatment has been profound and lasting. Monsignor O' Brien's enduring legacy will be his selfless dedication to saving young lives and his unswerving devotion to his church and God. A mass of Christian burial will be held at St. Pius X Church, 91 Secor Road, Scarsdale, NY, on Saturday, October 25 at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory may be made to St. Pius X Church.
