NICHOLSON--Susan Zeckendorf, daughter of the late William Zeckendorf, Sr., and Irma Levy Kolodin and sister of the late William Zeckendorf, Jr., on Tuesday, October 21, in New York City, her home for 83 years. Susan was the devoted mother of James Nicholson and Leslie Nicholson, beloved mother-in-law of Susan Nicholson, adored grandmother of Amanda (Francis) Bergold, David and Michael Nicholson, and Madeleine, Eric, Alison and Scott Goldstein, and cherished aunt of William (Laura) and Arthur Zeckendorf, dear sister-in-law of Nancy Zeckendorf. We will miss her grace, warmth, charm, wit and passion for the arts. She was truly one of a kind. Service Friday, October 31, 2104, 1:30pm at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

LEIFER--Milton "Mike," on October 22, 2014 at age 95. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Loving father of Roberta Fisher and Joyce Leifer Schenck. Devoted father-in- law of Bob Fisher and James Schenck. Cherished grandfather of Michael, Lara, Graham and Ben. Special cousin of the late Dr. David Grob and family. Mike was very proud of his military service in the 94th Division during World War II, and a recipient of a Silver and two Bronze Stars. He had a successful business with his late brother Walter, Leifer Bros Steel. In his spare time he wrote a novel, "Murder on The Rocks," published by his family for his 90th birthday. He composed numerous songs and was known for his sense of humor and creative word play. Donations may be made in his memory to a Veteran's charity of your choice. Services 11am, Friday, October 24, 2014 at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 11021. www.RiversideNassauNorth Chapels.com

KAMMERER--Julie, prominent Manhattan residental real estate broker with Kenneth Ives, Inc. and Douglas Elliman, a quintessential New Yorker, who was widely known as much for her tireless charity work on behalf of several of the city's major institutions and community services as for her impeccable taste, died on October 12, 2014 at Southampton Hospital after a long illness. She was 84. A funeral mass was held for her on October 17 at the Parish Basilica of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary in Southampton. Julie Kammerer was born on July 25, 1930, the daughter of Paul and Agnes Kammerer. She graduated from Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart in New York. She was witty and well-read, naturally sociable and the epitome of correctness. She was a generous and loyal friend and a profoundly civic-minded woman. She served as a board member of the Society of Memorial Sloan Kettering, the Bronx Zoo, the Girls Scouts of America and the Southampton Association. She was a former president of the Garden Club of Southampton and a former president of the New York Junior League. She was a member of the Colony Club in New York; The Southampton Bathing Corporation, The Meadow Club and the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club in Southampton; The Bath & Tennis Club and the Everglades Club in Palm Beach, Florida.

de la RENTA--Oscar. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Oscar de la Renta, a devoted and generous friend of our company for 30 years. He joined the Met board in 1987 and served as a Managing Director from 1990 until his retirement in 2004. On behalf of the entire company, we extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Annette; to his son, Moises; and to his family members and friends around the world. Ann Ziff, Chairman of the Board Kevin W. Kennedy, President & CEO Mercedes T. Bass, Vice Chairman Peter Gelb, General Manager

de la RENTA--Oscar. The Directors of New Yorkers For Children mourn the loss and will forever cherish the memory of our beloved fellow Director, Oscar de la Renta. He joined the board soon after the organization was founded in 1996 and brought the children in New York City's child welfare system to the attention of the fashion industry and his legions of friends. More than any other individual he developed our capacity to raise funds and awareness for New York's most vulnerable children. For Oscar any child in need was his child, and that compassion led to actions that have changed outcomes for countless young lives. We send our heartfelt sympathy to his loving wife Annette and his children and grandchildren. The world has lost an extraordinary man, and we are grateful for all that he contributed throughout his life. Nicholas Scoppetta, Founder and President Emeritus, Eric Brettschneider, President Susan Burden, Vice President Susan Magazine, Executive Director The Board of Directors

CARSWELL--Bruce, of Greenwich CT, passed away at his home in Naples, Florida on October 13, 2014. He was 84 years old. He was a graduate of Colby College, Waterville, Maine and Cornell Law School, Ithaca, NY. He was Senior Vice President of Human Resources and Administration for GTE Corp. now Verizon. Bruce made a huge impact on the Human Resource function and received many honors and awards for his many accomplishments. He is survived by his loving wife, Cathy, two sons, Douglas and David, one daughter, Meredith, and one step-son, Matt Rossi. He is also survived by four grandchildren and one great-grandson.

BRANCAZIO--Robert T. Sr.,known to many as "Cos", passed away on Wednesday, October 22 surrounded by his loving family. Born in 1948, he was a lifelong resident of Bronx, NY. Beloved husband to Camille for 42 years. Devoted father to Lisa Collins and her husband John, Andrea Iannuccilli and her husband Peter, and Robert T. Brancazio Jr. Cherished Papa to Jack Ryan, Amelia Margaret, and Peter Robert. He proudly served his country in the Vietnam War and worked in the Advertising Department at The New York Times for 41 years. Robert was always optimistic. He warmed people with his smile and was always willing to help others. We will miss his gentle and selfless nature. Services will be held at Schuyler Hill Funeral Home. Donations can be made to Fred's Team at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

WEINTRAUB--Eric A, died Friday October 24, surrounded by parents, Susan Brecher and Michael Weintraub, and sister Rebecca, from IPEX, a rare autoimmune disorder. Eric inspired with love of music, college football, dedication to family, and humor. His strength and resilience gave courage to all. Like his beloved grandfathers, Eric was a dedicated Mason and Shriner. He was heroic and will remain our hero.

WEINBERGER--Peggy. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of 885 Park Avenue Corporation are saddened by the loss of Mrs. Peggy Weinberger, who died at home on Monday morning October 20th. She and her first husband, James Foster, moved to 885 Park in 1950 and as original co-op board members, they set a tone of congeniality and neighborliness. Following Mr. Foster's death, Peggy married Dr. Howard Weinberger. They made an elegant, charming and sophisticated couple. Mrs. Weinberger's warm, generous and outgoing personality will be missed by residents and staff alike. Our sympathies to her family and many good friends.

SMITH-BURKE--Margaret P. Margaret "Trika" Smith-Burke, Born September 6, 1943 in Princeton, NJ, to Albridge C. and Margaret Smith: died peacefully at home in SoHo, NY on October 13, 2014, after a brave battle with colon cancer. A graduate of Miss Fine's School (1961) and Vassar College (1965) Trika received her Ed.D from Rutgers University in 1975. She was formerly married to New York artist Michael Burke. As a professor at NYU from 1975-2007, Trika was passionate about making reading pedagogy more effective. She also worked hard to to assure that young women scholars received the support they needed to become successful literacy researchers. She served as President of the National Reading Conference. At NYU Trika led the way in establishing the Reading Recovery Project, an early intervention program which trained teachers and teacher leaders, working directly with school districts, teachers, and students as well as national and international Reading Recovery programs. She always enjoyed teaching students one-on-one and developing strategies for struggling readers. She adored her long-time friends and loved to make new friends and mentor young people. She delighted in the arts, attending operas at the Met and dance at the Joyce Theater. She enjoyed mindfulness meditation and quiet time in nature. She is survived by her sister and brother-in-law, Cary and Gary Hart, her nieces Elissa, Katherine and Laura and their families and many devoted extended family members, friends and students. Her generous spirit and zest for life will be sorely missed. Donations in her memory may be made to The Reading Recovery Project of NYU, 239 Greene St, New York,NY 10003 or the Margaret "Trika" Smith-Burke Scholarship Fund, c/o Community Foundation of the Virginias, POBox 4127, Bluefield, WV 24701

SACKSTEIN--Harvey A.,of Garden City, NY and Boca Raton, FL. Born December 30, 1927 in Brooklyn, NY, he is survived by his cherished wife of almost 60 years, Iris, children Ellen, Mark and Robert, daughters-in-law Georgina and Robin, and grandchildren Michael, Paul, Sophie, Matthew, Daniel and James. A graduate of Brooklyn Law School, he practiced law for 62 years and was universally held in the highest esteem. He was a solo practitioner for many years, while also an arbitrator for the American Arbitration Association. Ultimately Harvey became the founding partner of the law firm Sackstein Sackstein & Lee, LLP, where he especially enjoyed working with his children Ellen and Mark. An optimistic man with a zest for life, he always had a smile and a kind word. He enjoyed traveling, reading, sports and the arts, but his greatest joy was being in the company of his family and close friends. Harvey was a champion of those in need, whether through his law practice, philanthropy or everyday life. He will be greatly missed and never forgotten.

O'BRIEN--Monsignor William B.,a remarkable man who selflessly used his life to save young lives. We are not liable to see the likes of him again, never having seen suchlike before him. How very fortunate I was to have him as my mentor and friend. Love you, brother! Brian Madden

NITZBURG--Eunice Ann Coolidge, on October 22, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Robert. Adoring mother of George (Emily Chasan) and Benjamin, and grandmother of baby girl Nitzburg (due November 13, 2014). Loving sister of Oliver Coolidge and Liz Coolidge. Donations in lieu of flowers, to The Churchill School or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center would be appreciated. Services 11:30am Monday at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 11021. www.riversidenassau northchapels.com

MOHR-MAYER--Heidrun. March 5, 1941, Free City of Danzig, Germany October 14, 2014 Baden-Baden, Germany. Mrs. Mohr Mayer was a German jeweller best known for reviving the international jewelry brand Faberge. She was a CEO of the German jewelry company Victor Mayer from 1990 to 2001 and was a co-founder and supporter of several cultural institutions. Together with her husband and co-owner of the family jewelry business she established the first contemporary Faberge collection in 1990 which was presented in Munich to the public. The Faberge jewelry license was given to the Victor Mayer Company by Unilever until 2004 when it was sold to another company. Heidrun Mohr-Mayer died in a hospital in Baden-Baden after losing the battle with cancer. Her close family members were present at the time of her death. She is survived by her husband Dr. Herbert Mohr-Mayer and their sons, Dr Marcus Mohr, Dr. Daniel Mohr and Dipl-Ing Philipp Mohr with their families. Over four hundred people attended the funeral in Pforzheim, Germany on Tuesday, October 21, 2014.

KEENAN--Terry, on October 23, 2014. It is with tremendous sorrow that we report the passing, due to a massive cerebral hemorrhage, of a wonderful mother, wife, sister, and pioneering financial journalist. Terry was a trailblazer who credited much of her success to her beloved mother's emphasis on education, which led her to Holy Names Academy in Albany, NY, and a math scholarship to Johns Hopkins University. After Johns Hopkins, she produced the iconic PBS show "Wall Street Week" with Louis Rukeyser; Rukeyser, recognizing her very rare combination of talents a flair for words coupled with an amazing facility with numbers - became a mentor. Soon she was picked up by CNN's Moneyline, hosted by another longtime mentor, Lou Dobbs. Terry reported on the 1987 stock market crash, and was the first journalist to report live from the New York Stock Exchange. She went on to have various anchor stints at CNBC and Fox News. She left Fox to spend more cherished time with her son, Benjamin Kass, and husband, Ron Kass. Throughout her post-TV career, she never missed a deadline for her weekly New York Post financial column. Aside from her son Benjamin and husband Ron, Terry leaves behind her two sisters, Joellen Gardner and Linda Keenan, as well as many nieces and nephews. She was predeceased by her much-loved parents, Marie and Joseph Keenan. In lieu of flowers, those who wish to may donate to Loyola School, 980 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10028. Services to be held Friday, October 31, at 11am, at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park at 84th Street. Reception to follow.

GLADSTEIN--Muriel, 90, of Bayside, NY. Died on October 24, 2014. Predeceased by her husband Eli. Mother to Amy (Jim Reif), Eva (Ben Burenstein) and Sam (Katie Fisher). Doting grandmother to Daniel, Jason, Jacob, Noah, Micah and Ruben. Retired professor of social work at Hunter College. Donations in her memory may be made to Family Focus Adoption Service of Little Neck or Doctors Without Borders. Services Sunday 3pm at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 N Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

EHRENPREIS--Ralph. June 9, 1942 - October 18, 2014 Ralph Ehrenpreis wrote a first draft of his obituary over the years, but often quipped that he wanted it to be published many years in the future, if at all. Ralph was born in Memphis, Tennessee to Irv and Bess Ehrenpreis and shortly thereafter moved to Oak Park, MI, a suburb of Detroit, where he grew up with his only sister, Tobi. When he was ten, his father passed away and there began his everlasting quest to avoid his own death. He went to University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, where he graduated in 1963. Thereafter, he moved to California to marry Sandra Jackson and to attend Stanford Law School, where he received his Juris Doctor in 1967. After moving to Los Angeles to work for a large law firm, he quickly found his niche by establishing an immigration law practice more than 40 years ago, which continues to be one of the most successful such firms in the country. His passion for his work was only surpassed by his love of jazz, theater, film, exercise, literature, and his family. Over the years he amassed a remarkable and vast collection of jazz recordings. He played his music loud, scrutinizing every word of the liner notes, had an encyclopedic knowledge of the history of the music and artists, and was a scholar of all things jazz. He was a voracious reader with his home filled with shelves of books from decades of interests. Although he will be remembered for his tireless commitment to his law practice, most will remember a man with an unsurpassed sense of humor, wry and quick wit, and sarcasm. As much as he loved making others laugh, he loved making himself laugh even more. Beneath his irreverence was a man who loved his friends, made strangers smile, and made time every day of his life to be there for his closest family. So many people loved and admired his insatiable curiosity, depth of interests, sheer intellect, and charisma and warmth. He was deeply committed to his wife of eighteen years, Jennifer Kaufman, his three children, Ira, Jeff, and Jason, his daughters-in-law, Ellen and Brooke, his step-children Darian and Ben, and his three grandchildren, Lindsay, Ashley, and Zachary. In the ultimate irony, his death was tragic like that of his father and so many of the jazz figures who were his heroes. Services were held at Hillside Memorial Park in Los Angeles on Wednesday, October 22, 2014 at 10am. To view the service, go to: http://RalphEhrenpeis53696. HillsideMemorialParkSympathyNet.ezwebcast.com/ login/user/user900948/password/aba1bf836e3b4b5464a21864ef9928c5 As Ralph would have wanted to have had the last laugh: in lieu of flowers or donations, please send gifts. Cash also accepted. Please send notes of remembrances, stories, and memories about Ralph to ralph@ehrenpreis.com

DARNELL--Eleanor (nee Kaiser), on October 22, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Ralph. Devoted mother of Wade, Colin, Eileen, Jean, David, Paul, and Kevin. COAKLEY--James Francis, emeritus professor of theatre in the Northwestern University School of Communication, died on June 18, 2014 of complications from non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. He was 80. He earned his bachelor of fine arts degree at Carnegie Institute of Technology (now Carnegie Mellon University), and then served as a cryptographer in the U.S. Army Signal Corps. He earned an M.A. from the University of Minnesota (1959) and a Ph.D. from Northwestern University (1964). He lived a life of the mind, as teacher, director, and critic. He was respected and adored by his family, friends, and students. His teaching career spanned four decades, beginning at Loyola University and the Goodman Theatre in Chicago, followed by a stint at the University Michigan before returning to Northwestern University in 1976, where he remained until his retirement in 2005. He taught theatre history, interpretation, stage directing, acting, theory, and the development of dramatic art. He was highly regarded as an outstanding director of both classical and contemporary works for university theatre and other theatre companies. His many productions included "Much Ado About Nothing," "Love's Labour's Lost," Brecht's "Edward II," "Amadeus," Robert Patrick's "Kennedy's Children," and a distinguished production of "After the Fall," with the playwright, Arthur Miller, in attendance throughout the production process. He was chosen by the dean of what was then called the School of Speech, to direct the opening production of the new Theatre and Interpretation Center. He did so with a production of "Hippolytus" in the Ethel Barber Theatre. Composer Alan Stout, head of the Composition Department in the School of Music, provided an original score. In addition to publishing many academic essays and reviews in respected journals such as Comparative Drama, he worked as a theatre and music critic for the daily newspaper Chicago American. He was also known for his tremendously incisive wit and his hearty, sometimes outrageous, laugh. Many of his students have gone on to achieve great success in the entertainment industry and in academia, some receiving Tony and Emmy nominations and awards. He was deeply proud of his students' achievements in or outside of the arts. After retiring from Northwestern he relocated to Pennsylvania, where he lived with his sister, Irma Deiderick, who survives him along with his nephew, Brian Deiderick.

WINDT--Robert. He was born April 27, 1920 and died October 24, 2014. Robert Stanley Windt was bred in Brooklyn. He was a graduate of New Utrecht High School and a life-long baseball fan having seen the Dodgers play at Ebbets Field. He joined the Army for World War II becoming a carburation expert and B-29 Bomber instructor. At the end of the War, he returned home to live with his mother and start a career in public relations working for such companies as CBS, Mountain Valley Water, Dumont Television, Fairchild Publications, Pepsi Cola, Royal Crown Cola, Seagram's and STP Motor Oil. He retired from the profession when he and his two partners sold their ownership of Bebidas, a Spanish language beverage industry magazine. Uncle Bob, as he was known, was a loving, son, brother, uncle, great-uncle and great-great-uncle with a story or three at every family gathering. He will be missed by his family and friends. At the request of the family, donations in his memory can be made to the List Family Fund for Jewish Culture in Memory of Lawrence List at the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue (131 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201). To use Uncle Bob's favorite word - he had a "Fabulous" life. Bobye, Deborah and Mali List.

WEINTRAUB--Eric A, died Friday October 24, surrounded by parents, Susan Brecher and Michael Weintraub, and sister Rebecca, from IPEX, a rare autoimmune disorder. Eric inspired with love of music, college football, dedication to family, and humor. His strength and resilience gave courage to all. Like his beloved grandfathers, Eric was a dedicated Mason and Shriner. He was heroic and will remain our hero.

TORREST--Eleanor, age 94, beloved mother of Barbara Torrest and Sherry Zelvin died on October 14, 2014 in the Bronx, NY. She was pre-deceased by her devoted husband, Paul Torrest, who died in 1995. Mourning her loss are her grandchildren Dan, Josh and Lori and her family and many friends. Eleanor spent over 30 years as the college guidance counselor at Bayside High School, Queens, where she touched the lives of many grateful students.

TANANBAUM--Doris. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Doris Tananbaum, who with her husband Stanley has been a Benefactor of the Museum since 1997 and a steadfast supporter of the American Wing for more than 50 years. In addition to their longstanding participation as Friends of the American Wing and as William Cullen Bryant Fellows, they have contributed significantly to the development of the Museum's activities and galleries for American art. In recognition of these gifts, The Doris and Stanley Tananbaum Galleries for American decorative arts were named in their honor. Doris and Stanley have helped the Met remain at the forefront of presenting American art to the public, to the benefit of the millions of visitors who enjoy the American Wing each year. We extend our condolences to Stanley and the entire family. Daniel Brodsky, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director and CEO Emily K. Rafferty, President

SOLLINS-BROWN--Susan. The Board of Directors of the Earle Brown Music Foundation is deeply saddened by the unexpected and sudden passing of Susan Sollins-Brown on October 13, 2014. Life and work were inseparable to her, as she understood work to be a creative activity -- not to be stopped other than to spend time with her dear family, or with her closest friends. Gentle and soft- spoken, she was a leader with natural authority. Grace permeated all of her actions. Although she served and fostered the art of others, both through ICI (now Independent Curators International), ART21, and as President and Trustee of the Earle Brown Music Foundation, she herself was also an exceptional artist and respected filmmaker. She chose her friends and her endeavors carefully and wisely, knowing that she would devote herself to them fully, often, for life. It was her genuine creativity and gentle power, her devotion, her long-term vision, and what appeared to be unstoppable energy that allowed her to build a legacy whose success and influence on others has spread throughout the world. This seemed to surprise her. Susan created the Earle Brown Music Foundation together with her beloved husband, the late composer Earle Appleton Brown, during a time when he was already terminally ill. After Earle's death in 2002, it was her mission and ongoing gift to him to ensure that his work would be well published in its entirety, as it is today, and that his archive would be available for study by future generations of researchers and musicologists. The Board of Directors and staff of the Earle Brown Music Foundation, continuing her mission, will miss her sorely.

SMITH-BURKE--Margaret P. Margaret "Trika" Smith-Burke, Born September 6, 1943 in Princeton, NJ, to Albridge C. and Margaret Smith: died peacefully at home in SoHo, NY on October 13, 2014, after a brave battle with colon cancer. A graduate of Miss Fine's School (1961) and Vassar College (1965) Trika received her Ed.D from Rutgers University in 1975. She was formerly married to New York artist Michael Burke. As a professor at NYU from 1975-2007, Trika was passionate about making reading pedagogy more effective. She also worked hard to to assure that young women scholars received the support they needed to become successful literacy researchers. She served as President of the National Reading Conference. At NYU Trika led the way in establishing the Reading Recovery Project, an early intervention program which trained teachers and teacher leaders, working directly with school districts, teachers, and students as well as national and international Reading Recovery programs. She always enjoyed teaching students one-on-one and developing strategies for struggling readers. She adored her long-time friends and loved to make new friends and mentor young people. She delighted in the arts, attending operas at the Met and dance at the Joyce Theater. She enjoyed mindfulness meditation and quiet time in nature. She is survived by her sister and brother-in-law, Cary and Gary Hart, her nieces Elissa, Katherine and Laura and their families and many devoted extended family members, friends and students. Her generous spirit and zest for life will be sorely missed. Donations in her memory may be made to The Reading Recovery Project of NYU, 239 Greene St, New York,NY 10003 or the Margaret "Trika" Smith-Burke Scholarship Fund, c/o Community Foundation of the Virginias, POBox 4127, Bluefield, WV 24701

SLAUGHTER--Thomas Robert, an artist, designer, and illustrator living and working in New York City, died October 24, 2014 from brain cancer. He was 59. Discovered by Henry Geldzahler in the 1980s, Slaughter had more than 30 solo exhibitions in New York, Los Angeles, Miami, Vancouver, Germany and Japan. He worked as a printmaker in collaboration with Durham Press for 25 years, and his editions are included in the permanent collections of MoMA and the Whitney Museum of American Art. He illustrated twelve children's books, including "Boat Works," "Do You Know Which Ones will Grow? " - a 2011 Notable American Library Association book of the year - and collaborations with Marthe Jocelyn such as "ABC x 3," "Same Same," and "123." These books have been translated into six languages. Slaughter also worked for the last ten seasons as the Art Director for the New Victory Theater. As a designer, he created everything from t-shirts to skateboard decks, beach towels as well as a line of wallpaper for Cavern Home. Slaughter served on the board of directors of MoMA PS1, the Public Theater, and the Horace W. Goldsmith Foundation. As a director of the Goldsmith Foundation, Slaughter was instrumental in the Foundation's support of numerous art and theater organizations including The Drawing Center, Naked Angels, and the Studio Museum in Harlem. Slaughter will be remembered as a consummate New Yorker, a vivid institution in his SoHo community. He most enjoyed spending time with his daughters at his second home in Noyac, Long Island. He is survived by his mother Virginia Slaughter, his daughter Nell Jocelyn, his daughter and son-in-law Hannah Jocelyn and Jimmy Mezei, brothers Bill, Chuck and Jamie Slaughter, as well as eight nephews and nieces and one great nephew. Services will be held Monday, November 3, 2014 at 11am at the New Victory Theater.

SCHRADE-JAMES--Robelyn. The Allen-Stevenson School community mourns the loss of Ms. Robelyn Schrade-James, our beloved Magical Music Lady for over 25 years. Through her unique ability to make each person feel special, Ms. Schrade-James inspired generations of boys to love music. She enriched the lives of countless students, parents and colleagues, and she will remain in our thoughts and hearts forever. In gratitude, we send our sincerest condolences to her family. Mark I. Greene, President, Board of Trustees David R. Trower, Headmaster

SALZBANK--Julius, 97 Roslyn, NY October 19, 2014. Food Industry Pioneer and staunch supporter of Jewish causes. Devoted husband of the late Claire, and beloved father of Robert (Stephanie), Alan (Karen), Michael (Barbara). Loving grandfather of Yosef, Zev, Zach, Sara, Jackie and Lena. He will be sorely missed yet with us forever.

SAKOL--Jeannie. With sadness we report the passing of our sister Jeannie. A journalist, editor, publisher and columnist. Survived by two sisters Miriam Sakol and Maple Phyllis Canner. Jeannie's generous spirit, wit and zest for life will be missed.

SACKSTEIN--Harvey A.,of Garden City, NY and Boca Raton, FL. Born December 30, 1927 in Brooklyn, NY, he is survived by his cherished wife of almost 60 years, Iris, children Ellen, Mark and Robert, daughters-in-law Georgina and Robin, and grandchildren Michael, Paul, Sophie, Matthew, Daniel and James. A graduate of Brooklyn Law School, he practiced law for 62 years and was universally held in the highest esteem. He was a solo practitioner for many years, while also an arbitrator for the American Arbitration Association. Ultimately Harvey became the founding partner of the law firm Sackstein Sackstein & Lee, LLP, where he especially enjoyed working with his children Ellen and Mark. An optimistic man with a zest for life, he always had a smile and a kind word. He enjoyed traveling, reading, sports and the arts, but his greatest joy was being in the company of his family and close friends. Harvey was a champion of those in need, whether through his law practice, philanthropy or everyday life. He will be greatly missed and never forgotten.

RUSSO--Alvin A. At approximately 6am on Wednesday morning, October 22nd, Alvin A. Russo passed away at home with his loving wife at his side. He had been battling bone cancer since last spring and endured a leg amputation in hopes of recovery when his heart gave out. Born on September 21st, 1927 in Brooklyn, NY, he grew up in a classic New York City brownstone on 64th street in the Hell's Kitchen area where Lincoln Center now stands. Very often, he would fondly recall happy times as a child spent fishing, playing and exploring Central Park. In 1945 at the age of 18, he enlisted in the United States Navy and served his country honorably and faithfully till his discharge in 1952. He then attended the Rhodes Preparatory School at 11 East 54th Street before going on to study mechanical engineering at the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, NJ. He was a proud member of the varsity squash and chess teams as a student there. From 1954 to 1964, he worked in the Brooklyn Navy Yards helping in the construction of numerous Navy vessels. He then accepted a position with the New York City Board of Education as a master machinist, where he worked until his retirement in 1984 at the age of 57. Then, he began his second career as an investor, spending good portions of each day working on his portfolio and looking for companies he believed in. It was an endeavor he enjoyed passionately till his last days. He also enjoyed playing poker and spending time with his beautiful wife of 60 years, Erna. He would often declare how blessed he was to have her. They split their time between homes in Tom's River, NJ and Melbourne, FL since 1994. His legacy lives on through his loving wife, Erna, a son Joseph and four beautiful grandchildren, Ariana, Mason, Colton and Hope. Memorial services will be held at a later date. Friends and family will be notified as soon as plans are in place.

QUIGLEY--Joan Ceciel. Joan was fortunate to be the dearly loved daughter of John Baird and Zelda Marks Quigley. Joan was the valedictorian of her class at the Sarah Dix Hamlin School and graduated with honors from Vassar College. After college, Joan returned to San Francisco to lead a life filled with volunteer work, the Junior League, docent work at the De Young Museum etc. Joan also led a very active social life filled with parties and courtship. Joan became the toast of the town, one of the most beautiful women in a city known for its beautiful women. During this period of her life, Joan also learned astrology and began to practice the discipline that would take her to the highest point of her profession. After writing a series of articles for Seventeen magazine, Joan used the nom de plume Angel Star for "Astrology For Teens" published in 1968. Joan also appeared many times on the Merv Griffin Show during the '60s and '70s. When Nancy Reagan, then First Lady of California, asked Merv for the best astrologer he knew, Merv recommended Joan. Joan worked as a volunteer on both of Ronald Reagan's presidential campaigns even though she knew that Reagan would not win the nomination in 1976. During the 1980 campaign before becoming the Republican nominee, Reagan misspoke on Taiwan. The campaign manager checked Joan's daily guide to find that she had warned in red that Reagan might misspeak on foreign policy that day. After that incident, Joan's advice was followed religiously. When Reagan won the presidency, Joan went on to other projects. After the assassination attempt, Nancy Reagan called Joan to ask if she could have predicted it. Joan said that she could have had she been following his chart. Nancy then asked Joan to take on the responsibility for keeping Reagan safe. Since 1860, all presidents elected in zero years have died in office or been assassinated. Joan asked for 24 hours to think it over and then agreed. While working with the Reagans, Joan modified Nancy's image, convinced Reagan to stop referring to the USSR as an "Evil Empire" and said that the President would be able to work with Gorbachev to achieve his goal of ending the Cold War. Joan timed Reagan's first meeting with Gorbachev in Geneva, the meeting at Reykjavik and all subsequent meetings. Joan helped defuse the Bitburg controversy and kept Reagan under wraps during Irangate. Joan was the teflon in the "Teflon" presidency. Joan wrote a book about her Reagan years called, "What Does Joan Say?" (1990) Joan also wrote two other books, "Astrology For Adults" (1969) and "Astrology For The Parents Of Teenagers And Children" (1971) and published a monograph, "An Essay In Honor of Mohandas K. Gandhi" in 1999. Joan had a very lively, creative and original mind. A published author and brilliant astrologer, Joan was also a gifted jewelry designer and artist. Joan had a mesmerizing kind of charm, a dry wit and did not suffer fools gladly. Joan loved art, opera, ballet and symphony. Joan also loved to travel and enjoyed fine food and wine. Joan is predeceased by her loving parents, John B. and Zelda M. Quigley and dear friends Dr. Albert Shumate, Marge Townsend and Ann Witter. She is survived by her devoted and grieving sister Ruth and friends VV de Margitay, Virginia Warner, Flo Eyre, Lovice de Reviczky, Katerina Cambron and Romy Babajian. Joan was cared for in her final illness by her loving caregiver Tima Nawai and visiting nurse Lourdes Torres. A memorial is planned at a later date. Donations may be made to the San Francisco Opera, San Francisco Ballet, Fine Arts Museums or the charity of your choice.

PRYOR--Sam, 1928-2014. Samuel F. Pryor III passed away on Friday, October 17 at the age of 86 surrounded by his family. He was born in Greenwich, CT, attended the Taft School, Yale University, and the University of Pennsylvania Law School. Sally Reese Pryor, his wife of sixty years, survives him as do his children, Sam, Kathy Burgeson, Dan, Joe and Ted, their spouses, and his nine grandchildren. He was a leader in law and philanthropy, a mentor to countless individuals, an author and adventurer. The funeral service will take place on Saturday, November 1st at 11am at St. Matthews Church in Bedford, NY. He served in the United States Marine Corps from 1953 to 1955, and joined the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell in New York City in 1956. He retired and became Senior Counsel in 1998. He was a dedicated volunteer throughout his life, assisted many philanthropic organizations working to help people and conserve the environment. He received the prestigious New York Governor's Award for Parks and Preservation, The Land Trust Alliance President's Award, and the Open Space Institute Conservation Award. He was chair of the World Rehabilitation Fund and chair emeritus of the Republican Majority for Choice until the time of his death. He is the author of two books, "Make It Happen," which is a biography of his late father, Samuel F. Pryor, Jr, and his own memoir, "My Interesting Life." In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Northern Westchester Hospital and the Westchester Land Trust.

PRAVER--Arnold, 94, passed away peacefully on October 17th, with his beloved wife, Heide, by his side. Mr. Praver leaves four daughters and a son (deceased), two daughters-in-law and a son-in-law, eight grandchildren, four great-grandchildren, a brother and two brothers-in-law, as well as many friends. "The Comeback Kid" lived his life to the fullest and died on his own terms, with no regrets.

PELS--Donald A. The Board, Co-Founders, and staff of Friends of the High Line mourn with much sorrow the loss of Donald A. Pels. Don and his beloved wife, Wendy Keys, were among our first supporters and have championed the High Line with vision, dedication, and inspiring generosity. Time spent with Don was always illuminating, sparked by his appreciation for thought-provoking art, beautiful parks, and funny stories. His gentle warmth as a husband, father, grandfather, brother, and friend touched all who knew him. His intellectual curiosity and sense of humor were as expansive as the Atlantic views that brought him such contentment. We will always treasure the friendship he gave us and the joyful times we shared. Catie Marron, Chair Mario J. Palumbo, Jr., Vice-Chair John H. Alschuler, Emeritus Chair Philip E. Aarons, Founding Chair Joshua David and Robert Hammond, Co-Founders

PELS--Donald A. The Board of Directors and staff of Asphalt Green mourn the passing on October 16 of our friend and supporter Donald A. Pels. As a Board Member during the organization's early years, Donald was deeply committed to helping New Yorkers of all ages and backgrounds achieve health through a lifetime of sports and fitness. After stepping down from the Board in 1987, Donald continued to be one of Asphalt Green's most generous supporters, directly impacting the lives of thousands of New Yorkers. We share his loss with his wife, Wendy Keys, the Pels family, and friends to whom we extend our sincerest condolences.

O'BRIEN--Monsignor William B.,a remarkable man who selflessly used his life to save young lives. We are not liable to see the likes of him again, never having seen suchlike before him. How very fortunate I was to have him as my mentor and friend. Love you, brother! Brian Madden

NITZBURG--Eunice Ann Coolidge, on October 22, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Robert. Adoring mother of George (Emily Chasan) and Benjamin, and grandmother of baby girl Nitzburg (due November 13, 2014). Loving sister of Oliver Coolidge and Liz Coolidge. Donations in lieu of flowers, to The Churchill School or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center would be appreciated. Services 11:30am Monday at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 11021. www.riversidenassau northchapels.com
NICHOLSON--Susan Zeckendorf, October 21, 2014. Longtime New York literary agent, dear friend and champion of her writers. Linda Dahl Mary Ann Eckels Joan Duncan Oliver Edith Van Slyck

NICHOLSON--Susan Zeckendorf, daughter of the late William Zeckendorf, Sr., and Irma Levy Kolodin and sister of the late William Zeckendorf, Jr., on Tuesday, October 21, in New York City, her home for 83 years. Susan was the devoted mother of James Nicholson and Leslie Nicholson, beloved mother-in-law of Susan Nicholson, adored grandmother of Amanda (Francis) Bergold, David and Michael Nicholson, and Madeleine, Eric, Alison and Scott Goldstein, and cherished aunt of William (Laura) and Arthur Zeckendorf, dear sister-in-law of Nancy Zeckendorf. We will miss her grace, warmth, charm, wit and passion for the arts. She was truly one of a kind. Service Friday, October 31, 2104, 1:30pm at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

NICHOLAS--John Cary, resident of Carmel, CA died on October 18, 2014 following complications of Alzheimer's Disease. Born in New Brunswick, New Jersey, January 21, 1930, John spent his formative years in Highland Park, NJ. A graduate of Highland Park High School, John held degrees from Colgate University, '51 and Harvard MBA, '57. As a Lieutenant in the US Navy, John served onboard the USS Irwin during the Korean conflict and brought honor to himself and to his country. Success followed John as an advertising executive for Chesebrough-Pond's and for Bristol Myers before he left to start his own company, The Cary Corporation, known for introducing "Chaser" one of the first hangover pills in the country. John's wit and positive disposition also landed him an appearance on the TV Show, "What's My Line?" Ultimately, John's career path changed to pursue his true passion, owning and operating an antique store, JJ Nicholas, first on San Francisco's artsy Sansome Street and later in Southampton, NY. Mr. Nicholas is survived by his wife of 42 years, Joyce, his brother, Bruce, four children and five grandchildren all of whom inherited elements of artistic appreciation and creativity. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in Mr. Nicholas' name to the Alzheimer's Association or the SPCA of Monterey County, CA. There will be a private family memorial.

MOHR-MAYER--Heidrun. March 5, 1941, Free City of Danzig, Germany October 14, 2014 Baden-Baden, Germany. Mrs. Mohr Mayer was a German jeweller best known for reviving the international jewelry brand Faberge. She was a CEO of the German jewelry company Victor Mayer from 1990 to 2001 and was a co-founder and supporter of several cultural institutions. Together with her husband and co-owner of the family jewelry business she established the first contemporary Faberge collection in 1990 which was presented in Munich to the public. The Faberge jewelry license was given to the Victor Mayer Company by Unilever until 2004 when it was sold to another company. Heidrun Mohr-Mayer died in a hospital in Baden-Baden after losing the battle with cancer. Her close family members were present at the time of her death. She is survived by her husband Dr. Herbert Mohr-Mayer and their sons, Dr Marcus Mohr, Dr. Daniel Mohr and Dipl-Ing Philipp Mohr with their families. Over four hundred people attended the funeral in Pforzheim, Germany on Tuesday, October 21, 2014.

MOHAN--Thomas Reed, of Manhattan and Lanesville, NY, on October 11, 2014, age 64, at Mount Sinai Palliative Care. Born on August 16, 1950, the youngest son of Adell and Joseph Mohan, Tom grew up in Middletown, OH. Tom graduated from Middletown High School in 1968. Following a freshman year at Dartmouth, Tom in the autumn of 1969, just a few months after the Stonewall riots, transferred to NYU, where he embraced activism as a ground-floor member of the Gay Liberation Front. After earning his B.A., Tom attended Yale School of Drama with Meryl Streep, Sigourney Weaver, Wendy Wasserstein, Christopher Durang and Albert Innaurato, and obtained an M.F.A. in playwriting in 1975. Tom's many plays, influenced by Ronald Firbank, Ivy Compton-Burnett and Joe Orton, were never produced, perhaps because they were too eccentric. While continuing to write, Tom maintained his strong relationship with NYU by working at the university's American Language Institute, starting full-time in 1977, and eventually becoming its assistant director, a position he held until his death. About 20 years ago, Tom shifted his passion from writing, cooking and opulent party-giving to the quarter-acre garden he established at his retreat in the Catskill hamlet of Lanesville, where despite the limitation of Hardiness Zone 5a, he nurtured an astonishing and ever-expanding multitude of plants, including more than 150 varieties of astilbes, his favorite flower (especially pink ones). Tom was diagnosed with lymphoma in 1999 and combated it valiantly and without complaint to the end. In addition to his brother, Patrick, and sister-in-law, Lee, of Bluffton, SC, and five nephews, Tom is survived by a tight circle of friends and colleagues who will love and miss him until they too are gone. A memorial at NYU is planned for November 14.

MANISCHEWITZ--Beatrice Hoffman (nee Soloway), of Delray Beach, Florida and Verona, NJ, died October 24, 2014 at home. She was predeceased by her husband Sam Hoffman, husband Bernard Manischewitz, sisters Shirley Swilder and Ann and son-in-law Alan Theodore. Surviving is her son Dr. Ronald (Alice) Hoffman and daughter Harriet Theodore.

MALINSKY--Randie W. A devoted daughter, sister, wife, mother, grandmother, friend, intellectual and philanthropist passed away on October 18, 2014 in her home. She was 64 and had waged a courageous fight against lung cancer. Randie was a true lover of life! She lived inside of each moment spontaneously and with great zest. Her intellectual curiosity had no bounds. Randie continually strived to learn more history, culture, religion and current events. She thoroughly immersed herself into her family life, as well as her professional career. Randie's quest for knowledge began at an early age. She received an MBA from Hofstra University and began a marketing career at American Home Products. Eventually, she joined the family business, Waldbaum's Supermarkets. At Waldbaum's, Randie was the buyer of ethnic and kosher foods that were delivered directly to stores, bypassing the warehouse. She was ahead of her time in utilizing direct store delivery, as well as promoting and introducing a vast array of varied ethnic products to the public. She developed marketing campaigns around the products, including food festivals, competitions and holiday calendars. Randie played a significant role in developing this unique niche market which is now emulated by some of the biggest supermarket chains in the world. In addition to her significant professional contributions, Randie devoted significant time and effort in pursuit of her many passions. She explored museums in the United States and abroad, the contemporary art scene, porcelain painting and jewelry design. She loved the theater, ballet and opera. Randie traveled around the world on great adventures alongside of her husband of 44 years, Aaron Malinsky. They shared a wonderful love story, having met on a blind date and been best friends every day since. Randie and Aaron were a true compliment to one another and shared great joy, as well as sorrow, holding hands through it all. Born to Bernice and Ira Waldbaum, Randie grew up with strong family values and a commitment to Jewish learning. Her greatest philanthropic devotion was to The Jewish Theological Seminary. Randie served as a member of the Board of the Rabbinical School at JTS since 1994 and as the Board's Chairperson since 2009. During her tenure she championed the development of the Pastoral Care program and created a connection with JTS and the Hebrew language program at Middlebury College. Most recently Randie and Aaron gifted a fellowship to the incoming classes of the Rabbinical School and the H.L. Miller Cantorial School and College of Jewish Music of JTS. The Malinsky Fellowship will provide a living stipend to first year rabbinical and cantorial students. Randie also served and supported several non-profit organizations including the Long Island Committee for Soviet Jewry, The Eglevsky Ballet, the Auschwitz Jewish Center, The Rhinelander Center of the Children's Aid Society, and the Jewish Lens. She served on the Art Collection Committee of the Jewish Museum and had provided a grant to Uniting Against Lung Cancer for continued research in the fight to cure lung cancer. Randie's most valuable treasure was her family. She is survived by her mother, Bernice Waldbaum, husband Aaron, children Carolyn, Benjamin, and David, daughter-in-law Rebecca, grandchildren Liam and Molly, siblings Martin Waldbaum, Arthur and Nadine Waldbaum, Nancy Waldbaum, Linda Malinsky, Debbie and David Orshevsky, five nieces, five nephews, many cousins and beloved friends. Her funeral service was held on Monday, October 20, 2014 at Park Avenue Synagogue.

LYONS--Gloria, on October 21, 2014. Beloved wife of Jack for 66 years. Loving mother of Karen Lyons Kalmenson and Warren. Devoted mother-inlaw of Melvin Kalmenson and Maryanne. Cherished grandmother of David.

KLEY--John Arthur, retired, Vice-Chairman and Director of The Bank of New York, passed away on October 23, 2014. He was a resident of Naples, Florida. His career began with The Washington Irving Trust Company, Tarrytown, predecessor of The County Trust Company that became part of a bank holding company with The Bank of New York in 1969 and merged with it in 1976. He was a graduate of Pace University and The Stonier Graduate School of Banking at Rutgers University. He was born in Jericho, New York to the late John Kley and Annie Louise (Upton) Kley. He was preceded in death by his wife Florence Elizabeth (nee) Cannon. He is survived by a daughter, Martha Anne, two grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. He is also survived by his wife of 25 years, Lorelei (nee) Wilkening, of Naples, as well as three stepchildren and two step-grandchildren. A burial service will be held later this week in The Garden of the Apostles, Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be sent to: The Endowment Fund of St. John's Episcopal Church, 500 Park Shore Drive, Naples, Florida 34103 or The Building Fund, Christ Episcopal Church, 43 South Broadway, Tarrytown, NY 10591. Please visit: www.hodgesfhatnaplesmg.com for more details.

KLEIN--Arthur, August 20, 1927 - October 21, 2014. 87 years old. Beloved husband of Debra, father of Andra and Sherri, grandfather of Lara and Marc. Executive Vice President of The Lefrak Organization from 1958-2000. Baruch City College graduate. Founding member Hollis Hills Jewish Center. Member of Boca West Country Club. Accomplished CPA and real estate businessman. A prince among men. Donations to Hollis Hills Jewish Center, 210-10 Union Turnpike, Hollis Hills, NY 11427. Funeral Thursday, 12:45pm at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, NY.
KING--Sharon My dearest friend, I miss you already. Love, MJM

KING--Sharon B.,a highly respected leader in philanthropy, died peacefully at home on October 21st, following a long battle with cancer. She was 68 years old. Prior to her work in philanthropy, Sharon held positions in the nonprofit, private, and government sectors, where she devoted her energy and talent to economic and social justice. She began her career as a grantmaker and evaluator for the City of New York, working in underserved communities. She returned to her hometown of Chicago, where she earned a law degree and a Masters Degree in Public Administration. Sharon was a founding Trustee of Horizon Hospice, one of the first such programs in the U.S. While working as an administrator at Cook County Hospital, she met and married Dr. Lambert King, and gave birth to their beloved daughter, Martha Whitney King. Returning to NYC, she continued to focus on public health-related issues, working as a senior policy advisor to then Borough President David Dinkins. Sharon began her career in private philanthropy as a program officer at the Edna McConnell Clark Foundation, served as president of the Edward B. Hazen Foundation, and worked as a philanthropic advisor in the Rockefeller Family Office. Sharon then led the F.B. Heron Foundation for nearly 20 years. As president at Heron, she advanced innovative practices, including mission-related investing, that gained wide influence in philanthropy. Throughout her life, she was inspired by listening to and maintaining strong connections with community leaders. Sharon was a Trustee of the Altman Foundation, the founding Board chair of Firelight Media, and a Board member of: Rockefeller Philanthropy Advisors, Council on Foundations, and Association of Black Foundation Executives. Sharon is survived by her daughter, Martha; her brothers, Wendell and Mark Burns; numerous nieces and nephews; and countless friends. We will miss her blend of wisdom, compassion, and joy. Her generous spirit will continue to inspire us.

KEENAN--Terry Kass. The Board of Directors of 82-83 Tenants Corp. are deeply saddened by the sudden passing of Terry Keenan Kass, the wife of Ron Kass, a former president and current Board member of our co-op. Terry was our long time neighbor, gracious and warm, and will be missed by all who knew her. On behalf of the residents and staff of 45 East 82nd Street and 40 East 83rd Street, we send our deepest sympathy to Ron and their son Benno.

KEENAN--Terry Kass. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Terry (Keenan) Kass, and extend sincere condolences to her family. James Dreyfus, President

KEENAN--Terry, on October 23, 2014. It is with tremendous sorrow that we report the passing, due to a massive cerebral hemorrhage, of a wonderful mother, wife, sister, and pioneering financial journalist. Terry was a trailblazer who credited much of her success to her beloved mother's emphasis on education, which led her to Holy Names Academy in Albany, NY, and a math scholarship to Johns Hopkins University. After Johns Hopkins, she produced the iconic PBS show "Wall Street Week" with Louis Rukeyser; Rukeyser, recognizing her very rare combination of talents a flair for words coupled with an amazing facility with numbers - became a mentor. Soon she was picked up by CNN's Moneyline, hosted by another longtime mentor, Lou Dobbs. Terry reported on the 1987 stock market crash, and was the first journalist to report live from the New York Stock Exchange. She went on to have various anchor stints at CNBC and Fox News. She left Fox to spend more cherished time with her son, Benjamin Kass, and husband, Ron Kass. Throughout her post-TV career, she never missed a deadline for her weekly New York Post financial column. Aside from her son Benjamin and husband Ron, Terry leaves behind her two sisters, Joellen Gardner and Linda Keenan, as well as many nieces and nephews. She was predeceased by her much-loved parents, Marie and Joseph Keenan. In lieu of flowers, those who wish to may donate to Loyola School, 980 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10028. Services to be held Friday, October 31, at 11am, at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park at 84th Street. Reception to follow.

KAYE--Sidney M.,96, of Armonk, NY, passed away on October 23, 2014, of natural causes, at home. Beloved husband of Rose (March 7, 1922-July 11, 2006), of blessed memory, father of Ronnie, Barry (Hilary), and Shelley Kaye, grandfather of Donna and Ira Josephs, Joshua (Caroline) Kaye, and Jordana (Zachary) Kahn, great -grandfather of Isadora and Amelia Kaye and Ellis Kahn. Services at Temple Israel Center of White Plains on Sunday, October 26 at 1pm.

KARPELL--David Reed, 67, of Dobbs Ferry, NY passed away on October 9, 2014, after battling leukemia for 25 years. He is survived by his wife, Stephanie, his soul-mate of 31 years, his daughters, Katherine Lena, Carolee Hope and a sister, Dr. Merrily Karpell Buck. He loved his family with all his heart. He served in the United States Army in Germany as a military policeman. He earned a BA in Theater, and an MS in Education both at CCNY. He found great fulfillment in his 23 years of teaching, retiring in 2012. David loved his life. He was grateful for his family, career and simple pleasures. He was an elegant man. A memorial service will be held at the First Unitarian Society of Westchester, 25 Old Jackson Avenue, Hastings, NY on November 9, 2pm.

KALTER--Herbert. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of Herbert Kalter, beloved husband of Diane and father of Linda (and Burt) Blass, Doreen (and Beryl) Eckstein, YU Guardians, and Joshua (and Beth) Kalter, and to his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Herbert Kalter was a widely respected member of the Great Neck Community. Heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire family. May you be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus

Grover--John C.,96, of New Jersey and Massachusetts, passed away on October 23, 2014. Predeceased by his two wives, Helen King Grover and Kay Bud Grover. He is survived by his children: Katherine Grover, Jonathan Grover, Carol King, Sandra Kennedy and Charlotte McMullen. Services will be at Central Presbyterian Church of Montclair on November 26, 2014 at 11:00am.

GRAU--Barbara Gilman, owner and passionate art frame maker of Frames 27th, devoted mother of Deborah Grau, daughter of Phyllis and Harry Gilman, sister of Larry and Andy Gilman, and companion of Eli Wolfson, died on October 23. Ms. Grau was proud to frame art works of Picasso and Chagal and new artists. A selfless volunteer for Achilles International and GMHC for many years. We will dearly miss her.

GOLDFARB--Michael, died peacefully at home in Garrison, N.Y. October 19, 2014 after a brief illness. Born May 18, 1941 in Manhattan to Dr. William Goldfarb and Frances Lyons Goldfarb, Michael graduated from Bronx High School of Science, NYU and Brown University. He taught philosophy at Brooklyn College before beginning a career in human services, ultimately serving as executive director of AHRC, New York City chapter from 1975 until his retirement in 2011. Michael was a passionate advocate on behalf of people with developmental disabilities and devoted his career to ensuring their rights and opportunities. A man of principle, humor, sensitivity and a big heart, he leaves a legacy of love and cherished memories for his wife of 46 years, Priscilla Stevens Goldfarb; sons Will Goldfarb (Maria), Ubud, Bali; Ben Goldfarb (Nora Whalen), Minneapolis, Minn.; Abe Goldfarb (Jennifer Sherrill), Brooklyn, N.Y.; grandchildren LouLou, Emilia, Oliver and Isaac; sister Deborah Reichert (Walter), Salt Lake City, UT; numerous nieces, nephews, extended family, colleagues and friends. Services private. Donations may be made to AHRC NYC Foundation, 83 Maiden Lane, New York, NY 10038 or VNA of Hudson Valley Hospice, 540 White Plains Rd. Ste. 300, Tarrytown, NY 10591.

GLADSTEIN--Muriel, 90, of Bayside, NY. Died on October 24, 2014. Predeceased by her husband Eli. Mother to Amy (Jim Reif), Eva (Ben Burenstein) and Sam (Katie Fisher). Doting grandmother to Daniel, Jason, Jacob, Noah, Micah and Ruben. Retired professor of social work at Hunter College. Donations in her memory may be made to Family Focus Adoption Service of Little Neck or Doctors Without Borders. Services Sunday 3pm at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 N Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

GIELISSE--Peter J.,Professor Emeritus of Mechanical Engineering, Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL, died at the age of 80 on October 15, 2014. His obituary can be viewed at www. culleysmeadowwood.com

FRYE--Clayton Wesley, Jr.,died on October 19, 2014. The cause was complications from congestive heart failure. Mr. Frye was the senior associate of Laurance S. Rockefeller for 31 years until Mr. Rockefeller's death in 2004, and then served as executor of his estate, along with continuing with other business and investment interests. Mr. Frye was born in Los Angeles, CA, on May 18, 1930, the son of Clayton W. Frye, Sr, who was the Amateur Middleweight Boxing Champion in 1925, a boxing coach and instructor at Stanford University, and who later served as Secretary of the California State Athletic Commission, and Virginia Briggs Frye. Neither of his parents attended college. Mr. Frye was born in very modest circumstances and attended nine different public schools in California. He worked through high school and was three-sport letterman. After high school he trained briefly to become a professional boxer and then served on active duty as an airman in the U.S. Naval Reserve. He attended Los Angeles City College for two years before transferring to Stanford University where he worked his way through school while competing in athletics. He graduated from Stanford in 1953, and Stanford University Graduate School of Business in 1959. Prior to joining Mr. Rockefeller in New York City in 1973, Mr. Frye co-founded several businesses in California and Texas. He was president and CEO of Palo Alto-based Sutter Hill Development Company, co-founder of Homesmith, Inc., and a general partner and co-founder of San Antonio-based Johnson and Frye Investment Company. For three decades, Mr. Frye worked side by side with Mr. Rockefeller and was responsible for overseeing his diverse business, resort, real estate and investment interests and assisting with his philanthropic programs. In his role with Mr. Rockefeller and the Rockefeller Family, Mr. Frye held leadership positions in Rockresorts, Inc., Rockefeller Center Inc., Rockefeller & Associates Realty, which he founded, and Pacific Properties Services, the manager and operator of Embarcadero Center in San Francisco, of which David Rockefeller was a major partner. Mr. Frye was also a director of Colonial Williamsburg Foundation; a trustee of the Laurance S. Rockefeller Fund and Historic Hudson Valley; and chairman of Jackson Hole Preserve and of the Woodstock Foundation and Woodstock Resort Corporation. Among Mr. Frye's many outside affiliations were directorships of the Times Mirror Company in Los Angeles, California's 270,000-acre Tejon Ranch Company, the King Ranch of Texas and the White House Historical Association. He also served as an overseer of the Hoover Institution at Stanford University. Mr. Frye is survived by a daughter, Diane Frye Tanner, and her husband, Brooks Tanner of New York City; a brother, Craig Frye of Los Angeles, three granddaughters: Carolyn M. Tanner, and Charlotte and Sydney Halloran; and numerous beloved nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his older daughter, Carolyn Frye Halloran, in 2000; by his by his sister, Joan Frye Clark in 2008; and by his wife of 52 years, Dorothy Rumsfeld Frye, in 2009. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center or the Laurance S. Rockefeller Preserve in Jackson Hole, Wyoming. MSKCC donations will be directed to lung and brain cancer research and should be addressed to: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 633 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10017 with "Memory of Clayton W. Frye, Jr." in the memo line. Gifts to the LSR Preserve should be made payable to Jackson Hole Preserve, Inc., with "LSR Preserve Fund" in the memo line and mailed to: Jackson Hole Preserve, Inc., P.O. Box 489, Woodstock, VT 05091.

EHRENPREIS--Ralph. June 9, 1942 - October 18, 2014 Ralph Ehrenpreis wrote a first draft of his obituary over the years, but often quipped that he wanted it to be published many years in the future, if at all. Ralph was born in Memphis, Tennessee to Irv and Bess Ehrenpreis and shortly thereafter moved to Oak Park, MI, a suburb of Detroit, where he grew up with his only sister, Tobi. When he was ten, his father passed away and there began his everlasting quest to avoid his own death. He went to University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, where he graduated in 1963. Thereafter, he moved to California to marry Sandra Jackson and to attend Stanford Law School, where he received his Juris Doctor in 1967. After moving to Los Angeles to work for a large law firm, he quickly found his niche by establishing an immigration law practice more than 40 years ago, which continues to be one of the most successful such firms in the country. His passion for his work was only surpassed by his love of jazz, theater, film, exercise, literature, and his family. Over the years he amassed a remarkable and vast collection of jazz recordings. He played his music loud, scrutinizing every word of the liner notes, had an encyclopedic knowledge of the history of the music and artists, and was a scholar of all things jazz. He was a voracious reader with his home filled with shelves of books from decades of interests. Although he will be remembered for his tireless commitment to his law practice, most will remember a man with an unsurpassed sense of humor, wry and quick wit, and sarcasm. As much as he loved making others laugh, he loved making himself laugh even more. Beneath his irreverence was a man who loved his friends, made strangers smile, and made time every day of his life to be there for his closest family. So many people loved and admired his insatiable curiosity, depth of interests, sheer intellect, and charisma and warmth. He was deeply committed to his wife of eighteen years, Jennifer Kaufman, his three children, Ira, Jeff, and Jason, his daughters-in-law, Ellen and Brooke, his step-children Darian and Ben, and his three grandchildren, Lindsay, Ashley, and Zachary. In the ultimate irony, his death was tragic like that of his father and so many of the jazz figures who were his heroes. Services were held at Hillside Memorial Park in Los Angeles on Wednesday, October 22, 2014 at 10am. To view the service, go to: http://RalphEhrenpeis53696. HillsideMemorialParkSympathyNet.ezwebcast.com/ login/user/user900948/password/aba1bf836e3b4b5464a21864ef9928c5 As Ralph would have wanted to have had the last laugh: in lieu of flowers or donations, please send gifts. Cash also accepted. Please send notes of remembrances, stories, and memories about Ralph to ralph@ehrenpreis.com

DEVINE--Nina Cave, passed away peacefully in her home in Litchfield on Wednesday, October 22, 2014. She was predeceased by her husband of 51 years, Joseph Edward Devine, in 2012. Following graduation from The Chapin School in New York, she matriculated at Bryn Mawr College, from which graduated in 1950 with an A.B. in History. She went on to serve as a teacher and librarian at the Harvey School in Katonah, NY, while raising four children in Wilton, CT. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club in New York, a trustee of the Wilton Public Library, and an active parish member of St. Michael's Church in Litchfield. Nina is survived by her four children, Henry Cave Devine of West Roxbury, MA, Joan Devine Morosani of Litchfield, CT, Nancy Devine Pike of Block Island, RI, Alison Devine Celico of Wakefield, RI, and nine grandchildren. A funeral will be held at St. Michael's Church at 2pm on Saturday, November 1. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to either the Wilton Public Library or the Oliver Wolcott Library in Litchfield. BROWN--Constantine. 1927-2014. Constantine Brown passed away on October 22, 2014. His friends and family will miss his enthusiasm and active life style. In 1923, his parents and sister escaped from the forced exchange of Greek and Turkish populations, and came to New York City. He was born in Manhattan's "Hell's Kitchen" where his mother struggled to bring up her fatherless children while working at the Greek Orthodox church nearby. He enlisted in the New York State Guard when a teen-ager. During World War II, he joined the Air Force Cadet Program to become a flight engineer on B-24 bombers. His fluency with the Greek language was used by the C.I.A. When the war ended, he completed high school and earned a B.A. from Columbia University while working full-time with the New York City Housing Authority Police. From 1954, he rose through the ranks of the Housing Authority Police which merged with the New York City Police Department. He married Olga Boondas, a professor of social work at Columbia University. His beloved wife and daughter, Themis, pre-deceased him. Constantine was an active member of several organizations, including the Captains' Endowment Association--NYPD, International Association of Chiefs of Police, Fraternal Order of Police, and St. Paul's Society, NYPD. Olga and Constantine inaugurated the Themis Anastasia Brown Endowment Fund at the Morgan Library and Museum 21 years ago. He was in the process of instituting a chair for Classical and Byzantine Studies at Queens College in NYC, and provide support for the Orphanage under the aegis of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese.
BRAUNSCHWEIG--Robert S.,CPA, JD, LLM, passed October 20, 2014. Preeminent Tax Attorney and CPA. He loved life, his work, his clients, and his family. He is and will be deeply missed, forever.

BRADY--Robert Charles, a longtime Franklin Lakes, NJ, resident who was the patriarch of a large, far-flung family full of know-it-alls, died at home on October 4th with his wife of 64 years and three of his four daughters by his side. He was 91, and the biggest know-it-all of all. His wife, the former Katherine Stocker, met Bob Brady through her brother, the late Joseph P. Stocker, who studied chemical engineering at the University of Detroit with Mr. Brady. She was 19, and said she "was envy of all the girls" when she started dating the handsome Omaha native 67 years ago. Mr. Brady was the eldest of four boys born to Charles F. Brady and the former Gertrude Cobry. His three brothers, John R. of Omaha, William G. of Phoenix, and Michael G. of Nelson, New Zealand, survive him, as do six children: Ann E. Brady of Hawthorne, NJ; Patrick R. Brady of Dover, NH; Susan M. Brady of Boston; Carol L. Lundgren of Malmo, Sweden; Thomas M. Brady of New York City; and Katherine A. Spencer of Wynnewood, PA; and thirteen grandchildren. Mr. Brady graduated from Creighton Preparatory School in Omaha in 1941, where he was a top student and played guard and end on a co-state championship football team in 1940. He also found time to edit the school newspaper, co-edit the yearbook and play on an intramural basketball championship team. He earned the award of Eagle Scout, a fact unknown his wife for the first 55 years of their marriage. Mr. Brady enlisted in the military after high school and trained to be a pilot all over the United States throughout 1943-44, eventually winding up as co-pilot on a B-29 Flying Fortress called the Raidin Maiden II based on Tinian Island as part of the 468th Bomber Group. His squadron conducted seven bombing raids on Japan in July and August of 1945, the last one on Hikari Naval Arsenal on August 14, 1945, his 22nd birthday. It was one of the last bombing raids of World War II. In a rare conversation about the war, he described the missions as "seven hours of boredom, followed by seven minutes of terror, followed by seven hours of boredom." Katherine A. Stocker and Robert C. Brady were married on June 17, 1950 and honeymooned at the Broadmoor in Colorado Springs, Colorado. They settled in Franklin Lakes, in 1965, after he was hired by Pfister Chemical, a small specialty chemical manufacturer in Ridgefield. Traveling the world to buy and sell chemicals, Mr. Brady held the position of general manager at Pfister until he was nearly 80, never once calling in sick. Mr. Brady joined the Ridgewood Country Club in 1972, and was a director on the club's board from 1989-92. He was elected to the Franklin Lakes Borough Council in 1981 and served until 1992, and was the police commissioner for much of that time. He coached youth football for four years, and was active at the Most Blessed Sacrament Church. His brother John, who goes by Jack, remembers that his older brother Bob stuck up for him and kept older boys "from beating the hell out of me because I was kind of a smart aleck." In a recent phone conversation, Jack, now 88 and living in Omaha, says his brother had one last piece of advice for him on aging and facing death. "Don't worry about it," Bob told him, "you can't get out of this life alive."

BIRLE--Mary McDaniels, beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister and friend, died at home on October 21 in Village of Golf, Florida of Hodgkin's Lymphoma. She was 77. A native of San Francisco, Mary attended Convent of the Sacred Heart in San Francisco as a young child and, after moving to Atherton, California, Convent of the Sacred Heart in Menlo Park. Mary graduated from The University of California, Berkeley, in 1960, where she was a member of the Kappa Alpha Theta sorority. During her college years, she lived in Paris and studied at the Sorbonne. Mary married her husband, Jim, in Atherton in 1961. After marrying, she and Jim lived in Los Gatos, California with their four children. A devoted and loving mother and wife for more than 53 years, Mary found endless energy in the service of others. She was an active community volunteer and a member of the Junior League of San Jose and the Summit League in Los Gatos. In the early 70s, Mary was recognized by the City of San Jose as Young Woman of the year. In 1977, Mary and her family moved to Greenwich, Connecticut where, with the exception of two wonderful years in Louisville, Kentucky, they lived for more than 30 years. Mary was a member of The Green Fingers Garden Club, The Field Club of Greenwich and The Round Hill Club. She was a longtime board member of the Family Center of Greenwich, and a founding board member of the Cure for Lymphoma Foundation in New York. Mary enjoyed summers at their home in Charlestown, Rhode Island, where she loved to bird watch. She was committed to the preservation of Rhode Island's tidal ponds and wetlands and was a generous supporter of The Nature Conservancy. Since 2004, Mary resided in Village of Golf, Florida with her husband, Jim. In 2013, Mary and Jim made Belvedere, California their second home. Insatiably curious, there was virtually no subject beyond her knowing command. She read voraciously and participated in book clubs throughout her life. Mary had a lifelong passion for the history and culture of Native Americans. She enjoyed a good laugh and would find humor in the most challenging of circumstances. She loved to cook, garden, travel, and play tennis and golf. Most of all, she loved Labrador Retrievers, which she bred and showed for many years. In later years, Mary's great love of music led to her support of the Conservatory of Music at Lynn University in Boca Raton, Florida. Mary inspired all in her presence with an indomitable inner strength, wisdom, dignity, and humility. Her countless acts of generosity, large and small, were always done modestly and quietly. She was much loved and leaves many dear friends, each of whom she cherished. Mary is survived by her husband, Jim; her sons Jim Birle, Jr. (Judy) of Summit, New Jersey, and John Birle (Sue) of Laguna Niguel, California; daughters Anne Veh (George) of Mill Valley, California, and Lexie Clifford (Scott) of Kentfield, California; grandchildren Katie, Melissa, Jimmy, Emily, Peter, Christopher, Matthew, Claire, Megan, Jack and Alex; and her brother, Fr. John Lea McDaniels of Melbourne, Australia. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations in Mary's memory can be made to: Cipotes Honduras Mission, c/o Hope for a Healthier Humanity, PO Box 90547, Staten Island, NY 10309 www.hopeforahealthier humanity.org or Hospice of Palm Beach County/Trustbridge, 5300 East Ave., West Palm Beach, FL., 33407 www.hpbc.com.

BAUMSLAG--Gilbert. Distinguished Professor Emeritus, CCNY, died October 20, after a brief illness. Born in Johannesburg, South Africa, he earned his B.Sc. Honours (Masters) and D.Sc. from the University of Witwatersrand, and his Ph.D. from the University of Manchester. He has given keynote addresses in most conferences in infinite group theory on five continents. He worked with many mathematicians and had more than 30 doctoral students. He played tennis, golf and squash in adulthood but always regretted that he had not followed his first ambition, persuaded not to by his father who thought it frivolous: to play cricket for South Africa a game he followed throughout his lifetime. He first came to the U.S. to teach at Princeton and then moved on to NYU, CUNY, and Rice University before rejoining CUNY at City College in 1973 as Distinguished Professor, a classification limited to 175 and is described by CUNY as an exceptional scholar with an international reputation for scholarly and/or research excellence. He had several academic relationships including ETH in Zurich and the University of Warwick in the U.K. He was the author of more than 150 mathematical papers along with books and monographs. His research was supported for decades and for millions by the National Science Foundation. He was also the Founder and Director of the Center for Algorithms & Interactive Scientific Software (CAISS). He had a great fondness for Nantucket where he spent more than 25 years during school vacations and holidays writing papers, exploring problems on his famous 500lb blackboard installed on the office wall of his his beloved old house on Darling Street. He was enormously fond of many friends on Nantucket with whom he shared a lot of important and silly experiences. One such was playing cricket on Darling Street on a hot August night with four amateurs at the game.There were no winners. There were also no losers. He also loved having lunch at The Opera House where there was no rush, no impatience, and just great food, a great atmosphere, all under the guidance of the renowned Gwen Gaillard. And the always present lure of the Atlantic Ocean was not to be ignored. He loved the land of his birth and was truly happy when the government was transformed by the release of Nelson Mandela. He went to Johannesburg whenever possible for more than 40 years not only to see old friends but also to encourage math projects in the country. He is survived by his wife, Mary Kennedy Baumslag, Len Cohen of South Africa, his childhood partner in many misadventures; his well respected friend, Howard Siegel,M.D. and a lot of beloved friends and colleagues, in New York, on Nantucket and around the world; devoted and accomplished former students, several nieces and nephews, and a few remote blood relatives. No service is planned at this time.

APPEL--Bette Jean, of Bloomfield Hills and Grand Haven, Michigan quietly passed away October 21, 2014. Born in Toledo, Ohio, February 2, 1931, Bette graduated from Bowling Green University. Bette designed children's clothes sold in Saks Fifth Avenue in NYC. Creator, of the "NO SWET" brand, in the Museum of the Fashion Institute of Technology, Bette brought spandex to the forefront with her attractive athletic clothing. She was preceded in death by her son, Jeffrey Alridge. Bette is survived by her daughter, Lisa Guichici of Mohawk, Michigan and grandson, Bill Brookins of Palmer, Alaska. A private Memorial Service is to be held. The family requests memorial contributions be made to your local Human Society. Please visit: pixleyfuneral.com.
