WINTER--Sondra, died in the city that she loved on October 25. A bright light has been dimmed. A strong and clear spirit has been taken. Sondra had the enthusiasm and lust for life of someone many decades younger - with a great sense of humor and timing, and an amazing attitude towards life that probably extended hers by at least a decade. She was always ready to laugh, eat, drink, shop and keep right on having fun. Sondra seemed just as much in love with her beloved partner, Sam Citron, now, as she was when they first met almost 25 years ago. Seeing them together was always like seeing two teenagers in love. Sam's term of endearment for her was "Little Bird", an affectionate pet name that endured through the years. Sondra (a/k/a my fabulous mother) had a remarkable ability to focus only upon a positive outcome for any situation and to navigate her way towards that best possible outcome. In doing so, she would also take the rest of us along with her for the ride and turn us into believers. She was a great cook, a loving and never-overbearing mother, and for 37 years, she was the wife of Jack Winter, whom she married only 10 days after their chance meeting on a Midtown street in 1952. She is survived by her son Gregg and daughter-in-law Barbara, and by her loving partner Sam, with whom she spent her happiest years. From the start, once Gregg married Barbara in 1999, Sondra and Barbara became best friends and had their own unique and special bond. To the very end, her hunger to live and to enjoy even a shrinking number of good hours each day makes it hard to accept that there will no more long phone calls, and no more visits to her apartment where she would hold court in her pink bedroom, with all of us talking and watching TV together and commenting on everyone and everything and laughing, and laughing...

WINDT--Robert. He was born April 27, 1920 and died October 24, 2014. Robert Stanley Windt was bred in Brooklyn. He was a graduate of New Utrecht High School and a life-long baseball fan having seen the Dodgers play at Ebbets Field. He joined the Army for World War II becoming a carburation expert and B-29 Bomber instructor. At the end of the War, he returned home to live with his mother and start a career in public relations working for such companies as CBS, Mountain Valley Water, Dumont Television, Fairchild Publications, Pepsi Cola, Royal Crown Cola, Seagram's and STP Motor Oil. He retired from the profession when he and his two partners sold their ownership of Bebidas, a Spanish language beverage industry magazine. Uncle Bob, as he was known, was a loving, son, brother, uncle, great-uncle and great-great-uncle with a story or three at every family gathering. He will be missed by his family and friends. At the request of the family, donations in his memory can be made to the List Family Fund for Jewish Culture in Memory of Lawrence List at the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue (131 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201). To use Uncle Bob's favorite word - he had a "Fabulous" life. Bobye, Deborah and Mali List.

SMITH-BURKE--Margaret P. Margaret "Trika" Smith-Burke, Born September 6, 1943 in Princeton, NJ, to Albridge C. and Margaret Smith: died peacefully at home in SoHo, NY on October 13, 2014, after a brave battle with colon cancer. A graduate of Miss Fine's School (1961) and Vassar College (1965) Trika received her Ed.D from Rutgers University in 1975. She was formerly married to New York artist Michael Burke. As a professor at NYU from 1975-2007, Trika was passionate about making reading pedagogy more effective. She also worked hard to to assure that young women scholars received the support they needed to become successful literacy researchers. She served as President of the National Reading Conference. At NYU Trika led the way in establishing the Reading Recovery Project, an early intervention program which trained teachers and teacher leaders, working directly with school districts, teachers, and students as well as national and international Reading Recovery programs. She always enjoyed teaching students one-on-one and developing strategies for struggling readers. She adored her long-time friends and loved to make new friends and mentor young people. She delighted in the arts, attending operas at the Met and dance at the Joyce Theater. She enjoyed mindfulness meditation and quiet time in nature. She is survived by her sister and brother-in-law, Cary and Gary Hart, her nieces Elissa, Katherine and Laura and their families and many devoted extended family members, friends and students. Her generous spirit and zest for life will be sorely missed. Donations in her memory may be made to The Reading Recovery Project of NYU, 239 Greene St, New York,NY 10003 or the Margaret "Trika" Smith-Burke Scholarship Fund, c/o Community Foundation of the Virginias, POBox 4127, Bluefield, WV 24701

SLAUGHTER--Tom. Everybody at The New 42nd Street and The New Victory Theater is deeply saddened and will desperately miss our beloved master artist and dear friend Tom Slaughter. Tom's spirited images and inventive graphics provided instant iconic identity to The New Victory for the past 10 years. We adored him for his rock steady opinions, always encouraging Lauren, Alexis and Noah to strive for bold and original work during their years of collaboration with Tom. His brilliant artistry, and his deep understanding of the New Vic's mission, informs all that we present to the public about the Theater's programs. Tom was defined, in great measure, by his uniquely complex artistic soul coupled with a surprisingly sweet loving nature. We send our love to Nell, Hannah and Jimmy and all Tom's dear family and friends. Cora Cahan, President Fiona Howe Rudin, Chairman The New 42nd Street

SLAUGHTER--Thomas R. The Trustees and Staff of The Studio Museum in Harlem mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend and longtime supporter, artist Thomas R. Slaughter. We are forever grateful for Tom's generosity, both personally and as a director of the Horace W. Goldsmith Foundation. His visionary support over the past decade allowed the museum to broaden and deepen our commitment to presenting art by artists of African descent. His incomparable intellect, passion, artistic vision and wit will be deeply missed. We extend our condolences to his family. Raymond J. McGuire, Chairman Thelma Golden, Director

SLAUGHTER--Thomas Robert, an artist, designer, and illustrator living and working in New York City, died October 24, 2014 from brain cancer. He was 59. Discovered by Henry Geldzahler in the 1980s, Slaughter had more than 30 solo exhibitions in New York, Los Angeles, Miami, Vancouver, Germany and Japan. He worked as a printmaker in collaboration with Durham Press for 25 years, and his editions are included in the permanent collections of MoMA and the Whitney Museum of American Art. He illustrated twelve children's books, including "Boat Works," "Do You Know Which Ones will Grow? " - a 2011 Notable American Library Association book of the year - and collaborations with Marthe Jocelyn such as "ABC x 3," "Same Same," and "123." These books have been translated into six languages. Slaughter also worked for the last ten seasons as the Art Director for the New Victory Theater. As a designer, he created everything from t-shirts to skateboard decks, beach towels as well as a line of wallpaper for Cavern Home. Slaughter served on the board of directors of MoMA PS1, the Public Theater, and the Horace W. Goldsmith Foundation. As a director of the Goldsmith Foundation, Slaughter was instrumental in the Foundation's support of numerous art and theater organizations including The Drawing Center, Naked Angels, and the Studio Museum in Harlem. Slaughter will be remembered as a consummate New Yorker, a vivid institution in his SoHo community. He most enjoyed spending time with his daughters at his second home in Noyac, Long Island. He is survived by his mother Virginia Slaughter, his daughter Nell Jocelyn, his daughter and son-in-law Hannah Jocelyn and Jimmy Mezei, brothers Bill, Chuck and Jamie Slaughter, as well as eight nephews and nieces and one great nephew. Services will be held Monday, November 3, 2014 at 11am at the New Victory Theater.

ROSENTHAL--Stuart, on October 25, 2014. Beloved husband of June. Devoted father of Steven, Peter and Jill. Cherished grandfather of Jacob and Daniel. Dear brother-in-law of Doris Perch and uncle of Allyson Perch and Jennifer Lutz. Service Monday, October 27, at Gutterman's in Woodbury, NY at 1pm.

PRYOR--Samuel. Board and staff of the Women's eNews non-profit news service mourn the October 17 passing of founding board member Samuel F. Pryor, III, an unwavering advocate for women's rights with a generous heart.

LENVIN--Gail Elizabeth, 63, loving mother and sister. Died October 25 in Los Angeles. Gail lived a life devoted to family and friends, achieving excellence in everything she did personally and professionally. Survived by her daughter Amanda, son David (Taylor) and brother Jeffrey (Susan) Stern. Services were held October 26. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to Simms/Mann UCLA Center for Integrative Oncology, 200 UCLA Medical Plaza, Suite 502, Los Angeles, CA 90095.

KESSLER--Irving Jerome, 88, died on October 25, 2014 after an extended battle with Alzheimer's Disease. He was a loving father, grandfather and friend. Jerry, as he was known to his friends, had a distinguished career in the fine jewelry industry, having held executive positions at Saks Fifth Avenue, Fred Joaillier and Jean Lassale. He was a veteran of the US Army and received an honorable discharge. He is survived by his four children, Melissa Drazka, Carolyn Thow, Craig Bihari, and Karon Bihari, and his four grandchildren Ashley Drazka, Amanda Drazka, Dylan Drazka and Alexandra Thow.

KEENAN--Terry, on October 23, 2014. It is with tremendous sorrow that we report the passing, due to a massive cerebral hemorrhage, of a wonderful mother, wife, sister, and pioneering financial journalist. Terry was a trailblazer who credited much of her success to her beloved mother's emphasis on education, which led her to Holy Names Academy in Albany, NY, and a math scholarship to Johns Hopkins University. After Johns Hopkins, she produced the iconic PBS show "Wall Street Week" with Louis Rukeyser; Rukeyser, recognizing her very rare combination of talents a flair for words coupled with an amazing facility with numbers - became a mentor. Soon she was picked up by CNN's Moneyline, hosted by another longtime mentor, Lou Dobbs. Terry reported on the 1987 stock market crash, and was the first journalist to report live from the New York Stock Exchange. She went on to have various anchor stints at CNBC and Fox News. She left Fox to spend more cherished time with her son, Benjamin Kass, and husband, Ron Kass. Throughout her post-TV career, she never missed a deadline for her weekly New York Post financial column. Aside from her son Benjamin and husband Ron, Terry leaves behind her two sisters, Joellen Gardner and Linda Keenan, as well as many nieces and nephews. FRYE--Clayton Wesley, Jr.,died on October 19, 2014. The cause was complications from congestive heart failure. Mr. Frye was the senior associate of Laurance S. Rockefeller for 31 years until Mr. Rockefeller's death in 2004, and then served as executor of his estate, along with continuing with other business and investment interests. Mr. Frye was born in Los Angeles, CA, on May 18, 1930, the son of Clayton W. Frye, Sr, who was the Amateur Middleweight Boxing Champion in 1925, a boxing coach and instructor at Stanford University, and who later served as Secretary of the California State Athletic Commission, and Virginia Briggs Frye. Neither of his parents attended college. Mr. Frye was born in very modest circumstances and attended nine different public schools in California. He worked through high school and was three-sport letterman. After high school he trained briefly to become a professional boxer and then served on active duty as an airman in the U.S. Naval Reserve. He attended Los Angeles City College for two years before transferring to Stanford University where he worked his way through school while competing in athletics. He graduated from Stanford in 1953, and Stanford University Graduate School of Business in 1959. Prior to joining Mr. Rockefeller in New York City in 1973, Mr. Frye co-founded several businesses in California and Texas. He was president and CEO of Palo Alto-based Sutter Hill Development Company, co-founder of Homesmith, Inc., and a general partner and co-founder of San Antonio-based Johnson and Frye Investment Company. For three decades, Mr. Frye worked side by side with Mr. Rockefeller and was responsible for overseeing his diverse business, resort, real estate and investment interests and assisting with his philanthropic programs. In his role with Mr. Rockefeller and the Rockefeller Family, Mr. Frye held leadership positions in Rockresorts, Inc., Rockefeller Center Inc., Rockefeller & Associates Realty, which he founded, and Pacific Properties Services, the manager and operator of Embarcadero Center in San Francisco, of which David Rockefeller was a major partner. Mr. Frye was also a director of Colonial Williamsburg Foundation; a trustee of the Laurance S. Rockefeller Fund and Historic Hudson Valley; and chairman of Jackson Hole Preserve and of the Woodstock Foundation and Woodstock Resort Corporation. Among Mr. Frye's many outside affiliations were directorships of the Times Mirror Company in Los Angeles, California's 270,000-acre Tejon Ranch Company, the King Ranch of Texas and the White House Historical Association. He also served as an overseer of the Hoover Institution at Stanford University. Mr. Frye is survived by a daughter, Diane Frye Tanner, and her husband, Brooks Tanner of New York City; a brother, Craig Frye of Los Angeles, three granddaughters: Carolyn M. Tanner, and Charlotte and Sydney Halloran; and numerous beloved nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his older daughter, Carolyn Frye Halloran, in 2000; by his by his sister, Joan Frye Clark in 2008; and by his wife of 52 years, Dorothy Rumsfeld Frye, in 2009. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center or the Laurance S. Rockefeller Preserve in Jackson Hole, Wyoming. MSKCC donations will be directed to lung and brain cancer research and should be addressed to: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 633 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10017 with "Memory of Clayton W. Frye, Jr." in the memo line. Gifts to the LSR Preserve should be made payable to Jackson Hole Preserve, Inc., with "LSR Preserve Fund" in the memo line and mailed to: Jackson Hole Preserve, Inc., P.O. Box 489, Woodstock, VT 05091.

Fearless traveler, feisty friend, independent, successful business woman and a generous benefactor to many, Pam was able to find humor in all things. She was predeceased by her sister Marie Driscoll and brother Robert Cifu. She is survived by nieces Palma and Marisa Driscoll, nephew Adam Cifu and sister-in-law, Anne Cifu. The family will be celebrating Palma's life, at home, Wednesday and Thursday, October 29 and 30, 2pm-4pm and 6pm-8pm. ALLISON--Thomas. Born in Columbus, Ohio, Tom died in New York City on October 17th at the age of 67. A designer in the Art Department of People Magazine for many years, Tom was also an artist, photographer, audiophile, Formula One enthusiast and avid reader of history. But his greatest talent was for happiness. Seven years ago he received a double lung transplant and his second life began. Whether he was snorkeling at the Great Barrier Reef, making Hungarian Goulash in the depths of winter, or doing the Times crossword at the local cafe, he relished every moment of the extra years he had been given. He will be missed terribly by all those whose lives he illuminated, especially his wife, Barbara, his sisters, Jane Halleck and Elizabeth Feinson, and a multitude of friends. He was an irreplaceable man. A memorial gathering will be held but has not yet been scheduled.

HOOGENBOOM--Ari, historian, died October 25 of complications from mesothelioma. He was 86. He was born in Richmond Hill, Queens, on November 28, 1927. He attended public schools, graduated from John Adams High School in 1945, then attended Atlantic Union College, graduating in 1949. There, he met Olive Youngberg, and they married August 28, 1949. Ari received his MA (1951) and his PhD (1958) from Columbia University. He was an instructor and assistant professor at the University of Texas at El Paso (1956-58), an instructor, assistant professor, associate professor and full professor at Penn State (1958-68), and a full professor at Brooklyn College (1968-98), where he was chairman of the history department from 1968-74. He was also a Guggenheim fellow (1965-66) and the visiting George Bancroft professor of American history at the University of Gottingen, Germany (1991-92). Ari had a distinguished publishing career. He made a splash in 1960 with a tongue-in-cheek article in the Wisconsin Magazine of History positing that scholars had overlooked the true cause of the Civil War: the burgeoning popularity of beards, which had made Northerners and Southerners alike more aggressive. His first book was "Outlawing the Spoils: A History of the Civil Service Reform Movement, 1865-1883" (1961). He co-authored "The Enterprising Colonials: Society on the Eve of the Revolution (with William S. Sachs, 1965), "A History of the ICC: From Panacea to Palliative" (with Olive Hoogenboom, 1976) and "A History of Pennsylvania" (with Phillip S. Klein, 1973). He wrote two defining books on Rutherford B. Hayes: "The Presidency of Rutherford B. Hayes" (1988) and "Rutherford B. Hayes: Warrior and President" (1995; Ohioana Book Award, 1996). He continued to be a productive scholar after his retirement, publishing "Rutherford B. Hayes: One of the Good Colonels" (1999) and "Gustavus Vasa Fox of the Union Navy: A Biography" (2008). In the past few years, he has worked with his wife, Olive, on her book, "Washington Women: The Woodbury Sisters," giving her the same assistance that she had given him on a number of his books. They finished revisions shortly before his death. He is survived by his wife, Olive; his children, Lynn, Ari Jr. and Jan; his granddaughters, Amelia, Charlotte, and Calliope, and countless friends. His sister, Clara, predeceased him. A memorial service will be held November 8 at 2pm at the First Unitarian Church, 116 Pierrepont St., Brooklyn, where he was a member of the choir for over 30 years. Wake Service and Visiting Hours Tuesday, October 28, 6-9pm at Raccuglia & Son Funeral Home Inc., 321-323 Court Street, Brooklyn. 718-855-7737.

CLARK--Audrey Iselin, September 25, 1920 - October 26, 2014. The third and youngest child of Oliver Iselin and Beatrice Iselin, died peacefully in Jupiter Island, FL, with family members at her bedside. Beloved mother and grandmother, she went to be with her Lord Jesus Christ, after requesting the solitude she desired in the latter period of her life. She was predeceased by her husband of 59 years, Reed "Fritz" Clark, President of Czarnikow Rionda Company. Born in Westbury, NY, she graduated from Green Vale School (New York), Foxcroft School (Virginia), and attended The Juilliard School (New York). She spent most of her adult life in Old Brookville, NY and Jupiter Island, FL. She was devoted to her immediate and extended family. In her younger years, she was an avid skier and sportswoman. In her latter years she cared deeply about women's Bible classes in Long Island and Florida. She had a gift of hospitality for Christian ministries, supporting several, especially those focusing on youth programs. She was considered by all who knew her to be loving, humble, and wise. She is survived by her daughter, Sandra Clark Moore, wife of The Rev. Dr. Peter C. Moore; their children Jennifer Clark Moore, Catharine Mackay Norris, and David Clark Moore; her son, Peter Reed Clark, husband to Alison Moore Clark; their children William Reed Clark and Eileen Clark Wilder; and nine great-grandchildren. She requested that any gifts or remembrances be made in her name to Trinity School for Ministry, 311 Eleventh St., Ambridge, PA 15003; or FOCUS (Fellowship of Christians in Universities & Schools), P.O. Box 1027, New Canaan, CT 06840. Memorial Services will be held at Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter Island, FL and at St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, NY. Dates and times to be announced.

BROOKS--Robert Evan, passed away on October 24, at the age of 55 after a long and valiant struggle with a blood disease. He was the beloved son of Diane Hallenbeck and the late Gilbert Brooks. He was the loving husband of Kathy Kelrick Brooks and the devoted father of Hayley and Rachel Brooks whom he adored. Robert "Beau" is survived by his brother Stephen Brooks (Sally) and his sister Lindsay Brooks Sturman (Howard), and Shawn Hallenbeck-Hardin (Bill). Memorial service will be held in Florida on Sunday, November 2 at Temple Solel in Hollywood, FL at 1pm. The family will be receiving friends at the Brooks home, 2861 Birkdale Drive in Weston, FL following the service and on Monday evening.

Bayer--Alan, on October 26, 2014 from multiple myeloma, surrounded by his loving family, beloved wife Naomi, cherished children Avi Bayer and Sarah Brown, and granddaughters Sadie and Josephine. Also survived by his mother, Dolores Bayer and brother, Michael Bayer. Lifelong commitment to tikkun olam--Jewish Federation of San Antonio, ADL, CLAL, UJA Federation. Touched the lives of countless friends. Donations--Doctors Without Borders, Mazon, Bet Am Shalom, Enterprise Community Partners, Inc.
ANOUSSI--Rina. We will remember you forever. Deepest condolences to Takis and Doron. Love, Sally, Elliott and Jack

ANOUSSI--Rina. Brooklyn Academy of Music mourns the magnificent Rina - full of life, passionate, worldly. Travel with Rina was a joyous adventure. Knowing Rina was a joyous adventure. Sending a message of love to Takis and Doron. Karen Brooks Hopkins, Joseph Melillo, Alan Fishman, Adam Max & Bill Campbell

ANOUSSI--Rina, 67, passed away peacefully in her Manhattan home with her husband, Takis and son, Doron Tal at her side. Born in Greece and having lived abroad, Rina used her knowledge and passion for travel to establish The Travel Business 30 years ago. Her love of people and dedication to her clients made her an outstanding professional. We will miss her grace, charm and sense of style. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11217.

ALAGAPPAN--Alagappa, A former United Nations official and founder of the Hindu Temple movement in North America, died in New Hyde Park, New York on Friday, October 24. He was 89 years old. Born in Kanadukathan, Tamil Nadu, India, Alagappan held five academic and professional degrees from institutions across the world. He received his B.A. and M.A. from Presidency College in Chennai, India and his M.Sc. from the London School of Economics. He later earned his LL.B. and was called to the Bar at the Middle Temple in London. Finally, he earned his Ph.D. in International Relations from New York University. While studying in London, Alagappan also worked as a journalist for the British Broadcasting Corporation, during which time he interviewed the Pope. Upon returning to India, he declined a bank job to work as a journalist for the Hindu Newspaper. He then applied to work at the United Nations, whose mission to promote world peace and socioeconomic equality resonated deeply with him. As a career official with the United Nations, first in Bangkok and then in New York, Alagappan served as Chief of the Water Resources Section and later Deputy Director of the Natural Resources and Energy Division. He was also elected Chairman of the staff of ten thousand employees of the United Nations. In his thirty years of service to the United Nations, Alagappan valued the opportunity to travel, visiting more than 90 countries during his career. After leaving the United Nations, Alagappan pursued a life of social service inspired by his professional career and his personal devotion to Hinduism. He maintained the deep conviction that faith heals and inspires. As Founder of the Hindu Temple Society of North America, he sought to create sacred spaces for worshippers visiting and living in the United States. In 1977, he established the Maha Vallabha Ganapati Temple in Flushing, New York. This granite stone temple was the first authentic Hindu Temple in North America with classical Indian architecture. Alagappan proposed that a large ecumenical icon at the temple's entrance display symbols of various worldwide religions. He said, "Just as all streams lead to the same greater body of water, and all mountain trails to the same summit, so do all world religions lead to the same God." Alagappan's most recent projects include the establishment of Arupadai Veedu, a single temple complex that houses replicas of six pilgrimage sites in an urban neighborhood in Chennai, making it accessible to people of all socioeconomic backgrounds. He also established the Saraswati Temple devoted to the transmission of knowledge and education. Alagappan maintained that education was the greatest gift parents could give their children. He credited his mother with instilling in him this principle, which guided his life and the lives of his children. His wife Visalakshi Alagappan said, "When I think of my husband, I think of Mahatma Gandhi's quotation: 'My life is my message.' Alagappan is survived by his beloved wife of 59 years, four children, Kumar, Arun, Vairam and Meena, and seven granddaughters, Lakshmi, Jyothi, Visala, Serena, Kaya, Uma and Vimala. Witty, kind, cheerful, dynamic, and creative, Dr. Alagappa Alagappan will be dearly missed by his family and friends. All who knew him were inspired by his compassion, magnetic morality, pragmatic spirit, and unwavering determination. Dr. Alagappa Alagappan's final words remind us of how he lived his life and urged others to live theirs. They are a testament to his avid pursuit of education, his loyalty to the United Nations, his decades-long commitment to temple projects, his dedication to social service, and his profound, pure love for his family. These words will serve as his legacy and epitaph: "I'm trying my best."
MELNICK--Gisele. 10/27/1935 - 05/02/2006. The world is diminished without her.
GREEN--Charlotte & Moishe Miss you SO much. Wish you were here. "Love & Kisses"
BENSLEY--Norman C. March 27, 1943 - October 28, 2013 Beloved brother. Guardian angel. Frannie

WILLIAMS--Douglas. We at Madison Square Boys & Girls Club are deeply saddened to learn of the passing of Doug Williams. A tireless advocate for our cause, Doug was a member of our Board of Trustees for the past 66 years, which is more than half of our 130 year existence. He helped empower thousands of underprivileged youth here in New York City and our deepest sympathies go out to his family and friends. He will be missed.

SLAUGHTER--Tom. Everybody at The New 42nd Street and The New Victory Theater is deeply saddened and will desperately miss our beloved master artist and dear friend Tom Slaughter. Tom's spirited images and inventive graphics provided instant iconic identity to The New Victory for the past 10 years. We adored him for his rock steady opinions, always encouraging Lauren, Alexis and Noah to strive for bold and original work during their years of collaboration with Tom. His brilliant artistry, and his deep understanding of the New Vic's mission, informs all that we present to the public about the Theater's programs. Tom was defined, in great measure, by his uniquely complex artistic soul coupled with a surprisingly sweet loving nature. We send our love to Nell, Hannah and Jimmy and all Tom's dear family and friends. Cora Cahan, President Fiona Howe Rudin, Chairman The New 42nd Street

SLAUGHTER--Thomas Robert. The Juilliard community mourns the loss of artist, designer, and illustrator Thomas Robert Slaughter. He was a generous supporter of Juilliard through the Horace W. Goldsmith Foundation, which helped fund Juilliard's Novick Career Advancement Grants in Vocal Arts. These grants assist newly graduated singers as they embark on their careers and have allowed Juilliard's most promising singers to continue their studies after graduation by subsidizing further study and professional expenses. Our condolences go to Thomas's family. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President Brian Zeger, Artistic Director, Marcus Institute for Vocal Arts
SLAUGHTER--Tom. So smart, so funny, so generous. I will miss you, my friend. Steve Novick

SLAUGHTER--Thomas R. The Trustees and Staff of The Studio Museum in Harlem mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend and longtime supporter, artist Thomas R. Slaughter. We are forever grateful for Tom's generosity, both personally and as a director of the Horace W. Goldsmith Foundation. His visionary support over the past decade allowed the museum to broaden and deepen our commitment to presenting art by artists of African descent. His incomparable intellect, passion, artistic vision and wit will be deeply missed. We extend our condolences to his family. Raymond J. McGuire, Chairman Thelma Golden, Director

SLAUGHTER--Tom. The Miller Family is deeply saddened by the loss of an incredible person whose heart and soul was always larger than the room in which he stood or sat. His love for children, friends and his family will be sorely missed. The art world has lost a true talent that will forever be missed and remembered. Our deepest condolences to the entire Slaughter family. May Tom's memory be for a blessing. With Our Love, The Miller Family, Keith, Stacy, Julian and Olivia.

SLAUGHTER--Tom. The Board of Trustees, artists, and staff of The Public Theater mourn the passing of our dear friend and former Trustee, Tom Slaughter. Tom displayed an intense passion for theater and belief in The Public's mission as well as for the sustainability of the organization he loved. Through his own work as an artist and as a board member of the Horace W. Goldsmith Foundation, his contribution to New York City and its many arts and cultural organizations is continuing, innovative and renowned. We offer our deepest sympathies to Tom's family and friends. Oskar Eustis, Artistic Director; Patrick Willingham, Executive Director; Arielle Tepper Madover, Board Chair
PHILIPS--Sylvia, 85, of Sarasota. Leaves husband Eliot, children Walter, Janet, Ruth. Flutist, teacher. Exuberant lover of life and family.

PEARL--Ruth. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Ruth Pearl. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved family. Stuart Albrecht, President Robert D. Lang, Secretary

O'CONNELL--Madeline Louise, died at her home in Sarasota, FL on October 25, 2014. She was born on March 15, 1932 in Bronx, NY. Madeline graduated from The College of New Rochelle. She retired as the head of the fiduciary accounting department at the New York firm of Davis Polk & Wardell, where she was widely respected as an accomplished professional by the lawyers and clients who worked with her. Madeline is survived by a multitude of cousins and a legion of friends. Madeline's love of family was boundless just as her passion for flying her plane was endless. Jennings Funeral Home in Sarasota, FL has been entrusted with the services. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Salesian Missions - (914-633-8344), 2 Lefevre Ln., New Rochelle 10801-5710, info@salesianmissions.org. In addition to the Sarasota services a future Memorial Service will be held at The College of New Rochelle in New York. Funeral Mass will be 9:30am Thursday at Incarnation Catholic Church in Sarasota, FL.

LENVIN--Gail Elizabeth. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Gail Lenvin, beloved sister of Jeffrey Stern. We extend our deepest condolences to Gail's children, Amanda and David (Taylor); her brother and sister-in-law, Jeffrey and Susan Stern, esteemed leaders in our community; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

WOLF--Charles R.,a security analyst at Needham and Company, died on October 28, 2014, of lung cancer. Born in Mason City, Iowa, Charlie shed any evidence of his midwestern roots as soon as he arrived at Harvard, where he earned an AB, MBA and DBA. A brilliant intellect with an irresistible smile and a twinkle in his eye, he shared his gifts by educating two generations of Wall Street at the Columbia Business School, rising from assistant professor in 1966 to professor. His articles on financial economics and decision theory were published in major academic journals and he was co-author of "The Role of Private Placements in Corporate Finance," published by the Harvard University Press. On a leave from Columbia, intending to incorporate the practical tools of securities analysis into a course, he became an analyst at CS First Boston in 1984, covering the personal computer industry. A Wall Street Journal "Heard on the Street Column" in 1986 featured him as the rookie analyst from academia who made good. Between 1988 and 1993, he was elected to Institutional Investor's prestigious "All American Research Team" in the personal computer industry category. His signature publication, Wolf Bytes, has provided in-depth analysis of significant industry issues for years. Charlie, nicknamed "The Wolfman," brought a level of professionalism and rigor that raised the bar in every Research Department he inhabited, including a stint at UBS. His quests for data, and the resulting ten-year models, were legendary. When he completed an opus, he was as giddy as a kid. When he discovered flawed data, his colleagues heard his growl. He is survived by his devoted wife of almost 23 years, Margot; a brother Ronald; a step-daughter Alexandra (Dr. Hao Vuong); a step-son, Adam Sitkoff; and a grandson Gavin Sitkoff-Vuong. Services to be held Friday, October 31, at 11:30am, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue. Those who wish may donate to Weill Cornell Medical College in care of Dr. Ronald Scheff's research fund.

SLAUGHTER--Tom. Everybody at The New 42nd Street and The New Victory Theater is deeply saddened and will desperately miss our beloved master artist and dear friend Tom Slaughter. Tom's spirited images and inventive graphics provided instant iconic identity to The New Victory for the past 10 years. We adored him for his rock steady opinions, always encouraging Lauren, Alexis and Noah to strive for bold and original work during their years of collaboration with Tom. His brilliant artistry, and his deep understanding of the New Vic's mission, informs all that we present to the public about the Theater's programs. Tom was defined, in great measure, by his uniquely complex artistic soul coupled with a surprisingly sweet loving nature. We send our love to Nell, Hannah and Jimmy and all Tom's dear family and friends. Cora Cahan, President Fiona Howe Rudin, Chairman The New 42nd Street

SLAUGHTER--Tom. The Miller Family is deeply saddened by the loss of an incredible person whose heart and soul was always larger than the room in which he stood or sat. His love for children, friends and his family will be sorely missed. The art world has lost a true talent that will forever be missed and remembered. Our deepest condolences to the entire Slaughter family. May Tom's memory be for a blessing. With Our Love, The Miller Family, Keith, Stacy, Julian and Olivia.

SLAUGHTER--Thomas Robert, is remembered by MoMA PS1 and The Museum of Modern Art as a devoted member of the MoMA PS1 Board of Directors since 2003, a wonderful artist celebrated by numerous solo exhibitions, illustrator of imaginative children's books, and dear friend. He passed away on October 24, 2014 at the age of 59 while surrounded by his loving family. His tireless efforts to ensure the vibrancy of the art community in New York City while simultaneously creating a renowned body of his own work remain unmatched. His imprint and the mark of his supportive legacy will continue to be felt at MoMA PS1 where Slaughter was instrumental in leading the institution. Slaughter also served on the board of directors of the Public Theater, and was a director at the Horace W. Goldsmith Foundation through which he generously supported organizations such as The Drawing Center, Naked Angels, and the Studio Museum in Harlem, as well as MoMA PS1 and MoMA. Slaughter will be remembered for his tenacity, energy and great wit, and as a driving force in his SoHo community. He is survived by his mother Virginia Slaughter, his daughter Nell Jocelyn, his daughter and son-in-law Hannah Jocelyn and Jimmy Mezei, brothers Bill, Chuck and Jamie Slaughter, as well as eight nephews and nieces and one great nephew. We will miss Tom dearly and send our deepest sympathies to his family. Services will be held Monday, November 3, 2014 at 11am at the New Victory Theater. The Board of Directors, MoMA PS1

SLAUGHTER--Thomas. Mannes College The New School for Music mourns the loss of our dear friend Thomas Slaughter. As a Director of The Horace Goldsmith Foundation, he established initiatives at The New School including support for facilities, housing, scholarships, and programming. RUSSO--Alvin A. At approximately 6am on Wednesday morning, October 22nd, Alvin A. Russo passed away at home with his loving wife at his side. He had been battling bone cancer since last spring and endured a leg amputation in hopes of recovery when his heart gave out. Born on September 21st, 1927 in Brooklyn, NY, he grew up in a classic New York City brownstone on 64th street in the Hell's Kitchen area where Lincoln Center now stands. Very often, he would fondly recall happy times as a child spent fishing, playing and exploring Central Park. In 1945 at the age of 18, he enlisted in the United States Navy and served his country honorably and faithfully till his discharge in 1952. He then attended the Rhodes Preparatory School at 11 East 54th Street before going on to study mechanical engineering at the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, NJ. He was a proud member of the varsity squash and chess teams as a student there. From 1954 to 1964, he worked in the Brooklyn Navy Yards helping in the construction of numerous Navy vessels. He then accepted a position with the New York City Board of Education as a master machinist, where he worked until his retirement in 1984 at the age of 57. Then, he began his second career as an investor, spending good portions of each day working on his portfolio and looking for companies he believed in. It was an endeavor he enjoyed passionately till his last days. He also enjoyed playing poker and spending time with his beautiful wife of 60 years, Erna. He would often declare how blessed he was to have her. They split their time between homes in Tom's River, NJ and Melbourne, FL since 1994. His legacy lives on through his loving wife, Erna, a son Joseph and four beautiful grandchildren, Ariana, Mason, Colton and Hope. Memorial services will be held at a later date. Friends and family will be notified as soon as plans are in place.

ALAGAPPAN--Alagappa, A former United Nations official and founder of the Hindu Temple movement in North America, died in New Hyde Park, New York on Friday, October 24. He was 89 years old. Born in Kanadukathan, Tamil Nadu, India, Alagappan held five academic and professional degrees from institutions across the world. He received his B.A. and M.A. from Presidency College in Chennai, India and his M.Sc. from the London School of Economics. He later earned his LL.B. and was called to the Bar at the Middle Temple in London. Finally, he earned his Ph.D. in International Relations from New York University. While studying in London, Alagappan also worked as a journalist for the British Broadcasting Corporation, during which time he interviewed the Pope. Upon returning to India, he declined a bank job to work as a journalist for the Hindu Newspaper. He then applied to work at the United Nations, whose mission to promote world peace and socioeconomic equality resonated deeply with him. As a career official with the United Nations, first in Bangkok and then in New York, Alagappan served as Chief of the Water Resources Section and later Deputy Director of the Natural Resources and Energy Division. He was also elected Chairman of the staff of ten thousand employees of the United Nations. In his thirty years of service to the United Nations, Alagappan valued the opportunity to travel, visiting more than 90 countries during his career. After leaving the United Nations, Alagappan pursued a life of social service inspired by his professional career and his personal devotion to Hinduism. He maintained the deep conviction that faith heals and inspires. As Founder of the Hindu Temple Society of North America, he sought to create sacred spaces for worshippers visiting and living in the United States. In 1977, he established the Maha Vallabha Ganapati Temple in Flushing, New York. This granite stone temple was the first authentic Hindu Temple in North America with classical Indian architecture. Alagappan proposed that a large ecumenical icon at the temple's entrance display symbols of various worldwide religions. He said, "Just as all streams lead to the same greater body of water, and all mountain trails to the same summit, so do all world religions lead to the same God." Alagappan's most recent projects include the establishment of Arupadai Veedu, a single temple complex that houses replicas of six pilgrimage sites in an urban neighborhood in Chennai, making it accessible to people of all socioeconomic backgrounds. He also established the Saraswati Temple devoted to the transmission of knowledge and education. Alagappan maintained that education was the greatest gift parents could give their children. He credited his mother with instilling in him this principle, which guided his life and the lives of his children. His wife Visalakshi Alagappan said, "When I think of my husband, I think of Mahatma Gandhi's quotation: 'My life is my message.' Alagappan is survived by his beloved wife of 59 years, four children, Kumar, Arun, Vairam and Meena, and seven granddaughters, Lakshmi, Jyothi, Visala, Serena, Kaya, Uma and Vimala. Witty, kind, cheerful, dynamic, and creative, Dr. Alagappa Alagappan will be dearly missed by his family and friends. All who knew him were inspired by his compassion, magnetic morality, pragmatic spirit, and unwavering determination. Dr. Alagappa Alagappan's final words remind us of how he lived his life and urged others to live theirs. They are a testament to his avid pursuit of education, his loyalty to the United Nations, his decades-long commitment to temple projects, his dedication to social service, and his profound, pure love for his family. These words will serve as his legacy and epitaph: "I'm trying my best."

WOLF--Charles R.,a security analyst at Needham and Company, died on October 28, 2014, of lung cancer. Born in Mason City, Iowa, Charlie shed any evidence of his midwestern roots as soon as he arrived at Harvard, where he earned an AB, MBA and DBA. A brilliant intellect with an irresistible smile and a twinkle in his eye, he shared his gifts by educating two generations of Wall Street at the Columbia Business School, rising from assistant professor in 1966 to professor. His articles on financial economics and decision theory were published in major academic journals and he was co-author of "The Role of Private Placements in Corporate Finance," published by the Harvard University Press. On a leave from Columbia, intending to incorporate the practical tools of securities analysis into a course, he became an analyst at CS First Boston in 1984, covering the personal computer industry. A Wall Street Journal "Heard on the Street Column" in 1986 featured him as the rookie analyst from academia who made good. Between 1988 and 1993, he was elected to Institutional Investor's prestigious "All American Research Team" in the personal computer industry category. His signature publication, Wolf Bytes, has provided in-depth analysis of significant industry issues for years. Charlie, nicknamed "The Wolfman," brought a level of professionalism and rigor that raised the bar in every Research Department he inhabited, including a stint at UBS. His quests for data, and the resulting ten-year models, were legendary. When he completed an opus, he was as giddy as a kid. When he discovered flawed data, his colleagues heard his growl. He is survived by his devoted wife of almost 23 years, Margot; a brother Ronald; a step-daughter Alexandra (Dr. Hao Vuong); a step-son, Adam Sitkoff; and a grandson Gavin Sitkoff-Vuong. Services to be held Friday, October 31, at 11:30am, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue. Those who wish may donate to Weill Cornell Medical College in care of Dr. Ronald Scheff's research fund.

SNYDER--Jeanne, on October 28, 2014. Survived by her stepdaughters Susan Snyder and Eileen Fonte, and grandchildren Toni Ann, Nicole and Dominick Fonte. Service Thursday, October 30, 2014, 10 am, at The Riverdale Temple, 4545 Independence Ave, Riverdale.

SLAUGHTER--Tom. The Dean, Trustees, staff, faculty and students of the New York Studio School mourn the passing of Tom Slaughter, a special person and unique artist. A long-term advocate of the School's program through the Horace W. Goldsmith Foundation, his support was always deeply appreciated. Tom's commitment to the development of young artists at the Studio School was generous in both spirit and vision. We extend our deepest condolences to his family.

SLAUGHTER--Tom. Artist Tom Slaughter was a most beloved friend of the Creative Time family. Fiercely curious, smart, kind and generous, his inspiration will live on in our hearts and in our work. We will forever cherish his vibrant memory, and we send our deepest condolences to his beautiful family, who he loved so dearly.

ROSCH--Maurice Charles, was born on October 11, 1915 in NYC and grew up in Yonkers. He was predeceased by his parents Samuel and May Rosch, his sister Gertrude Linett, and his daughter in law Alice Lepie. He is survived by Bea Rosch, his wife of 68 years; his brother Paul Rosch MD; sons Elliott Rosch MD and Joel Rosch Ph.D his wife Carol Vatz; grandchildren Jacob Rosch, Anna Rosch and husband Isaac Wolf; and great granddaughter Alice Rosch. Maurice graduated from New York University and from the Harvard Business School. A WWII veteran, Maurice served as a lieutenant in three campaigns, received a medal for bravery at Monte Cassino and was awarded three Purple Hearts. Prior to his military service he was a three time tennis champion of Westchester County. A successful business man, he started and ran a manufacturing company and later had a successful career on Wall Street where he advised private clients, mutual funds, and charitable organizations. He was an accomplished violinist, played competitive tennis well into his 80's, and was an active member of the Lincoln Park Jewish Center. He was a devoted husband, loving father and grandfather who will be missed, especially by his extended family including his many nieces and nephews, cousins, and his many friends. The way Maurice lived his life continues to be an inspiration to all who knew him.
NEWMAN--Terrie Lynne. October 15, a bright star joined heaven. She will be missed by husband Fred Kerstein, brother Bruce and sister Geraldine. Visit legacy.com

MILNER--Sheila. A devoted wife of Saladin Bucak; daughter of Sheila Casey and Michael J. Milner; sister of Michel Milner; and a caring aunt of Paula. Sheila was a conscientious, honest; courageous and outspoken person. She was a dedicated teacher who worked for about 40 years in the teaching profession. She was so passionate for the well being of humanity and justice. She was a very dedicated daughter, who took care of her mother for about 30 years. Her mother was suffering from Alzheimer's Disease, which she herself suffered with for about 14 years. Sheila always had a smile and a very positive outlook at life regardless of the difficult times she had to go through. She wanted to help everyone and believed that no matter what; life is worth living, regardless of the challenges we face. Let us celebrate the life of Sheila Milner; and always remember, life is challenging and the future is unpredictable for all of us but we have to make the best of each and everyday we are here. may the memory of Sheila remains in our hearts and minds now and forever.

JACOFF--Sydney, died peacefully at home on October 28 at age 99. Businessman, sailor, philanthropist, serious reader, crack anagrams player. For 66 years, loving husband of Helen until her death in 2005. Born June 12, 1915, the second of four sons of Samuel and Sarah Jacoff, he is survived by his sons Michael (Jeanne) and Daniel, Daniel's sons Benjamin and Samuel, and many nieces and nephews. Graduating from City College of New York in 1935, he went to work with his father who had shortly before established a small tool manufacturing business, essentially a two-man operation, where Sydney had already been helping out part-time. As the enterprise grew, all his brothers joined them over the next decade or so. Together they built it into the still flourishing Great Neck Saw Manufacturers, now run by a third generation, through their dedication and hard work. Hap- piest when at the wheel of the Sarah in a stiff breeze, if Helen was with him, or, again in her company, gazing out over the Provencal landscape and discussing what the day's excursion should be. He also took great pleasure in a close circle of extraordinary friends with whom he and Helen shared many good times and some difficult ones as well over many decades. He also experienced his share of adversities most notably, the long, ever deepening darkness of Helen's Alzheimer's. A remarkable ability to maintain a positive spirit in the face of setbacks and a gift for connecting with people helped sustain him through these times. In lieu of flowers, contributions to either of the two causes that were closest to his heart would be appreciated: the Sydney and Helen Jacoff Scholarship Fund at the City College Fund or the Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation. Funeral on Thursday, October 30 at 1:30pm at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, 11021. 516-487-2513.

HIRSCH--Bernard S. (Bill) of Hewlett Harbor, New York, long time resident of Boca Raton, Florida passed on October 25, 2014 at age 90. Adoring husband of Arlyne, father to Barry (Jean), Steve (Elizabeth) and Laurie (Alec), grandfather to Lindsay, Michael, Julia, David, Jillian, Peter and Lucas and caring brother to Leonard (Roberta) and Gloria (Burton). Following a short career in dentistry, his family ran Harvey Stores and then Corlaine Fabrics. He was lovingly devoted to his family. He will be deeply missed. FORMAN--Murray. Died October 22, 2014, 94. Graduated from City College, English Major/Military Officer during World War II, navigator on bomber planes in Australia serving for the Army Air Force as Lieutenant/ Teacher Lindenhurst School District. Long Island 20 years/life long stamp collector/ Life Master Bridge Recipient. Devoted husband to Cynthia, together they fought her Alzheimer's disease until her death July 20, 2014 at 89. The late Dr. Ed Levin who phoned my father once a week, even as his health was weakening. What a mensch. Survivors include loving son Frank (Joan) and Dr. Donna Geffner, his late wife's first cousin and her husband Sandy Schaeffer, they were like closest of friends. Services were held privately.

CLAUSEN--Enid M Clausen. Enid Clausen, 77, passed away peacefully but unexpectedly on Sunday evening October 26 at her home in New York City. Born in New York to John and Meta Clausen, she graduated from Julia Richmond High School and the University of Bridgeport. Enid managed the family business, Yorkville Van and Storage, for over 55 years. Known for her kindness and generosity, she was happiest in her Upper Eastside neighborhood surrounded by friends and the neighborhood dogs. Her passion was her family and was often seen at her grandsons' sporting events and activities. She is survived by her daughter, Gail Donnelly Kingsley, son-in-law Scott Kingsley, grandsons--Andrew, Matthew, and Jonathan Kingsley, of Montclair, New Jersey, her sister Joan Behrens, of Ringwood, NJ, and beloved niece and nephews. A memorial service is scheduled for Saturday, November 1 at 2pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Second Chance Rescue at www. nycsecondchancerescue.org.

BROOKS--Robert Evan, passed away on October 24, at the age of 55 after a long and valiant struggle with a blood disease. He was the beloved son of Diane Hallenbeck and the late Gilbert Brooks. He was the loving husband of Kathy Kelrick Brooks and the devoted father of Hayley and Rachel Brooks whom he adored. Robert "Beau" is survived by his brother Stephen Brooks (Sally) and his sister Lindsay Brooks Sturman (Howard), and Shawn Hallenbeck-Hardin (Bill). Memorial service will be held in Florida on Sunday, November 2 at Temple Solel in Hollywood, FL at 1pm. The family will be receiving friends at the Brooks home, 2861 Birkdale Drive in Weston, FL following the service and on Monday evening.

BIRNBAUM--Edward, passed peacefully at his home in Forest Hills, NY, on October 24, 2014. He is survived by his loving wife Doris, stepchildren Mona and Ira, grandchildren Stephen and Michelle and multiple nieces and nephews. Edward was a member of the Knights of Pythias for over 50 years. He was a former Grand Chancellor of the state of New York and was a Supreme Representative at the time of his passing. He will be missed dearly by all who knew and loved him.

WASSER--Shirley Shapiro, passed peacefully on October 28 at age 90. A loving mother, grandmother, aunt and friend, she will be missed by all.

STANTON--Gordon Rentschler, Died on October 29, 2014 at the age of 55, after a long battle with pulmonary fibrosis. Beloved son of Phoebe R. Stanton and Louis L. Stanton (Berit). He leaves behind his wife Catherine (Kitty), their sons Niles and Henry, his brother Lee (Beth), his sister Susan Benedict (Rod), and half-brother Fredrik. He graduated from The Buckley School, St. Paul's School, Yale, and the NYU Stern School of Business. Gordon was a real-estate broker with Brown Harris Stevens. He was a member of the Blue Hill Troupe, The Amateur Comedy Club, Holland Lodge No. 8, and served on the board of The Interfaith Center of New York. Gordon was a devoted father whose greatest joys were spending time with family and friends and his strong commitment to service to others. He will be greatly missed. Memorial Service at St. James' Church Madison Avenue and 71st Street Monday, November 24, 2014 at 2:00pm.

SLAUGHTER--Thomas Robert. The American Society for Yad Vashem mourns the passing of dedicated supporter and friend Thomas Slaughter. We are profoundly grateful for his friendship with Milton Steinberg and the American Society and for his generosity as a director of the Horace W. Goldsmith Foundation. The Foundation's support of Yad Vashem's efforts was invaluable. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his family and loved ones. Leonard A. Wilf, Chairman; Ron B. Meier, Executive Director

PEREIRA--Mortimer, of Manhattan, passed away on October 28, 2014 at age 96. Wonderful husband of Dorothy for over 50 years. Wonderful father to son Marshall and stepson Jeffrey Shaw and grandfather to three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

NICHOLSON--Susan Zeckendorf, October 21, 2014. Your kindness, yes, but that sense of humor: David and the price of bananas; your father and the price of two pint-sized fur coats; you and your cholesterol-free York peppermints: "Eat enough and you'll disappear." Save some for the gang: Mary Ann, Vicki, Denise, Marjorie and me, as you're sharing with Ruth and Paul. Much love, Eileen Fallon

MAZUR--Joseph A.,most remembered as a New State Supreme Court Judge, officiated for over 33 years and was instrumental in clearing over 10,000 indictments. He was born the youngest of three siblings, on May 29, 1918 in the Lower Eastside, to two Polish immigrants. Before graduating from DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx, he spent time as a varsity football fullback and a discus and shot put thrower on the track team. While attending Brooklyn College, World War II began. He was drafted into the U.S. Navy and spent the next three years dropping depth charges in the Gulf of Mexico. Joe supplemented his education during the War with USAFI courses at Ohio State University, and graduating from Brooklyn College at the conclusion of his service. While working full-time, delivering news papers, selling magazines and clerking in food stores, the young Mazur advanced to the job of Political and Educational Director for Local 22 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. These jobs were necessary to support his wife Helen and his two kids while he was obtaining his law degree from New York Law School. After graduating, he established the law firm of Mazur, Dontzin, Mazur and Dewitt, and shortly thereafter, became Counsel to the New York City Department of Labor, under Mayor Lindsey. Then he became Counsel to the New York State Department of Labor, first under Governor Harriman and then Governor Rockefeller. Mayor Lindsey appointed him to the Criminal Bench in 1965, where he was reappointed two more times under Mayor Koch. In 1985, The Judge was elected to the New York State Supreme Court, where he spent the rest of his judicial career. As a member of the Bronx Bar, he was revered by many attorneys for his hard work, intelligence, understanding and cooperation. After retiring in 1994, he continued on the bench, in various capacities, for an additional fifteen years. He was an adjunct professor of Labor Law at Cornell University and Rutgers Law School. He taught Commercial Law at Bronx Community College and taught grievance procedure to the prisoners at Sing Sing prison. The Judge was a wonderful loving and caring husband to the former Helen Schaffel for almost 70 years. He had two daughters, Bonnie Kirschenbaum, who pre-decreased him, and Sheryl Miller, who lives in Poughkeepsie, NY. The Judge is also survived by his two son-in-laws, Dr. Joel Miller and David Kirschenbaum; three grandsons, Daniel and Jonathan Miller, and Joshua Kirschenbaum; and five great grandchildren, Holden and Kieran Miller, Alison and Matthew Miller, and Sophia Kirschenbaum.
KEENAN--Terry Kass. The soundtrack to "The Sound of Music" will never be the same. Always, Jane

KEENAN--Terry, Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of Terry Keenan, beloved wife of our member, Ron Kass. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Joshua M. Davidson, Senior Rabbi John H. Streicker, President

HELD--Dr. Barry T. Died October 6, 2014, at his home in Sharon, CT surrounded by his family. Born November 5, 1931 in Brooklyn, NY, he was the son of the late Tillie and Julius Held and the beloved husband of Melinda Sweet Held. Barry had a long and distinguished medical and academic career. A graduate of Hamilton College '52 and SUNY Downstate Medical School '56, he completed his Radiology residency at Long Island College Hospital and fellowship training at Yale University School of Medicine. In 1962 he joined the radiology department at Roosevelt Hospital and in 1965 was appointed Chairman of the Department of Radiology at Booth Memorial Hospital, a position he maintained until 1992. In 1998 he became co-head of outpatient radiology at New York Hospital, retiring in 2003. He was a senior faculty member of NYU Medical Center and Weill Cornell University Medical College. He served as President of the New York Roentgen Society, National Advisor for Accreditation and Standards of Radiologic Care for the American College of Radiology, and was a member of the National Board of Medical Examiners and the American Board of Radiology. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his daughter Patricia Grunebaum, husband George and children Sebastian, Annabel and Charlotte; daughter-in-law Sharon Held; step-daughter Elizabeth Dowling, husband Tim and children Emily and Grace; step-son Howard Sweet, wife Lisa, and children Adam and Lila; and his wife from a previous marriage, Barbara Held. He was predeceased by his son Jamie Held. Barry was a wonderful husband, father, grandfather, colleague and friend. He will be deeply missed by all who were fortunate enough to know him. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, November 8.

HARNIK--Edith B.,died at home, October 28, age 94. She is survived by sons, Peter (Carol) and Stephen (Deborah), grandchildren, Andrew, Rebecca and Nicholas, step-granddaughters Caline (Eric), Lara (Michael) and step-greatgrandson Crosby. A role model, all her friends will miss her indomitable spirit. Memorial service at Central Synagogue, Lexington Ave. at 55th St., Friday 2pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to an environmental organization of your choice.

GREENBERG--Gertrude (Gerry) on October 30, 2014. Beloved wife of the late David. Loving mother of Keith (Patti), Risa (Larry) Chain, Michael and Robert. Cherished grandmother of Peri and David. Devoted sister of Larry and Marilyn Hofstein and sister-in-law of Martha and John Schaeffer. Services 12 noon Sunday, November 2, 2014 at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY www.riversidenass aunorthchapels.com.

FAY--Sr. Teresita, RSHM, Ph.D. The entire Marymount Manhattan College community mourns the loss of Sr. Teresita Fay, RSHM, Ph.D., who was a loyal and dedicated member of the College's Board of Trustees. Sr. Teresita was a member of the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary for 65 years. Her vision, intelligence, wisdom and talent for engaging and bringing people together were the hallmarks of her service to our College. Elected to the College's Board of Trustees in 2010, Sr. Teresita served as Chair of the Academic Affairs and Student Affairs Committees and was active on the Executive, Student Affairs, and Trustees Committees. Her strategic leadership had a tremendous impact on the College and her warm, genuine friendship touched many. Sr. Teresita was a trailblazer and worked for Arthur Andersen & Co. for 20 years where she served as Director of Internal and Client Training for Performance Management, Strategic Planning, Change, Stress, Time Management and Relationship Building, and was promoted to serve as a Principal in the company. Since her retirement from Arthur Andersen, Sr. Teresita engaged in consulting work with small not-for-profit organizations. Her time was devoted to her work in academia, serving both the Marymount School and Marymount Manhattan College. Her loss is profound, and we will never forget her devotion to the mission of our College and her love for our community and students. Judson R. Shaver, Ph.D. President Marymount Manhattan College

ESCHEN--Albert H.,O.D., (92), passed away in Arlington, VA, on October 24, 2014. He is preceded in death by his loving wife Florence Eschen, his parents Samuel and Frances Eschen. He is survived by his sons Burt Eschen (Caryn) and Andrew Eschen; his grandchildren Meryl Mills and Lowell Eschen, and great-grandchild Elena Farran Mills; and sister Ruth Sloan. Service in the US Army Air Corp during WWII. Services will be at Arlington National Cemetery.

CUSIMANO--Rose (nee Governale) age 99, on October 27, 2014. Devoted wife of the late Joseph C. Cusimano. Beloved mother of Catherine SanFilippo (J.Anthony SanFilippo, M.D.) and Dominic J. Cusimano (Rita). Cherished grandmother of Joseph(Mary Kate) and John(Maryann) SanFilippo, Donna, Michelle Vachris (Craig) and Joseph Robert (Sara) Cusimano. Dear great-grandmother of Anthony, Emma Rose, Mary Grace, Julia and Elizabeth SanFilippo, Charles and Sam Vachris and Joseph Robert, Eleanor, Alexandra and John Thomas Cusimano. CLAUSEN--Enid M Clausen. Enid Clausen, 77, passed away peacefully but unexpectedly on Sunday evening October 26 at her home in New York City. Born in New York to John and Meta Clausen, she graduated from Julia Richmond High School and the University of Bridgeport. Enid managed the family business, Yorkville Van and Storage, for over 55 years. Known for her kindness and generosity, she was happiest in her Upper Eastside neighborhood surrounded by friends and the neighborhood dogs. Her passion was her family and was often seen at her grandsons' sporting events and activities. She is survived by her daughter, Gail Donnelly Kingsley, son-in-law Scott Kingsley, grandsons--Andrew, Matthew, and Jonathan Kingsley, of Montclair, New Jersey, her sister Joan Behrens, of Ringwood, NJ, and beloved niece and nephews. A memorial service is scheduled for Saturday, November 1 at 2pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Second Chance Rescue at www. nycsecondchancerescue.org.

VISWANATH--BANAD N, M.D. December 26, 1937 October 30, 2014. With deep sorrow, the extended members of the Viswanath and Banad families announce the passing of their family patriarch, Banad N Viswanath, M.D., beloved son of the late Nandiswar and Parvathamma Banad; husband of Sathya Viswanath; father of Deepak, Dilip and Dev Viswanath and his loving daughters-in-law Jaimini, Carmen, Kara and his eight precious grandchildren Abhishek, Rishi, Simran, Isabella, Carolina, Kiran, Meena and Dev. Junior. Dr. Viswanath is also survived by his loving siblings Banad Jagannath, Chandraprabha Chinnappala, Shiva Prakash Banad and Premanath Banad and all the other members of his loving family. Dr. Banad N. Viswanath lived a full and varied life and was a trail blazer in the fields of Medicine, Broadcasting, Business and Philanthropy. Emigrating to the US in 1962, he trained at Baylor University Hospital under the legendary Dr. Denton Cooley in Houston, Texas and went on to a distinguished career as an eminent cardiologist in a medical career spanning more than five decades. He practiced until the very end, working six days a week and always putting his patients' needs above his own. Dr. Viswanath is known as the 'Pioneer of Indian TV in the USA, when he launched 'Vision of Asia' the first Indian American TV show in 1976 , making it a 'must see' show for the South Asian Diaspora, every Sunday morning. With this success, in 1986, Dr. Viswanath, launched ITV Gold, the first, full time 24 hours a day, seven days a week cable TV channel in the United States, bringing the latest news and culture of the Indian Sub Continent to TV screen in the US. Among his many philanthropic interests, Dr. Viswanath supported various non-profit, religious and humanitarian institutions in the US and in South Asia, which his family will continue to be active in. For our family and friends, Dr. Viswanath will never be forgotten. In our hearts, he will forever remain. Funeral services are under the care of Frederick Funeral Home, Flushing, New York

TYLER--Ruth Ann 1931-2014 Ruth Ann Tyler, a native of Shawnee, Oklahoma and a fifty-five year resident of Port Washington, NY, died unexpectedly on October 26th with her life-partner, Barbara Scheid, by her side. Ruth Ann was the daughter of the late Frances V. and Claude Tyler of Shawnee, Oklahoma and was predeceased by her brother, John Tyler, M.D., of Austin, Texas. A Phi Beta Kappa honor graduate of the University of Oklahoma, Ms. Tyler became a Field Representative for the Kappa Kappa Gamma Women's Fraternity after graduation. She traveled throughout the United States and Canada to provide administrative support to the Fraternity's chapters. Ruth Ann completed the Harvard-Radcliff Program in Business Administration before joining the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in 1956. She rapidly advanced in several positions until she was named Chief of the Personnel Services Division in 1961. Ruth Ann remained one of the few female Officers of the Federal Reserve Bank until her retirement. While employed, Ruth Ann received an advanced degree from the American Banking Association's Stonier Graduate School of Banking at Rutgers University, now part of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. A perpetual "Sooner" football fan, Ruth Ann was an avid sportswoman throughout her life. She played tennis and golf, but above all, she was a passionate boater. Ruth Ann and Barbara spent countless hours sailing the Long Island Sound and traveling the Intercoastal Waterways from New York to Florida in both sailboats and power boats. Ruth Ann was a former member, president and treasurer of the Port Washington Estates Association. Ruth Ann and Barbara were married on January 20, 2014. In July, they celebrated 49 years of partnership. Ruth Ann is survived by her life-partner and wife, Barbara Scheid, their nieces and nephews, many friends and neighbors, all of whom will miss her dry sense of humor and generosity. Visitation will be held on Sunday, November 2, at the Austin F. Knowles Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. Calling hours are 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm. A celebration of her life and prayer service will commence at 8:30pm.

Gormley Funeral Home, 2055 Centre Street, West Roxbury, Tuesday, November 4, at 9am., followed by a Funeral Mass in Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church at 10 o'clock. Visiting hours Monday 2-8pm. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Berklee College of Music Scholarship Fund, 1140 Boylston Street, Boston, MA 02215. For directions and guestbook, please visit www.gormleyfuneral.com.

QUICK--Elizabeth Ann, 87, passed away peacefully October 24, 2014. Born in Michigan to Mabel McKissack Featherston and Dr. Anthony G. Featherston. Widow of Howard Roland Quick, former AT&T executive and Principal at public relations firms Reavey and Quick International, and Quick Associates. Attended The Little Red Schoolhouse and Elizabeth Irwin High School in New York, studying cello under Leonard Bernstein. After earning bachelor's and master's degrees from NYU, Elizabeth taught for more than 25 years in New York and New Jersey public schools. Elizabeth was a long-time resident of Morristown, NJ where she founded a business, the After School Reading Center, and was actively involved with the Recreation Commission, the NAACP, Essex Northwest Lung Association, YMCA and Planned Parenthood. She was a charter member of the Pi Theta Omega Chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority and first President of the Morris County Chapter of the Links, Inc. In retirement, Elizabeth lived on Martha's Vineyard where she volunteered at the Edgartown Senior Center, quilted, made pottery and developed her gift for taking beautiful photos. She later moved to New Rochelle, NY to live with her daughter Louise and family. Elizabeth Quick was a compassionate mother, wife and grandmother. Survived by daughters, Annette Elizabeth Quick and Louise Quick Spann; grandson Howard Lewis Spann; sons-in-laws Roger E. Coy and Lewis B. Spann, Jr., and family and friends who will not quickly recover from their loss. Viewing and funeral service are Saturday, November 1 at 9am, White Plains Presbyterian Church, 39 North Broadway, White Plains, NY 10601. Memorial contributions to: The Links Foundation, Incorporated, PO Box 2221-R, Morristown, NJ 07960. Note: "For the benefit of Morris County Chapter/Elizabeth Quick Scholarship for Excellence."
