WINTER--Sondra. Sondra Winter, died in the city that she loved on October 25. A bright light has been dimmed. A strong and clear spirit has been taken. Sondra had the enthusiasm and lust for life of someone many decades younger - with a great sense of humor and timing, and an amazing attitude towards life that probably extended hers by at least a decade. She was always ready to laugh, eat, drink, shop and keep right on having fun. Sondra seemed just as much in love with her beloved partner, Sam Citron, now, as she was when they first met almost 25 years ago. Seeing them together was always like seeing two teenagers in love. Sam's term of endearment for her was "Little Bird", an affectionate pet name that endured through the years. Sondra (a/k/a my fabulous mother) had a remarkable ability to focus only upon a positive outcome for any situation and to navigate her way towards that best possible outcome. In doing so, she would also take the rest of us along with her for the ride and turn us into believers. She was a great cook, a loving and never-overbearing mother, and for 37 years, she was the wife of Jack Winter, whom she married only 10 days after their chance meeting on a Midtown street in 1952. She is survived by her son Gregg and daughter-in-law Barbara, and by her loving partner Sam, with whom she spent her happiest years. From the start, once Gregg married Barbara in 1999, Sondra and Barbara became best friends and had their own unique and special bond. To the very end, her hunger to live and to enjoy even a shrinking number of good hours each day makes it hard to accept that there will be no more long phone calls, and no more visits to her apartment where she would hold court in her pink bedroom, with all of us talking and watching TV together and commenting on everyone and everything and laughing, and laughing...

WEINGOLD--Maurice, age 85, on October 31, 2014. Born on August 5, 1929, "Mush" was the cherished son of the late Sylvia and Pincus. He was the devoted husband of Rita his adoring wife of 61 years. Beloved father of Carol (Jonathan) and Philip (Jane). Loving grandfather of Avi, Aliza, Eva and Elizabeth. Dear brother of Shirley and brother-in-law of Frieda. A graduate of Clarkson University and Columbia Law School, Mush was a brilliant lawyer, respected judge and both lived his life and practiced his profession with dignity, class and respect. He was loved by his family and friends and will be missed every day! Funeral services will be held at Temple Beth El, where he once served as President, located at 46 Locust Ave., Cedarhurst, NY 11516 on Monday, November 3, 2014 at 10:30am.

THORP--Almus Morse, Jr.,73, died peacefully in Los Angeles, on Thursday, July 24, 2014 after a long battle with Parkinson's and Alzheimer's. Mr. Thorp was born in Columbus, Ohio on March 16, 1941 to the late Reverend Almus Morse Thorp and Merriel Kimball Thorp. He attended Amherst College, graduating cum laude in 1963, and Union Theological Seminary. He married Joanne Smith. He held posts at Christ Church Cincinnati and St. James Episcopal Church (NYC), and was rector at St. Francis Church (Maryland) and Christ Church Cranbrook (MI). In 1993, Mr. Thorp left the church and was divorced. He led the Greater Lansing Housing Coalition until 2008. Mr. Thorp is survived by his children: Rebecca Hutchinson (Charles) of Los Angeles, Sarah Khetani (Jay) of Concord, MA and Almus M. Thorp III (Elizabeth) of Bethesda, MD, his brother Peter Thorp (Vivian) of Las Vegas and his sister Merriel Thorp of Falls Church, VA, and eight grandchildren. Services are private. Memorial donations to Greater Lansing Housing Coalition http://www.glhc.org/index.php/donate. Condolences to his son: almusthorp@gmail.com.
WASSER--Shirley Shapiro, passed peacefully on October 28 at age 90. A loving mother, grandmother, aunt and friend, she will be missed by all.
SURATT--Samuel T. The Society of the Silurians notes with sadness the passing of devoted member Samuel T. Suratt.

STEGMAN--Bernard, on October 31, 2014 Beloved husband of the late Irene. Much loved father of Jackie Grabin (Jo), Steven, Debby Tappan (Gary) and the late Susan. Treasured grandfather of David, Jessica, Daniel, August, and Sydney. He was a very fine man and always a gentleman. Founder of Arrow Exterminating. He left a shining, lasting legacy. Services Today 12 noon at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels Hewlett, LI.

STANTON--Gordon Rentschler, Died on October 29, 2014 at the age of 55, after a long battle with pulmonary fibrosis. Beloved son of Phoebe R. Stanton and Louis L. Stanton (Berit). He leaves behind his wife Catherine (Kitty), their sons Niles and Henry, his brother Lee (Beth), his sister Susan Benedict (Rod), and half-brother Fredrik. He graduated from The Buckley School, St. Paul's School, Yale, and the NYU Stern School of Business. Gordon was a real-estate broker with Brown Harris Stevens. He was a member of the Blue Hill Troupe, The Amateur Comedy Club, Holland Lodge No. 8, and served on the board of The Interfaith Center of New York. Gordon was a devoted father whose greatest joys were spending time with family and friends and his strong commitment to service to others. He will be greatly missed. Memorial Service at St. James' Church Madison Avenue and 71st Street Monday, November 24, 2014 at 2:00pm.

SONNETT--Enid, daughter of the late Herman E. Hoberman and Florence Alterson Hoberman, passed away peacefully at home on October 30th, surrounded by those who loved her. Enid was born in Brooklyn, NY on September 20, 1932 and graduated from the Berkeley School and Centenary College. Most of her life was spent at her home in Ditmas Park until moving to Scarborough, NY. She was predeceased by her former husband Carl Sonnett and leaves behind her daughters Meridith Sonnett (Larry Fisher), Stacy Sonnett (Avram Heby), her son Anthony Sonnett (Sharon) and her brother Owen Hoberman (Arlyn). Her insight, compassion and wit will forever influence her devoted grandchildren Alex, Joshua, Richard, Jacob, Evan, Anna, Rachel and Samantha, all of whom were fortunate to have a loving, elegant Bubbe with impeccable good taste. Her life was eased by the warm care of Michelle McCloud-Harris, her companion of many years as well as by Carmen, her canine companion.

SLAUGHTER--Thomas R. The Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation Board of Directors mourn the loss of our dear friend and dedicated supporter Tom Slaughter. Tom's indomitable spirit and deep commitment to the fight against cancer in honor of all patients and families will always be remembered. Our deepest appreciation and condolences go out to his loved ones.

SCHWARTZ--Daylle Deanna. , age 65, of New York, NY, passed away peacefully on October 31, 2014 at Brighton Gardens of Saddle River, NJ. Born September 19, 1949 in Bronx, NY, she is the daughter of the late Robert and Ruth Herman. Daylle is survived by her daughter Tami Kramer, son-in-law Lonny Kramer, grandsons Bryce and Devin Kramer, sister Carla Herman and brother-in-law Douglas Landy. Burial services will be held on November 2, 2014 at New Montefiore Cemetery, West Babylon, NY at 11am. Shiva will be on November 3, 2014 at her daughter's home in Ringwood, NJ from 10am 2pm and 6pm 9pm. For address call (201)-256-6342. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the NYWICI Foundation, in support of the Member Empowerment Grant (MEG) Program, a grant which Daylle received herself in 2013. Donations can be made at www.nywici.org. An acclaimed speaker, music industry expert, self-empowerment counselor and best-selling author of 13 books, Daylle specialized in helping people overcome obstacles in their lives. She was a committed member of New York Women in Communications (NYWICI), ASJA, and other noteworthy organizations. There is a memorial website at daylledeannaschwartz.com.

SLAUGHTER--Tom. Artist Tom Slaughter was a most beloved friend of the Creative Time family. Fiercely curious, smart, kind and generous, his inspiration will live on in our hearts and in our work. We will forever cherish his vibrant memory, and we send our deepest condolences to his beautiful family, who he loved so dearly.

SANTISI--Ray, of Boston, October 28, 2014. Berklee College of Music Professor for over five decades, jazz pianist, composer, arranger and recording artist. Ledwak, Josephine Galvin, Mary Cameron, Serena Seacrist, Celeste Lundell, Frank Santisi, and Alfred Santisi, also survived by many nieces and nephews. Funeral from the William J. REIFF--Renee, 93 years old, beloved mother of Isabel, Kenneth, and Russell, and wife of the late Sidney Reiff, left this earth on October 28. She died peacefully at her home in California, surrounded by the people she loved and who loved her. Renee was born in 1921 in Brooklyn, NY to immigrant parents, Fanny and Isidore Polansky. One of three daughters, all of whom went to college, Renee graduated from Brooklyn College and had an early career as a sportswear buyer for the Abraham and Strauss department store. After launching her children, Renee worked with Sidney managing his medical practice. They commuted to work together, ate lunch together, and together they cared for their community. In 1971 Renee and Sidney moved to Los Angeles. Renee went back to her roots in merchandising and worked for the United Nations Association store where she managed the UNICEF card concession - combining her love of beautiful things with her passion for social justice and programs. She is survived by her children, Isabel (Lee), Kenneth (Angela), Russell (Anna), and grandchildren, Sam, Faye, Matthew, Elizabeth, Sophia, and Alexis as well as nieces and nephews and friends. She will be missed. Contributions, in lieu of flowers, can be made to UNICEF. Services will be Sunday, November 2, 1pm at Hillside Mortuary in Los Angeles, CA. 800-576-1994.

PEREIRA--Mortimer, of Manhattan, passed away on October 28, 2014 at age 96. Wonderful husband of Dorothy for over 50 years. Wonderful father to son Marshall and stepson Jeffrey Shaw and grandfather to three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

PATEL--Kunal. Kunal Patel, February 15, 1987 - October 23, 2014. We are celebrating the life of an extraordinary human being, Kunal Patel who was with us for 27 years and passed away on October 23rd after a tragic bike accident. Kunal was born and raised in San Francisco Bay Area, CA, went to the University of Southern California for his undergraduate degree in Chemical Engineering and then received his Masters in Chemical Engineering from Cornell University. He was a research intern in nanotechnology at the NASA Ames Research center and most recently an entrepreneur; in true Silicon Valley style, he cofounded a company called Arevo Labs. At 27, he had accomplished more than most do in a lifetime. Kunal was a star athlete he was passionate about soccer, completed the Escape from Alcatraz and New York Triathlons, and was a 4.5 USA National tennis champion. He loved classical music and was an extraordinary traveler, backpacking through so many countries all over the world and always looking for off the beaten path experiences with great enthusiasm and energy. Most importantly, Kunal was kind, compassionate, affectionate, gentle, and always brimming with a zest for life. He taught us how to live life to the fullest, encouraging us to explore beyond our boundaries, and always coming up with new ideas for family and friends. He was our inspiration: an amazing son, a wonderful brother, and an extraordinary human being. Words cannot describe how much we will miss you Kunal but we are grateful for the years we had with you. Our blessings for your journey ahead and thank you for all you gave us. Our love will always be with you. Mom, Dad and Monique
NEWMAN--Terrie Lynne. October 15, a bright star joined heaven. She will be missed by husband Fred Kerstein, brother Bruce and sister Geraldine. Visit legacy.com

MILNER--Sheila. A devoted wife of Saladin Bucak; daughter of Sheila Casey and Michael J. Milner; sister of Michael Milner; and a caring aunt of Paula. Sheila was a conscientious, honest; courageous and outspoken person. She was a dedicated teacher who worked for about 40 years in the teaching profession. She was so passionate for the well being of humanity and justice. She was a very dedicated daughter, who took care of her mother for about 30 years. Her mother was suffering from Alzheimer's Disease, which she herself suffered with for about 14 years. Sheila always had a smile and a very positive outlook at life regardless of the difficult times she had to go through. She wanted to help everyone and believed that no matter what; life is worth living, regardless of the challenges we face. Let us celebrate the life of Sheila Milner; and always remember, life is challenging and the future is unpredictable for all of us but we have to make the best of each and everyday we are here. may the memory of Sheila remains in our hearts and minds now and forever.

MAZUR--Joseph A.,most remembered as a New York State Supreme Court Judge, officiated for over 33 years and was instrumental in clearing over 10,000 indictments. He was born the youngest of three siblings, on May 29, 1918 in the Lower Eastside, to two Polish immigrants. Before graduating from DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx, he spent time as a varsity football fullback and a discus and shot put thrower on the track team. While attending Brooklyn College, World War II began. He was drafted into the U.S. Navy and spent the next three years dropping depth charges in the Gulf of Mexico. Joe supplemented his education during the War with USAFI courses at Ohio State University, and graduating from Brooklyn College at the conclusion of his service. While working full-time, delivering news papers, selling magazines and clerking in food stores, the young Mazur advanced to the job of Political and Educational Director for Local 22 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. These jobs were necessary to support his wife Helen and his two kids while he was obtaining his law degree from New York Law School. After graduating, he established the law firm of Mazur, Dontzin, Mazur and Dewitt, and shortly thereafter, became Counsel to the NYC Department of Labor, under Mayor Lindsey. Then he became Counsel to the New York State Department of Labor, first under Governor Harriman and then Governor Rockefeller. Mayor Lindsey appointed him to the Criminal Bench in 1965, where he was reappointed two more times under Mayor Koch. In 1985, The Judge was elected to the New York State Supreme Court, where he spent the rest of his judicial career. As a member of the Bronx Bar, he was revered by many attorneys for his hard work, intelligence, understanding and cooperation. After retiring in 1994, he continued on the bench, in various capacities, for an additional fifteen years. He was an adjunct professor of Labor Law at Cornell University and Rutgers Law School. He taught Commercial Law at Bronx Community College and taught grievance procedure to the prisoners at Sing Sing prison. The Judge was a wonderful loving and caring husband to the former Helen Schaffel for almost 70 years. He had two daughters, Bonnie Kirschenbaum, who pre-decreased him, and Sheryl Miller, who lives in Poughkeepsie, NY. The Judge is also survived by his two son-in-laws, Dr. Joel Miller and David Kirschenbaum; three grandsons, Daniel and Jonathan Miller, and Joshua Kirschenbaum; and five great grandchildren, Holden and Kieran Miller, Alison and Matthew Miller, and Sophia Kirschenbaum.
MILLER--Joan. A "Remembering Jo" event will be held at 281 Woodland Rd., Highland Park, IL on November 25, 5-7pm.

LESSER--Lola, of New York City died on October 26, 2014. Born July 28, 1927 in Berlin Germany, Lola is survived by her three children: Jacquie Herz of Stamford, CT; Shoshana Angyalfi of Leeds, England; Roger Lewin of Ft. Lauderdale, FL. She was the adored Nana to eight grandchildren: Jordie, Nikki, Chani, Yossi, Mendy, Rivki, Chaya, Moshe and a loving GG to 24 great-grandchildren. A very beautiful woman, both inside and out, Lola touched the hearts of everyone she knew. She will be truly missed by family and friends alike.

LEE--Dr. Isabella, age 93, died October 24, in her home in New York City after a long illness. Widow of Chinese artist and teacher Jim Lee. Although she earned her Doctorate and was a Professor at NYU, her true calling and lifelong commitment, work, struggle, and passion was for women's rights, civil rights, the labor movement and peace. She is survived by her devoted friend and caregiver Linda King. Her intelligence, wit, humor, and caring will be sorely missed by many who knew and loved her.

KOVER--Susan Deutsch, died on October 31 after a brave struggle. She was a teacher, librarian, storyteller, and mixed media artist. She is survived by her husband of forty-four years Andy; her children, Hillary and David and their spouses; and her loving grandson Sam. Funeral services will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 11:30am on November 3. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation to the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society.

KINNELL--Galway. The MacDowell Colony wishes to acknowledge the life of poet Galway Kinnell, an extraordinary talent, teacher, and Colony friend. Galway was a great presence during seven residencies from 1959 to 1992. His poem "Oatmeal" stirs memories of cooking his breakfast in a pot on the radiator in his studio at MacDowell. For the many wonderful volumes of poetry and prose, we thank him. His friendship will be remembered fondly by the staff, artists and board. Our deepest condolences to his family and wife, MacDowell board member Bobbie Bristol.

KENNY--Margaret Herrmann "Peggy", on October 27th at home, aged 81. Survived by her husband of 60 years, John J. Kenny, her sister, Rosemary Lockwood, her children, Christopher, Maeve (John), Justin (Peggy) and Deirdre as well as six grandchildren Dylan, Grace, Owen, Thomas, Charlotte and Nicholas. Teacher, traveller and bon vivant, she will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association. Funeral Mass November 3rd at 3:30pm St Charles Borromeo Church, 19 Sidney Place, Brooklyn, NY 11201.
KEENAN--Terry Kass. The soundtrack to "The Sound of Music" will never be the same. Always, Jane

JACOFF--Sydney, died peacefully at home on October 28 at age 99. Businessman, sailor, philanthropist, serious reader, crack anagrams player. For 66 years, loving husband of Helen until her death in 2005. Born June 12, 1915, the second of four sons of Samuel and Sarah Jacoff, he is survived by his sons Michael (Jeanne) and Daniel, Daniel's sons Benjamin and Samuel, and many nieces and nephews. Graduating from City College of New York in 1935, he went to work with his father who had shortly before established a small tool manufacturing business, essentially a two-man operation, where Sydney had already been helping out part-time. As the enterprise grew, all his brothers joined them over the next decade or so. Together they built it into the still flourishing Great Neck Saw Manufacturers, now run by a third generation, through their dedication and hard work. Hap- piest when at the wheel of the Sarah in a stiff breeze, if Helen was with him, or, again in her company, gazing out over the Provencal landscape and discussing what the day's excursion should be. He also took great pleasure in a close circle of extraordinary friends with whom he and Helen shared many good times and some difficult ones as well over many decades. He also experienced his share of adversities most notably, the long, ever deepening darkness of Helen's Alzheimer's. A remarkable ability to maintain a positive spirit in the face of setbacks and a gift for connecting with people helped sustain him through these times. In lieu of flowers, contributions to either of the two causes that were closest to his heart would be appreciated: the Sydney and Helen Jacoff Scholarship Fund at the City College Fund or the Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation. Funeral was held on Thursday, October 30.

KAFFE-ROSENBERG-- Dr. Sara. A dedicated physician and woman of fierce intellect, sharp wit and endless devotion to her family. She passed away August 12 and is survived by her children, Yuval and Anat; her former husband, Dr. Vladimiro Rosenberg; her brother, Israel Kaffe; and her two grandchildren, Leo and Ella. Memorial service Sunday, November 9, 2014, 2pm at "The Riverside," 180 W. 76th St. Donations in her memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association and to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York.

HIRSCH--Bernard S. (Bill) of Hewlett Harbor, New York, long time resident of Boca Raton, Florida passed on October 25, 2014 at age 90. Adoring husband of Arlyne, father to Barry (Jean), Steve (Elizabeth) and Laurie (Alec), grandfather to Lindsay, Michael, Julia, David, Jillian, Peter and Lucas and caring brother to Leonard (Roberta) and Gloria (Burton). Following a short career in dentistry, his family ran Harvey Stores and then Corlaine Fabrics. He was lovingly devoted to his family. He will be deeply missed. Charitable donations can be made to JDRF (Los Angeles Chapter).

HELD--Dr. Barry T. Died October 6, 2014, at his home in Sharon, CT surrounded by his family. Born November 5, 1931 in Brooklyn, NY, he was the son of the late Tillie and Julius Held and the beloved husband of Melinda Sweet Held. Barry had a long and distinguished medical and academic career. A graduate of Hamilton College '52 and SUNY Downstate Medical School '56, he completed his Radiology residency at Long Island College Hospital and fellowship training at Yale University School of Medicine. In 1962 he joined the radiology department at Roosevelt Hospital and in 1965 was appointed Chairman of the Department of Radiology at Booth Memorial Hospital, a position he maintained until 1992. In 1998 he became co-head of outpatient radiology at New York Hospital, retiring in 2003. He was a senior faculty member of NYU Medical Center and Weill Cornell University Medical College. He served as President of the New York Roentgen Society, National Advisor for Accreditation and Standards of Radiologic Care for the American College of Radiology, and was a member of the National Board of Medical Examiners and the American Board of Radiology. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his daughter Patricia Grunebaum, husband George and children Sebastian, Annabel and Charlotte; daughter-in-law Sharon Held; step-daughter Elizabeth Dowling, husband Tim and children Emily and Grace; step-son Howard Sweet, wife Lisa, and children Adam and Lila; and his wife from a previous marriage, Barbara Held. He was predeceased by his son Jamie Held. Barry was a wonderful husband, father, grandfather, colleague and friend. He will be deeply missed by all who were fortunate enough to know him. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, November 8.

HALEY--Gano B. The members of St. Anthony Hall fraternity mourn the death of their distinguished former leader and cherished Brother, Gano Bland Haley (Columbia, Class of '46) on October 19 in Princeton, NJ.

GREENBERG--Gertrude (Gerry) on October 30, 2014. Beloved wife of the late David. Loving mother of Keith (Patti), Risa (Larry) Chain, Michael and Robert. Cherished grandmother of Peri and David. Devoted sister of Larry and Marilyn Hofstein and sister-in-law of Martha and John Schaeffer. Services 12 noon Sunday, November 2, 2014 at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY www.riversidenass aunorthchapels.com.

GOLOMB--Barry, 90. The Golomb Cousins' Club mourns the loss of our dear senior member Barry, on October 29. He is survived by his cherished wife Adeline, his beloved sister Sarai Zitter, many children and grandchildren and a large loving family.

GOLDSTEIN--Elayne, on October 31, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Seymour. Loving mother of Jeffrey and Chere, Kenneth and Jill. Cherished grandmother of Allison, Jennifer, Sara and Jake. Graveside service Sunday 1pm at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

FAY--Sr. Teresita, RSHM, Ph.D. The entire Marymount Manhattan College community mourns the loss of Sr. Teresita Fay, RSHM, Ph.D., who was a loyal and dedicated member of the College's Board of Trustees. Sr. Teresita was a member of the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary for 65 years. Her vision, intelligence, wisdom and talent for engaging and bringing people together were the hallmarks of her service to our College. Elected to the College's Board of Trustees in 2010, Sr. Teresita served as Chair of the Academic Affairs and Student Affairs Committees and was active on the Executive, Student Affairs, and Trustees Committees. Her strategic leadership had a tremendous impact on the College and her warm, genuine friendship touched many. Sr. Teresita was a trailblazer and worked for Arthur Andersen & Co. for 20 years where she served as Director of Internal and Client Training for Performance Management, Strategic Planning, Change, Stress, Time Management and Relationship Building, and was promoted to serve as a Principal in the company. Since her retirement from Arthur Andersen, Sr. Teresita engaged in consulting work with small not-for-profit organizations. Her time was devoted to her work in academia, serving both the Marymount School and Marymount Manhattan College. Her loss is profound, and we will never forget her devotion to the mission of our College and her love for our community and students. Judson R. Shaver, Ph.D. President Marymount Manhattan College

FAY--Sr. Teresita, RSHM, 82, Brooklyn, NY, October 24, 2014. Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary 65 years. Taught in Portugal and at St. Catharine of Alexandria, Brooklyn; SHM High School, Rolling Meadows, IL; Marymount Manhattan College; Marymount School of New York; Loyola Marymount University, Los Angeles, CA. Did corporate worldwide training for Arthur Andersen. Member of Board of Trustees of Marymount Manhattan College, Marymount School of New York, and Board of Directors of Columba Kavanagh House in Harlem. Survived by sisters, Caroline McEnroe of Amenia, NY; Agnes Redmond of Smithtown, NY; Marion Fay of Great Neck, NY; brother, John Fay of La Verne, CA; and members of her religious congregation. Services Marymount Convent, 32 Warren Avenue, Tarrytown, NY. Wake Monday, November 3, 3:00pm-7:30pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, November 4, 11:00am.

EMERY--Hiram Weber, Jr. died Wednesday, October 29 at the age of 84. of the effects of Parkinson's Disease. Born in Providence, RI. He graduated from St. Mark's School ('48), Harvard College, ('52), served as a Lieutenant in Korea and graduated from the Harvard Business School ('56). He was a partner for 30 years of the White Weld Company, In New York City which was later acquired by Merrill Lynch. Upon retirement he worked for Gottesmann & Co. He is survived by his twin brother, John, his loving wife of 47 years Susan Curtis his children, Marjorie McCleary, (Benjamin) and Hiram III (Caroline) and five grandchildren. He was a devoted board member of the United Congregational Church in Little Compton, a member of the Union Club in New York City, General Society of Colonial Wars, and The Sakonnet Golf Club. A memorial service will be held, Friday, November 7th at 11:00am at the United Congregational Church in Little Compton, RI. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. Mark's School, Southborough, MA or the United Congregation Church, Little Compton, RI.

DONAHUE--Daniel James, A resident of Riverside, CT and Pacific Palisades, CA, Daniel J. Donahue died suddenly on October 21st in Pacific Palisades, CA. He was born in Chicago, Il on January 28, 1939. He was the eldest son of Donald F. Donahue, Sr. and Mary Fuller Donahue. He graduated from Fenwick High School in Oak Park, Il, and received a Congressional appointment to attend the United States Military Academy at West Point. After graduation, Dan completed Ranger and Paratrooper training at Fort Benning, GA, and Fort Campbell, KY. During his Army service, he was in charge of the Guerilla Warfare Training School in Korea from 1962-1963. Dan resigned from the Army in 1963 to pursue a career in finance. He joined Merrill Lynch where he worked for thirty-seven years. He started as a financial consultant in Chicago, and then became an office manager in Tacoma, WA, and then Manhattan. Next he took on the role of Director of General Services, and then became District Director in New England. During his early years at Merrill Lynch, he attained a Master's Degree in Business Administration from the University of Chicago. Dan retired from Merrill Lynch in 2000 and directed his energy to many activities, including continuing his career in the world of finance by founding the Fieldpoint Private Bank and Trust in Greenwich with his good friend, Dan Tully, and others. Dan served as founding Chairman from the bank's inception in 2008 until January 2013, after which he became Lead Director, and ultimately in May 2014, he became Chairman Emeritus. "Duty, honor, country," West Point's motto, were guiding principles throughout Dan's life. Dan was once told as he was leaving the Army and dressing out of uniform that he "looked like a soldier in civilian clothes," and he always tried to live up to the high ideals of West Point. Everywhere he lived or worked, Dan remained dedicated to a life of serving others and making the world a better place. He enjoyed being active in many charitable causes and community organizations. In Tacoma, WA, he chaired a town-wide fundraiser for all private and parochial high schools. In Greenwich, CT, he chaired the Republican Town Committee, was an early supporter of the Arch Street Teen Center, and was a founding board member of the Greenwich Point Conservancy. He was Parish Council President at St. Catherine of Siena, and a devoted member of the parish. In New York, he was the Chairman of the New York City Roundtable for the Center for Strategic and International Studies, and was also Chairman for the Tri-State United Way. He was appointed to the Grace Commission in Washington, DC. One of his favorite experiences was to be in charge of Merrill Lynch's Scholarship Builder Program in Harlem. Through that program, he helped mentor a class of 25 students from kindergarten through their school years and beyond. Recently he attended the wedding of a student with great pride and joy. It was also in smaller, less notable ways that Dan lived these principles. He spoke out and wrote letters for less fortunate people to institutions that might not otherwise listen. Dan had a serious gravitas and sterling integrity that commanded respect, and yet his sharp wit and easy laugh made him beloved by all who knew him well. He loved reading and his book club, golfing and his partners, boating and fishing with his grandchildren, travelling the world, mentoring young people, providing advice to the many who came to him, and simply enjoying his family as an incredibly devoted husband, father, and grandfather. Dan and his wife, Judy, fell in love in high school and they celebrated their fiftieth wedding anniversary this year with all their children and grandchildren in Carmel, CA. He is survived by her and his children, Daniel, Joseph, and Laura, his daughter-in-law Katharine, and son-in-law Michael, and his seven grandchildren, Daniel, Charles, Samuel, Henry, Hannah, Connor, and Ryan. Dan is predeceased by his parents and brothers and by his infant daughter, Susan. Dan will be interred at West Point after a private funeral. Memorial services will be held at St. Catherine of Siena Church, 4 Riverside Avenue, Riverside, CT at 11am on Saturday, November 22, 2014. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name may be made to "Campaign for West Point" at WPAOG, 608 Mills Road, West Point, NY 10996, or a charity of one's choice.

CLARK--David Crawford, of Oyster Bay, NY on October 24th. Husband of the late Elizabeth Ives Clark for 57 years. Served in the United States Navy aboard the submarine USS Kingfish (SS-234) during WWII. Father of David Jr., Henry and Peter; grandfather of Antonia, Elizabeth, Caroline, Hillary, Avery and Charlie; father-in-law of Peri, Harriet and Elizabeth; and friend to many. Memorial service, St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY on Saturday, November 15th at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, the family welcomes donations to St. John's Episcopal Church, PO Box 266, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724.

CLARK--Audrey Iselin, September 25, 1920 - October 26, 2014. The third and youngest child of Oliver Iselin and Beatrice Iselin, died peacefully in Jupiter Island, FL, with family members at her bedside. Beloved mother and grandmother, she went to be with her Lord Jesus Christ, after requesting the solitude she desired in the latter period of her life. She was predeceased by her husband of 59 years, Reed "Fritz" Clark, President of Czarnikow Rionda Company. Born in Westbury, NY, she graduated from Green Vale School (New York), Foxcroft School (Virginia), and attended The Juilliard School (New York). She spent most of her adult life in Old Brookville, NY and Jupiter Island, FL. She was devoted to her immediate and extended family. In her younger years, she was an avid skier and sportswoman. In her latter years she cared deeply about women's Bible classes in Long Island and Florida. She had a gift of hospitality for Christian ministries, supporting several, especially those focusing on youth programs. She was considered by all who knew her to be loving, humble, and wise. She is survived by her daughter, Sandra Clark Moore, wife of The Rev. Dr. Peter C. Moore; their children Jennifer Clark Moore, Catharine Mackay Norris, and David Clark Moore; her son, Peter Reed Clark, husband to Alison Moore Clark; their children William Reed Clark and Eileen Clark Wilder; and nine great-grandchildren. She requested that any gifts or remembrances be made in her name to Trinity School for Ministry, 311 Eleventh St., Ambridge, PA 15003; or FOCUS (Fellowship of Christians in Universities & Schools), P.O. Box 1027, New Canaan, CT 06840. Memorial Services will be held at Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter Island, FL on December 6, 11am and St. George's Episcopal Church, 4 Rutherford Place, New York City, NY at 11am, February 28th, Reception afterwards Olmstead Hall.
CALDWELL--Peter Devigne, 80. Memorial December 13, 2pm, 15th St Meeting House. See legacy.com/obituaries/ nytimes/ for full obituary.

BRAUDE--Theodore, 96. Very much loved father of Erica Braude, cousin of Michael Stone, and long-time companion of Joan Kuchkuda. Her family joins us in sadness, Kira and Peter Kibler and their children Aleta and Guy. We miss him.

BESKIND--Dorothy M. Levitt, 97, notable photographer and film-maker died peacefully at home in Easthampton NY, family by her side. Cherished mother of Joanne Beskind Elkin, Susan B. Lelyveld (Michael), Ellen Safir (Peter), grandchildren Katherine, Victor, Archie, Roland, Jesse; longtime companion, Sidney Goldstein. Her 25 year marriage to D. Herbert Beskind ended in divorce. We will forever miss her bright light, keen eye and spare aesthetic, adventurous zest for life, the wisdom, warmth, love and sparkle she brought to ours. Daughter of the late Rebecca and Adolph Levitt, dubbed the "Doughnut King" for his invention of the automated donut machine, founder of Doughnut Corp of America; predeceased by sister Irene L. Morse, and twin brother David M. Levitt. Beskind produced an extensive archive of over 300 films and numerous photographs of renowned artists including Joseph Beuys, Keith Haring, Louise Bourgeois, Bob Morris, Eva Hesse, Alice Neel, and Andy Warhol. Her work has been shown at the Whitney, Tate Modern, SFMoMA, the Jewish Museum, Yale University, Kutztown, U. Leeds, UK., and Pentax Gallery Tokyo. Memorial service in New York, details to be announced.

ANSPACH--Barbara Bodne. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, aunt, and friend, Barbara Anspach passed away peacefully on October 24, 2014. She was born on July 18, 1933 in Charleston, South Carolina, and attended Ashley Hall. As a teenager she moved to New York City when her parents, Ben and Mary Bodne, bought the historic Algonquin Hotel, which became her new home. Throughout the years she contributed to the daily life of the Algonquin. With her great taste, sense of style and history, and passion for the arts she helped make the hotel a welcoming home-away-from-home for visitors from around the world, many of whom she befriended with her wit and warmth. An accomplished student, she graduated as valedictorian from The Calhoun School and later from Finch College in New York City. In 1955 she met Andrew A. Anspach at the Algonquin, and the following year on June 24th, midsummer night, they were married. She enjoyed the next fifty-seven years as his beloved wife. Although "Bobbie," as some of her friends called her, loved both New York City and Charleston, she held a special place in her heart for Paris and especially London, where she often travelled with family and friends. She had a passion for London and New York theater and often reminisced about attending legendary opening nights. She is survived by her adored children, Elizabeth Carlson and Roxanna Anspach Devlin, and by her grandchildren, Annie and Margaret Carlson and Bennett, Emma, and William Devlin. She will also be greatly missed by her sister, Renee Mae Colby, by her nephews, Michael, Douglas, and David Colby, and by her devoted friends. A private funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to Save The Children or Heifer International.

WEINGOLD--Maurice. Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst mourns the passing of our longtime member and Past President Maurice Weingold. A three generation Beth El family, Maurice gave countless hours of dedicated service to guiding and leading our synagogue as well as the Village of Cedarhurst. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife Rita, children Philip and Carol, grandchildren and the entire Weingold family. Rabbi Matthew Futterman Richard Holland, President

WEINGOLD--Maurice, age 85, on October 31, 2014. Born on August 5, 1929, "Mush" was the cherished son of the late Sylvia and Pincus. He was the devoted husband of Rita his adoring wife of 61 years. Beloved father of Carol (Jonathan) and Philip (Jane). Loving grandfather of Avi, Aliza, Eva and Elizabeth. Dear brother of Shirley and brother-in-law of Frieda. A graduate of Clarkson University and Columbia Law School, Mush was a brilliant lawyer, respected judge and both lived his life and practiced his profession with dignity, class and respect. He was loved by his family and friends and will be missed every day! Funeral services will be held at Temple Beth El, where he once served as President, located at 46 Locust Ave., Cedarhurst, NY 11516 on Monday, November 3, 2014 at 10:30am.

SMITH--Myron, 86, beloved husband to Barbara (nee Herlands) for nearly 56 years. Father of Jeffrey (Sandra), Stephen (Stephanie) and Raquel (Steve). Adored grandfather to Leanna, Ethan, Alexander, Josie and Jack. A indefatigable force of nature first in the embroidery industry and later in commercial real estate. We will miss his feistiness and humor; our grief is assuaged recalling the love he showed us daily. Funeral at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel (Amsterdam and 91st St) Monday at 930am.

SPITZER--Bernard, a civil engineer, innovative real estate developer and philanthropist who built millions of square feet of prime Manhattan buildings, died on November 1. According to a family spokesperson, Mr. Spitzer succumbed after a long battle with Parkinson's Disease. He was 90 years of age. Always grateful for the opportunities he received, he and his wife, Anne, established a family foundation, which endowed a new architecture and urban planning school at City College as well as the Hall of Human Origins at the American Museum of Natural History. They also funded stem cell research at Columbia University and Public Theater productions of Shakespeare in the Park, among many other philanthropic initiatives. Education was a priority for his parents, Molly and Morris, who emigrated from Austria to a Lower East Side tenement on East 5th Street after World War I. His father ran a printing business in the basement, with assistance from the young Bernard, who was fluent in five languages and could typeset in four. A gifted student, he attended a local Yeshiva and then Townsend Harris High School, from which he graduated at age 14. He received his Bachelor of Science in Civil Engineering from City College four years later. Initially assisting the war effort designing gyroscopically stabilized gun-mounts, he then joined the Navy, and was posted to heavily bombarded Bremen as a Lieutenant JG in naval counter-intelligence. After discharge from the Navy, he attended Columbia University on the G.I. bill, earning a Master of Science in Engineering in 1947 and then accepted a position as field supervisor for the colorful Russian builder, Sam Minskoff. With a few years of experience under his belt, he set out on his own, building Spitzer Engineering, one successful project leading to the next, into a successful family company. Beginning in Riverdale with a seven-story brick apartment house completed in 1954, he then constructed a 112-unit residence on the northern section of the Grand Concourse. In 1960 he and a business partner developed a 22-story co-op at 1050 Fifth Avenue opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Eight more large-scale projects were developed from inception to completion over the next four decades. As described by real estate reporter Alan Oser in the December 15, 1991 New York Times, he was "a civil engineer with a taste for esthetics and design, a reputation as an insightful taskmaster and a preference for residential buildings in Manhattan locations. If there is an unusual construction challenge, so much the better." In 1962, he began development on the iconic 35-story apartment building at the corner of Central Park South and Seventh Avenue, a site diligently acquired parcel by parcel over many years after he spotted it from a taxicab window. Poring over drawings and coffee with long-term architect Michael Schimenti late one evening, he sketched a design for a distinctively curved structure stretching around the corner from Central Park South to broad Seventh Avenue. This provided maximum light, air and park views for the 310 residences and space for a curved driveway/port-cochere. One critic amiably suggested, "It's a nice building, just too far from the beach." "But not too far from the park." Mr. Spitzer wryly observed. After acquiring at auction the site of the former East Side Airlines Terminal at First Avenue between 37th and 38th Streets, Mr. Spitzer faced another formidable hurdle. While the zoning would allow some 865 apartments, making it the largest residential building in the city at the time (1989), connections to the Midtown tunnel ran like fault veins under a portion of the site. The result was The Corinthian, a 57-story curvilinear tower with an undulating facade of semi-circular windows gracefully secure on terra firma. Mr. Spitzer and partners purchased a Manhattan trophy commercial property, the Crown Building on Fifth Avenue across the street from Tiffany's, in 1991. The focus on commercial buildings in vibrant markets continued with the acquisition of two prime office properties in Washington, DC and one in Bethesda, MD. More recently, Spitzer Engineering acquired a retail condominium in SoHo and a development site in the Hudson Yards area. A voracious reader and enthusiastic interlocutor, Mr. Spitzer presided over the family dinner table, which became a field for discussion, debate, questioning authority and intellectual rigor. Meals were punctuated with Socratic discourse. Any appeal to authority or resort to ad hominem argumentation automatically lost the debate. Before Mr. Spitzer had a drafting or dining table, he had a saxophone, which he played in the band at Weinrib's resort in the Catskills. It was there, when both were teens, that he met Anne Goldhaber, a counselor at the children's camp. They married three years later, and recently celebrated their 69th wedding anniversary. They shared a passion for city life, classical music, tennis, skiing and literature - which Anne taught for decades at Hunter and Marymount Manhattan College. Reflecting his many interests, Mr. Spitzer served on the boards of the Juilliard School, the Museum of Jewish Heritage, the Hospital for Joint Diseases, the Michael J. Fox Foundation and others. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his daughter, Emily, a lawyer and former executive director of the National Health Law Program, his son, Daniel, a neurosurgeon, his son Eliot, former Attorney General and Governor of New York State, and seven grandchildren. Interment will be private. Funeral services will take place on Monday, November 3rd at 10am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, the Spitzer family would request that donations be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation in memory of Bernard Spitzer.

PIMSLER--Alvin J.,led a life full of love and joy, challenges and opportunities, buoyed by his unfailingly positive perspective, wickedly sharp wit, and devilishly handsome good-looks. He passed Saturday morning, 1 November. He was born to Adolph and Jennie Pimsler in Flushing, New York on May 17, 1918, the younger brother of Harold Pimsler. He graduated from Flushing High School in 1936, and then from the Pratt Institute School of Fine and Applied Arts in 1938. Alvin was drafted into the Army in 1941. He rose to become a Captain in the Infantry of the Army of the United States, where he served in the European theater. He was captured in combat, and was a Prisoner of War. His life was forever colored by these extreme experiences. Later in his life, he became heavily involved with the New York Veterans Administration community and diligently attended the POW Support Group for many years, finding comfort and camaraderie in the shared experiences of his peers. The group leader, Sharon Morrison, advocated tirelessly on his behalf and his family will forever be thankful. After his return from the war, he met the love of his life in the Art Students League and married Norma Moran on August 3rd, 1947. The couple has been together for 67 years, and Norma says there was nobody like Alvin in all the world. Alvin is survived by Norma, his two sons Meade and Paul, and his granddaughters Meaghan and Jaime. Alvin was respected internationally as a fashion illustrator, with a client list representing nearly all of the high fashion publications and men's fashion houses, including The New York Times' men's fashion section and Sak's Fifth Avenue. He was President of the Society of Illustrators and The Artists Fellowship, attended the Art Students League and The National Academy School of Fine Art, was inducted into the Soc. of Ill. Hall of Fame, contributed to the Soc. of Illus. Air Force Arts Program for 40 years, and was recipient of the William Collins award from the Hudson Valley Art Association. Alvin was distinguished as an innovative and beloved Professor at the Fashion Institute of Technology for many decades, who provided his students invaluable, real-world work experience. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 12:45pm on Monday, November 3rd, 180 West 76th St., NY, NY.

LUXENBERG--Stan. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our long time, devoted member, Stan Luxenberg, husband of the late Sara Holiner. Our deepest condolences to their children Daniel and Louis, partner Sue, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine,DD., Senior Rabbi Martin Flumenbaum, President

HILLS--Roderick M.,age 83, died October 29, 2014, at Johns Hopkins Hospital. His wife Carla A. Hills, was by his side. Roderick was founder and chairman of the Hills Program on Governance. In the Ford administration, he served as counsel to the President and Chairman of the Securities Exchange Commission. Roderick is survived by his beloved wife Carla A. Hills; children Laura H. Hills, Roderick M. Hills, Jr., Megan E. Hills, and Alison M. Hills; grandchildren Philip Hills Bunnell, Daniel Hills Bunnell, Emma Montoya Hills, Sarah Montoya Hills, and Owen Hills-Klaus. The family will have a private burial service. They will hold a public memorial at a future date. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be sent to Fidelity Charitable, a charity at which a fund has been established to make contributions to The Hills Governance Center in memory of Roderick M. Hills. Checks should be made payable to Fidelity Charitable and should be sent to Fidelity Charitable, P.O. Box 770001, Cincinnati, OH 45277-0053. Please reference The Hills Governance Fund in the memo field of your check.

FISHBACH--Myron. The Board of Governors and members of Rockrimmon Country Club are profoundly saddened by the passing of their beloved friend and esteemed member. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Patti Fishbach and all members of the Fishbach Family. Robert J. Bluestone, President

FISHBACH--Myron "Mike", of Stamford, CT, passed away very suddenly on November 1, 2014. Beloved husband of Patti and cherished father to Barry (Lauren) and Debra (Ed O'Keefe). Loving grandfather to Julie, Jordan, Emily and Evan. Devoted brother to Ronald (Connie) and Karen (Bruce Kimmel). Mike was born May 9, 1939 on Long Island to Nathan and Shirley Fishbach. He was a graduate of Syracuse University and Fordham University law school. Mike was a trusted and respected attorney and advisor who built long-lasting relationships with multiple generations of his clients. An avid golfer, Mike was an esteemed member of Rockrimmon Country Club. Funeral services will be held at 1pm, November 4th at Temple Beth El, Stamford, CT.

EMERY--Hiram Weber, Jr. died Wednesday, October 29 at the age of 84. of the effects of Parkinson's Disease. Born in Providence, RI. He graduated from St. Mark's School ('48), Harvard College, ('52), served as a Lieutenant in Korea and graduated from the Harvard Business School ('56). He was a partner for 30 years of the White Weld Company, In New York City which was later acquired by Merrill Lynch. Upon retirement he worked for Gottesmann & Co. He is survived by his twin brother, John, his loving wife of 47 years Susan Curtis his children, Marjorie McCleary, (Benjamin) and Hiram III (Caroline) and five grandchildren. He was a devoted board member of the United Congregational Church in Little Compton, a member of the Union Club in New York City, General Society of Colonial Wars, and The Sakonnet Golf Club. A memorial service will be held, Friday, November 7th at 11:00am at the United Congregational Church in Little Compton, RI. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. Mark's School, Southborough, MA or the United Congregation Church, Little Compton, RI.

BUSSEL--Irving, died November 1, 2014. He was born on July 17, 1926 in Plainfield, NJ. His parents were the late Max and Sarah Bussel. Irving attended New York University and the New School of Social Research. He was a Research Editor for the Anti Defamation League in New York for over 40 years. He is survived by a brother, Eli Bussell of Edison, NJ, a sister, Roselyn Ramist of Stamford, CT, and nieces and nephews Lisa, Frank, Joanne, Lauren, and Jordan.

BROWNSTEIN--Harriet, passed away on October 31, 2014. Beloved sister of Anne Bussel, adoring and adored daughter of Molly and Jacob Brownstein. Harriet was creative, talented and gifted. She will be missed by everyone who knew her.

BESKIND--Dorothy M. Levitt, 97, notable photographer and film-maker died peacefully at home in Easthampton NY, family by her side. Cherished mother of Joanne Beskind Elkin, Susan B. Lelyveld (Michael), Ellen Safir (Peter), grandchildren Katherine, Victor, Archie, Roland, Jesse; longtime companion, Sidney Goldstein. Her 25 year marriage to D. Herbert Beskind ended in divorce. We will forever miss her bright light, keen eye and spare aesthetic, adventurous zest for life, the wisdom, warmth, love and sparkle she brought to ours. Daughter of the late Rebecca and Adolph Levitt, dubbed the "Doughnut King" for his invention of the automated donut machine, founder of Doughnut Corp of America; predeceased by sister Irene L. Morse, and twin brother David M. Levitt. Beskind produced an extensive archive of over 300 films and numerous photographs of renowned artists including Joseph Beuys, Keith Haring, Louise Bourgeois, Bob Morris, Eva Hesse, Alice Neel, and Andy Warhol. Her work has been shown at the Whitney, Tate Modern, SFMoMA, the Jewish Museum, Yale University, Kutztown, U. Leeds, UK., and Pentax Gallery Tokyo. Memorial service in New York, details to be announced.

SPITZER--Bernard, a civil engineer, innovative real estate developer and philanthropist who built millions of square feet of prime Manhattan buildings, died on November 1. According to a family spokesperson, Mr. Spitzer succumbed after a long battle with Parkinson's Disease. He was 90 years of age. Always grateful for the opportunities he received, he and his wife, Anne, established a family foundation, which endowed a new architecture and urban planning school at City College as well as the Hall of Human Origins at the American Museum of Natural History. They also funded stem cell research at Columbia University and Public Theater productions of Shakespeare in the Park, among many other philanthropic initiatives. Education was a priority for his parents, Molly and Morris, who emigrated from Austria to a Lower East Side tenement on East 5th Street after World War I. His father ran a printing business in the basement, with assistance from the young Bernard, who was fluent in five languages and could typeset in four. A gifted student, he attended a local Yeshiva and then Townsend Harris High School, from which he graduated at age 14. He received his Bachelor of Science in Civil Engineering from City College four years later. Initially assisting the war effort designing gyroscopically stabilized gun-mounts, he then joined the Navy, and was posted to heavily bombarded Bremen as a Lieutenant JG in naval counter-intelligence. After discharge from the Navy, he attended Columbia University on the G.I. bill, earning a Master of Science in Engineering in 1947 and then accepted a position as field supervisor for the colorful Russian builder, Sam Minskoff. With a few years of experience under his belt, he set out on his own, building Spitzer Engineering, one successful project leading to the next, into a successful family company. Beginning in Riverdale with a seven-story brick apartment house completed in 1954, he then constructed a 112-unit residence on the northern section of the Grand Concourse. In 1960 he and a business partner developed a 22-story co-op at 1050 Fifth Avenue opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Eight more large-scale projects were developed from inception to completion over the next four decades. As described by real estate reporter Alan Oser in the December 15, 1991 New York Times, he was "a civil engineer with a taste for esthetics and design, a reputation as an insightful taskmaster and a preference for residential buildings in Manhattan locations. If there is an unusual construction challenge, so much the better." In 1962, he began development on the iconic 35-story apartment building at the corner of Central Park South and Seventh Avenue, a site diligently acquired parcel by parcel over many years after he spotted it from a taxicab window. Poring over drawings and coffee with long-term architect Michael Schimenti late one evening, he sketched a design for a distinctively curved structure stretching around the corner from Central Park South to broad Seventh Avenue. This provided maximum light, air and park views for the 310 residences and space for a curved driveway/port-cochere. One critic amiably suggested, "It's a nice building, just too far from the beach." "But not too far from the park." Mr. Spitzer wryly observed. After acquiring at auction the site of the former East Side Airlines Terminal at First Avenue between 37th and 38th Streets, Mr. Spitzer faced another formidable hurdle. While the zoning would allow some 865 apartments, making it the largest residential building in the city at the time (1989), connections to the Midtown tunnel ran like fault veins under a portion of the site. The result was The Corinthian, a 57-story curvilinear tower with an undulating facade of semi-circular windows gracefully secure on terra firma. Mr. Spitzer and partners purchased a Manhattan trophy commercial property, the Crown Building on Fifth Avenue across the street from Tiffany's, in 1991. The focus on commercial buildings in vibrant markets continued with the acquisition of two prime office properties in Washington, DC and one in Bethesda, MD. More recently, Spitzer Engineering acquired a retail condominium in SoHo and a development site in the Hudson Yards area. A voracious reader and enthusiastic interlocutor, Mr. Spitzer presided over the family dinner table, which became a field for discussion, debate, questioning authority and intellectual rigor. Meals were punctuated with Socratic discourse. Any appeal to authority or resort to ad hominem argumentation automatically lost the debate. Before Mr. Spitzer had a drafting or dining table, he had a saxophone, which he played in the band at Weinrib's resort in the Catskills. It was there, when both were teens, that he met Anne Goldhaber, a counselor at the children's camp. They married three years later, and recently celebrated their 69th wedding anniversary. They shared a passion for city life, classical music, tennis, skiing and literature - which Anne taught for decades at Hunter and Marymount Manhattan College. Reflecting his many interests, Mr. Spitzer served on the boards of the Juilliard School, the Museum of Jewish Heritage, the Hospital for Joint Diseases, the Michael J. Fox Foundation and others. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his daughter, Emily, a lawyer and former executive director of the National Health Law Program, his son, Daniel, a neurosurgeon, his son Eliot, former Attorney General and Governor of New York State, and seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the Spitzer family would request that donations be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation in memory of Bernard Spitzer.

SPITZER--Bernard. The Trustees and staff of the Museum of Jewish Heritage -A Living Memorial to the Holocaust express profound sadness on the passing of Trustee Bernard Spitzer, a remarkable man dedicated to the Museum's mission since its early years, whose name graces the Museum's lobby in recognition of his generosity and commitment. We send our condolences to his wife, Anne, his children, and his grandchildren. Bruce C. Ratner, Chair David G. Marwell, Director

SMITH--Myron. We are deeply saddened at the loss of a beloved and major presence in our lives. Myron celebrated life's joys, and met its challenges with faith and dignity. Our hearts go out to his exceptional wife, Barbara, and their devoted children and grandchildren. Min Hashamayim Tenuchamu Aunt Els and Family

SCHWARTZ--Anita, passed away November 2, 2014 in Charlotte, NC. She was born in Brooklyn, NY and lived most of her life in New York. She is survived by her husband of 66 years, Jerome Schwartz; daughter, Susan Sorensen; and grandchildren, Dena and Rory Rashkover. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation to your favorite local charity, animal shelter, or hospice care center. Condolences may be offered at www.HarryandBryantFuneralHome.com.

PIMSLER--Alvin J.,led a life full of love and joy, challenges and opportunities, buoyed by his unfailingly positive perspective, wickedly sharp wit, and devilishly handsome good-looks. He passed Saturday morning, 1 November. He was born to Adolph and Jennie Pimsler in Flushing, New York on May 17, 1918, the younger brother of Harold Pimsler. He graduated from Flushing High School in 1936, and then from the Pratt Institute School of Fine and Applied Arts in 1938. Alvin was drafted into the Army in 1941. He rose to become a Captain in the Infantry of the Army of the United States, where he served in the European theater. He was captured in combat, and was a Prisoner of War. His life was forever colored by these extreme experiences. Later in his life, he became heavily involved with the New York Veterans Administration community and diligently attended the POW Support Group for many years, finding comfort and camaraderie in the shared experiences of his peers. The group leader, Sharon Morrison, advocated tirelessly on his behalf and his family will forever be thankful. After his return from the war, he met the love of his life in the Art Students League and married Norma Moran on August 3rd, 1947. The couple has been together for 67 years, and Norma says there was nobody like Alvin in all the world. Alvin is survived by Norma, his two sons Meade and Paul, and his granddaughters Meaghan and Jaime. Alvin was respected internationally as a fashion illustrator, with a client list representing nearly all of the high fashion publications and men's fashion houses, including The New York Times' men's fashion section and Sak's Fifth Avenue. He was President of the Society of Illustrators and The Artists Fellowship, attended the Art Students League and The National Academy School of Fine Art, was inducted into the Soc. of Ill. Hall of Fame, contributed to the Soc. of Illus. Air Force Arts Program for 40 years, and was recipient of the William Collins award from the Hudson Valley Art Association. Alvin was distinguished as an innovative and beloved Professor at the Fashion Institute of Technology for many decades, who provided his students invaluable, real-world work experience.

PETILLO--Gennaro J.,69, of Cranbury, NJ passed away at home on Saturday, November 1, 2014. He worked for New York State Controller's Office for 30 years. Funeral services are under the direction of A.S. Cole Funeral Home, 22 North Main Street, Cranbury, NJ. www.saulfuneralhomes.com
MISHCON--Mildred "Mimi", 90, On November 2, 2014, of New York City and The Berkshhires. Adored wife of Sidney (deceased). Loving mother of Arnie, Jude, Jonny, Andy (deceased), Missy and June.

LUXENBERG--Stanley. Beloved father of Daniel and Louis, died October 31, 2014, after battling cancer for six months. His wife, Sara Holiner, died seven years earlier. Stanley was a prominent business journalist for nearly forty years. A graduate of Swarthmore College and the Columbia Journalism School, he had a long career as an editor for magazines and newspapers and as a freelance business writer. He was the author of the book, "Roadside Empires," and contributed frequently to The New York Times, The Street.com and many magazines. He was an expert on mutual funds and investing and published a newsletter, the Critical Investor. The publications where he worked included: the New Leader, Businessweek, Forbes, Newsday, Medical Economics and Individual Investor, where he was executive editor. He wrote a landmark article on socially responsible investing for Harper's Magazine in 1982. He was one of the founders of the New York Media Alliance and the National Writers Union. He was an active member of Temple Rodeph Sholom and participated in its social justice efforts. He also studied at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem. Born in Indiana, PA, on April 5, 1951, he is survived by his parents, Irene and David Luxenberg, his sister Deborah and brother Larry and his partner Sue Mittenthal. Funeral services are 11:45am, Monday, November 3 at Riverside Memorial Chapel with burial immediately afterwards at New Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ.

KREINGOLD--Ida R.,passed away on November 1st, 2014 after a long and fulfilling life. Born July 3rd, 1917 in the Bronx, Ida was a woman of great accomplishment and varied interests. Loved by her family and friends, Ida will be deeply missed. A first generation American, Ida was proud of her Yiddish heritage. She received her education in the New York City Public Schools, earned master degrees in education and library science and taught for thirty years. With her husband Sam, who passed away November 4th, 1989, Ida enjoyed folk dancing, opera and ballet, world travel, bridge and nature. Before World War II Ida was a supervisor for the IWO and during the War was a civilian instructor in bomber electrical systems. Sixty years later, she could still describe the wiring specs for the B-24 Liberator. Ida was a supporter of many organizations including the Bronx Botanical Gardens where she volunteered for many years. In later years she served as Treasurer of CHAC, the activity organization of Cryder House. Ida's intelligence, sense of humor, thirst for knowledge, love of family and friends and a lifelong commitment to human progress inspired all who knew her. She was preceded in death by her beloved parents Adolph and Tillie Rambam, husband of forty-nine years, Samuel Kreingold and brother, Mark Rambam. She leaves behind her sister Norma Pomerantz, three children Ruthann Kreingold, Judy Braunsberg (Geoffrey) and Paul Kreingold (Linda), her grandchildren and many nephews and nieces. Funeral services will be held at the Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills on Wednesday, November 5th 2014 at 11am.

KATZ--ELAINE Arnowich, 85 yrs young passed November 1. Predeceased by parents Joe & Eva Arnowich, beloved husband of 56 yrs Phil, brother Ira, cherished son, Steve. A loving mother to Ellyn & Jeff, Rob & Sherrill, Deborah & Mark. She relished being Nanny to Mat, Ben, Emma & Zoe. She adored sisters-in-law Sandra & Gladys & was Auntie Elaine to loving nieces/ nephews. She was a force of nature, living a full active life, always giving to others. She was much loved by many. She will be missed.
HYDOCK--Jerry died October 27, 2014. Jerry lived in Warren, NJ then Houston, TX. He is survived by his two sons Luke & Jordan Hydock and his three grandsons.

DAWSON--Sue, died at home of pancreatic cancer on November 2; Trustee of the Leopold Schepp Foundation; survived by husband Evan Dawson, daughter Julia Dawson and granddaughter Charlotte Dawson Ravage.

CAYRE--Grace. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Grace Cayre. Grace leaves behind a legacy of exceptional Jewish philanthropy and commitment to the Sephardic community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Grace's children, Stanley, Joseph, Kenneth, Renee Serure, Shirley Franco, and Bobbie Beyda; her grandchildren; her great-grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

BUSSEL--Irving, died November 1, 2014. He was born on July 17, 1926 in Plainfield, NJ. His parents were the late Max and Sarah Bussel. Irving attended New York University and the New School of Social Research. He was a Research Editor for the Anti Defamation League in New York for over 40 years. He is survived by a brother, Eli Bussell of Edison, NJ, a sister, Roselyn Ramist of Stamford, CT, and nieces and nephews Lisa, Frank, Joanne, Lauren, and Jordan.

BENNETT--William. Sometimes words cannot express a loss, measure a life, or convey how much one person has given us. We, his colleagues at the Saltaire Volunteer Fire Company, grieve our dear friend, Will Bennett. But his spirit remains, cherished and kept safe in the hearts of those who knew and loved him. A memorial service for Will Bennett will be held Thursday, November 6, 2014, at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th Street (corner of 5th Avenue). In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations in Will's name be sent to: Saltaire Volunteer Fire Company, PO Box 5375, Bay Shore, NY 11706. Hugh O'Brien, President James Rieger, Chief

BENNETT--William Stephen, of Bronxville, New York died on October 29, 2014. His family and many close friends will miss him deeply. A service will be held on November 6 at 4pm at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Saltaire Volunteer Fire Co., Bay Shore, NY.

APPEL--Beatrice H.,of New York City, on November 1, 2014, in her 105th year. Daughter of Samuel L. and Eva Hoffman, she had been married to Alfred for 69 years. She was a graduate of Adelphi Academy, attended Adelphi College, and was a graduate of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. For four years she was a volunteer guide at the United Nations in Lake Success, and spent twenty-four years as a docent at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, specializing in Egyptology, about which she was passionate. She also loved studying and teaching art history, and taught English to Russian emigres. She was an elegant, bright, and dynamic lady, who adored her family and is survived by her children, Prof. Nina S. Appel (late Alfred, Jr.), Betty and Paul Schaffer, and John S. Appel and Barbara Wolkowitz, her grandchildren Karen and Gene Oshman, Richard J. Appel, Dr. Mark A. Schaffer and David Goldman, and Catherine and Michael Rose, and her great-grandchildren Stephen and Katherine, Gabriel and Grace, and Andrew and Jenna. Also surviving is her devoted brother, Dr. Burton P. Hoffman, and his family. Services on Thursday, November 6, 2014, 10am, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.
